senses.definition: to dismiss somebody from a job

examples.en: She was sacked for refusing to work on Sundays.

senses.definition: (of an army, etc., especially in the past) to destroy things and steal property in a town or building

examples.en: Rome was sacked by the Goths in 410.

senses.definition: to knock down the quarterback

examples.en: The quarterback was sacked on the 45 yard line, and it was first down for the other team.

senses.definition: a large bag with no handles, made of strong rough material or strong paper or plastic, used for storing and carrying, for example flour, coal, etc.

examples.en: They filled the sacks with potatoes.
bulging sacks of toys

senses.definition: a strong paper bag for carrying shopping
the contents of a sack

examples.en: They got through a sack of potatoes.
two sacks of groceries
a sack of coal

senses.definition: being told by your employer that you can no longer continue working for a company, etc., usually because of something that you have done wrong

examples.en: He got the sack for swearing.

senses.definition: a bed

examples.en: He caught them in the sack together.

senses.definition: the act of stealing or destroying property in a captured town

examples.en: the sack of Rome

senses.definition: to go to bed

examples.en: I decided to hit the sack and have an early night.

senses.definition: connected with God or a god; considered to be holy

examples.en: a sacred image/shrine/temple
sacred music

senses.definition: very important and treated with great respect; that must not be changed or challenged

examples.en: Human life must always be sacred.

senses.definition: the fact of giving up something important or valuable to you in order to get or do something that seems more important; something that you give up in this way

examples.en: The makers of the product assured us that there had been no sacrifice of quality.

to make the ultimate/supreme sacrifice (= to die for your country, to save a friend, etc.)

senses.definition: the act of offering something to a god, especially an animal that has been killed in a special way; an animal, etc. that is offered in this way

examples.en: They offered sacrifices to the gods.
a human sacrifice (= a person killed as a sacrifice)

senses.definition: to give up something that is important or valuable to you in order to get or do something that seems more important for yourself or for another person

examples.en: She sacrificed everything for her children.
The designers have sacrificed speed for fuel economy.
Would you sacrifice a football game to go out with a girl?
In her writing, clarity is sometimes sacrificed to brevity.

senses.definition: to kill an animal or a person and offer it or them to a god, in order to please the god
unhappy or showing unhappiness

examples.en: We are very sad to hear that you are leaving.
I was sad that she had to go.
I felt terribly sad about it.
I won't pretend I'm not slightly sad at the idea of never seeing them again.
I felt so sad for her.
She looked sad and tired.

I was sad to see the series end.

senses.definition: that makes you feel unhappy

examples.en: a sad story
It was sad to see them go.
It is sad that so many of his paintings have been lost.
We had some sad news yesterday.

senses.definition: unacceptable; deserving blame or criticism

examples.en: a sad state of affairs

senses.definition: boring or not fashionable

senses.definition: in poor condition

senses.definition: seasonal affective disorder (= a condition in which a person feels sad and tired during late autumn and winter when there is not much light from the sun)

senses.definition: unfortunately

senses.definition: very much and in a way that makes you sad

senses.definition: protected from any danger, harm or loss

examples.en: The children are quite safe here.

Your secret is safe with me (= I will not tell anyone else).

senses.definition: not likely to lead to any physical harm or danger

examples.cf: safe for somebody to do something
examples.en: The street is not safe for children to play in.

senses.definition: not harmed, damaged, lost, etc.

examples.en: We all want to live in safer cities.

senses.definition: not involving much or any risk; not likely to be wrong or to upset somebody

senses.definition: doing an activity in a careful way

examples.en: a safe driver

senses.definition: based on good evidence

examples.en: a safe verdict

senses.definition: used by young people to show that they approve of somebody/something

examples.en: I like him, he's safe.

senses.definition: used by young people as a way of accepting something that is offered

examples.en: ‘You want some?’ ‘Yeah, safe.’

senses.definition: used to say that it is wiser to be too careful than to act too quickly and do something you may later wish you had not

examples.en: She decided to avoid travelling at night. Better safe than sorry.

senses.definition: something that is likely to happen, to succeed or to be suitable

idioms.word: in safe hands | in the safe hands of somebody

senses.definition: being taken care of well by somebody

examples.en: I've left the kids in safe hands—with my parents.

senses.definition: being especially careful; taking no risks

examples.en: I took some extra cash just to be on the safe side.

senses.definition: to be careful; to avoid risks

examples.en: Play safe—keep out of the sun in the middle of the day.

senses.definition: very safe
confident because you know that something is true or will happen

examples.en: She went out safe in the knowledge that she looked fabulous.

senses.definition: a person that you can trust to do a job well

examples.en: Colleagues regard him as a safe pair of hands.

senses.definition: a strong metal box or cupboard with a complicated lock, used for storing valuable things in, for example, money or jewellery
the state of being safe and protected from danger or harm

examples.en: a place where children can play in safety

measures to ensure patient safety

senses.definition: the state of not being dangerous

examples.en: I'm worried about the safety of the treatment.
a local campaign to improve road safety

a safety officer (= somebody whose job is to ensure safety)

senses.definition: a place where you are safe

variants.text: (also safety catch especially in British English)
variants.html: (also safety catch especially in British English)

senses.definition: a device that stops a gun from being fired or a machine from working by accident
(in American football) a defending player who plays in a position far away from the other team

senses.definition: being in a group makes you safer and makes you feel more confident

a very good and honest person that you can always depend on

senses.definition: the same person

senses.definition: the same person or thing

variants.html: (usually the same)

senses.definition: to make somebody pleased by doing or giving them what they want

examples.en: Nothing satisfies him—he's always complaining.
The proposed plan will not satisfy everyone.

senses.definition: to provide what is wanted, needed or asked for

examples.en: The food wasn't enough to satisfy his hunger.
to satisfy somebody’s curiosity
The education system must satisfy the needs of all children.
We cannot satisfy demand for the product.
to satisfy a requirement/condition/criterion
She failed to satisfy all the requirements for entry to the college.

senses.definition: to make somebody certain something is true or has been done

examples.en: Her explanation did not satisfy the teacher.
People need to be satisfied of the need for a new system.
Once I had satisfied myself (that) it was the right decision, we went ahead.
All you have to do is satisfy the court he is not at risk.

senses.definition: the day of the week after Friday and before Sunday

examples.en: It's Saturday today, isn't it?
She started art classes last Saturday.
Are you busy next Saturday?
Saturday morning/afternoon/evening
We'll chat at Saturday's party.
I work Saturday to Wednesday.
I work Saturdays to Wednesdays.
We'll meet on Saturday (= next Saturday).
We met on Saturday (= last Saturday).
We'll meet Saturday.
The office is closed on Saturdays (= every Saturday).
The office is closed Saturdays.
He was born on a Saturday.
I always do yoga on a Saturday (= every Saturday).
I went to Mexico City on Monday, and came back the following Saturday.
‘When did the accident happen?’ ‘It was the Saturday (= the Saturday of the week we are talking about).’
Come back Saturday week (= a week after next Saturday).

senses.definition: a thick liquid that is eaten with food to add taste to it

examples.en: tomato/cranberry/chilli sauce
chicken in a white sauce
ice cream with a hot fudge sauce
pasta sauce (= sauce that is served with pasta)
A honey-mustard dipping sauce helped add flavour to the crab cakes.
coconut tart served with hot chocolate sauce

senses.definition: talk or behaviour that is annoying or shows no respect

idioms.word: what’s sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander

senses.definition: what one person is allowed to do, another person must be allowed to do in a similar situation
to keep somebody/something safe from death, harm, loss, etc.

examples.en: to save somebody’s life
Doctors were unable to save her.
He's trying to save their marriage.
She needs to win the next two games to save the match.
Workers chose longer hours in order to save jobs.
If you really want to save the planet, sell your car.
Thanks for doing that. You saved my life (= helped me a lot).
She started a campaign to save her business.
to save a rare species from extinction
His intrepid act saved five men from death.
Money from local businesses helped save the school from closure.
This new technology might just have the power to save the world from ecological disaster.
She saved a little girl from falling into the water.

senses.definition: to keep money instead of spending it, especially in order to buy a particular thing

examples.en: I'm not very good at saving.
We scrimp and save to send our children to a private school.
I'm saving up to buy a new car.
I'm saving for a new bike.
For all younger people in the US saving for retirement will be an absolute necessity.
We've been saving up to go to Australia.
I'm trying to save up for my holiday.
You should save a little each week.
I've saved almost £100 so far.
He saved up some money and made plans to travel.
He's been saving his allowance up for a new bike.

senses.definition: to avoid wasting something or using more than necessary

examples.en: People are looking for ways to save money.
We'll take a cab to save time.
Recycling waste saves energy.
Images are captured in black and white to save hard disk space.
Book early and save £50!
We should try to save water.
The government is trying to save £1 million on defence.
If we go this way it will save us two hours on the trip.
A professional wedding coordinator can save you time and money.
I save on fares by walking to work.

senses.definition: to keep something to use or enjoy in the future or for somebody else to use

examples.en: He's saving his strength for the last part of the race.
We'll eat some now and save some for tomorrow.
Save some food for me.
The main event is saved until last.
Save me some food.
I won't save you a seat if you're late.

senses.definition: to make a computer keep data by putting a copy in a location where it will be stored

examples.en: We recommend you save regularly by clicking on the update button.
Save data frequently.
All your recent searches are automatically saved.
The data can be saved to disk.

senses.definition: to collect something because you like it or for a special purpose

examples.en: I've been saving theatre programmes for years.
If you save ten tokens you can get a T-shirt.

senses.definition: to avoid doing something difficult or unpleasant; to make somebody able to avoid doing something difficult or unpleasant

examples.en: The prize money saved her from having to find a job.
She did it herself to save argument.
Thanks for sending that letter for me—it saved me a trip.
The new system will save people the trouble of taking recyclable materials to collection points.
He's grown a beard to save shaving.
If you phone for an appointment, it'll save you waiting.

senses.definition: to prevent an opponent’s shot from going in the goal

examples.en: to save a penalty
The goalie saved Johnson's long-range shot.
The goalie saved brilliantly from Johnson's long-range shot.

senses.definition: to prevent a person's soul from going to hell

examples.en: The missionaries believed they were sent to save souls.
A large poster proclaimed, ‘Jesus saves.’

idioms.word: not be able to do something to save your life

senses.definition: to be completely unable to do something

examples.en: He can't interview people to save his life.

senses.definition: to rescue somebody from a very difficult situation

examples.en: He's out to save his own political neck.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody that it is not worth wasting time and effort saying something because it will not change anything

examples.en: Save your breath—you'll never persuade her.
It's useless talking to him—you may as well save your breath.

senses.definition: to prevent failure or defeat, when this seems certain to happen

examples.en: Salah's late goal saved the day for Liverpool.

senses.definition: to avoid or help somebody avoid being embarrassed

examples.en: She was fired, but she saved face by telling everyone she'd resigned.

senses.definition: to try to avoid death, punishment, etc., especially by leaving others in an extremely difficult situation

examples.en: To save his own skin, he lied and blamed the accident on his friend.

senses.definition: an action by the goalkeeper that stops a goal being scored

examples.en: He made a spectacular save.
some great saves from both goalkeepers

senses.definition: except something

examples.en: They knew nothing about her save her name.

senses.definition: except

examples.en: They found out nothing more save that she had borne a child.

senses.definition: an amount of something such as time or money that you do not need to use or spend

examples.en: Buy three and make a saving of 55p.
With the new boiler you can make big savings on fuel bills.
The company reported cost savings of about $ 29 million during the second quarter.
The new building enjoys energy savings of 25 percent annually.
The service has delivered significant cost savings.

senses.definition: money that you have saved, especially in a bank, etc.

examples.en: He put all his savings into buying a boat.
She spent her entire life savings (= all the money she had saved throughout her life) to furnish and equip the house.
Tan financed the film himself from his personal savings.
He's living off his retirement savings.
Savings rates are at historic lows.

senses.definition: that prevents the waste of the thing mentioned or stops it from being necessary

examples.en: labour-saving devices
space-saving fitted furniture

senses.definition: to speak or tell somebody something, using words

examples.en: ‘Hello!’ she said.
‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.
A legendary football coach once said, ‘Winning is everything.’
Be quiet, I have something to say.
Come and say hello.
Please say yes!
I didn't believe a word she said.
That's a terrible thing to say.
She said nothing to me about it.
I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’
He said (that) his name was Sam.
Can I just say I'm not happy about this?
I have to say I was pleasantly surprised.
It is said that she lived to be over 100.
She finds it hard to say what she feels.
‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’
‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’
‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’
He said to meet him here.
He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.

senses.definition: to repeat words, phrases, etc.

examples.en: to say a prayer
Try to say that line with more conviction.

senses.dis_g: (of something that is written or can be seen)
senses.definition: to give particular information or instructions

examples.en: The notice said ‘Keep Out’.
The clock said three o'clock.
The instructions say (that) we should leave it to set for four hours.
The book doesn't say where he was born.
The guidebook says to turn left.

senses.definition: to express an opinion on something

examples.en: Say what you like (= although you disagree) about her, she's a fine singer.
I'll say this for them, they're a very efficient company.
Anna thinks I'm lazy—what do you say (= what is your opinion)?
I can't say I blame her for resigning (= I think she was right).
I have to say I enjoyed every minute.
I say (= suggest) we go without them.
I wouldn't say they were rich (= in my opinion they are not rich).
That's not to say it's a bad movie (= it is good but it is not without faults).
It's hard to say what caused the accident.
It's difficult to say whether the story is true.
‘When will it be finished?’ ‘I couldn't say (= I don't know).’
Is it worth it? I would say not.

senses.definition: to make thoughts, feelings, etc. clear to somebody by using words, looks, movements, etc.

examples.en: His angry glance said it all.
Just what is the artist trying to say in her work?
The museum's architects have managed to say something about our national story.

senses.definition: to show, sometimes indirectly, what somebody/something is like

examples.en: That says it all really, doesn't it? (= it shows clearly what is true)
The incident says an awful lot about his character.
This says to me that there is more here than you are letting on.

senses.definition: to suggest or give something as an example or a possibility

examples.en: You could learn the basics in, let's say, three months.
Let’s take any writer, say (= for example) Dickens…
Say you lose your job: what would you do then?
Just say he refuses to talk to you.

senses.definition: to be much more difficult to do than to talk about

examples.en: ‘Why don't you get yourself a job?’ ‘That's easier said than done.’

idioms.word: before you can say Jack Robinson

senses.definition: very quickly; in a very short time
used to say that you understand a situation and there is no need to say any more

examples.en: ‘He's a politician, remember.’ ‘Enough said.’

senses.definition: to be very obvious or easy to predict

examples.en: Of course I'll help you. That goes without saying.

idioms.word: have something, nothing, etc. to say for yourself

senses.definition: to be ready, unwilling, etc. to talk or give your views on something

examples.en: She doesn't have much to say for herself (= doesn't take part in conversation).
He had plenty to say for himself (= he had a lot of opinions and was willing to talk).
Late again—what have you got to say for yourself (= what is your excuse)?

idioms.word: have something to say (to somebody) about something

senses.definition: to be angry

examples.en: He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it.

senses.definition: used to introduce an opinion that makes what you have just said seem less strong

examples.en: I sometimes get worried in this job. Having said that, I enjoy doing it, it's a challenge.

variants.text: (also I daresay especially in British English)
variants.html: (also I daresay especially in British English)

senses.definition: used when you are saying that something is likely

examples.en: I dare say you know about it already.

idioms.word: if you don’t mind me/my saying so…

senses.definition: used when you are going to criticize somebody or say something that might upset them

examples.en: That colour doesn't really suit you, if you don't mind my saying so.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody that you have listened to their opinion, especially when you are going to express a different opinion

examples.en: I hear what you're saying, but you're wrong.

senses.definition: used for emphasis to say ‘yes’

examples.en: ‘Does she see him often?’ ‘I'll say! Nearly every day.’

senses.definition: used when you are commenting on a situation and saying that you are happy about it

examples.en: Most teachers, I'm glad to say, take their jobs very seriously.

senses.definition: used for saying that something is disappointing

examples.en: He didn't accept the job, I'm sorry to say.

senses.definition: used to emphasize an opinion

examples.en: Well, I must say, that's the funniest thing I've heard all week.

senses.definition: used to express surprise, shock, etc.

examples.en: I say! What a huge cake!

senses.definition: used to attract somebody’s attention or introduce a new subject of conversation

examples.en: I say, can you lend me five pounds?

idioms.word: it says a lot, very little, etc. for somebody/something

senses.definition: it shows a good/bad quality that somebody/something has

examples.en: It says a lot for her that she never lost her temper.
It didn't say much for their efficiency that the order arrived a week late.

senses.definition: used to say that you would like something or to accept something that is offered

examples.en: I wouldn't say no to a pizza.
‘Tea, Brian?’ ‘I wouldn't say no.’

senses.definition: a bad situation will pass or be forgotten most quickly if nothing more is said about it
the best thing to do is say as little as possible about something
used when commenting on a situation to suggest that you could say something more or worse but prefer not to

examples.en: Let's just say he wasn't very happy about the decision (= he was very unhappy or angry about it).

senses.definition: used when making a suggestion or giving an example

examples.en: I can let you have it for, well let's say £100.

senses.definition: used to emphasize what you are saying or to ask somebody if they really mean what they say

examples.en: I mean to say, you should have known how he would react!
Do you mean to say you've lost it?

senses.definition: used to emphasize that the information you are giving is obvious

examples.en: The problem, needless to say, is the cost involved.

senses.definition: do not stop hoping
used to say that something was, or will be, done immediately

idioms.word: not have a good word to say for somebody/something

senses.definition: to never say anything good about somebody/something

examples.en: Nobody had a good word to say about him.

idioms.word: not say boo to a goose

variants.text: (North American English not say boo to anyone)
variants.html: (North American English not say boo to anyone)

senses.definition: to be very shy or gentle

examples.en: He's so nervous he wouldn't say boo to a goose.

senses.definition: used to introduce a stronger way of describing something

examples.en: a difficult, not to say impossible, task

senses.definition: used to ask somebody to smile before you take their photograph
to say something important

examples.en: You said a mouthful there, buddy.

senses.definition: to refuse an offer, a suggestion, etc.

examples.en: If you don't invest in this, you're saying no to a potential fortune.

senses.definition: used to say that you understand exactly what somebody means or is trying to say, so it is unnecessary to say anything more

examples.en: ‘They went to Paris together.’ ‘Say no more!’

senses.definition: to say exactly what you feel or think
used to express surprise at what somebody has just said

examples.en: ‘He's getting married.’ ‘Say what?’

senses.definition: used to ask somebody to tell you when you should stop pouring a drink or serving food for them because they have enough
to give an order; to make a request

examples.en: Just say the word, and I'll go.

senses.definition: used to suggest that although you could say more, what you do say will be enough to explain what you mean

examples.en: I won’t go into all the details. Suffice it to say that the whole event was a complete disaster.

senses.definition: in other words

examples.en: three days from now, that is to say on Friday

senses.definition: used to introduce an opinion that makes what you have just said seem less strong
used to say that something is not very unusual or special

examples.en: She's a better player than me, but that's not saying much (= because I am a very bad player).

senses.definition: used to say that it is impossible to predict what might happen

examples.en: There's no saying how he'll react.

idioms.word: there’s something, not much, etc. to be said for something/doing something

senses.definition: there are/are not good reasons for doing something, believing something or agreeing with something
without making something seem better, worse, more serious, etc. than it really is

examples.en: I was surprised, to say the least.

senses.definition: used to introduce a further fact or thing in addition to those already mentioned

examples.en: It was too expensive, to say nothing of the time it wasted.

senses.definition: I agree completely

examples.en: ‘We must stand up for ourselves.’ ‘Well said, John.’

idioms.word: what do/would you say (to something/doing something)

senses.definition: would you like something/to do something?

examples.en: What would you say to eating out tonight?
Let's go away for a weekend. What do you say?

senses.definition: used to agree to somebody’s suggestion because you do not want to argue
a particular person must be obeyed

examples.en: Sarah wanted the kitchen painted green, and what she says, goes.

idioms.word: when all is said and done

senses.definition: when everything is considered

examples.en: I know you're upset, but when all's said and done it isn't exactly a disaster.

senses.definition: used to say that nobody knows the answer to a question

examples.en: Who can say what will happen next year?

senses.definition: used to disagree with a statement or an opinion

examples.en: Who says I can't do it?

senses.definition: used to say that something might happen or might have happened in a particular way, because nobody really knows

examples.en: Who's to say we would not have succeeded if we'd had more time?

senses.definition: I agree with you completely

examples.en: ‘He's in a bad mood today.’ ‘You can say that again!’

senses.definition: used to say that you think the offer you are making is reasonable or generous

examples.en: Look, I'll give you £100 for it. You can't say fairer than that.

senses.definition: used to express surprise

examples.en: ‘They left without us.’ ‘You don't say!’ (= I'm not surprised)

senses.definition: used to agree with somebody when they say something about themselves that you would not have been rude enough to say yourself

examples.en: ‘I know I'm not the world's greatest cook.’ ‘You said it!’

senses.definition: used to agree with somebody’s suggestion
the right to influence something by giving your opinion before a decision is made

examples.en: We had no say in the decision to sell the company.
People want a greater say in local government.
The judge has the final say on the sentence.

senses.definition: to have the opportunity to express yourself fully about something

examples.en: She won't be happy until she's had her say.

senses.definition: used for showing surprise or pleasure

examples.en: Say, that's a nice haircut!

senses.definition: used for attracting somebody’s attention or for making a suggestion or comment

examples.en: Say, how about going to a movie tonight?

senses.definition: the size or extent of something, especially when compared with something else

examples.en: They entertain on a large scale (= they hold expensive parties with a lot of guests).
Here was corruption on a grand scale.
On a global scale, 77 per cent of energy is created from fossil fuels.
Corporations are borrowing on a massive scale.
Western-style consumerism is unsustainable on a global scale.
Manufacturing is done on a small scale.
His work as a portrait painter is small in scale.
to achieve economies of scale in production (= to produce many items so the cost of producing each one is reduced)
It was impossible to comprehend the full scale of the disaster.
It was not until morning that the sheer scale of the damage could be seen (= how great it was).
The scale of the problem is difficult to measure.

senses.definition: a range of levels or numbers used for measuring something

examples.en: a five-point pay scale
to evaluate performance on a scale from 1 to 10
The salary scale goes from £12 000 to £20 000.
a scale of charges
Use the following scale to rate each item.

senses.definition: the set of all the different levels of something, from the lowest to the highest

examples.en: At the other end of the scale, life is a constant struggle to get enough to eat.
You're higher on the social scale than I am.

senses.definition: a series of marks at regular points on an instrument that is used for measuring

examples.en: How much does it read on the scale?
He read the altitude in degrees off the scale.

senses.definition: an instrument for weighing people or things

examples.en: bathroom/kitchen/weighing scales
the scales of justice (= represented as the two pans on a balance)

senses.definition: the relation between the actual size of something and its size on a map, diagram or model that represents it

examples.en: a scale of 1:25 000
a scale model/drawing
Both plans are drawn to the same scale.
Is this diagram to scale? (= are all its parts the same size and shape in relation to each other as they are in the thing represented)

senses.definition: a series of musical notes moving upwards or downwards, with fixed intervals between each note, especially a series of eight starting on a particular note

examples.en: the scale of C major
to practise scales on the piano

senses.definition: any of the thin plates of hard material that cover the skin of many fish and reptiles

examples.en: The beast was a dragon, with great purple and green scales.

variants.html: (British English also fur)

senses.definition: a hard white substance that is sometimes left inside water pipes and containers for heating water
a hard substance that forms on teeth, especially when they are not cleaned regularly

variants.html: (also swing the balance)

senses.definition: to affect the result of something in one way rather than another

examples.en: In an interview, smart presentation can tip the scales in your favour.
New evidence tipped the balance against the prosecution.

senses.definition: to weigh a particular amount

examples.en: He tipped the scales at just over 80 kilos.

senses.definition: to climb to the top of something very high and steep

examples.en: the first woman to scale the world's five highest peaks
He somehow managed to scale the sheer outside wall of the tower.
He has scaled the heights of his profession.

senses.definition: to remove the small flat hard pieces of skin from a fish
to remove tartar from the teeth by scraping

examples.en: The dentist scaled and polished my teeth.

senses.definition: to change the size of something

examples.en: Text can be scaled from 4 points to 108 points without any loss of quality.

senses.definition: to look quickly but not very carefully at a document, etc.

examples.en: I scanned the list quickly for my name.
We quickly scanned the menu.
She scanned through the newspaper over breakfast.
You should teach students to scan for essential information.

senses.definition: to look at every part of something carefully, especially because you are looking for a particular thing or person

examples.en: He scanned the horizon for any sign of land.
She scanned the room for an empty seat.
She scanned his face anxiously.
She scanned the street nervously, looking for the two men.

senses.definition: to pass light over a picture or document using a scanner in order to copy it and put it in the memory of a computer

examples.en: How do I scan a photo and attach it to an email?
digitally scanned photographs
This recognizes text in a scanned image.
The pencil image is scanned into a computer.

senses.definition: to get an image of an object, a part of somebody’s body, etc. on a computer by passing X-rays, ultrasound waves or electromagnetic waves over it in a special machine

examples.en: Their brains are scanned so that researchers can monitor the progress of the disease.

senses.definition: to pass across an area

examples.en: Concealed video cameras scan every part of the compound.

senses.definition: to examine a computer program or document in order to look for a virus

examples.en: This software is designed to scan all new files for viruses.

senses.definition: to have a regular rhythm according to fixed rules

examples.en: This line doesn't scan.

senses.definition: a medical test in which a machine produces a picture of the inside of a person’s body, or a baby inside its mother's body, on a computer screen

examples.en: to have a brain scan
At twenty weeks she had a scan and the midwife told her the baby looked fine.

senses.definition: the act of looking quickly through something written or printed, usually in order to find something

examples.en: a scan of the newspapers
I had a quick scan down the guest list but couldn’t see my name.

senses.definition: behaviour or an event that people think is morally or legally wrong and causes public feelings of shock or anger

examples.en: a series of sex scandals
to cause/create a scandal
The scandal broke (= became known to the public) in May.
There has been no hint of scandal during his time in office.
a promising career wrecked by scandal

senses.definition: talk or reports about the very bad or wrong things that people have done or are thought to have done

examples.en: to spread scandal
newspapers full of scandal

senses.definition: an action, attitude, etc. that you think is very wrong and not at all acceptable

examples.en: It is a scandal that such a large city has no orchestra.
The real scandal is that nothing has been done to make sure it doesn't happen again.

senses.definition: to frighten somebody

examples.en: You scared me.

examples.cf: it scares somebody to do something
examples.en: It scared me to think I was alone in the building.

senses.definition: to become frightened

examples.en: He doesn't scare easily.

idioms.word: frighten/scare the (living) daylights out of somebody

senses.definition: to frighten somebody very much

idioms.word: frighten/scare the life out of somebody

senses.definition: to frighten somebody very much

examples.en: You scared the life out of me coming in so suddenly like that.

senses.definition: to frighten somebody very much

examples.en: Spiders frighten him to death.

idioms.word: scare the shit out of somebody | scare somebody shitless

senses.definition: to frighten somebody very much
a situation in which a lot of people are anxious or frightened about something

examples.en: a health scare
recent scares about pesticides in food
a scare story (= a news report that spreads more anxiety or fear about something than is necessary)
to cause a major scare
scare tactics (= ways of persuading people to do something by frightening them)

senses.definition: a sudden feeling of fear

examples.en: You gave me a scare!
We've had quite a scare.

senses.definition: frightened of something or afraid that something bad might happen

examples.en: The thieves got scared and ran away.
He looked scared and hid behind Jesse.
She is scared of going out alone.
He's scared of heights.
People are scared to use the buses late at night.
Some victims are too scared to speak out.
I’m scared (that) I’m going to fall.
He was scared at the prospect of running out of food.
Anne was scared at seeing her father crying.
We were scared for our lives (= thought we would die).
a scared look
I was scared to death (= very frightened).
We were scared stiff (= very frightened).
He's scared out of his mind (= very frightened).

idioms.word: be frightened/nervous/scared of your own shadow

senses.definition: to be very easily frightened; to be very nervous

idioms.word: be frightened/scared/terrified out of your wits

variants.text: (also to frighten/scare the wits out of somebody)
variants.html: (also to frighten/scare the wits out of somebody)

senses.definition: to be very frightened; to frighten somebody very much

examples.en: I was scared out of my wits!
The latest news has scared the wits out of investors.

senses.definition: to be extremely frightened or bored
frightening

examples.en: It was a really scary moment.
a scary movie
Close up the statue looked even more scary.
It was a pretty scary experience.

senses.definition: spread far apart over a wide area or over a long period of time

examples.en: a few scattered settlements
sunshine with scattered showers
Her family are scattered around the world.

senses.definition: a description of how things might happen in the future

examples.en: Let me suggest a possible scenario.
The worst-case scenario (= the worst possible thing that could happen) would be for the factory to be closed down.
a nightmare scenario

senses.definition: a written outline of what happens in a film or play
the place where something happens, especially something unpleasant

examples.en: the scene of the accident/crime/crash
The attacker fled the scene.
Italy was the scene of many demonstrations at that time.
Firefighters arrived on the scene within minutes.
Sadly the man died at the scene.

senses.definition: an event or a situation that you see, especially one of a particular type

examples.en: The team's victory produced scenes of jubilation all over the country.
a scene of devastation/carnage
She witnessed some very distressing scenes.

senses.definition: a part of a film, play or book in which the action happens in one place or is of one particular type

examples.en: sex/fight/action/battle scenes
deleted scenes (= ones that were not included in the final version)
to film/shoot a scene
They shot the opening scene 15 times.
I got very nervous before my big scene (= the one where I have a very important part).
The scene where he arrives at the factory is the turning point in the book.

senses.definition: one of the small sections that a play or an opera is divided into

examples.en: Act I, Scene 2 of ‘Macbeth’

variants.html: the scene, the… scene

senses.definition: a particular area of activity or way of life and the people who are part of it

examples.en: the art/club/punk scene
a newcomer on the music scene
British players were finding it increasingly difficult to compete on the international scene.
Tarantino burst onto the cinema scene in the ’90s.
After years at the top, she just vanished from the scene.

senses.definition: a view that you see

examples.en: a delightful rural scene
They went abroad for a change of scene (= to see and experience new surroundings).
We stood and surveyed the scene.
I stared out of the window of the train on the ever-changing scene.

senses.definition: a painting, drawing, or photograph of a place and the things that are happening there

examples.en: an exhibition of Parisian street scenes

senses.definition: a loud, angry argument, especially one that happens in public and is embarrassing

examples.en: She had made a scene in the middle of the party.

senses.definition: in the part of a theatre, etc. that the public does not usually see

examples.en: The students were able to go behind the scenes to see how programmes are made.

senses.definition: in a way that people in general are not aware of

examples.en: A lot of negotiating has been going on behind the scenes.
behind-the-scenes work

senses.definition: not the type of thing that somebody likes or enjoys doing

examples.en: Hillwalking is not my scene, so I stayed at home.

senses.definition: to create a situation in which something can easily happen or develop

examples.en: His arrival set the scene for another argument.

senses.definition: to give somebody the information and details they need in order to understand what comes next

examples.en: The first part of the programme was just setting the scene.
The scene is set in the first paragraph with an account of Sally's childhood.

variants.html: (North American English skeptical)

senses.definition: having doubts that a claim or statement is true or that something will happen

examples.en: She looked highly sceptical.
I am sceptical about his chances of winning.
The public remain sceptical of these claims.

senses.definition: a plan that lists all the work that you have to do and when you must do each thing

examples.en: I have a hectic schedule for the next few days.
a busy/gruelling/punishing schedule
We're working to a tight schedule (= we have a lot of things to do in a short time).
He has taken some time out of his busy schedule to talk to us.
They have a very flexible work schedule.
I have no time available in my regular schedule.
Filming began on schedule (= at the planned time).
The project will be completed on schedule this summer.
The new bridge has been finished two years ahead of schedule.
The tunnel project has already fallen behind schedule.
At this stage everything is going according to schedule (= as planned).
We are trying desperately to keep to our schedule.
The countries have yet to set the schedule for the next round of talks.

variants.html: (also timetable especially in British English)

senses.definition: a chart showing the times at which trains, buses and planes leave and arrive

examples.en: Connor checked the bus schedules for the day.
disruptions to flight schedules caused by the strike

variants.html: (British English timetable)

senses.definition: a chart or plan of the classes that a student or teacher has in school each week

examples.en: Besides a full school schedule, Kayla's week is jam-packed with other activities.

senses.definition: a list of the television and radio programmes that are on a particular channel and the times that they start

examples.en: The channel's schedules are filled with old films and repeats.

senses.definition: a written list of things, for example prices, rates or conditions

examples.en: tax schedules

senses.definition: to arrange for something to happen at a particular time

examples.en: The meeting is scheduled for Friday afternoon.

senses.definition: to include something in an official list of things

examples.en: The substance has been scheduled as a poison.

senses.definition: a plan or system for doing or organizing something

examples.en: a training scheme

to introduce/launch/run a scheme
a salary/insurance/loan scheme

senses.definition: a plan for getting money or some other advantage for yourself, especially one that involves cheating other people

examples.en: an elaborate scheme to avoid taxes

senses.definition: an ordered system or arrangement

senses.definition: an area of social housing (= houses or flats for people to rent or buy at low prices)

senses.definition: the way things seem to be organized; the way somebody wants everything to be organized

senses.definition: to think or form an opinion about something

senses.definition: a person who knows a lot about a particular subject because they have studied it in detail

senses.definition: a student who has been given a scholarship to study at a school, college or university

senses.definition: a clever person who works hard at school

senses.definition: an amount of money given to somebody by an organization to help pay for their education

senses.definition: the serious study of an academic subject and the knowledge and methods involved

senses.definition: all the children or students and the teachers in a school

senses.definition: a place where people go to learn a particular subject or skill

senses.definition: a college or university; the time that you spend there

senses.definition: a department of a college or university that teaches a particular subject

examples.en: the business/law/medical school
the School of Dentistry

senses.definition: a group of writers, artists, etc. whose style of work or opinions have been influenced by the same person or ideas

examples.en: the Dutch school of painting

senses.definition: a large number of fish or other sea animals, swimming together

senses.definition: an old-fashioned person who likes to do things as they were done in the past

senses.definition: very fashionable

senses.definition: to train somebody/yourself/an animal to do something

senses.definition: to educate a child

senses.definition: knowledge about the structure and behaviour of the natural and physical world, based on facts that you can prove, for example by experiments

examples.en: new developments in science and technology
the advance of modern science
the laws of science

senses.definition: the study of science

examples.en: science students/teachers/classes

senses.definition: a particular branch of science

examples.en: medical/environmental science
the biological sciences

senses.definition: a system for organizing the knowledge about a particular subject, especially one that deals with aspects of human behaviour or society

examples.en: a science of international politics

senses.definition: to confuse somebody by using technical or complicated language that they do not understand
involving science; connected with science

examples.en: a scientific discovery/theory/fact
scientific research/evidence/knowledge/methods
sites of scientific interest
a scientific journal/paper/study

senses.dis_g: (of a way of doing something or thinking)
senses.definition: careful and logical

examples.en: He took a very scientific approach to management.

senses.definition: a person who studies or is an expert in one or more of the natural sciences (= for example, physics, chemistry or biology)

nuclear/climate scientists
scientists and engineers

senses.definition: the opportunity or ability to do or achieve something

senses.definition: a British charity which helps people with a disability, especially those with cerebral palsy (= a condition caused by brain damage before or at birth, which makes people lose control of their movements). It was formed in 1952 as the Spastics Society and given the new name Scope in 1994. It has several schools and other centres in Britain.

about that/this matter
