a sea voyage
a hotel room with sea view
The temperature of most of the deep sea is only just above freezing.
The boat, broken to bits, lay on the sea floor.
The amount of Arctic sea ice in summer has shrunk 15 to 20%.

senses.definition: a large area of salt water that is part of an ocean or surrounded by land

examples.en: the North Sea
the Caspian Sea

senses.definition: the movement of the waves of the sea

examples.en: It was a calm sea.
The sea was very rough.
The ship sank in heavy seas.
stormy/choppy seas

senses.definition: a large amount of something that stretches over a wide area

examples.en: He looked down at the sea of smiling faces before him.

senses.definition: on the sea, especially in a ship, or in the sea

examples.en: It happened on the second night at sea.
They were lost at sea.

senses.definition: confused and not knowing what to do

examples.en: I'm all at sea with these new regulations.

idioms.word: between the devil and the deep blue sea

senses.definition: in a difficult situation where there are two equally unpleasant or unacceptable choices
to become a sailor; to leave your home and family without permission to become a sailor

examples.en: He ran away to sea at the age of 13.

senses.definition: far away from land where the sea is deepest

examples.en: She fell overboard and was swept out to sea.
She stood on the cliff, staring out to sea.

senses.definition: to leave a port or harbour by ship or boat

examples.en: The ship put to sea in deteriorating weather conditions.

idioms.word: there are plenty more fish in the sea

senses.definition: used to comfort somebody whose romantic relationship has ended by saying that there are many other people they may have a successful relationship with in the future
to close an envelope, etc. by sticking the edges of the opening together

examples.en: Make sure you've signed the document before sealing the envelope.
a sealed bid (= one that is kept in a sealed envelope and therefore remains secret until all other bids have been received)

senses.definition: to close a container tightly or fill a small opening, etc., especially so that air, liquid, etc. cannot get in or out

examples.en: He sealed the bag tightly with sticky tape.
The windows and doors had been sealed up with bricks.
The evidence is kept in sealed plastic bags.

senses.definition: to make something definite, so that it cannot be changed or argued about

examples.en: to seal a contract
They shook hands to seal the deal.
The discovery of new evidence sealed his fate (= nothing could prevent what was going to happen to him).
She sealed victory with a birdie at the final hole.

senses.definition: to cover the surface of something with a substance in order to protect it

examples.en: The floors had been stripped and sealed with varnish.

senses.definition: to prevent people from passing through a place

examples.en: Troops have sealed the borders between the countries.

senses.definition: used to say that you will not repeat somebody’s secret to other people

idioms.word: signed and sealed | signed, sealed and delivered

senses.definition: definite, because all the legal documents have been signed

examples.en: The contracts are already signed and sealed.

senses.definition: an official design or mark, stamped on a document to show that it is real and carries the authority of a particular person or organization

examples.en: The letter bore the president's seal.

senses.definition: a thing that makes something definite

examples.en: The project has been given the government's seal of approval (= official approval).
I looked upon the gift as a seal on our friendship.

senses.definition: a substance, piece of material, etc. used to fill a small opening so that air, liquid, etc. cannot get in or out

examples.en: a jar with a rubber seal in the lid
Only drink bottled water and check the seal isn't broken.

senses.definition: a piece of wax (= a soft substance produced by bees), soft metal or paper that is placed across the opening of something such as a letter or box and which has to be broken before the letter or box can be opened

examples.en: He broke the wax seal and unrolled the paper.
an official-looking letter with a wax seal

senses.definition: a piece of metal, a ring, etc. with a design on it, used for stamping a wax or metal seal
a sea animal that eats fish and lives around coasts. There are many types of seal, some of which are hunted for their fur.

examples.en: a colony of seals
grey seals basking on the rocks

senses.definition: to make something definite or complete

examples.en: Her election to the premiership set the seal on a remarkable political career.

senses.definition: in a sealed envelope that cannot be opened before a particular time
an attempt to find somebody/something, especially by looking carefully for them/it

examples.en: a long search for the murder weapon
She began a search for new premises
The search for a cure goes on.
The search is on (= has begun) for someone to fill the post.
Detectives carried out a thorough search of the building.
Police conducted a fingertip search of the garden.
She went into the kitchen in search of (= looking for) a drink.
Eventually the search was called off.
a search and rescue team

senses.definition: an act or the activity of looking for information on a computer or on the internet

examples.en: I've just done a search on the internet and came up with this website.
I did an image search for ‘vinyl record’.
A Google search on her name yielded nothing.
Our site is found on the first page of search results.

senses.definition: to look carefully for something/somebody; to examine a particular place when looking for something/somebody

examples.en: She searched in vain for her passport.
Police searched for clues in the area.
The customs officers searched through our bags.
I've searched high and low for those files.
I found these photos while searching among some old papers.
His house had clearly been searched and the book was missing.
Police searched the area for clues.
Firefighters searched the buildings for survivors.

senses.definition: to look for information on a computer or on the internet

examples.en: You can search for any word or phrase in the text.
I searched online today for more information on sonic booms.
The database can be searched by keyword, topic or source.
I searched the internet for recipes.

senses.definition: to examine somebody’s clothes, their pockets, etc. in order to find something that they may be hiding

examples.en: Visitors are regularly searched as they enter the building.
The youths were arrested and searched for anything that would incriminate them.

senses.definition: to think carefully about something, especially in order to find the answer to a problem

examples.en: He searched desperately for something to say.
We are continually searching for ways to cut costs.
She paused, searching for the right word.
They were still searching for answers about what had happened.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you do not know the answer to somebody’s question

examples.en: ‘Why didn't she say anything?’ ‘Search me!’

senses.definition: any of the four main periods of the year: spring, summer, autumn and winter

examples.en: the changing seasons
Autumn is my favourite season.

senses.definition: a period of the year in tropical countries when it is either very dry or it rains a lot

examples.en: In this climate there are no real changes of temperature, just a wet and a dry season.
Next month is the start of the rainy season.

senses.definition: a period of time during a year when a particular activity happens or is done

examples.en: the cricket/football/hunting/shooting season
He scored his first goal of the season on Saturday.
They achieved their first win of the season.
He will not be offered a new contract at the end of the season.
The team have had a dream start to the season.
The female changes colour during the breeding season.
The growing season for these trees varies depending on species.
We're in the middle of the roughest hurricane season we've seen in quite some time.
The hotels are always full during the peak season (= when most people are on holiday).
the holiday season
the tourist season
the holiday season (= the time of Thanksgiving, Hanukkah, Christmas and New Year)
the festive season (= Christmas and New Year)
the summer blockbuster season

senses.definition: a period of time in which a play is shown in one place; a series of plays, films or television programmes

examples.en: The play opens for a second season in London next week.
a season of films by Alfred Hitchcock

senses.definition: a period of time during one year when a particular style of clothes, hair, etc. is popular and fashionable

examples.en: This season's look is soft and romantic.
The fashion magazines are full of the new look for the spring season.

senses.definition: a set of television or radio programmes that have the same characters or deal with the same subject

examples.en: The show begins its second season next week.
I binge-watched an entire season of ‘Succession’ (= watched all of the episodes on one occasion) on Sunday.
I can't wait to see the season finale (= last episode in the season).
the season opener (= the first episode in the season)

idioms.word: be in season | come into season

senses.definition: be/become easily available and ready to eat because it is the right time of year for them

examples.en: Strawberries are now in season.
Melons are just coming into season.

senses.definition: be/become ready to have sex and produce young
not easily available because it is not the right time of year for them

examples.en: Lobster's out of season right now.

senses.definition: at the times of year when few people go on holiday

examples.en: Hotels are cheaper out of season.

senses.definition: used during the Christmas period to wish somebody a pleasant holiday
to add salt, pepper, etc. to food in order to make it taste better

examples.en: Season the lamb with garlic.
Add the mushrooms, and season to taste (= add as much salt, pepper, etc. as you think is necessary).
Season the meat well with salt and pepper.
highly seasoned food

senses.definition: a place where you can sit, for example a chair

examples.en: She sat back in her seat.
He put his shopping on the seat behind him.
Please take a seat (= sit down).
Ladies and gentlemen, please take your seats (= sit down).
the front/passenger seat (= in a car)
the back/rear seats
a child seat (= for a child in a car)
a window/an aisle seat (= on a plane or train)
a window/corner seat (= one near a window/in a corner)
a car/toilet seat
We used the branch of an old tree as a seat.
We all filed back to our seats in silence.

senses.definition: with the number of seats mentioned

examples.en: a ten-seater minibus
an all-seater stadium (= in which nobody is allowed to stand)

senses.definition: the part of a chair, etc. on which you actually sit

examples.en: a steel chair with a plastic seat

senses.definition: a place where you pay to sit in a plane, train, theatre, etc.

examples.en: Call the theatre box office to book your seats.
To reserve a seat, visit our website.
There are no seats left on that flight.
Airlines often give great deals to fill empty seats.
We had excellent seats for the show, on the third row.

senses.definition: an official position as a member of a parliament, council, committee, etc.

examples.en: a seat on the city council/in Parliament/in Congress
Republicans currently hold 51 seats in the Senate.
The majority of seats on the board will be held by business representatives.
The party won 32 seats in the recent elections.
Several ministers are in danger of losing their seats.
to take your seat (= to begin your duties, especially in Parliament)
One vote could make all the difference in the highly marginal seat of Crawley.

senses.definition: a place where people are involved in a particular activity, especially a city that has a university or the offices of a government

examples.en: Washington is the seat of government of the US.
a university town renowned as a seat of learning

senses.definition: a large house in the country that belongs to a member of the upper class

examples.en: For the first two years of her life she lived at Ickworth, the family seat in Sussex.

senses.definition: the part of the body on which a person sits
the part of a pair of trousers that covers a person’s seat
to have an advantage over other people or be in control of a situation

examples.en: Canada is in the catbird seat as an energy powerhouse.

variants.text: (North American English be in the driver’s seat)
variants.html: (North American English be in the driver’s seat)

senses.definition: to be the person in control of a situation
used to refer to the number of people who attend a show, talk, etc., especially when emphasizing the need or desire to attract a large number

examples.en: They're not bothered about attracting the right audience—they just want bums on seats.

idioms.word: (fly) by the seat of your pants

senses.definition: to act without careful thought and without a plan that you have made in advance, hoping that you will be lucky and be successful

idioms.word: on the edge of your seat

senses.definition: very excited and giving your full attention to something

examples.en: The game had the crowd on the edge of their seats.
I was on the edge of my seat waiting to find out what happened next.

senses.definition: to allow somebody else to play a more active and important role in a particular situation than you do

examples.en: Many managers take a back seat and leave recruitment to specialists.

senses.definition: to give somebody a place to sit; to sit down in a place

examples.en: Please wait to be seated (= in a restaurant, etc.).
Please be seated (= sit down).
He seated himself behind the desk.
She was wondering where to seat her guests.
I found myself seated next to her.

senses.definition: to have enough seats for a particular number of people

examples.en: The aircraft seats 200 passengers.
The auditorium can seat an audience of 5 000.
The car seats six comfortably.

senses.definition: connected with teaching children of 11–18 years

examples.en: secondary teachers
the secondary curriculum

senses.definition: less important than something else

examples.en: That is just a secondary consideration.
Experience is what matters—age is of secondary importance.
Raising animals was only secondary to other forms of farming.
After a while, his writing became secondary to his celebrity.
Forests are secondary in importance only to the oceans in their effects on the earth.
The characters and plot become secondary to the setting and atmosphere.

senses.definition: happening as a result of something else

examples.en: a secondary infection
a secondary effect
a secondary colour (= made from mixing two primary colours)
a secondary outcome

senses.definition: used to introduce the second of a list of points you want to make in a speech or piece of writing

examples.en: Firstly, it's expensive, and secondly, it's too slow.
First of all, there's no time to do all this, and secondly, it's the wrong thing to be doing anyway.
Secondly, and importantly, cultural influences on behaviour are discussed.

senses.definition: known about by only a few people; kept hidden from others

examples.en: secret information/meetings/talks
They belong to an age-old secret society.
He tried to keep it secret from his family.
Details of the proposals remain secret.
a secret passage leading to the beach
The two candidates were chosen by a secret ballot (= in which nobody knows how you voted) of MPs.
He's a natural salesman, whose secret weapon is the sheer confidence and optimism that he exudes.
The group is on a highly secret mission.
Secret police documents were leaked to the press.
The scandal was kept secret from the French public for 18 years.
What could be so secret that it had to stay hidden?

senses.definition: used to describe actions and behaviour that you do not tell other people about

examples.en: He's a secret drinker.
I didn't know you were a secret football fan.
her secret fears
Perhaps he has secret hopes that she'll go back to him.

senses.definition: liking to have secrets that other people do not know about; showing this

examples.en: They were so secret about everything.
Jessica caught a secret smile flitting between the two of them.

senses.definition: something that is known about by only a few people and not told to others

examples.en: Can you keep a secret?
She will not reveal his secret.
The location of the ship is a closely guarded secret.
This bar is one of central London's best/worst kept secrets.
Shall we let him in on (= tell him) the secret?
He made no secret of his ambition (= he didn't try to hide it).
It's no secret that the past few years have been challenging for the industry.
dark secrets from his past
The dirty little secret of gaming is how much time you spend not having fun.
Let me tell you a secret.

senses.definition: the best or only way to achieve something; the way a particular person achieves something

examples.en: She still looks so young. What's her secret?
Careful planning is the secret of success.
These animals may hold the secret to combating the virus.
The secret to happiness is love.
What is the secret to their success?

senses.definition: a thing that is not yet fully understood or that is difficult to understand

examples.en: the secrets of the universe
He spent much of his childhood here, learning the secrets of the woods.

senses.definition: if something is an open secret, many people know about it, although it is supposed to be a secret
a secret that somebody feels ashamed about
without other people knowing about it

examples.en: The meeting was held in secret.
She admired him, in secret of course.
The film stars were married in secret to avoid publicity.

senses.definition: a person who works in an office, working for another person, dealing with mail and phone calls, keeping records, arranging meetings with people, etc.

examples.en: a legal/medical secretary
the mayor's press secretary
Please contact my secretary to make an appointment.
He is secretary to the board of governors.

senses.definition: an official of a club, society, etc. who deals with mail, keeping records and making business arrangements

examples.en: the membership secretary
She served as club secretary for 25 years.
The union's branch secretary said he hoped a solution would be found.
secretary to the Jockey Club

senses.definition: (in the UK) the head of an important government department
the head of a government department, chosen by the president

examples.en: Secretary of the Treasury
She was deputy secretary of agriculture.

senses.definition: an assistant of a government minister, an ambassador, etc.

examples.en: Ms Watson is a former parliamentary secretary to the Minister of Education.

senses.definition: any of the parts into which something is divided

examples.en: That section of the road is still closed.
the tail section of the plane
The library has a large biology section.

senses.definition: a separate part of a structure from which the whole can be put together

examples.en: The shed comes in sections that you assemble yourself.

senses.definition: a separate part of a document, book, etc.

examples.en: These issues will be discussed more fully in the next section.
the sports section of the newspaper
The report has a section on accidents at work.
The book is divided into four sections.
It is difficult to navigate from one section of the site to another.
Feel free to add your own ideas in the comments section.
the previous/following/final section
Section by section, this essay examines and explores the key terms.

senses.definition: a separate group within a larger group of people

examples.en: an issue that will affect large sections of the population
the brass section of an orchestra
an area populated largely by the poorer sections of society
The way he's been treated by certain sections of the media is despicable.
We've had meetings with all sections of the community.

senses.definition: a department in an organization, institution, etc.

examples.en: He's the director of the finance section.
the section of the company dealing with customer services

senses.definition: a district of a town, city or county

examples.en: the Dorchester section of Boston
one of the city’s most affluent sections

senses.definition: a measure of land, equal to one square mile
a drawing or diagram of something as it would look if it were cut from top to bottom or from one side to the other

examples.en: The illustration shows a section through a leaf.
The architect drew the house in section.

senses.definition: the act of cutting or separating something in an operation

examples.en: The surgeon performed a section (= made a cut) on the vein.

senses.definition: a very thin flat piece cut from body tissue to be looked at under a microscope

examples.en: to examine a section from the kidney

senses.definition: to divide body tissue by cutting
to cut animal or plant tissue into thin slices in order to look at it under a microscope
to officially send somebody to a psychiatric hospital, using a law that can force them to stay there to have treatment

examples.en: He was sectioned under the Mental Health Act because he was harming himself.

senses.definition: a part of an area of activity, especially of a country’s economy

examples.en: the service/banking/manufacturing/financial sector
jobs in the agricultural sector
She works in the voluntary sector (= organizations that do not make a profit).
We have seen rapid growth in the services sector.
the privileged sectors of society

senses.definition: a part of a particular area, especially an area under military control

examples.en: each sector of the war zone
The partition of the city meant that members of the same family were living in different sectors.

senses.definition: a part of a circle lying between two straight lines drawn from the centre to the edge
not connected with spiritual or religious matters

examples.en: secular music
We live in a largely secular society.

senses.definition: living among ordinary people rather than in a religious community
to obtain or achieve something, especially when this means using a lot of effort

examples.en: to secure a contract/deal/funding
The team managed to secure a place in the finals.
The team were unable to secure a victory.
She secured 2 000 votes.
The delegation has secured the promise of a ceasefire.
A production company secured the film rights to the biography.
They are contract workers unable to secure a full-time position.
Retailers will need to pay a higher price in order to secure supplies.
He secured a place for himself at law school.
He secured himself a place at law school.

senses.definition: to attach or fasten something so that it does not move

examples.en: She secured the rope firmly to the back of the car.
He secured the boat with a rope.
The tables on board were secured firmly to the floor.

senses.definition: to protect something so that it is safe and difficult to attack or damage

examples.en: to secure a property against intruders
Have you properly secured your computer from viral attack?
a savings plan that will secure your child’s future
We must all do everything we can to secure our borders.
The windows were secured with locks and bars.

senses.definition: to legally agree to give somebody property or goods that are worth the same amount as the money that you have borrowed from them, if you are unable to pay the money back

examples.en: a loan secured on the house

senses.definition: likely to continue or be successful for a long time

examples.en: a secure job/income
It's not a very secure way to make a living.
The future of the company looks secure.

senses.definition: where somebody/something cannot be harmed; that cannot be affected or harmed by something

examples.en: It's important to keep your documents secure.
Civilians are being evacuated to a secure location.
Parents are primarily concerned with leaving their children in a safe, secure environment.
Information must be stored so that it is secure from accidental deletion.

senses.definition: feeling happy and confident about yourself or a particular situation

examples.en: At last they were able to feel secure about the future.
She finished the match, secure in the knowledge that she was through to the next round.
She felt safe and secure in his arms.
I would like to be financially secure by age 55.

senses.definition: guarded and/or made stronger so that it is difficult for people to enter or leave

examples.en: Check that all windows and doors have been made as secure as possible.
a secure unit for child offenders
The building is secure against intruders.

senses.definition: not likely to move, fall down, etc.

examples.en: The aerial doesn't look very secure to me.
It was difficult to maintain a secure foothold on the ice.
Our relationship was now on a more secure footing.

senses.definition: the activities involved in protecting a country, building or person against attack, danger, etc.

examples.en: national/homeland security (= the defence of a country)
airport security officers
The bars are to provide security against break-ins.
They carried out security checks at the airport.
Passwords are a very important security measure.
The visit took place amidst tight security (= the use of many police officers).
the security forces/services (= the police, army, etc.)
a high/maximum security prison (= for dangerous criminals)
a security alert/threat/situation
a security adviser/expert
The criminals were caught (= filmed) on a security video.
to tighten/improve/enhance security
The team abandoned its tour due to security concerns.
The two countries agreed to work together to strengthen border security.
We will protect our national security.
Before I can answer your question I have to take you through security (= ask some questions to check a person's identity).

senses.definition: a place at an airport where you go after your passport has been checked so that officials can find out if you are carrying illegal drugs or weapons

examples.en: My bag was emptied and searched when I went through security.
It took ages to clear security and reach the departure lounge.
Airport security might decide you're unfit to fly.

senses.definition: the department of a large company or organization that deals with the protection of its buildings, equipment and staff

examples.en: Security was/were called to the incident.

senses.definition: protection against something bad that might happen in the future

examples.en: financial security
Which type of investment offers the greatest security?
This system provides basic security for employees.

senses.definition: the state of feeling happy and safe from danger or worry

examples.en: the security of a loving family life
She'd allowed herself to be lulled into a false sense of security (= a feeling that she was safe when in fact she was in danger).

senses.definition: a valuable item, such as a house, that you agree to give to somebody if you are unable to pay back the money that you have borrowed from them

examples.en: His home and business are being held as security for the loan.
She pledged her jewellery as security for a £50 000 loan.
His father agreed to stand security for his son's house-purchase loan.
The bank will make a loan against the security of the lender's house.

senses.definition: documents proving that somebody is the owner of shares, etc. in a particular company

examples.en: government securities

senses.definition: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes

examples.en: She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.
I looked out of the window but saw nothing.
The opera was the place to see and be seen (= by other important or fashionable people).
I would like to see some proof of this statement.
The divers reported seeing a lot of sharks.
He recalls seeing his father sitting at the kitchen table.
I've never seen anything like this!
He could see (that) she had been crying.
Did you see what happened?
If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.
I hate to see you unhappy.
She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.
I saw you put the key in your pocket.

examples.cf: somebody/something is seen to do something
examples.en: He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.
The government not only has to do something, it must be seen to be doing something (= people must be aware that it is doing something).
The walls were too high to see over.

senses.definition: to have or use the power of sight

examples.en: She will never see again (= she has become blind).
On a clear day you can see for miles from here.
It was getting dark and I couldn't see to read.
I could hardly see because of the smoke.

senses.definition: to watch a game, television programme, performance, etc.

examples.en: Did you see that programme on Brazil last night?
In the evening we went to see a movie.
Fifty thousand people saw the match.
I finally got to see them in concert.
I really want to see this film now.
This performance was very beautiful, like nothing I had ever seen before.
I remember seeing that movie when I was a kid.
It's not the sort of thing you see on TV that often.
This film really deserves to be seen on a big screen.

senses.definition: to look at something in order to find information; to go to somebody in order to ask for help or information

examples.en: See page 158.
If you missed the session, see a member of staff for advice.
See Table 2 for details.
See also paragraphs 6.5 to 6.9 above.
See above/below for a breakdown of the costs.
See over (= the next page) for details.

senses.definition: to be near and recognize somebody; to meet somebody by chance

examples.en: Guess who I saw at the party last night!
Aren't you pleased to see me?
It's so good to see you!

senses.definition: to visit somebody/something

examples.en: Come and see us again soon.
Around 200  000 visitors each year come to see the summer palace.

senses.definition: to have a meeting with somebody

examples.en: You ought to see a doctor about that cough.
What is it you want to see me about?
I can only see you for five minutes.

senses.definition: to spend time with somebody

examples.en: Are you seeing anyone (= having a romantic relationship with anyone)?
They've been seeing a lot of each other (= spending a lot of time together) recently.
We haven't seen much of Liz lately.
He has changed since his family last saw him.

senses.definition: to understand something

examples.en: ‘It opens like this.’ ‘Oh, I see.’
He didn't see the joke.
I don't think she saw the point of the story.
He changed the way we see the world around us.
to see a/the need for something
I see no need to involve the law.
I can see both sides of the argument.
They saw nothing wrong with having three cars.
Make Lydia see reason (= be sensible), will you?
Can’t you see (that) he’s taking advantage of you?
I don't see that it matters what Josh thinks.
‘It's broken.’ ‘Oh yes, I see what you mean.’
‘Can we go swimming?’ ‘I don't see why not (= yes, you can).’
They will be able to see what really happened there.

senses.definition: to have an opinion of something

examples.en: I see things differently now.
Try to see things from her point of view.
The way I see it, you have three main problems.
As far as I can see (= in my opinion), you've done nothing wrong.
Lack of money is the main problem, as I see it (= in my opinion).
She is in love with him but Darren sees their relationship in a different light (= has a different opinion).

senses.definition: to consider something as a future possibility; to imagine somebody/something as something

examples.en: I can't see her changing her mind.
I can't really see myself working in a lab all day.
His colleagues see him as a future director.
She was quiet and withdrawn and never saw herself as a dancer.

senses.definition: to find out something by looking, asking or waiting

examples.en: ‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll just go and see.’
‘Is he going to get better?’ ‘I don't know, we'll just have to wait and see.’
We'll have a great time, you'll see.
Go and see what the kids are doing, will you?
We'll have to see how it goes.
It will be interesting to see what happens.
I see (that) interest rates are going up again.
It can be seen that certain groups are more at risk than others.

senses.definition: to find out or decide something by thinking or considering

examples.en: ‘Will you be able to help us?’ ‘I don't know, I'll have to see.’
‘Can I go to the party?’ ‘We'll see (= I'll decide later).’
I'll see what I can do to help.

senses.definition: to make sure that you do something or that something is done

examples.en: See that all the doors are locked before you leave.
Could you see that the kids are in bed by 8 o'clock?

senses.definition: to experience or suffer something

examples.en: He has seen a great deal in his long life.
I hope I never live to see the day when computers finally replace books.
It didn't surprise her—she had seen it all before.

senses.definition: to be the time when an event happens

examples.en: Next year sees the centenary of Saint-Saëns' death.
The twentieth century saw dramatic changes in most areas of life.

senses.definition: to be the place where an event happens

examples.en: This stadium has seen many thrilling football games.

senses.definition: to go with somebody to help or protect them

examples.en: I saw the children across (= helped them cross) the road.
May I see you home (= go with you as far as your house)?
My secretary will see you out (= show you the way out of the building).

senses.definition: that can be seen clearly; in a way that can be seen clearly
used when you are thinking or trying to remember something

examples.en: Now let me see—how old is she now?

senses.definition: to realize that there is going to be a problem before it happens

examples.en: We should have seen it coming. There was no way he could keep going under all that pressure.

idioms.word: see somebody/something for what they are/it is

senses.definition: to realize that somebody/something is not as good, pleasant, etc. as they/it seem
to find out or look at something yourself in order to be sure that what somebody is saying is true

examples.en: If you don't believe me, go and see for yourself!

variants.html: (also informal seeing as (how)…)

senses.definition: because of the fact that…

examples.en: Seeing that he's been off sick all week he's unlikely to come.

senses.definition: goodbye

examples.en: I'd better be going now. See you!

senses.definition: used when you are explaining something

examples.en: You see, the thing is, we won't be finished before Friday.

senses.definition: the district or office of a bishop or an archbishop

examples.en: the Holy See (= the office of the Pope)

senses.definition: the small hard part produced by a plant, from which a new plant can grow

examples.en: a packet of wild flower seeds
sesame seeds
Sow the seeds outdoors in spring.
Plant the seeds 10cm apart.
These vegetables can be grown from seed.
seed potatoes (= used for planting)

variants.html: (also pip especially in British English)

senses.definition: the small hard seed that is found in some types of fruit
the beginning of a feeling or development that continues to grow

examples.en: the seeds of rebellion
This planted the seeds of doubt in my mind.
He argued that capitalism contained the seeds of its own destruction.

senses.definition: one of the best players in a competition. The seeds are given a position in a list to try and make sure that they do not play each other in the early parts of the competition.

examples.en: The top seed won comfortably.
the number one seed
She was the top seed at the US Open this year.

senses.definition: semen
all the people who are the children, grandchildren, etc. of one man
to produce flowers and seeds as well as leaves

examples.en: The lettuces had all run to seed.
Cutting weeds before they go to seed will greatly reduce future weed problems.

senses.definition: to become much less attractive or good because of lack of attention

examples.en: After his divorce, he let himself go to seed.

senses.definition: to start the process that leads to a particular situation or result

examples.en: In this way he sowed the seeds of his own success.

senses.definition: to produce seeds
to produce other plants using its own seeds
to plant seeds in an area of ground

examples.en: The site has been seeded with prairie grasses and wildflowers.
a newly seeded lawn

senses.definition: to make somebody a seed in a competition

examples.en: He has been seeded 14th at Wimbledon next week.

senses.definition: to look for something/somebody

examples.en: Drivers are advised to seek alternative routes.
Police are not seeking anyone else in connection with the deaths.
They sought in vain for somewhere to shelter.

senses.definition: to ask somebody for something; to try to obtain or achieve something

examples.en: I think it's time we sought legal advice.
They sought refuge in the mountain villages.
She fled the country and is now seeking asylum in Sweden.
The pilot sought permission to land.
EU citizens have the right to seek employment in any member state.
He has not sought medical treatment for his condition.
She was determined to seek revenge.
She managed to calm him down and seek help from a neighbour.
We need to seek approval from the local council.
They came seeking for the truth.

senses.definition: to try to do something

examples.en: He sought to establish himself as a writer.
They quickly sought to distance themselves from the protesters.

senses.definition: looking for or trying to get the thing mentioned; the activity of doing this

examples.en: attention-seeking behaviour
Voluntary work can provide a framework for job-seeking.

senses.definition: to try to find a way to become rich, especially by going to another place

examples.en: Many emigrated to Australia to seek their fortune.

senses.definition: a person who is trying to find or get the thing mentioned

examples.en: an attention/a publicity seeker
seekers after the truth
The new attraction is expected to draw pleasure seekers from across the region.

senses.definition: to give the impression of being or doing something

examples.en: You seem happy.
Do whatever seems best to you.
This may seem obvious to you.
It seems clear that there has been a mistake.
It seems likely that they will lose the election.
Strange as it may seem, exactly the same thing happened to me.
He seems a nice man.
She seems to be a smart woman.
You seem to be nervous.
People aren’t always what they seem to be.
It seemed like a good idea at the time.
It always seemed as though they would get married.
‘He'll be there, then?’ ‘So it seems (= people say so).’
It seems to me that teachers have to work pretty hard.
It must have seemed to him that he was safe.
It seems that they know what they're doing.
They seem to know what they're doing.

senses.definition: used to make what you say about your thoughts, feelings or actions less strong

examples.en: I seem to have left my book at home.
I can't seem to (= I've tried, but I can't) get started today.

senses.definition: used to suggest that something is true when you are not certain or when you want to be polite

examples.en: It would seem that we all agree.
This last point, it seems to me, is particularly important.
It seems only reasonable to ask students to buy a dictionary.

senses.definition: in a way that appears to be true but may in fact not be

examples.en: a seemingly stupid question
a seemingly endless journey
It was a seemingly impossible task.

senses.definition: according to what you have read or heard

examples.en: Seemingly, he borrowed the money from the bank.
They were seemingly having an affair.

senses.definition: a part of something that is separate from the other parts or can be considered separately

examples.en: She cleaned a small segment of the painting.
Lines divided the area into segments.
The changes will affect only a small segment of the population.
They divided the bone into equal segments.

senses.definition: one of the sections of an orange, a lemon, etc.
a part of a circle separated from the rest by a single line
the smallest speech sound that a word can be divided into
to divide something into different parts

examples.en: Market researchers often segment the population on the basis of age and social class.
The worm has a segmented body (= with different sections joined together).

senses.definition: to take somebody/something in your hand suddenly and using force

examples.en: She tried to seize the gun from him.
He seized her by the arm.
She seized hold of my hand.

senses.definition: to take control of a place or situation, often suddenly and violently

examples.en: They seized the airport in a surprise attack.
The army has seized control of the country.
He seized power in a military coup.

senses.definition: to arrest or capture somebody

examples.en: The men were seized as they left the building.
Terrorists have seized five hostages.

senses.definition: to take illegal or stolen goods away from somebody

examples.en: A large quantity of drugs was seized during the raid.
We have the legal right to seize his property.

senses.cf: seize a chance, an opportunity, the initiative, etc.
senses.definition: to be quick to make use of a chance, an opportunity, etc.

examples.en: The party seized the initiative with both hands (= quickly and with enthusiasm).
She promptly seized the opportunity his absence gave her.

senses.definition: to affect somebody suddenly and deeply

examples.en: Panic seized her.
He was seized by curiosity.

variants.text: (also seize up British and North American English)
variants.html: (also seize up British and North American English)

senses.definition: if a machine seizes, it no longer works because the parts are stuck and cannot move

variants.text: (also seize up British and North American English)
variants.html: (also seize up British and North American English)

senses.definition: if a part of your body seizes, you are unable to move it easily and it is often painful
not often

examples.en: He had seldom seen a child with so much talent.
She seldom, if ever, goes to the theatre.
They seldom watch television these days.
Seldom had he seen such beauty.

senses.definition: to choose somebody/something from a group of people or things, usually according to a system

examples.en: He hasn't been selected for the team.
All our hotels have been carefully selected for the excellent value they provide.
She was selected as the parliamentary candidate for Bath.
a randomly selected sample of 23 schools
selected poems of T.S. Eliot
This model is available at selected stores only.
She selected an apple from the fruit bowl.
It is important to select a software package that suits your requirements.
Six theatre companies have been selected to take part in this year's festival.
Select what you want from the options available.
They could select from a range of choices depending on their interests and skills.

senses.definition: to mark something on a computer screen; to choose something, especially from a menu

examples.en: Select the text you want to format by holding down the left button on your mouse.
Select ‘New Mail’ from the ‘Send’ menu.

senses.definition: carefully chosen as the best out of a larger group of people or things

examples.en: a select wine list
Only a select few (= a small number of people) have been invited to the wedding.
It was a very fashionable event with a select audience.

senses.definition: used by people who have a lot of money or a high social position

examples.en: They live in a very select area.
a select club

senses.definition: the process of choosing somebody/something from a group of people or things, usually according to a system

examples.en: She took a long time to make her selection.
The final team selection will be made tomorrow.
the random selection of numbers
selection criteria
the selection process
Artists are chosen by a selection committee.
Jury selection in the cases is due to begin next week.
her selection for the England squad
his unexpected selection as party leader

senses.definition: a number of people or things that have been chosen from a larger group

examples.en: A selection of readers' comments is published below.
The orchestra played selections from Hollywood musicals.

senses.definition: a collection of things from which something can be chosen

examples.en: The showroom has a wide selection of kitchens.
The wine selection isn't bad.

senses.definition: affecting or involving only a small number of people or things from a larger group

examples.en: the selective breeding of cattle
selective strike action
the socially selective nature of population changes

senses.definition: tending to be careful about what or who you choose

examples.en: You will have to be selective about which information to include in the report.

a selective school (= one that chooses which children to admit, especially according to ability)

senses.definition: the type of person you are, especially the way you normally behave, look or feel

examples.en: You'll soon be feeling your old self again (= feeling well or happy again).

his private/professional self (= how he behaves at home/work)

variants.html: (also the self [singular])

senses.definition: a person’s personality or character that makes them different from other people

examples.en: Many people living in institutions have lost their sense of self (= the feeling that they are individual people).
the inner self (= a person’s emotional and spiritual character)
a lack of confidence in the self

senses.definition: your own advantage or pleasure rather than that of other people

examples.en: She didn't do it for any reason of self.
Self, self, self! That’s all you ever think about!

senses.definition: used to refer to a person

examples.en: You didn't hurt your little self, did you?

I was very thirsty (note to self: bring water on walks!).

idioms.word: be a shadow/ghost of your former self

senses.definition: to not have the strength, influence, etc. that you used to have

examples.en: When his career ended, he became a shadow of his former self.

senses.definition: of, to or by yourself or itself

examples.en: self-control
self-addressed
self-taught

senses.definition: to give something to somebody in exchange for money

examples.en: I recently sold my bike.

The board agreed to sell the company.
The shares were sold in the open market.
We offered them a good price but they wouldn't sell.
The council is planning to sell the land to developers for housing.

examples.cf: sell something to somebody for something
examples.en: I sold my car to James for £800.
I sold James my car for £800.
They sold the business at a profit/loss (= they gained/lost money when they sold it).
They sold at a loss.
They never buy more than they can sell at a good price.

senses.definition: to offer something for people to buy

examples.en: Most supermarkets sell a range of organic products.
Do you sell stamps?
to sell insurance
His books are sold worldwide.
She decided to sell her work in order to support her family.
They began selling spectacles in 1783.
We sell these little notebooks at €1 each.

senses.definition: to be bought by people in the way or in the numbers mentioned; to be offered at the price mentioned

examples.en: The book sold well and was reprinted many times.

The magazine sells 300 000 copies a week.

The pens sell for just 50p each.

senses.definition: to make people want to buy something

examples.en: You may not like it but advertising sells.

senses.definition: to persuade somebody that something is a good idea, service, product, etc.; to persuade somebody that you are the right person for a job, position, etc.

examples.en: Now we have to try and sell the idea to management.

senses.definition: to accept money or a reward from somebody for doing something that is against your principles
to be very enthusiastic about something

examples.en: We were really sold on the idea.

senses.definition: to be bought quickly or in great numbers
to have sex with somebody in exchange for money
to give poor or unfair treatment to somebody you have promised to help
to sell a country's assets, such as land or property, to foreign owners

examples.en: The government is happy to keep selling off the farm.

senses.definition: to sell somebody something/to buy something that has no value or is worth much less than the price paid
to not value somebody/yourself highly enough and show this by the way you treat or present them/yourself
to do anything, even something really bad or dishonest, in return for money, success or power

senses.cf: a hard, tough, easy, etc. sell
senses.definition: something that is difficult/easy to persuade people to buy or accept

examples.en: This policy is going to be a tough sell to the public.

senses.definition: something that is not as good as it seemed to be

examples.en: The band only played for about half an hour—it was a real sell.

senses.definition: a class at a university or college when a small group of students and a teacher discuss or study a particular topic

examples.en: Teaching is by lectures and seminars.
a graduate seminar
a seminar room

senses.definition: a meeting for discussion or training

examples.en: a one-day management seminar

senses.definition: a member of a senate

examples.en: Senator McCarthy

senses.definition: to make something go or be taken to a place, especially by post, email, radio, etc.

examples.en: She sent a letter of support.
Let me just send this email.
to send something by post
to send something by mail
I sent the package by airmail.
Users were unable to send or receive emails for two days.
Have you sent a Christmas card to your mother yet?
A radio signal was sent to the spacecraft.
Have you sent your mother a Christmas card yet?
I'll send you a text message.
Can you send me a link to the website?

senses.definition: to tell somebody something by sending them a message

examples.en: My parents send their love.

He sent me word to come.
She sent word (that) she could not come.

senses.definition: to tell somebody to go somewhere or to do something; to arrange for somebody to go somewhere

examples.en: Ed couldn't make it so they sent me instead.
She sent the kids to bed early.
The judge sent her to prison for two years.

We are being sent on a training course next month.

I've sent Tom to buy some milk.

senses.definition: to make something/somebody move quickly or suddenly

examples.en: Every step he took sent the pain shooting up his leg.

senses.definition: to make somebody behave or react in a particular way

examples.en: Her music always sends me to sleep.

senses.definition: to tell somebody clearly or rudely to go away

examples.en: She tried to interfere but I sent her packing.

idioms.word: these things are sent to try us

senses.definition: used to say that you should accept an unpleasant situation or event because you cannot change it
high in rank or status; higher in rank or status than others

examples.en: a senior official/officer/manager/executive
a senior adviser/analyst/lecturer
a senior partner in a law firm
She is senior vice president of marketing.
senior figures in the Labour party
senior members of staff
a senior position
a senior post/job
I have ten years' experience at senior management level.
Junior nurses usually work alongside more senior nurses.
He is a former senior civil servant who now runs a campaign website.
He is senior to me.
The meeting should be chaired by the most senior person present.

senses.definition: for adults or people at a more advanced level

examples.en: to take part in senior competitions
his first game of senior football
He won the senior men's 400 metres.

senses.definition: for senior citizens (= older people, especially those who have retired from work)

examples.en: Get one third off rail fares with a senior railcard.
senior discounts/concessions

senses.definition: used after the name of a man who has the same name as his son, to make it clear who is being referred to

senses.dis_g: (of a school or part of a school)
senses.definition: for children over the age of 11 or 13
connected with the last year in high school or college

examples.en: the senior prom

senses.definition: a person who is older than somebody else

examples.en: She was ten years his senior.
My brother is my senior by two years.

variants.text: (also senior citizen British and North American English)
variants.html: (also senior citizen British and North American English)

senses.definition: an older person, especially somebody who has retired from work

examples.en: His company helps seniors maintain their independence

senses.definition: a person who is higher in rank or status

examples.en: She felt unappreciated both by her colleagues and her seniors.

senses.definition: adults or people who have reached an advanced level

examples.en: tennis coaching for juniors and seniors

senses.definition: a child at a senior school; an older child in a school
(in the US and some other countries) a student in the last year at a high school or college

examples.en: high school seniors

senses.definition: a feeling that you get when something affects your body

examples.en: a tingling/burning sensation
I had a sensation of falling, as if in a dream.

senses.definition: the ability to feel through your sense of touch

examples.en: She seemed to have lost all sensation in her arms.

senses.definition: a general feeling or impression that is difficult to explain; an experience or a memory

examples.en: He had the eerie sensation of being watched.
When I arrived, I had the sensation that she had been expecting me.

senses.definition: very great surprise, excitement, or interest among a lot of people; the person or the thing that causes this surprise

examples.en: News of his arrest caused a sensation.
The band became a sensation overnight.

senses.definition: an understanding about something; an ability to judge something

examples.en: One of the most important things in a partner is a sense of humour (= the ability to find things funny or make people laugh).
He has a very good sense of direction (= finds the way to a place easily).
She has lost all sense of direction in her life (= the idea of what she should do in her life).
Always try to keep a sense of proportion (= of the relative importance of different things).
a sense of rhythm/timing
a sense of fun/adventure
Readers gain a real sense of what life was like in the camp.
Alex doesn't have any dress sense (= does not know which clothes look attractive).

senses.definition: good understanding and judgement; knowledge of what is sensible or practical behaviour

examples.en: You should have the sense to take advice when it is offered.
There's no sense in (= it is not sensible) worrying about it now.
Can't you talk sense (= say something sensible)?
There's a lot of sense in what Mary says.

senses.definition: the meaning that a word or phrase has; a way of understanding something

examples.en: That word has three senses.
The word ‘love’ is used in different senses by different people.
Globalization in the broadest sense is nothing new.
The word ‘perspective’ is being used here in a technical sense.
He was a true friend, in every sense of the word (= in every possible way).
In a sense (= in one way) it doesn't matter any more.
In some senses (= in one or more ways) the criticisms were justified.
In no sense can the issue be said to be resolved.
I am using ‘cold’ in the sense of ‘unfriendly’.
I don't mean that the press ought to be free in the sense that no one ought to pay for it.
There is a sense in which we are all to blame for the tragedy.

senses.definition: one of the five powers (sight, hearing, smell, taste and touch) that your body uses to get information about the world around you

examples.en: the five senses
Dogs have a keen sense (= strong sense) of smell.
the sense organs (= eyes, ears, nose, etc.)
I could hardly believe the evidence of my own senses (= what I could see, hear, etc.).
The mixture of sights, smells and sounds around her made her senses reel.

senses.definition: a feeling about something important

examples.en: His career was guided by a strong sense of duty.
There is now a sense of urgency to fix the problem.
I have found a sense of purpose in the work I do here.
Most people in the country have a strong sense of national identity.
My parents instilled a strong sense of responsibility in me.
Clubs try to create a sense of community.
Helmets can give cyclists a false sense of security.
