I had the sense that he was worried about something.
I got the sense that she wasn't very pleased to see us.

senses.definition: a normal state of mind; the ability to think clearly

examples.en: If she threatens to leave, it should bring him to his senses.
I waited for them to come to their senses and return.
No one in their right senses would give him the job!
Are you out of your senses? You'll be killed!

senses.definition: to try and persuade somebody to stop behaving in a stupid way, sometimes using rough or violent methods

examples.en: Try and talk some sense into her before she makes the wrong decision.
Where would I be without you to knock some sense into my head?

senses.definition: to have a meaning that you can easily understand

examples.en: This sentence doesn't make sense.

senses.definition: to be a sensible thing to do

examples.en: It makes sense to buy the most up-to-date version.
There are strict medicals for pilots, which makes good sense.

senses.definition: to be easy to understand or explain

examples.en: John wasn't making much sense on the phone.
Who would send me all these flowers? It makes no sense.
It all made perfect sense to me.

senses.definition: to understand something that is difficult or has no clear meaning

examples.en: I can’t make sense of that painting.

senses.definition: to start to be sensible or reasonable

examples.en: I tried to make him see sense, but he just wouldn't listen.

senses.definition: a feeling or understanding that an event is important or special

examples.en: Candles on the table gave the evening a sense of occasion.

senses.definition: to start behaving in a crazy way
to become aware of something even though you cannot see it, hear it, etc.

examples.en: Sensing danger, they started to run.
I sensed a note of tension in his voice.
I could sense the presence of someone near me.
He sensed an opportunity to score a propaganda victory.
Lisa sensed that he did not believe her.
Thomas, she sensed, could convince anyone of anything.
He sensed someone moving around behind him.
He sensed something move in the bushes.
She could sense how nervous he was.

senses.definition: to discover and record something

examples.en: equipment that senses the presence of toxic gases

senses.definition: able to make good judgements based on reason and experience rather than emotion; practical

examples.en: She's a sensible sort of person.
I think that's a very sensible idea.
I think the sensible thing would be to take a taxi home.
Say something sensible.
a sensible approach/decision/solution/option
Diplomacy is the only sensible way to resolve this dispute.
This is an eminently sensible approach.
We have to be sensible about this.
We are just asking people to be sensible about the amount of water they use.

examples.cf: it is sensible to do something
examples.en: It is sensible to have contingency plans in place.

examples.cf: it is sensible for somebody to do something
examples.en: It would be sensible for the government to take precautionary measures.

senses.definition: useful rather than fashionable

examples.en: sensible shoes

senses.definition: aware of something

examples.en: I am sensible of the fact that mathematics is not a popular subject.

senses.definition: aware of and able to understand other people and their feelings

examples.en: a sensitive and caring man
She is very sensitive to other people's feelings.
Schools must be sensitive to the needs of students from different backgrounds.

senses.definition: reacting quickly or more than usual to something

examples.en: sensitive areas of the body
My teeth are very sensitive to cold food.
Young children are particularly sensitive to the harmful effects of pesticides.
The eyes of some fish are acutely sensitive to light.
I have become increasingly sensitive to the sun.
These drugs can make skin extremely sensitive to sunlight.
Coral reefs are very sensitive to changes in seawater temperature.

senses.definition: able to understand art, music and literature and to express yourself through them

examples.en: an actor’s sensitive reading of the poem
a sensitive portrait

senses.definition: easily offended or upset

examples.en: You're far too sensitive.
He's very sensitive about his weight.
She's very sensitive to criticism.

senses.definition: that you have to treat with great care because it may offend people or make them angry or embarrassed

examples.en: sensitive information/data
highly sensitive documents
Healthcare is a politically sensitive issue.
That's a sensitive area.
a sensitive subject/topic/matter

senses.definition: able to measure very small changes

examples.en: a sensitive instrument
The eyes can be a sensitive indicator of health.
The Stock Exchange is very sensitive to political change.

senses.definition: the ability to understand other people’s feelings

examples.en: sensitivity to the needs of children
She pointed out with tact and sensitivity exactly where he had gone wrong.

senses.definition: the ability to understand art, music and literature and to express yourself through them

examples.en: She played with great sensitivity.
He shows imaginative sensitivity in his review.

senses.definition: the fact of being easily offended or upset by something

examples.en: He's a mixture of anger and sensitivity.
She was blind to the feelings and sensitivities of other people.

senses.definition: the fact of needing to be treated very carefully because it may offend or upset people

examples.en: Confidentiality is important because of the sensitivity of the information.

senses.definition: the fact of reacting quickly or more than usual to something

examples.en: food sensitivity
allergies and sensitivities
Some children develop a sensitivity to cow's milk.
The eyes of some fish have a greater sensitivity to light than ours do.

senses.definition: the ability to measure very small changes

examples.en: the sensitivity of the test

senses.definition: a set of words expressing a statement, a question or an order, usually containing a subject and a verb. In written English sentences begin with a capital letter and end with a full stop/period (.), a question mark (?) or an exclamation mark (!).

examples.en: Does the sentence contain an adverb?
I was too stunned to finish my sentence.
There are mistakes in grammar, sentence structure and punctuation.
Let's take that paragraph apart sentence by sentence.

senses.definition: the punishment given by a court

examples.en: a jail/prison sentence
a custodial sentence
a harsh/stiff/heavy/lengthy sentence
a light/lenient sentence
The court will impose an appropriate sentence.
The judge passed sentence (= said what the punishment would be).
The prisoner has served (= completed) his sentence and will be released tomorrow.
a maximum/minimum sentence of five years
a mandatory sentence of life imprisonment
The charges carry a sentence of up to ten years.
She could face a sentence of between seven and ten years in jail.
He received an 18-year sentence for attempted murder.
to be under sentence of death
He spent a week in custody awaiting sentence.
He turned state's evidence in return for a reduced sentence.
She could face a long prison sentence.
The US Supreme Court recently upheld both of these sentences.
The judge imposed the mandatory sentence for murder.
The offence carries a maximum sentence of two years in prison.
an eight-year sentence for burglary
ex-felons who have completed their sentences

senses.definition: to say officially in court that somebody is to receive a particular punishment

examples.en: He sentenced the defendant to life in prison.
to be sentenced to death/life imprisonment
He was convicted and sentenced to a four-year jail term.
The judge sentenced him to hang.
The court sentenced him to serve nine months for the assault.
She was sentenced to do 30 hours of community service.
The same judge had previously sentenced him for burglary.

examples.cf: sentence somebody to something for something
examples.en: A court sentenced them to nine-year jail terms for fraud and tax evasion.
It was argued that judges should have discretion in sentencing first-time offenders.

senses.definition: a feeling or an opinion, especially one based on emotions

examples.en: the spread of nationalist sentiments
This is a sentiment I wholeheartedly agree with.
Public sentiment is against any change to the law.
My sentiments exactly! (= I agree)

senses.definition: feelings of sympathy, romantic love, being sad, etc. which may be too strong or not appropriate

examples.en: There was no fatherly affection, no display of sentiment.
There is no room for sentiment in business.
The new movie is to be applauded for refusing to drift into mawkish sentiment.

senses.definition: forming a unit by itself; not joined to something else

examples.en: They have begun to sleep in separate rooms.
Raw meat must be kept separate from cooked meat.
The school is housed in two separate buildings.
Write a list of names on a separate piece of paper.

senses.definition: different; not connected

examples.en: a separate incident/issue
The companies now exist as two separate entities.
I try to keep my private life separate from my work.
This is a completely separate matter.
It happened on three separate occasions.
Their ultimate political goal is the creation of a separate state.
For the past three years they have been leading totally separate lives.
The two groups are essentially separate and independent.
to merge the two previously separate businesses
species from widely separate parts of the world

senses.definition: to end a relationship with somebody

examples.en: When the business was sold they went their separate ways.
They decided to go their separate ways after being together for five years.
When we finished school, we all went our separate ways.

senses.definition: to go in a different direction from somebody you have been travelling with
in a separate envelope

examples.en: The information you requested is being forwarded to you under separate cover.

senses.definition: to divide into different parts or groups; to divide things into different parts or groups

examples.en: Stir the sauce constantly so that it does not separate.
Separate the eggs (= separate the yolk from the white).
A civil war separated the two sides.
It is impossible to separate belief from emotion.
the law separating church and state
Make a list of points and separate them into ‘desirable’ and ‘essential’.

senses.definition: to move apart; to make people or things move apart

examples.en: South America and Africa separated 200 million years ago.
They are actually twins separated at birth.
South America separated from Africa 200 million years ago.
We separated into several different search parties.
Police tried to separate the two men who were fighting.
The war separated many families.
Those suffering from infectious diseases were separated from the other patients.
Women and men are separated in Orthodox synagogues.
The children were separated into two groups.

senses.definition: to be between two people, areas, countries, etc. so that they are not touching or connected

examples.en: A thousand kilometres separates the two cities.
It is not uncommon for families to be separated by great distances.
A high wall separated our back yard from the playing field.
At this point a barbed wire fence separates the United States and Mexico.

senses.definition: to stop living together as a couple with your husband, wife or partner

examples.en: They separated last year.
He separated from his wife after 20 years of marriage.

senses.definition: to make somebody/something different in some way from somebody/something else

examples.en: Politics is the only thing that separates us (= that we disagree about).
Her lack of religious faith separated her from the rest of her family.
The judges found it impossible to separate the two contestants (= they gave them equal scores).
Only four points separate the top three teams.

idioms.word: separate/sort out the men from the boys

senses.definition: to show or prove who is brave, skilful, etc. and who is not

idioms.word: sort out/separate the sheep from the goats

senses.definition: to recognize the difference between people who are good at something, intelligent, etc. and those who are not

idioms.word: sort out/separate the wheat from the chaff

senses.definition: to recognize the difference between useful or valuable people or things and those that are not useful or have no value

examples.en: We sifted through the application forms to separate the wheat from the chaff.

senses.definition: the act of separating people or things; the state of being separate

examples.en: the state’s eventual separation from the federation
the need for a clear separation between Church and State

senses.definition: a period of time that people spend apart from each other

examples.en: They were reunited after a separation of more than 20 years.
Prolonged separations of this kind are damaging to very young children.
She is visiting her family after a long separation.

senses.definition: a decision that a husband and wife make to live apart while they are still legally married

examples.en: a legal separation
The couple are having a trial separation.
Sixty per cent of all marital separations occur before the tenth year of marriage.

senses.definition: the 9th month of the year, between August and October

examples.en: She was born in September.
The meeting is on the fifth of September/September the fifth.
The meeting is on September fifth.
We went to Japan last September.
I arrived at the end of September.
last September's election
the September issue of the magazine

senses.definition: a set of events, actions, numbers, etc. which have a particular order and which lead to a particular result

examples.en: He described the sequence of events leading up to the robbery.
The computer generates a random sequence of numbers.
Her latest book contains a sequence of poems about paintings.

senses.definition: the order that events, actions, etc. happen in or should happen in

examples.en: The tasks had to be performed in a particular sequence.
The interviewer should ask questions in a logical sequence.
Number the pages in sequence.
These pages are out of sequence.

senses.definition: a part of a film that deals with one subject or topic or consists of one scene

examples.en: the dream sequence in the middle of the movie

senses.definition: to arrange things into a sequence
to identify the order in which a set of genes or parts of molecules are arranged

examples.en: The human genome has now been sequenced.

senses.definition: doing the same thing in the same way several times; done in the same way several times

examples.en: a serial rapist
He is wanted for serial murder.
Such people can be described as serial monogamists.

senses.definition: broadcast or published in several separate parts

examples.en: a novel in serial form
The BBC has taken each installment of Charles Dickens' serial novel ‘Bleak House’ and created 15 half-hour episodes.

senses.definition: arranged in a series

examples.en: tasks carried out in the same serial order

senses.definition: a story that is broadcast or published in several separate parts on television, on the radio, on the internet, in a magazine, etc.

examples.en: a classic drama serial
a new six-part drama serial

senses.definition: a set of television or radio programmes or podcasts that deal with the same subject or that have the same characters

examples.en: The first episode of the new series is on Saturday.
Her stories have been made into a TV series.
She has a small part in a drama series for radio.
the hit comedy series ‘The Big Bang Theory’

senses.definition: several events or things of a similar kind that happen one after the other

examples.en: The incident sparked off a series of events that nobody had foreseen.
This case raises a whole series of important questions.
The two sides held a series of meetings in the summer.
The movie consisted of a series of flashbacks.
This is the latest in a series of articles on the nature of modern society.

senses.definition: a set of sports games played between the same two teams

examples.en: the World Series (= in baseball)
England have lost the Test series (= of cricket matches) against India.

senses.definition: an electrical circuit in which the current passes through all the parts in the correct order

examples.en: batteries connected in series
a series circuit

senses.definition: bad or dangerous

examples.en: a serious illness/offence/crime
a serious problem/issue
to cause serious injury/damage/harm
They pose a serious threat to security.
The consequences could be serious.
A few years ago, the company was in serious trouble.
Their economies continue to face serious challenges.
She is in serious financial trouble.
She is now in a serious condition in Belfast Hospital.
This situation could be very serious for her.

senses.definition: thinking about things in a careful and sensible way; not silly

examples.en: Be serious for a moment; this is important.
I'm afraid I'm not a very serious person.

senses.definition: sincere about something; not joking or meant as a joke

examples.en: Believe me, I'm deadly (= extremely) serious.
Don't laugh, it's a serious suggestion.
Is she serious about wanting to sell the house?
He knew it was time to get serious about losing weight.
He's really serious about Penny and wants to get engaged.
She doesn’t have a serious boyfriend.
You can't be serious! (= you must be joking)
You think I did it? Be serious! (= what you suggest is ridiculous)

senses.definition: needing to be thought about carefully; not only for pleasure

examples.en: a serious article
a serious newspaper
an appreciation of serious music
serious drama/fiction

senses.definition: that must be treated as important

examples.en: a serious matter
serious questions/concerns/doubts
serious allegations/charges
It's time to give serious consideration to this matter.
Please give it some serious thought before you make a decision.
The subject has received little serious attention.
We need to get down to the serious business of working out costs.
The team is a serious contender for the title this year.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that there is a large amount of something

examples.en: You can earn serious money doing that.
I'm ready to do some serious eating (= I am very hungry).

senses.definition: in a serious way

examples.en: to be seriously ill/injured/wounded/hurt
Smoking can seriously damage your health.
Migraines can seriously affect your quality of life.
You're not seriously expecting me to believe that?
They are seriously concerned about security.
You need to think seriously about your next career move.
He is seriously considering opening a second restaurant.
There is something seriously wrong with the whole system.

senses.definition: used at the beginning of a sentence to show a change from joking to being more serious

examples.en: Seriously though, it could be really dangerous.

senses.definition: very; extremely

examples.en: They're seriously rich.

senses.definition: to think that somebody/something is important and deserves your attention and respect

examples.en: We take threats of this kind very seriously.
Why can't you ever take anything seriously?
Headaches in young children should always be taken seriously.
You can’t take anything she says very seriously.
They're no help at all—they're refusing to take the problem seriously.

senses.definition: a person who works in another person’s house, and cooks, cleans, etc. for them

examples.en: a domestic servant
a faithful/devoted/trusted servant
They treat their mother like a servant.
She was working as a servant to the Smith family.
one of the servants of the king of Persia

senses.definition: a person who works for a company or an organization

examples.en: Mr Bennet said his client was a loyal servant to the council.

senses.definition: a person or thing that is controlled by something

examples.en: He was willing to make himself a servant of his art.

senses.definition: used to end a formal letter
to give somebody food or drink, for example at a restaurant or during a meal

examples.en: Breakfast is served between 7 and 10 a.m.
When do you stop serving hot food?
Pour the sauce over the pasta and serve immediately.
Shall I serve?
Serve the lamb with new potatoes and green beans.
They served a wonderful meal to more than fifty delegates.
The delegates were served with a wonderful meal.
She served us a delicious lunch.
The quiche can be served hot or cold.

senses.definition: to be enough for somebody/something

examples.en: This dish will serve four hungry people.

senses.definition: to help a customer or sell them something in a shop

examples.en: Are you being served?
The bar staff spend more time chatting to friends than serving customers.
She was serving behind the counter.

senses.definition: to be useful to somebody in achieving or satisfying something

examples.en: These experiments serve no useful purpose.
Most of their economic policies serve the interests of big business.
How can we best serve the needs of future generations?
Art serves an important function in our society.
His linguistic ability served him well in his chosen profession.
This old car has served me very well.
The story would be better served by slowing down a little.

senses.definition: to provide an area or a group of people with a product or service

examples.en: The centre will serve the whole community.
The town is well served with buses and major road links.

senses.definition: to work or perform duties for a person, an organization, a country, etc.; to spend a period of time in a particular job

examples.en: He served as a captain in the army.
She was elected to serve as secretary of the local party.
to serve as president/director/chairman
He served in the White House under Joe Biden.
She served in the medical corps.
His father served with distinction in the First World War.
He proudly served his country during the war.
I wanted to work somewhere where I could serve the community.
She has already served two terms as mayor.
He served a one-year apprenticeship.
He served the family faithfully for many years (= as a servant).

senses.definition: to be suitable for a particular use, especially when nothing else is available

examples.en: The sofa will serve as a bed for a night or two.

senses.definition: to have a particular effect or result

examples.en: The judge said the punishment would serve as a warning to others.
The highly visible ruins serve as a reminder of the building's history.
There are several women in the field who have served as role models.
The attack was unsuccessful and served only to alert the enemy.
This only served to complicate the situation further.

senses.definition: to spend a period of time in prison

examples.en: prisoners serving life sentences
She is serving two years for theft.
He has served time (= been to prison) before.

senses.definition: to give or send somebody an official document, especially one that orders them to appear in court

examples.en: to serve a writ/summons on somebody
to serve somebody with a writ/summons

senses.definition: to start playing by throwing the ball into the air and hitting it

examples.en: Who's serving?
She served an ace.

senses.definition: to perform two roles or functions at the same time

examples.en: This device can pull double duty as a decent laptop and an adequate tablet.
She deserves credit for serving double duty as a host and performer.

senses.definition: people will be dealt with, seen, etc. strictly in the order in which they arrive

examples.en: Tickets are available on a first come, first served basis.

idioms.word: if (my) memory serves me well, correctly, etc.

senses.definition: if I remember correctly

idioms.word: it serves somebody right (for doing something)

senses.definition: used to say that something that has happened to somebody is their own fault and they deserve it

examples.en: Left you, did she? It serves you right for being so selfish.

senses.definition: to be useful for a particular purpose or period of time
to support two different parties, principles, etc. at the same time
the action of serving the ball to your opponent

examples.en: He has not lost his serve (= lost a game in which it was his turn to serve) in three matches.

senses.definition: a system that provides something that the public needs, organized by the government or a private company

examples.en: the ambulance/bus/postal service
The government aims to improve public services, especially education.
Essential services (= the supply of water, gas, electricity) will be maintained.
Councillors have called for better provision of services for young people.
The charity provides a vital service to the local community.

senses.definition: an organization or a company that provides something for the public or does something for the government

examples.en: the prison service
the BBC World Service
the Foreign Service

senses.definition: a business whose work involves doing something for customers but not producing goods; the work that such a business does

examples.en: financial services
the development of new goods and services
Smith's Catering Services (= a company) offers the best value.
We guarantee (an) excellent service.
We aim to provide a high-quality service.
They offer an after-care service.
Training the staff required to deliver the service remains a challenge.
We are working hard to improve the services that we provide.
The number of people using the service has fallen.
I am not willing to pay for a service I am not receiving.
We offer clients a broad range of services.
the service sector (= the part of the economy involved in this type of business)
a service industry

senses.definition: the serving of customers in hotels, restaurants, and shops

examples.en: The food was good but the service was very slow.
I complained about the poor service.
10% will be added to your bill for service.

senses.definition: the work that somebody does for an organization, etc., especially when it continues for a long time or is admired very much

examples.en: She has just celebrated 25 years' service with the company.
He has retired after 30 years of dedicated service to the local community.
She was presented with a long-service award after 40 years with the firm.
The employees have good conditions of service.
After retiring, she became involved in voluntary service in the local community.

senses.definition: the army, the navy and the air force; the work done by people in them

examples.en: Most of the boys went straight into the services.
He saw service in North Africa.
After service in the US Army, he began his legal career.
the country's military intelligence services
a service family

senses.definition: the use that you can get from a vehicle or machine; the state of being used

examples.en: That computer gave us very good service.
This bus is not in service.
The ship will be taken out of service within two years.

senses.definition: an examination of a vehicle or machine followed by any work that is necessary to keep it operating well

examples.en: a service engineer
I had taken the car in for a service.
I had taken the car in for service.

senses.definition: the particular skills or help that a person is able to offer

examples.en: You need the services of a good lawyer.
He offered his services as a driver.

senses.definition: a religious ceremony

examples.en: a funeral/memorial service
A memorial service will be held at St James's Church on Sunday.
More than 100 people attended the service.
to go to morning/evening service

senses.definition: a bus, train, etc. that goes regularly to a particular place at a particular time

examples.en: the cancellation of the 10.15 service to Glasgow

senses.definition: a place next to a motorway where you can stop for petrol, a meal, the toilets, etc.

examples.en: motorway services
It's five miles to the next services.
The next services is/are five miles away.

senses.definition: an act of hitting the ball in order to start playing; the way that you hit it

examples.en: It's your service (= your turn to start playing).
Her service has improved.

senses.definition: a complete set of plates, dishes, etc. that match each other

examples.en: a tea service (= cups, saucers, a teapot and plates, for serving tea)

senses.definition: the state or position of being a servant

examples.en: to be in/go into service (= to be/become a servant)
a job in domestic service

senses.definition: the formal giving of an official document, etc. to somebody

examples.en: the service of a demand for payment

idioms.word: at the service of somebody/something | at somebody’s service

senses.definition: completely available for somebody to use or to help somebody

examples.en: Healthcare must be at the service of all who need it.
If you need anything, I am at your service.
The cabin staff are at your service throughout the flight.

senses.definition: to be useful or helpful

examples.en: Can I be of service to anyone?

senses.definition: to do something that is helpful/not helpful to somebody

examples.en: She was doing herself no service by remaining silent.
You have done us a great service.

senses.definition: to use somebody/something for a purpose that they were not trained or intended for because there is nobody or nothing else available

examples.en: Every type of boat was pressed into service to rescue passengers from the sinking ferry.

senses.definition: to examine a vehicle or machine and repair it if necessary so that it continues to work correctly

examples.en: We need to have the car serviced.
Make sure your boiler is serviced regularly.

senses.definition: to provide people with something they need, such as shops, or a transport system

examples.en: Botley is well serviced by a regular bus route into Oxford.
This department services the international sales force (= provides services for it).

senses.definition: to pay interest on money that has been borrowed

examples.en: The company can no longer service its debts.

senses.definition: a period of time that is spent doing a particular activity

examples.en: a training/practice session
a therapy/counselling/group session
a morning/afternoon session
a recording/jam session
The course is made up of 12 two-hour sessions.
The club held football coaching sessions for children in the area.
Participants will have the opportunity to attend sessions on a wide variety of topics.
The literacy programme includes sessions on encouraging children to read.
Two soccer fans plunged to their deaths after a heavy drinking session.

senses.definition: a formal meeting or series of meetings of a court, a parliament, etc.; a period of time when such meetings are held

examples.en: a session of the UN General Assembly
The president addressed a joint session of Congress (= both the Senate and the House of Representatives).
a plenary session of the European Parliament
a special session of the US Supreme Court
In the last legislative session, the two parties came close to agreement.
The court is now in session.
The committee met in closed session (= with nobody else present).
an emergency session of Congress
the current parliamentary session
We still have a number of weeks before the current legislative session ends.

senses.definition: a school or university year
an occasion when people meet to play music, especially Irish music, in a pub
to prepare or arrange something so that it is ready for use or in position

examples.en: Have you set the alarm clock?
She set the camera on automatic.
I set my watch by (= make it show the same time as) the TV.
Set the alarm for 7 o'clock.

senses.definition: to arrange knives, forks, etc. on a table for a meal

examples.en: Can you help me set the table?
Could you set the table for dinner?
The table was set for six guests.

senses.definition: to fix something so that others copy it or try to achieve it

examples.en: This could set a new fashion.
They set high standards of customer service.
I am unwilling to set a precedent.
She set a new world record for the high jump.
I rely on you to set a good example.
The opening scene sets the tone for the rest of the movie.

senses.definition: to give somebody a piece of work to do or a task or target to achieve

examples.en: Who will be setting (= writing the questions for) the French exam?
The government has set a growth target of 6%.
What books have been set (= are to be studied) for the English course?
She's set a difficult task for herself.
He likes to set challenging goals for himself.
She's set herself a difficult task.
I've set myself to finish the job by the end of the month.

senses.definition: to arrange or fix something; to decide on something

examples.en: They haven't set a date for their wedding yet.
The government has set strict limits on public spending this year.
We can't just let the global corporations set the agenda (= decide what is important) every time.
Set a time limit for your studying each night.
Individual countries don't really set the price of oil.

senses.definition: to place the action of a play, novel or film in a particular place, time, etc.

examples.en: The novel is set in London in the 1960s.
The movie is set in Los Angeles in the year 2050.
This powerful drama is set against the backdrop of the Civil War.

senses.definition: to be located in a particular place

examples.en: The house is set in fifty acres of parkland.

senses.definition: to put something/somebody in a particular place or position

examples.en: She set a tray down on the table.
They ate everything that was set in front of them.
When she fell he picked her up and set her on her feet again.

senses.definition: to cause somebody/something to be in a particular state; to start something happening

examples.en: Her manner immediately set everyone at their ease.
He pulled the lever and set the machine in motion.
The new leader has set the party on the road to success.
Demonstrators set two cars on fire.
Demonstrators set fire to two cars.
The hijackers set the hostages free.
Her remarks set me thinking.

senses.definition: to go down below the horizon

examples.en: We sat and watched the sun setting.

senses.definition: to put a precious stone into a piece of jewellery

examples.en: She had the sapphire set in a gold ring.
Her bracelet was set with emeralds.

senses.definition: to become solid or hard

examples.en: Leave the concrete to set for a few hours.
The glue had set hard.

senses.definition: to fix your face into a determined expression

examples.en: Her jaw was set in a determined manner.

senses.definition: to arrange somebody’s hair while it is wet so that it dries in a particular style

examples.en: She had her hair washed and set.

senses.definition: to put a broken bone into a fixed position and hold it there, so that it will join together again and get better; to get better in this way

examples.en: The surgeon set her broken arm.

senses.definition: to use a machine or computer to arrange writing and images on pages in order to prepare a book, newspaper, etc. for printing
to write music to go with words

examples.en: Schubert set many poems to music.

senses.definition: a group of similar things that belong together in some way

examples.en: a set of six chairs
a complete set of her novels
a set of false teeth
These companies operate under a strict set of rules.
This is an unusual set of circumstances.
I have a different set of values to them.
Now they faced a whole new set of problems.
You can borrow my keys—I have a spare set.
She won a silver medal in the long jump to complete her set.

senses.definition: a group of objects used together, for example for playing a game

examples.en: a chess set
a model train set

senses.definition: a group of people who have similar interests and spend a lot of time together socially

examples.en: the smart set (= rich, fashionable people)
Dublin’s literary set
It's known as a playground for Scotland's rich hunting and fishing set.
Her social set loves/love to party.

senses.definition: a piece of equipment for receiving television or radio signals

examples.en: a television/TV set

senses.definition: the scenery used for a play, film, etc.

examples.en: We need volunteers to help build and paint the set.
The locations and set designs were fabulous.

senses.definition: a place where a play is performed or part of a film is filmed

examples.en: The cast must all be on (the) set by 7 in the morning.

senses.definition: one section of a match in games such as tennis or volleyball

examples.en: She won in straight sets (= without losing a set).

senses.definition: a group of things regarded as a unit because they all have particular qualities in common

examples.en: the set of all square numbers less than 50

senses.definition: a series of songs or pieces of music that a musician or group performs at a concert

examples.en: a stunning solo set of ten songs

senses.definition: a group of school students with a similar ability in a particular subject

examples.en: She's in the top set for French.

senses.definition: the way in which somebody’s face or body is fixed in a particular expression, especially one showing a feeling of being determined

examples.en: She admired the firm set of his jaw.

senses.definition: an act of arranging hair in a particular style while it is wet

examples.en: A shampoo and set costs £15.

senses.definition: the state of becoming solid or hard

examples.en: To be sure of a good set when making the jam, use preserving sugar with added pectin.

senses.definition: a hole in the ground where a badger lives
a young plant, shoot etc. for planting

examples.en: onion sets

senses.definition: in a particular position

examples.en: a house set in 40 acres of parkland
He had close-set eyes.

senses.definition: planned or fixed

examples.en: Each person was given set jobs to do.
The school funds a set number of free places.
Mornings in our house always follow a set pattern.
New vehicles must comply with set safety standards.

senses.definition: not likely to change

examples.en: set ideas/opinions/views on how to teach
As people get older, they get set in their ways.
He had very set ideas of what he wanted.

senses.definition: having a fixed price and a limited choice of dishes

examples.en: a set dinner/lunch/meal
Shall we have the set menu?

senses.definition: likely to do something; ready for something or to do something

examples.en: The team looks set for victory.
Interest rates look set to rise again.
Be set to leave by 10 o'clock.
Get set… Go!

senses.definition: fixed; not natural

examples.en: a set smile
His face took on a set expression.

idioms.word: be (dead) set against something/against doing something

senses.definition: to be strongly opposed to something

examples.en: Why are you so dead set against the idea?
Her parents are dead set against the marriage.

idioms.word: be set on something/on doing something

senses.definition: to want to do or have something very much; to be determined to do something

examples.en: She’s set on a career in medicine.
He’s set on getting a new car

idioms.word: on your marks, get set, go!

senses.definition: used to tell runners in a race to get ready and then to start

variants.html: (also ready, steady, go! British English)

senses.definition: what you say to tell people to start a race
an environment where something is located; the place at which something happens

examples.en: a rural/an ideal/a beautiful/an idyllic setting
It was the perfect setting for a wonderful Christmas.
The exhibition shows how bees can live happily in an urban setting.
This is the first time the method has been tested in a clinical setting.
Infections acquired in health-care settings are of increasing concern.
People tend to behave differently in different social settings.

senses.definition: the place and time at which the action of a play, novel, etc. takes place

examples.en: short stories with a contemporary setting
New York City is the setting of his new novel.
London has been used as the setting for many films.
The Scottish Highlands provide the settings for many of his stories.

senses.definition: a position at which the controls on a machine can be set, to set the speed, height, temperature, etc.

examples.en: There are three speed settings: high, medium, and low.
The performance of the engine was tested at different settings.
The oven should be at a high setting.
He keeps the car's speakers on a low volume setting.
In very hot weather it may be necessary to adjust the temperature setting on your fridge.

variants.html: (usually settings [plural])

senses.definition: the place on a computer or other electronic device where you can choose the way that it works or looks; the particular choices that you make

examples.en: To change the size of the font, go to Settings.
It's easy to change the settings on your device.
All tests were run at default settings.

senses.definition: music written to go with a poem, etc.

examples.en: Schubert’s setting of a poem by Goethe

senses.definition: a piece of metal in which a precious stone is fixed to form a piece of jewellery

examples.en: a ruby in a heavy gold setting

senses.definition: a complete set of equipment for eating with (knife, fork, spoon, glass, etc.) for one person, arranged on a table

examples.en: a place setting

senses.definition: to put an end to an argument or a disagreement

examples.en: to settle a dispute/a matter/an issue
to settle a case/lawsuit/claim
to settle an argument/a disagreement
It's time you settled your differences with your father.
I want this thing settled.
There is pressure on the unions to settle.
The company has agreed to settle out of court (= come to an agreement without going to court).
Many cases are settled through negotiation.
The corporation later settled with the singer for $1.5 million.

senses.definition: to decide or arrange something finally

examples.en: It's all settled—we're leaving on the nine o'clock plane.
Good, that's settled, then.
Bob will be there? That settles it. I'm not coming.
He had to settle his affairs (= arrange all his personal business) in Paris before he could return home.
It's been settled that we leave on the nine o'clock plane.
All the loose ends should be settled within 48 hours.

senses.definition: to make a place your permanent home

examples.en: She settled in Vienna after her father's death.
She is an American who settled here a couple of years ago.
The couple afterwards settled near Bournemouth.
He has now settled permanently in London.
He married and settled in a seaside cottage.
His parents eventually settled in Paris.

senses.definition: to make your permanent home in a country or an area as colonists

examples.en: This region was settled by the Dutch in the nineteenth century.
a fertile area that was densely settled in early times
They settled on undeveloped land along the Mississippi.
It was the worst drought since the British settled in Australia in 1788.
Very few Maori were living in the area when the first Europeans settled there.

senses.definition: to make yourself or somebody else comfortable in a new position

examples.en: Ellie settled back in her seat.
They prepared to settle in for the night (= make themselves comfortable for an evening at home).
He settled himself comfortably in his usual chair.
I settled her on the sofa and put a blanket over her.

senses.definition: to put something carefully in a position so that it does not move

examples.en: She settled the blanket around her knees.

senses.definition: to become or make somebody/something become calm or relaxed

examples.en: The baby wouldn't settle.
I took a pill to help settle my nerves.
This should settle your stomach.

senses.definition: to fall from above and come to rest on something; to stay for some time on something

examples.en: Dust had settled on everything.
Two birds settled on the fence.
I don't think the snow will settle (= remain on the ground without melting).
His gaze settled on her face.
Slowly dusk began to settle.

senses.definition: to sink slowly down; to make something do this

examples.en: The contents of the package may have settled in transit.
Don't drink it yet. Let the grounds settle.

senses.definition: to pay the money that you owe

examples.en: Please settle your bill before leaving the hotel.
The insurance company is refusing to settle her claim.
They used the last of the money to settle their debts.
Let me settle with you for the meal.
I'll pay now—we can settle up later.

idioms.word: let the dust settle | wait for the dust to settle

senses.definition: to wait for a situation to become clear or certain

examples.en: He waited for the dust to settle after the election before making any new decisions.

idioms.word: settle a score/accounts (with somebody) | settle an old score

senses.definition: to hurt or punish somebody who has harmed or cheated you in the past

examples.en: ‘Who would do such a thing?’ ‘Maybe someone with an old score to settle.’
An embittered Charlotte is determined to settle accounts with Elizabeth.

senses.definition: an old-fashioned piece of furniture with a long wooden seat and a high back and arms, often also with a box for storing things under the seat
an official agreement that ends an argument between two people or groups

examples.en: to negotiate a peace settlement
The management and unions have reached a settlement over new working conditions.
an out-of-court settlement (= money that is paid to somebody or an agreement that is made to stop somebody going to court)

senses.definition: the action of reaching an agreement

examples.en: the settlement of a dispute

senses.definition: the conditions, or a document stating the conditions, on which money or property is given to somebody

examples.en: a divorce/marriage/property settlement

senses.definition: the action of paying back money that you owe

examples.en: the settlement of a debt
Settlement is made monthly by direct debit.
She had to pay over $5 000 in settlement of her debts.

senses.definition: a place where people have come to live and make their homes, especially where few or no people lived before

examples.en: signs of an Iron Age settlement
a mining settlement

senses.definition: the process of people making their homes in a place

examples.en: the settlement of the American West
early settlement patterns in South America

senses.definition: a person who goes to live in a new country or region

examples.en: Most of the settlers came from England.
There are seven cookies left.
seven of Sweden’s top financial experts
Ten people were invited but only seven turned up.
Can you lend me seven dollars?
a seven-month contract
Look at page seven.
Seven and two is nine.
Two sevens are fourteen.
I can't read your writing—is this meant to be a seven?
The bulbs are planted in fives or sevens (= groups of five or seven).
We moved to America when I was seven (= seven years old).
Shall we meet at seven (= at seven o'clock), then?

senses.definition: in a confused state; not well organized

examples.en: I haven't had time to clear up, so I'm all at sixes and sevens.

senses.definition: the desire for new sexual experience that is thought to be felt after seven years of marriage
numbers, years or temperatures from 70 to 79
between the ages of 70 and 79
more than two but not very many

examples.en: Several letters arrived this morning.
He's written several books about India.
Several more people than usual came to the meeting.
If you're looking for a photo of Alice you'll find several in here.
Several of the paintings were destroyed in the fire.

senses.definition: separate

examples.en: They said goodbye and went their several ways.

senses.definition: extremely bad or serious

examples.en: His injuries are severe.
severe pain/depression/asthma
a severe illness/disease
severe weather/storms
a severe winter (= one during which the weather conditions are extremely bad)
The fire has caused severe damage to the building.
The victim suffered severe brain damage.
a severe shortage of qualified staff
The party suffered severe losses during the last election.
severe symptoms
a severe case of woodworm
Strikes are causing severe disruption to all train services.
If the pain becomes severe, you may wish to contact a doctor.

senses.definition: punishing somebody in an extreme way when they break a particular set of rules

examples.en: a severe punishment/sentence/penalty
The courts are becoming more severe on young offenders.
Her parents were never so severe with her older brother.

senses.definition: not kind or showing sympathy; not smiling or showing approval

examples.en: a severe expression
He fixed them with a very severe look.
She was a severe woman who seldom smiled.

senses.definition: extremely difficult and requiring a lot of skill or ability

examples.en: The marathon is a severe test of stamina.

senses.definition: extremely plain and without any decoration

examples.en: Modern furniture is a little too severe for my taste.
Her hair was short and severe.
He was wearing a severe dark grey jacket.

senses.definition: very badly or seriously

examples.en: severely injured
areas severely affected by unemployment
The crops were severely damaged.

senses.definition: in an extreme or strict way

examples.en: Anyone breaking the law will be severely punished.
a severely critical report
Access to this information is severely restricted.

senses.definition: in a way that is not kind and does not show sympathy or approval

examples.en: He looked severely at me.

senses.definition: in a way that is extremely difficult and requires a lot of skill or ability

examples.en: Her patience was being severely tested.

senses.definition: in an extremely plain style that lacks any decoration

examples.en: Her hair was tied severely in a bun.

senses.definition: the state of being male or female

examples.en: How can you tell what sex a fish is?
a process that enables couples to know the sex of their baby
We determined the sex of the birds from their DNA.
Please indicate your sex and date of birth below.
Levels of infection vary dramatically according to age and sex.
discrimination on grounds of race or sex
sex discrimination (= the act of treating men and women differently in an unfair way)
Testosterone is the male sex hormone.
In some areas the male : female sex ratio has reached 130 : 100.
Trying to prove that sex differences in behaviour are innate is controversial.

senses.definition: either of the two groups that people, animals, and plants are divided into according to their function of producing young

examples.en: a member of the opposite sex
people of the same sex
single-sex schools
differences between the sexes
Exam results for both sexes have continued to improve.
Gibson was the first African American of either sex to play at Wimbledon.
the battle of the sexes (= the competitive relationship that exists between men and women)

senses.definition: physical activity between two people in which they touch each other’s sexual organs, and which may include sexual intercourse

examples.en: He had sex with someone he met in a bar.
gay sex
the sex act
a footballer involved in a sex scandal
victims of sex abuse
sex education in schools
a controversial film containing explicit sex scenes
a sex shop (= one selling magazines, objects, etc. that are connected with sex)
These drugs may affect your sex drive (= your interest in sex and the ability to have it).
Amid such poverty, the sex trade has flourished.
The slogan for the hippie generation of the 1960s was sex, drugs and rock and roll.

senses.definition: having the amount of sexual activity or desire mentioned

examples.en: a highly-sexed person

senses.definition: to examine an animal in order to find out whether it is male or female
connected with the physical activity of sex

examples.en: sexual behaviour/activity/desire
sexual acts/offences
sexual abuse/assault/violence
They were not having a sexual relationship at the time.
He denied having had sexual relations with her.
She engaged frequently in casual sexual encounters.
The drop-in centres will provide a range of advice and support on sexual health.
Her interest in him is purely sexual.
sexual orientation/identity (= whether you are heterosexual, gay, bisexual, etc.)
a sexual partner (= a person who you have sex with)
He has not threatened them, or made overtly sexual remarks.

senses.definition: connected with the process of producing young

examples.en: the sexual organs (= the penis, vagina, etc.)
sexual reproduction

senses.definition: connected with the state of being male or female

examples.en: sexual characteristics
sexual discrimination

senses.definition: the feelings and activities connected with a person’s sexual desires

examples.en: He was confused about his sexuality.
male/female sexuality
the psychology of human sexuality
Her overt sexuality shocked cinema audiences.
Victorian women were rarely allowed to express their sexuality.

senses.definition: sexually attractive

examples.en: the sexy lead singer
She looked incredibly sexy in a black evening gown.

senses.definition: sexually exciting

examples.en: sexy underwear
a sexy look
a sexy video

senses.definition: sexually excited

examples.en: The music was making him feel sexy.

senses.definition: exciting and interesting

examples.en: a sexy new range of software
Accountancy just isn't sexy.

senses.definition: an area that is dark and cool under or behind something, for example a tree or building, because the sun’s light does not get to it

examples.en: The shade of the pine tree provided some protection from the sun.
The temperature can reach 40°C in the shade.
We sat down in the shade of the wall.
These plants grow well in sun or shade.
Two cows were sleeping under the shade of some trees.
The trees provide shade for the animals in the summer.

senses.definition: a thing that you use to prevent light from coming through or to make it less bright

examples.en: I bought a new shade for the lamp.
an eyeshade

senses.definition: material that covers a window, often consisting of a roll of cloth that is fixed at the top of the window and can be pulled up and down
a particular form of a colour, that is, how dark or light it is

examples.en: a dark/light/pale/bright shade of blue
a subtle/delicate shade of grey
His face turned an even deeper shade of red.
Cool pastel shades are just right for summer.

senses.definition: the dark areas in a picture, especially the use of these to produce variety

examples.en: The painting needs more light and shade.

senses.definition: a different kind or level of opinion, feeling, etc.

examples.en: politicians of all shades of opinion
The word has many shades of meaning.
reformers of all political shades

senses.definition: a little; slightly

examples.en: He was feeling a shade disappointed.
The skirt was a shade too long for me.

senses.definition: sunglasses (= a pair of glasses with dark glass in them that you wear to protect your eyes from bright light from the sun)
the spirit of a dead person; a ghost
to be much better or more impressive than somebody/something

examples.en: I tried hard but her work put mine in the shade.

senses.definition: used when you are referring to things that remind you of a particular person, thing or time

examples.en: short skirts and long boots—shades of the 1960s

senses.definition: to prevent direct light from reaching something

examples.en: The courtyard was shaded by high trees.
She shaded her eyes against the sun.

senses.definition: to provide a screen for a lamp, light, etc. to make it less bright

examples.en: a shaded lamp

senses.definition: to make a part of a drawing, etc. darker, for example with an area of colour or with pencil lines

examples.en: What do the shaded areas on the map represent?
I'm going to shade this part in.

senses.definition: to win a contest by scoring only a very small number of points, goals, etc. more than your opponent
the dark shape that somebody/something’s form makes on a surface, for example on the ground, when they are between the light and the surface

examples.en: The children were having fun, chasing each other's shadows.
As the curtains moved in the breeze, the shadows on the floor seemed to dance.
The ship's sail cast a shadow on the water.
The shadows lengthened as the sun went down.
The man's face is hidden in a deep shadow cast by his umbrella.
They saw the shadow of a man pass by.
He didn't want to cast a shadow on (= spoil) their happiness.

senses.definition: darkness in a place or on something, especially so that you cannot easily see who or what is there

examples.en: I thought I saw a figure standing in the shadows.
His face was deep in shadow, turned away from her.
A man in black emerged from the shadows.
It had grown dark, and the shadows could be hiding anything.
It's a spooky story about the monsters that lurk in the shadows.
She shrank back into the shadows as the footsteps approached.
‘I'm right here,’ I said, stepping out of the shadows.

senses.definition: a very small amount of something

examples.en: A shadow of a smile touched his mouth.
She knew beyond a shadow of a doubt (= with no doubt at all) that he was lying.

senses.definition: the strong (often bad) influence of somebody/something

examples.en: The new leader wants to escape from the shadow of his predecessor.
Bergman casts a long shadow over world cinema.
These people have been living for years under the shadow of fear.

senses.definition: dark areas under somebody’s eyes, because they are tired, etc.

examples.en: She looked pale, with deep shadows under her eyes.

senses.definition: a person or an animal that follows somebody else all the time
a weaker or worse version of somebody/something

examples.en: So far this season the player has been a shadow of himself.
The result is a product that is a shadow of the real thing.

senses.definition: a thing that is not real or possible to obtain

examples.en: You can't spend all your life chasing shadows.

idioms.word: be frightened/nervous/scared of your own shadow

senses.definition: to be very easily frightened; to be very nervous

idioms.word: be a shadow/ghost of your former self

senses.definition: to not have the strength, influence, etc. that you used to have

examples.en: When his career ended, he became a shadow of his former self.

senses.definition: very close to

examples.en: The new market is in the shadow of the City Hall.

senses.definition: when you say that somebody is in/under the shadow of another person, you mean that they do not receive as much attention as that person

examples.en: A younger son often lives in the shadow of his elder brother.

senses.definition: to follow and watch somebody closely and often secretly

examples.en: He was shadowed for a week by the secret police.

senses.definition: to be with somebody who is doing a particular job, so that you can learn about it

examples.en: It is often helpful for teachers to shadow managers in industry.

senses.definition: to cover something with a shadow

examples.en: A wide-brimmed hat shadowed her face.
The bay was shadowed by magnificent cliffs.

senses.definition: used to refer to senior politicians of the main opposition party who would become government ministers if their party won the next election

examples.en: the shadow Chancellor
the shadow Cabinet

senses.definition: to move or make somebody/something move with short quick movements from side to side or up and down

examples.en: The whole house shakes when a train goes past.
Shake the bottle well before use.
The explosion shook windows miles from the site.
She shook him by the shoulders.
He knelt and gently shook her awake.
She shook her hair loose.

senses.definition: to move something in a particular direction by shaking

examples.en: She bent down to shake a pebble out of her shoe.
His father used to come home and shake the dust off his work clothes.
He stood up, shaking sand everywhere.

senses.definition: to take somebody’s hand and move it up and down as a way of saying hello or to show that you agree about something

examples.en: Do people in Italy shake hands when they meet?
She refused to shake hands with him.
He stepped forward and shook my hand.
Our host shook each of us warmly by the hand.
They shook hands on the deal (= to show that they had reached an agreement).
They shook on the deal (= shook hands to show the deal was agreed).
Let's shake on it.

senses.definition: to turn your head from side to side as a way of saying ‘no’ or to show that you are sad, feel doubt, etc.

examples.en: ‘Drink?’ he offered. She shook her head.
The old man watched them walk off into the night, shaking his head sadly.
She shook her head in disbelief.
He shook his head at the thought.

senses.definition: to show that you are angry with somebody; to threaten somebody by shaking your fist (= closed hand)

examples.en: The man shook his fist at the court after he was sentenced.

senses.definition: to make short quick movements that you cannot control, for example because you are cold or afraid

examples.en: Her hands had started to shake.
He was shaking with fear.
He saw his mother turn away, her shoulders shaking with laughter.
His whole body shook with rage.
I was shaking like a leaf.

senses.definition: to sound unsteady, usually because you are nervous, upset or angry

examples.en: ‘Who are you?’ he asked, his voice shaking.
Her voice shook with emotion.

senses.definition: to shock or upset somebody very much

examples.en: He was badly shaken by the news of her death.
The accident really shook her up.
Shaken up by the early goal against them, the team began to fight back.

senses.definition: to make a belief or an idea less certain

examples.en: The incident had shaken her faith in him.
This announcement is bound to shake the confidence of the industry.

senses.definition: to get rid of something

examples.en: I can't seem to shake off this cold.
She has finally managed to shake off her old wrist injury.
He couldn't shake the feeling that there was something wrong.
She never seemed to completely shake off the dumb blonde image.

idioms.word: shake/rock the foundations of something | shake/rock something to its foundations

senses.definition: to cause people to question their basic beliefs about something

examples.en: This issue has shaken the foundations of French politics.
an event which rocked the foundations of British politics
The scandal rocked the legal establishment to its foundations.

senses.definition: to be very frightened or nervous
used to tell somebody to start to do something or to hurry
an act of shaking somebody/something

examples.en: She gave him a shake to wake him.
Give the bottle a good shake before opening.
He dismissed the idea with a firm shake of his head (= turning it from side to side to mean ‘no’).

senses.definition: a physical condition in which you cannot stop your body from shaking because of fear, illness, or because you have drunk too much alcohol

examples.en: I always get the shakes before exams.

senses.definition: a drink made of milk, and sometimes ice cream, with the added taste of fruit or chocolate, which is mixed or shaken until it is full of bubbles

examples.en: a strawberry shake

senses.definition: to be not very good, efficient, suitable, etc.

variants.text: (Australian English, New Zealand English (give somebody/get) a fair go)
variants.html: (Australian English, New Zealand English (give somebody/get) a fair go)

senses.definition: (to give somebody/get) fair treatment that gives you the same chance as somebody else

examples.en: Are minority students getting a fair shake at college?
We need a government that cares about equity and a fair go for all.

idioms.word: in two shakes | in a couple of shakes

senses.definition: very soon

examples.en: We’ll be there in a couple of shakes.

senses.definition: used with I and we for talking about or predicting the future

examples.en: This time next week I shall be in Scotland.
We shan't be gone long.
I said that I should be pleased to help.

senses.definition: used in questions with I and we for making offers or suggestions or asking advice

examples.en: Shall I send you the book?
What shall we do this weekend?
Let's look at it again, shall we?

senses.definition: used to show that you are determined, or to give an order or instruction

examples.en: He is determined that you shall succeed.
Candidates shall remain in their seats until all the papers have been collected.

senses.definition: not having much distance between the top or surface and the bottom

examples.en: a shallow dish/pan/bowl
a shallow sea/lake/pool/pond
They were playing in the shallow end (= of the swimming pool).
These fish are found in shallow waters around the coast.
The body was found in a shallow grave.
Most earthquakes occur at much shallower depths.
shallow roots (= that grow near the surface of the ground)

senses.dis_g: (of a person, an idea, a comment, etc.)
senses.definition: not showing serious thought, feelings, etc. about something

examples.en: This shows how shallow their commitment to the environment really is.
Tony seemed very shallow and immature.

senses.definition: shallow breathing involves taking in only a small amount of air each time
used to say that something is a cause for feeling sad or disappointed

examples.en: She's retiring because of ill health, which is a great shame.
What happened was a real shame.
It's a shame that she wasn't here to see it.
Shame they didn't think of that earlier.
It’s a shame (that) you didn’t say something sooner.
What a shame they couldn't come.
It's a shame about Tim, isn't it?
It's a terrible shame about Stuart losing his job, isn't it?
It's a shame to see her wasting her talent like this.

examples.cf: shame for somebody/something to do something
examples.en: It'd be a shame for us to give up now.
It would be a crying shame (= a great shame) not to take them up on the offer.
It seems such a shame to throw perfectly good food away.

senses.definition: the feelings of being sad, embarrassed or guilty that you have when you know that something you have done is wrong or stupid

examples.en: His face burned with shame.
They should blush with shame.
She hung her head in shame.
The king preferred death to the shame of defeat.
It took me a while to get over the shame of not doing something to help him.
He could not live with the shame of other people knowing the truth.
I felt a twinge of shame at the thought.
She admitted her shame at having a parent in prison.
He was filled with shame for giving in to his anger.
She expressed her shame for her role in the whole unfortunate business.
I would die of shame if she ever found out.
To my shame (= I feel shame that) I refused to listen to her side of the story.

senses.definition: the ability to feel shame at something you have done

examples.en: Have you no shame?
That child is completely without shame!
She has no sense of shame.

senses.definition: the loss of respect that is caused when you do something wrong or stupid

examples.en: There is no shame in wanting to be successful.
She felt that her failure would bring shame on her family.
He risked public shame and possible imprisonment.

senses.definition: to be much better than somebody/something

examples.en: Their presentation put ours to shame.
Her energy and enthusiasm puts the rest of us to shame (= makes us feel embarrassed and guilty that we are not the same).

senses.definition: used to say that somebody should feel ashamed for something they have said or done

examples.en: Shame on you for doubting me!

senses.definition: to make somebody feel ashamed

examples.en: His generosity shamed them all.
The people who did this all deserve to be publicly shamed.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel that they have lost honour or respect

examples.en: You have shamed your family.

senses.definition: to publish the names of people or organizations who have done something wrong or illegal

examples.en: The companies that pollute our rivers should be named and shamed.

senses.definition: used to express sympathy, or to show that you like somebody/something

examples.en: Shame, she's so cute!

senses.definition: the form of the outer edges or surfaces of something; an example of something that has a particular form

examples.en: a rectangular/spherical/cylindrical shape
geometric shapes
fantastic creatures that can change shape and be either visible or invisible
You can recognize the fish by the shape of their fins.
They have completely different body shapes.
This old T-shirt has completely lost its shape.
The island was originally circular in shape.
Several rooms are irregular in shape.
Candles come in all shapes and sizes.
Glass is blown or moulded into many shapes.
The pool was in the shape of a heart.
The government provides money in the shape of (= consisting of) grants and student loans.

senses.definition: a person or thing that is difficult to see clearly

examples.en: Ghostly shapes moved around in the dark.
I could just make out a dark shape in the distance.
An enormous shape loomed up out of the mist directly in front of me.

senses.definition: the physical condition of somebody/something

examples.en: What sort of shape was the car in after the accident?
He's in good shape for someone who had surgery six months ago.
The ship was in bad shape as a result of damage sustained in the collision.
He’s not in any shape (= not well enough) to be working.

senses.definition: the particular qualities or characteristics of something

examples.en: Will new technology change the shape of broadcasting?
Prices vary according to the size and shape of each project.
He did much to determine the shape of Asia's political map.

idioms.word: get bent out of shape (about/over something)

senses.definition: to become angry, anxious or upset

examples.en: Don't get bent out of shape about it. It was just a mistake!

senses.definition: to take exercise, eat healthy food, etc. in order to become physically fit

examples.en: I’m trying to get into shape before summer.
I need to get back into shape after the Christmas holiday.

senses.definition: to train somebody so that they do a particular job, task, etc. well

examples.en: It took him just two weeks to knock the new recruits into shape.

senses.definition: to make something more acceptable, organized or successful

examples.en: I've got all the information together but it still needs knocking into shape.
It shouldn’t take long to get the company back into shape.

senses.definition: to express or explain a particular idea, plan, etc.

examples.en: Marie tried to find the right words to give shape to the confusion in her head.

senses.definition: of any type

examples.en: I don't approve of violence in any shape or form.
I can't stand insects in any shape or form.
I do not condone bullying in any way, shape or form.

senses.definition: (to get/stay) in good physical condition

examples.en: You don't have to spend a fortune on gym membership to get in shape.
I like to stay in shape.

senses.definition: not having the normal shape

examples.en: The wheel had been twisted out of shape.
The bicycle had been battered out of shape.

senses.definition: not in good physical condition

examples.en: I didn’t realize how out of shape I was!

idioms.word: the shape of things to come

senses.definition: the way things are likely to develop in the future

examples.en: Are solar-powered cars the shape of things to come?
This new system could be the shape of things to come.

senses.definition: to develop and become more complete or organized

examples.en: The garden is beginning to take shape.
A new song began to take shape in her mind.

senses.definition: to dance

examples.en: She spent the whole evening throwing shapes on the dance floor.

senses.definition: to behave in a way that makes you seem to threaten somebody, especially by standing as though you are ready to fight, without actually becoming violent

examples.en: I was worried he might get violent but he was just throwing shapes.
The two main investors threw some shapes during the debate.

senses.definition: to make something into a particular shape

examples.en: Shape the dough into a ball.
The man was busy shaping mud into bricks.
This tool is used for shaping wood.
They use traditional methods to shape the stone.
tools for cutting and shaping metal

senses.definition: to have an important influence on the way that somebody/something develops

examples.en: You are helping to shape the future of this country.
She had a leading role in shaping party policy.
the historical circumstances that shaped their lives.
His ideas had been shaped by his experiences during the war.

senses.definition: to prepare to do something, especially hit or kick something

examples.en: She was shaping to hit her second shot.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody that if they do not improve, work harder, etc. they will have to leave their job, position, etc.

examples.en: He finally faced up to his drug problem when his band told him to shape up or ship out.

senses.definition: having the type of shape mentioned

examples.en: a huge balloon shaped like a giant cow
almond-shaped eyes
an L-shaped room

senses.definition: to have, use or experience something at the same time as somebody else

examples.en: There isn't an empty table. Would you mind sharing?
to share a room/bed
Parents said there was insufficient room for the two schools to share space.
It's been 23 years since these four men shared a stage.
Sue shares a house with three other students.
Bob told Jess he wanted to share his life with her.

senses.definition: to have part of something while another person or other people also have part

examples.en: All members of the band equally share the band's profits.
He shared the pie with her.
The Hungarian king shared power with the Austrian emperor to form the Austro-Hungarian Empire.
Each partner is entitled to share in the profits of the business.

senses.definition: to divide something between two or more people

examples.en: We shared the pizza between the four of us.
Rita shared her money out among her six grandchildren.
Profits are shared out yearly.

senses.definition: to give some of what you have to somebody else; to let somebody use something that is yours

examples.en: John had no brothers or sisters and wasn't used to sharing.
The conference is a good place to share information and exchange ideas.
This online resource will give farmers a new way to share knowledge with each other.
Eli shared his chocolate with the other kids.

senses.definition: to have the same feelings, ideas, experiences, etc. as somebody else

examples.en: to share a concern/an opinion
shared values
They shared a common interest in botany.
a view that is widely shared
They share a love of cinema.
His son doesn't share his passion for athletics.
We share many beliefs with followers of other religions.
People often share their political views with their parents.
I didn't really share in her love of animals.

senses.definition: to tell other people about your ideas, experiences, and feelings

examples.en: to share thoughts/ideas/feelings/memories
I did not find it easy to share my problems.
The two friends shared everything—they had no secrets.
Please share this on social media so we can get the word out.
I want to share the stories of several people I met.
Think of this as an opportunity to share your experiences.
The group listens while one person shares (= tells other people about their experiences, feelings, etc.).
Would you like to share your experience with the rest of the group?

senses.definition: to be equally involved in something or responsible for something

examples.en: Both drivers shared the blame for the accident.
Don't try to do everything yourself: you will need to share the load with your partner.

examples.cf: be shared between A and B
examples.en: Responsibility is shared between parents and teachers.
I try to get the kids to share in the housework.

senses.definition: used to say that everyone should share things equally and in a fair way

idioms.word: a trouble shared is a trouble halved

senses.definition: if you talk to somebody about your problems and worries, instead of keeping them to yourself, they seem less serious
(in nouns) an arrangement to divide something between two or more people, groups, etc.

examples.en: a job-share (= a job that is done by two people who each work for part of the week)
a nanny share (= an arrangement for somebody to work for two families)

senses.definition: (in verbs) using an arrangement in which two or more people or groups use or have the same thing

examples.en: We encourage people to carshare to reduce congestion on the roads.
to rideshare

senses.definition: one part of something that is divided between two or more people

examples.en: Next year we hope to have a greater share of the market.
The charity was supposed to have been given a share of the profits.
The party won its biggest share of the vote since 1992.
The new TV channel has continued to increase its share of advertising revenue.
The three hospitals will each receive an equal share of the money raised.
Why should he be entitled to a larger share of the royalties?
How much was your share of the winnings?
I have a 50 per cent share in the business.
If you die before your husband, your share in the property may go directly to your children.
I'm looking for a flat share (= a flat that is shared by two or more people who are not related).

senses.definition: the part that somebody has in a particular activity that involves several people

senses.definition: an amount of something that is thought to be normal or acceptable for one person or thing

examples.en: He always eats more than his share.

The industry has had its share of problems this year.
