senses.definition: the action of sending on a message on social media for other people to see

examples.en: The campaign has already received 180 000 shares on Facebook.

senses.definition: any of the units of equal value into which a company is divided that are sold to raise money. People who own shares receive part of the company’s profits.

examples.en: to have/hold/own shares
to buy/sell/trade shares
The company purchased 5.5m shares of the stock this week.
The company's shares fell 4.37 per cent.
Earnings per share are growing.
They acquired shares in the company earlier this year.
a fall in share prices
70% of our share capital is in the hands of international investors.
a share certificate
The airline's shares closed (= finished trading for the day) up 8p at 171p.

senses.definition: the broad curved blade (= metal cutting edge) of a plough

idioms.word: (more than) your fair share of something

senses.definition: (more than) an amount of something that is considered to be reasonable or acceptable

examples.en: He has more than his fair share of problems.
I've had my fair share of success in the past.

senses.definition: the largest or best part of something when it is divided

variants.text: (British and North American English a piece/slice/share of the pie)
variants.html: (British and North American English a piece/slice/share of the pie)

senses.definition: a share of the available money or benefits that you believe you have a right to

examples.en: Scotland is demanding a larger share of the national cake.

senses.definition: an owner of shares in a company or business

examples.en: the major shareholders in the company

senses.definition: having a fine edge or point, especially of something that can cut or make a hole in something

examples.en: a sharp knife
Toys with sharp edges are not suitable for young children.
sharp teeth

senses.definition: sudden, rapid and large

examples.en: a sharp drop in prices
a sharp rise in crime
a sharp increase in unemployment
the sharp decline in the value of the pound against the dollar
He heard a sharp intake of breath.

senses.definition: clear and definite

examples.en: a sharp outline
The photograph is not very sharp (= there are no clear contrasts between areas of light and shade).

In sharp contrast to her mood, the clouds were breaking up to reveal a blue sky.

senses.dis_g: (of people or their minds, eyes, etc.)
senses.definition: quick to notice or understand things or to react

examples.en: to have sharp eyes
a girl of sharp intelligence
a sharp sense of humour
He kept a sharp lookout for any strangers.
It was very sharp of you to see that!
Her mind was as sharp as a razor.

senses.dis_g: (of a person or what they say)
senses.definition: critical or severe

examples.en: sharp criticism
Emma has a sharp tongue (= she often speaks in an unpleasant or unkind way).
He was very sharp with me when I was late.

senses.definition: loud, sudden and often high in tone

examples.en: She read out the list in sharp, clipped tones.
There was a sharp knock on the door.

senses.dis_g: (of a physical feeling or an emotion)
senses.definition: very strong and sudden, often like being cut or badly hurt

examples.en: He winced as a sharp pain shot through his leg.
Polly felt a sharp pang of jealousy.

senses.definition: changing direction suddenly

examples.en: a sharp bend in the road
a sharp turn to the left

senses.definition: strong and slightly bitter

examples.en: The cheese has a distinctively sharp taste.

senses.definition: used to describe a very cold or very severe frost or wind

senses.dis_g: (of a person or their way of doing business)
senses.definition: clever but possibly dishonest

examples.en: His lawyer's a sharp operator.
The firm had to face some sharp practice from competing companies.

senses.dis_g: (of clothes or the way somebody dresses)
senses.definition: fashionable and new

examples.en: The consultants were a group of men in sharp suits.
Todd is a sharp dresser.

senses.definition: not full or round in shape

examples.en: a man with a thin face and sharp features (= a pointed nose and chin)

senses.definition: used after the name of a note to mean a note a semitone higher

examples.en: the Piano Sonata in C sharp minor

senses.definition: above the correct pitch (= how high or low a note sounds)

examples.en: That note sounded sharp.

idioms.word: not the sharpest knife in the drawer | not the sharpest tool in the box

senses.definition: not intelligent

examples.en: He's not exactly the sharpest knife in the drawer, is he?

senses.definition: the place or position of greatest difficulty or responsibility

examples.en: He started work at the sharp end of the business, as a salesman.

senses.definition: used after an expression for a time of day to mean ‘exactly’

examples.en: Please be here at seven o'clock sharp.

senses.definition: turning suddenly to the left or right

examples.en: The road turns sharp left at the bottom of the hill.

senses.definition: above the correct pitch (= how high or low a note sounds)
used in orders to tell somebody to be quick or to hurry

examples.en: You'd better look sharp or you'll be late.

senses.definition: a note played a semitone higher than the note that is named. The written symbol is (♯)

examples.en: It's a difficult piece to play, full of sharps and flats.

senses.definition: things with a sharp edge or point, such as needles and syringes

examples.en: the safe disposal of sharps
sharps injuries

senses.definition: to suddenly break into small pieces; to make something suddenly break into small pieces

senses.definition: to make somebody feel extremely shocked and upset

senses.definition: a female person or animal that has already been mentioned or is easily identified

examples.en: ‘What does your sister do?’ ‘She's a dentist.’

senses.definition: it (used to refer to something not usually thought of as female)

senses.definition: a female

examples.en: What a sweet little dog. Is it a he or a she?

senses.definition: a female animal

examples.en: a she-wolf

senses.definition: to get rid of something that is no longer wanted

senses.definition: to take off a piece of clothing

senses.definition: to lose or drop what it is carrying

senses.definition: if an animal sheds its skin, or a plant sheds leaves, it loses them naturally

examples.en: How often does a snake shed its skin?

senses.definition: to send light over something; to let light fall somewhere

senses.definition: to cry

examples.en: She shed no tears when she heard he was dead.

senses.definition: to make a problem, etc. easier to understand

senses.definition: a small simple building, usually built of wood or metal, used for keeping things in

examples.en: a bicycle shed

senses.definition: a large industrial building, used for working in or keeping equipment

examples.en: an engine shed

senses.definition: a building with open sides where the wool is cut off sheep (= they are sheared) or where cows are milked
an animal with a thick coat, kept on farms for its meat (called mutton or lamb) or its wool

examples.en: a flock of sheep

sheep farmers

senses.definition: to imagine that sheep are jumping over a fence and to count them, as a way of getting to sleep
if people behave like sheep, they all do what the others are doing, without thinking for themselves

senses.definition: to recognize the difference between people who are good at something, intelligent, etc. and those who are not

used to emphasize the size, degree or amount of something

senses.definition: complete and not mixed with anything else

sheer terror/panic/exhaustion/hell

senses.definition: very steep

examples.en: sheer cliffs/slopes

senses.definition: thin, light and almost transparent

examples.en: sheer nylon

senses.definition: straight up or down

examples.en: The cliffs rise sheer from the beach.

senses.definition: a large piece of thin cloth used on a bed to lie on or lie under

examples.en: Have you changed the sheets (= put clean sheets on the bed)?

white bed sheets

senses.definition: a piece of paper for writing or printing on, etc. usually in a standard size

senses.definition: a flat thin piece of any material, normally square or rectangular

sheet metal (= metal that has been made into thin sheets)

senses.definition: a wide flat area of something, covering the surface of something else

examples.en: The road was covered with a sheet of ice.

senses.definition: a large moving mass of fire or water

examples.en: a sheet of flame

a record of your work or behaviour that does not show any mistakes or bad things that you have done

senses.definition: a flat board, made of wood, metal, glass, etc., fixed to the wall or forming part of a cupboard, bookcase, etc., for things to be placed on

examples.en: I helped him put up some shelves in his bedroom.

supermarket shelves
store shelves

empty shelves
the powerful retailers who control what products get shelf space

that can be bought immediately and does not have to be specially designed or ordered

examples.en: I bought this package off the shelf.

senses.definition: not wanted by anyone; not used
considered unlikely to get married or find a partner, because of being too old
to stop something from being sold

examples.en: The slimming pills were taken off the market.

senses.definition: the hard outer part of eggs, nuts, some seeds, and some animals

snail/oyster/clam shells
walnut shells
earrings made out of coconut shell

senses.definition: any object that looks like the shell of a snail or sea creature

examples.en: pasta shells

senses.definition: a metal case filled with explosive, to be fired from a large gun

variants.text: (also cartridge British and North American English)
variants.html: (also cartridge British and North American English)

senses.definition: a tube or case containing explosive and a bullet or shot, for shooting from a gun
the walls or outer structure of something, for example, an empty building or ship after a fire or a bomb attack

examples.en: The house was now a shell gutted by flames.

senses.definition: any structure that forms a hard outer frame

examples.en: the body shell of a car

senses.definition: the outer layer of somebody’s personality; how they seem to be or feel

senses.definition: to fire shells at something

examples.en: They shelled the city all night.
Just as they were leaving, the rebels started shelling.

senses.definition: to remove the shell or outer layer from nuts, peas, etc.

a large international oil company that was formed when the British company Shell combined with the Dutch company Royal Dutch in the 1900s. It is now involved in producing oil and gas in Asia, the Middle East, the North Sea and South America. It also owns petrol stations in many countries.
the fact of having a place to live or stay, considered as a basic human need

examples.en: Human beings need food, clothing and shelter.
Thousands of people are without shelter following the wildfires.

senses.definition: protection from rain, danger, or attack

examples.en: to take shelter from the storm

a bomb shelter

senses.definition: a building, usually owned by a charity, that provides a place to stay for people without a home, or protection for people or animals who have been badly treated

an animal shelter

senses.definition: to give somebody/something a place where they are protected from the weather or from danger; to protect somebody/something

senses.definition: a British charity established in 1966 to help people who have nowhere to live, either by finding homes for them or by providing places in cities where they can sleep at night. It also acts as a pressure group to try to influence the government to do more to help people without homes.

usually used in orders to tell somebody to get out of bed and be active
the bright quality that something has when light is reflected on it

idioms.word: come rain, come shine | (come) rain or shine

senses.definition: a final remark, especially an unkind one, that somebody makes as they leave

examples.en: As her parting shot she warned Pete never to come near her again.

senses.definition: something that you say or do as a warning to somebody about what might happen if they do not change, etc.
something that encourages somebody/something or gives them the help they need

examples.en: Their enthusiasm has been a shot in the arm for all of us.

senses.definition: a guess; something you do without knowing what the result will be

examples.en: The figure he came up with was really just a shot in the dark.
It was only a stab in the dark, but I hoped I might be right.

senses.definition: having another colour showing through or mixed with the main colour

examples.en: shot silk
black hair shot with grey
a cloudy sky shot with streaks of sunlight

senses.definition: in a very bad condition; destroyed

examples.en: The brakes on this car are shot.
I'm shot—I'm too old for this job.
After the accident his nerves were shot to pieces.

senses.definition: to get rid of somebody/something so you no longer have the problems they cause

examples.en: I'll be glad to get shot of this car.
By the end of the week I just couldn’t wait to get shot of them.

senses.definition: containing a lot of a particular colour, quality or feature

examples.en: a voice shot through with emotion

senses.definition: used to show what is right, appropriate, etc., especially when criticizing somebody’s actions

examples.en: You shouldn't drink and drive.
He should have been more careful.
A present for me? You shouldn't have! (= used to thank somebody politely)

senses.definition: used for giving or asking for advice

examples.en: You should stop worrying about it.
Should I call him and apologize?
I should wait a little longer, if I were you.
‘She doesn't think she'll get a job.’ ‘She should worry, with all her qualifications (= she does not need to worry).’

senses.definition: used to say that you expect something is true or will happen

examples.en: We should arrive before dark.
I should have finished the book by Friday.
The roads should be less crowded today.

senses.definition: used to say that something that was expected has not happened

examples.en: It should be snowing now, according to the weather forecast.
The bus should have arrived ten minutes ago.

senses.definition: used as the past form of shall when reporting what somebody has said

examples.en: He asked me what time he should come. (= His words were: ‘What time shall I come?’)
I said (that) I should be glad to help.

senses.definition: used after that when something is suggested or arranged

examples.en: She recommended that I should take some time off.
In order that training should be effective it must be planned systematically.

senses.definition: used with I and we to give opinions that you are not certain about

examples.en: I should imagine it will take about three hours.
‘Is this enough food for everyone?’ ‘I should think so.’
‘Will it matter?’ ‘I shouldn't think so.’

senses.definition: used for expressing strong agreement

examples.en: ‘I know it's expensive but it will last for years.’ ‘I should hope so too!’
‘Nobody will oppose it.’ ‘I should think not!’

senses.cf: why, how, who, what should somebody/something do
senses.definition: used to refuse something or to show that you are annoyed at a request; used to express surprise about an event or a situation

examples.en: Why should I help him? He's never done anything for me.
How should I know where you've left your bag?
I got on the bus and who should be sitting in front of me but Tony!

senses.definition: used to tell somebody that something would surprise them or make them laugh if they saw or experienced it

examples.en: You should have seen her face when she found out!

senses.definition: used after that after many adjectives that describe feelings

examples.en: I'm anxious that we should allow plenty of time.
I find it astonishing that he should be so rude to you.

senses.definition: used with I and we in polite requests

examples.en: I should like to call my lawyer.
We should be grateful for your help.

senses.definition: used after I or we instead of would for describing what you would do if something else happened first

examples.en: If I were asked to work on Sundays, I should resign.

senses.definition: used to refer to a possible event or situation

examples.en: If you should change your mind, do let me know.
In case you should need any help, here's my number.
Should anyone call (= if anyone calls), please tell them I'm busy.

senses.definition: either of the two parts of the body between the top of each arm and the neck

examples.en: your left/right shoulder
a tall man with broad shoulders
He slung the bag over his shoulder.
He looked back over his shoulder.
He carried the child on his shoulders.
I put a hand on her shoulder to stop her.
She tapped him on the shoulder.
He put an arm around her shoulders and pulled her close.
She shrugged her shoulders (= showing that she didn't know or care).
an off-the-shoulder dress (= that does not cover the shoulders)
a shoulder injury
I have to have shoulder surgery.

senses.definition: having the type of shoulders mentioned

examples.en: broad-shouldered

senses.definition: the part of a piece of clothing that covers the shoulder

examples.en: a jacket with padded shoulders
There was snow on the shoulders of his heavy black coat.

senses.definition: meat from the top part of one of the front legs of an animal that has four legs
a part of something, such as a bottle or mountain, that is like a shoulder in shape

examples.en: The village lay just around the shoulder of the hill.

senses.definition: an area of ground at the side of a road where vehicles can stop in an emergency

examples.en: No shoulder for next 5 miles (= on a notice).

idioms.word: be/stand head and shoulders above somebody/something

senses.definition: to be much better than other people or things

examples.en: His performance stood head and shoulders above the rest.

senses.definition: to be anxious and have the feeling that somebody is going to do something unpleasant or harmful to you
to treat somebody in a way that is not friendly

idioms.word: have a chip on your shoulder (about something)

senses.definition: to be sensitive about something that happened in the past and become easily offended if it is mentioned because you think that you were treated unfairly

examples.en: He has a real chip on his shoulder about not being chosen for the team.

idioms.word: have a good head on your shoulders

senses.definition: to be a sensible person

idioms.word: (have) an old head on young shoulders

senses.definition: used to describe a young person who acts in a more sensible way than you would expect for a person of their age
if blame, guilt, etc. is on somebody’s shoulders, they must take responsibility for it

examples.en: Stop trying to put the blame on somebody else’s shoulders.

idioms.word: put your shoulder to the wheel

senses.definition: to start working very hard at a particular task

examples.en: Everyone is going to have to put their shoulder to the wheel.

variants.text: (North American English also rub elbows with somebody)
variants.html: (North American English also rub elbows with somebody)

senses.definition: to meet and spend time with a famous person, socially or as part of your job

examples.en: He’s rubbing shoulders with stars all the time.
She had been rubbing elbows with celebrities.

senses.definition: used to describe a person who listens to your problems and gives you sympathy

examples.en: He was a fatherly shoulder to cry on when things went wrong.

senses.definition: physically close to somebody

examples.en: The large crowd stood shoulder to shoulder in the stands.
The route of the procession was lined with police officers standing shoulder to shoulder.

senses.definition: as one group that has the same aims, opinions, etc.
if you say something straight from the shoulder, you are being very honest and direct, even if what you are saying is critical
to accept the responsibility for something

examples.en: to shoulder the responsibility/blame for something
women who shoulder the double burden of childcare and full-time work

senses.definition: to push forward with your shoulder in order to get somewhere

examples.en: He shouldered his way through the crowd and went after her.
She shouldered past a woman with a screaming baby.

senses.definition: to push somebody/something out of your way with your shoulder

examples.en: He shouldered the man aside.

senses.definition: to carry something on your shoulder

examples.en: She shouldered her bag and set off home.
to shoulder arms (= to hold a weapon, rifle, etc. against your shoulder while you are not using it)

senses.definition: to say something in a loud voice; to speak loudly/angrily to somebody

examples.en: Stop shouting and listen!
I shouted for help but nobody came.
Then he started shouting and swearing at her.
There are few things that get me shouting at the television.
We cannot learn until we stop shouting at each other.

examples.cf: shout at somebody to do something
examples.en: She shouted at him to shut the gate.
Protesters shouted slogans denouncing the war.
to shout abuse/encouragement/orders
A drunk man was shouting obscenities at the police officer.
The coach shouts instructions to players on the pitch.
He shouted that he couldn't swim.
She shouted herself hoarse, cheering on the team.
‘Run!’ he shouted.

senses.definition: to make a loud noise

examples.en: She could hear him shouting and screaming in the next room.
I wanted to shout for joy.
He was hugging them and shouting with glee.
She shouted out in pain when she tried to move her leg.

senses.definition: to buy drinks or food for somebody in a bar, restaurant, etc.

examples.en: I'll shout—what are you drinking?
Who's going to shout me a drink?

idioms.word: shout, etc. something from the rooftops

senses.definition: to talk about something in a very public way

examples.en: He was in love and wanted to shout it from the rooftops.

senses.definition: a loud cry of anger, fear, excitement, etc.

examples.en: angry shouts
I heard her warning shout too late.
a shout of anger/encouragement
Thunderous applause and shouts of 'bravo' greeted his performance.
Charlie gave a shout of joy and even his brothers looked pleased.
He ignored the loud shouts from the crowd outside.
A shout from downstairs broke the silence.

senses.definition: a person’s turn to buy drinks

examples.en: What are you drinking? It's my shout.

idioms.word: be in with a shout (of something/of doing something)

senses.definition: to have a good chance of winning something or of achieving something
to tell somebody something

examples.en: Give me a shout when you're ready.
Give me a shout if you'd like to come with us.

senses.definition: to make something clear; to prove something

examples.en: The figures clearly show that her claims are false.
The government's popularity is declining, as the polls show.
Our research showed us that women were more interested in their health than men.
The report showed an increase in sales.
Studies show a link between cancer and processed meats.
His new book shows him to be a first-rate storyteller.
Tax records show Shakespeare living near the Globe Theatre in 1599.
This shows how people are influenced by TV advertisements.
History has shown us how dangerous nationalism can be.

senses.definition: to let somebody see something

examples.en: You have to show your ticket as you go in.
If there's a letter from France please show it to me.
Have you shown your work to anyone?
Have you shown anyone your work?
We were shown a training video.

senses.definition: to teach or demonstrate the way to do something, for example by letting somebody watch you do it or by explaining it

examples.en: She showed the technique to her students.
She showed her students the technique.
In my book I showed a method which is very quick and easy.
Glue the sticks to the paper as shown in Figure 37.
Can you show me how to do it?
The diagram shows how to assemble the shelves.

senses.definition: to point to something so that somebody can see where or what it is

examples.en: He showed me our location on the map.
Show me which picture you drew.

senses.definition: to lead or guide somebody to a place

examples.en: The attendant showed us to our seats.
The candidates were shown in.
I'll go first and show you the way.

senses.definition: to make it clear that you have a particular quality

examples.en: to show great courage
He has shown his commitment to his art.
She wants to show the world her ability.
She had shown herself unable to deal with money.
You have shown yourself a master tactician.
He has shown himself to be ready to make compromises.
He has shown that he is ready to make compromises.

senses.definition: to behave in a particular way towards somebody

examples.en: I wanted to be there to show support.
They showed no respect for their parents.
They showed their parents no respect.
They have shown us nothing but kindness.

senses.definition: if a feeling or quality shows, or if somebody/something shows it, it can be seen or noticed

examples.en: Fear showed in his eyes.
She tried not to let her disappointment show.
They loved working together, and it shows (= it can be seen in their work).
She showed no interest in my work.
Her expression showed her disappointment.
The market shows no sign of slowing down.
Her second attempt showed a marked improvement.
The new strategy shows promise.
She tried not to show how disappointed she was.

senses.definition: if something shows, people can see it. If something shows a mark, dirt, etc., the mark can be seen.

examples.en: She had a warm woollen hat and scarf on that left only her eyes and nose showing.
Nothing showed on the X-ray.
Their new white carpet showed every mark.
He grinned, and his teeth showed white in the darkness.

senses.definition: to give particular information, or a time or measurement

examples.en: The map shows the principal towns and rivers.
The clock showed midnight.
The end-of-year accounts show a loss.
The flow chart shows how resources are allocated.

senses.definition: to be of somebody/something; to represent somebody/something

examples.en: The photographs clearly show a broken window.
She had objected to a photo showing her in a bikini.
This picture shows my mother as a young woman.
The painting shows St George slaying the dragon.

senses.definition: to be or make something available for the public to see

examples.en: The movie is now showing at all major movie theaters.
The documentary will be shown on Sunday night.
She plans to show her paintings early next year.

senses.definition: to prove that you can do something or are something

examples.en: They think I can't do it, but I'll show them!
He has shown himself to be a caring father.
I'm giving him a chance to show what he can do.

senses.definition: to arrive where you have arranged to meet somebody or do something

examples.en: I waited an hour but he didn't show.

senses.definition: to enter an animal in a competition
to show your support for your country, an organization or an idea to encourage or persuade others to do the same

idioms.word: go through your paces | show your paces

senses.definition: to perform a particular activity in order to show other people what you are capable of doing

examples.en: We watched the horses going through their paces.
The British team showed its paces during a training session in the hotel pool.

senses.definition: used to say that something proves something

examples.en: It just goes to show what you can do when you really try.

senses.definition: to ask somebody to leave, because they are no longer welcome
to appear among your friends or in public

examples.en: She stayed at home, afraid to show her face.

variants.text: (North American English also tip your hand)
variants.html: (North American English also tip your hand)

senses.definition: to make your plans or intentions known
to show somebody/know/learn how a particular job should be done
to do something first so that other people can follow
to make it clear to somebody that you have more power and authority than they have
to show that you are ready to help, work hard, etc. if necessary

idioms.word: (have) something, nothing, etc. to show for something

senses.definition: (to have) something, nothing, etc. as a result of something

examples.en: All those years of hard work, and nothing to show for it!

senses.definition: a programme on television or the radio

examples.en: Millions of people watch the show.
She hosts the morning show.
a TV/television/radio show
a quiz show
a reality show (= one that is based on real people, not actors)

senses.definition: a theatre performance, especially one that includes singing and dancing

examples.en: to go to/see a show
to put on/stage a show
The book has been turned into a stage show.
They will perform in a live show on Saturday night.
a one-man/one-woman show
She's the star of the show!

senses.definition: a concert, especially of rock music

examples.en: My first full-scale rock show was Fleetwood Mac, Madison Square Garden, back in 1977.

senses.definition: an occasion when a collection of things are brought together for people to look at

examples.en: a dog/car/gun show
This is one of the biggest agricultural shows in Wales.
The artist is holding her first solo show.
The paintings are on show until April.

senses.definition: an action or a way of behaving that shows how you feel

examples.en: a show of emotion/support
a show of force/strength by the army
The Democrats organized a show of strength, a mass rally in Central Park.
A show of force by 4 000 soldiers led to an agreement being reached quickly.
He was completely unmoved by her little show of temper.
She made a great show of wanting to leave, but I knew she didn't mean it.
She was afraid that too demonstrative a show of gratitude might be misinterpreted.
The company is seeking to rally a big show of support for the project.

senses.definition: something that is done only to give a good impression, but is not sincere

examples.en: He may seem charming, but it's all show!
She pretends to be interested in opera, but it's only for show.
He made a great show of affection, but I knew he didn't mean it.

senses.definition: a brightly coloured or pleasant sight

examples.en: a lovely show of spring flowers

senses.definition: an event, a business or a situation where something is being done or organized

examples.en: She runs the whole show.
I won't interfere—it's your show.

senses.definition: something that is done in a particular way

examples.en: The team put on a good show in the competition.
It's a poor show if he forgets your birthday.

senses.definition: an event that is planned only in order to impress people so that they will support or buy something

examples.en: the dog and pony show of his visits to the war zone
a dog and pony show to sell the idea to investors

senses.definition: intended to be seen but not used

examples.en: These items are just for show—they're not for sale.

idioms.word: get the show on the road

senses.definition: to start an activity or a journey

examples.en: Let's get this show on the road!

senses.definition: used to show you like something or to say that somebody has done something well
a way of voting for or against something in which people raise their hands to vote

examples.en: The vote was passed by a show of hands.
Let’s have a show of hands. Who’s in favour of the proposal?

senses.definition: to attract more attention and praise than other people in a particular situation

examples.en: As always, the children stole the show.
British bands stole the show at this year’s awards.

senses.definition: a piece of equipment producing a flow of water that you stand under to wash yourself; the small room or part of a room that contains a shower

examples.en: He's in the shower.
I've just got out of the shower.
an en-suite shower room
a shower cubicle/curtain
an electric shower
a hotel room with bath and shower
She was getting into the shower when the doorbell rang.

senses.definition: the act of washing yourself with a shower

examples.en: a hot/cold shower
to have a shower
to take a shower
shower gel

senses.definition: a short period of rain or snow

examples.en: scattered/heavy showers
April showers
We were caught in a heavy shower.
There's a chance of showers this afternoon.
rain/snow showers
wintry showers (= of snow)
a shower of rain/hail/hailstones

senses.definition: a large number of things that arrive or fall together

examples.en: a meteor shower
a shower of leaves
a shower of sparks from the fire
a shower of kisses

senses.definition: a party at which you give presents to a woman who is getting married or having a baby

examples.en: a bridal/baby shower

senses.definition: to wash yourself under a shower

examples.en: She showered and dressed and went downstairs.
He had already showered by the time they got home.

senses.definition: to fall onto somebody/something, especially in a lot of small pieces

examples.en: Volcanic ash showered down on the town after the eruption.

senses.definition: to drop a lot of small things onto somebody

examples.en: The bride and groom were showered with rice as they left the church.
The roof collapsed, showering us with dust and debris.

senses.definition: to give somebody a lot of something

examples.en: He showered her with gifts.
He showered gifts on her.

senses.definition: to become smaller, especially when washed in water that is too hot; to make clothes, cloth, etc. smaller in this way

examples.en: My sweater shrank in the wash.

senses.definition: to become or to make something smaller in size or amount

examples.en: The tumour had shrunk to the size of a pea.
The market for their products is shrinking.
The internet in a sense has shrunk the world.

senses.definition: to move back or away from something because you are frightened or shocked

examples.en: He shrank back against the wall as he heard them approaching.

senses.definition: a very shy person
a psychiatrist or psychologist

examples.en: She sees her shrink once a week.

senses.definition: to raise your shoulders and then drop them to show that you do not know or care about something

examples.en: Sam shrugged and said nothing.
‘I don't know,’ Anna replied, shrugging her shoulders.

senses.definition: an act of raising your shoulders and then dropping them to show that you do not know or care about something

examples.en: Andy gave a shrug. ‘It doesn't matter.’

senses.definition: a very short jacket, usually made of wool, that is open at the front and worn by women

examples.en: The shrug offers a fashionable layer of extra warmth.
You can wear a shrug to keep your shoulders warm.

senses.definition: to close something; to become closed

examples.en: The window won't shut.
The doors open and shut automatically.
The door shuts and locks behind her.
Philip went into his room and shut the door behind him.
I can't shut my suitcase—it's too full.
She shut her eyes and fell asleep immediately.
He shut his book and looked up.

senses.definition: when a shop, restaurant, etc. shuts or when somebody shuts it, it stops being open for business and you cannot go into it

examples.en: The bank shuts at 4.
What time do the shops shut on Saturday?
We left the hotel only to discover that the whole city shuts at 10.30.
The factory is going to shut next year.
We decided to shut the cafe early as there were no customers.
They're going to shut two plants in Texas and fire 2 240 workers.

senses.definition: to make it unlikely that something will happen

examples.en: She was careful not to close the door on the possibility of further talks.

senses.definition: to not talk about something to somebody because it is a secret or because it will upset or annoy them

examples.en: I've warned them to keep their mouths shut about this.
Now she's upset—why couldn't you keep your mouth shut?
The athletes were warned to keep their mouths shut about politics.

idioms.word: shut/slam the door in somebody’s face

senses.definition: to shut a door hard when somebody is trying to come in
to refuse to talk to somebody or meet them, in a rude way
to make it unlikely that something will happen

examples.en: She was careful not to shut the door on the possibility of further talks.

senses.definition: to refuse to listen to something

examples.en: She decided to shut her ears to all the rumours.

senses.definition: to pretend that you have not noticed something so that you do not have to deal with it

examples.en: You can't just close your eyes to his violence.
They seem intent on shutting their eyes to the problems of pollution.

senses.definition: a rude way of telling somebody to be quiet or stop talking
to close a business permanently or to stop working for the day
very easily, without thinking about it

examples.en: I've made this trip so often, I could do it with my eyes shut.

senses.definition: not open

examples.en: The door was shut.
She slammed the door shut.
Keep your eyes shut.
His eyes remained tightly shut.
I hope you can keep your mouth shut (= not tell anyone) about what you saw.

senses.definition: not open for business

examples.en: Unfortunately the bank is shut now.
The swimming pool has been shut for a decade.

senses.definition: nervous or embarrassed about meeting and speaking to other people

examples.en: He is not exactly the shy and retiring type.
Don't be shy—come and say hello.
She was too shy to ask anyone for help.
As a teenager I was painfully shy.
She's very shy with adults.
a quiet, shy man

senses.definition: showing that somebody is nervous or embarrassed about meeting and speaking to other people

examples.en: a shy smile
a shy grin/glance
his shy demeanour/temperament

senses.definition: easily frightened and not willing to come near people

examples.en: The panda is a shy creature.

senses.definition: afraid of doing something or being involved in something

examples.en: The band has never been shy of publicity.
He disliked her and had never been shy about saying so.

senses.definition: not having quite the amount that is needed to be something or to reach a particular figure

examples.en: We are still two players shy (of a full team).

The bill was just shy of $1 million.

senses.definition: avoiding or not liking the thing mentioned

examples.en: camera-shy (= not liking to be photographed)
media-shy (= not liking to be photographed, filmed or interviewed by the media)
He's always been work-shy.

idioms.word: fight shy of something/of doing something

senses.definition: to be unwilling to accept something or do something, and to try to avoid it

examples.en: Successive governments have fought shy of such measures.

senses.definition: after an unpleasant experience you are careful to avoid something similar
to turn away with a sudden movement because it is afraid or surprised

examples.en: My horse shied at the unfamiliar noise.
Her horse shied violently at a gorse bush.

senses.definition: a brother or sister

examples.en: squabbles between siblings
sibling rivalry (= competition between brothers and sisters)
The younger children were badly treated by older siblings.
poor relationships between siblings

senses.definition: physically or mentally ill

examples.en: a sick child
a sick relative/patient
Her mother's very sick.
Peter has been off sick (= away from work because he is ill) for two weeks.
Emma has just called in sick (= phoned to say she will not be coming to work because she is ill).
Britain's workers went sick (= did not go to work because they were ill) for a record number of days last year.
I can't afford to get sick (= become ill).
They became sick after eating contaminated food.
I have been sick in bed since you left.
She was sick with the flu.
Many people were sick from diseases caused by pollution.

senses.definition: feeling that you want to vomit

examples.en: Mum, I feel sick!
If you eat any more cake you'll make yourself sick.
a sick feeling in your stomach

senses.definition: feeling sick as a result of travelling on a ship, plane, etc.

examples.en: seasick
airsick
carsick
travel-sick

senses.definition: bored with or annoyed about something that has been happening for a long time, and wanting it to stop

examples.en: I'm sick of the way you've treated me.
I'm sick and tired of your moaning.
I'm sick to death of all of you!
We are getting heartily sick of your attitude.
We're sick of waiting around like this.
I am sick of hearing about them and their wedding.
I'm so sick of him whining about how hard his job is.

senses.definition: dealing with physical or mental pain, disease or death in a cruel way that some people think is offensive

examples.en: a sick joke
That's really sick.

senses.definition: getting pleasure from doing strange or cruel things

examples.en: a sick mind
People think I'm sick for having a rat as a pet.
We live in a sick society.

senses.definition: very good, a lot of fun, etc.

examples.en: I love that song—it’s sick!

senses.definition: to bring food from your stomach back out through your mouth

examples.en: I was sick three times in the night.
She had been violently sick.

idioms.word: be worried sick; be sick with worry

senses.definition: to be extremely worried

examples.en: Where have you been? I've been worried sick about you.

variants.html: (also old-fashioned take sick)

senses.definition: to become sick

examples.en: A week later he fell sick and died.
He fell sick with yellow fever.

senses.definition: to make somebody angry or full of horror

examples.en: His hypocrisy makes me sick.
Her attitude makes me sick.

senses.definition: feeling very sick; vomiting a lot
very disappointed
very unhappy or disappointed
feeling very angry or worried

examples.en: Nora turned sick to her stomach on hearing this news.
It makes me sick to my stomach to hear such stupid attitudes.

senses.definition: feeling that you want to vomit
food that you bring back up from your stomach through your mouth

examples.en: There was a pool of sick on the carpet.

senses.definition: people who are sick

examples.en: to heal the sick
All the sick and wounded were evacuated.
workers who are caring for the sick and elderly

senses.definition: either of the two halves of a surface, an object or an area that is divided by an imaginary central line

examples.en: the right side of the brain
satellite links to the other side of the world
They drive on the left-hand side of the road in Japan.
She was on the far side of the room.
They crossed from one side of London to the other.
Keep on your side of the bed!
a factory on the west side of town

senses.definition: a position or an area to the left or right of something

examples.en: He crossed the bridge to the other side of the river.
The opposite side of the street was still in shadow.
There is a large window on either side of the front door.
people on both sides of the Atlantic
a town on this side of the border
She saw James standing on the other side of the fence.
She tilted her head to one side.

senses.definition: one of the flat surfaces of something that is not the top or bottom, front or back

examples.en: A notice was stuck to the side of the filing cabinet.
Write your name on the side of the box.
There's a scratch on the side of my car.
Now lay the jar on its side.
The ship was damaged on her starboard side.
The kitchen door is at the side of the house.
a side door/window/panel
a side wall/entrance

senses.definition: the vertical or sloping surface around something, but not the top or bottom of it

examples.en: A path went up the side of the hill.
Brush the sides of the tin with butter.
We could see sheep grazing on the side of the mountain.

senses.definition: a part near the edge of something; an area just beyond the edge of something

examples.en: The stream flows into the south side of the lake.
A path leads down one side of the garden.
We planted tulips along the side of the lawn.
She sat on the side of the bed.
The player received treatment on the side of the pitch.
A van was parked at the side of the road.

senses.definition: either the right or left part of a person’s body, from the armpit (= where the arm joins the body) to the hip (= where the leg joins the body)

examples.en: I've got a stitch in my side (= a sudden pain from running or laughing).
She has a pain down her right side.
He was lying on his side.

senses.definition: either of two surfaces of something flat and thin, such as paper or cloth

examples.en: The upper side of the leaf was a much darker green.
The reverse side of the coin has a picture of a flower.
Write on one side of the paper only.
Fry the steaks for two minutes on each side.

senses.definition: the amount of writing needed to fill one side of a sheet of paper

examples.en: He told us not to write more than three sides.

senses.definition: any of the flat surfaces of a solid object

examples.en: A cube has six sides.
Each side of the pyramid is greater than five acres in area.

senses.definition: any of the lines that form a flat shape such as a square or triangle

examples.en: a shape with five sides
The farm buildings form three sides of a square.

senses.definition: used in adjectives to state the number or type of sides

examples.en: a six-sided object
a glass-sided container

senses.definition: a place or position very near to somebody/something

examples.en: Her husband stood at her side.
She was glad to have him by her side.
Keep close to my side.
Her friends never seem to leave her side.
He rushed to be at her side.

senses.definition: one of the two or more people or groups taking part in an argument, war, etc.

examples.en: Both sides agreed to restore diplomatic relations.
At some point during the war he seems to have changed sides.
Each side is capable of destroying the other in a nuclear war.
We have finally reached an agreement acceptable to all sides.
The two sides announced a deal yesterday.
to be on the winning/losing side
There are faults on both sides.
There is anger on both sides of the political divide.

senses.definition: one of the opinions, attitudes, or positions held by somebody in an argument, a business arrangement, etc.

examples.en: We heard both sides of the argument.
I just want you to hear my side of the story first.
One side of the debate is articulated best by France and Germany.
The defendant has had no opportunity to put his side of the case.
Will you keep your side of the bargain?
On the plus side, the film is beautifully shot and edited.

senses.definition: a particular aspect of something, especially a situation or a person’s character

examples.en: These poems reveal her gentle side.
It's interesting to see another side of a story that is so well known.
It's good you can see the funny side of the situation.
I'll take care of that side of things.
This is a side of Alan that I never knew existed.
the darker side of human nature
a behind-the-scenes documentary which promises to show a side of him rarely seen in public

senses.definition: a feeling that you are better than other people

examples.en: There was no side to him at all.

senses.definition: a sports team

examples.en: As captain, Pryce is confident of leading his side to victory.
The French have a very strong side.
We were on the winning/losing side.
As the home side, they were expected to play an attacking game.

senses.definition: the part of your family that people belong to who are related either to your mother or to your father

examples.en: a cousin on my father’s side (= a child of my father’s brother or sister)

senses.definition: a side dish (= a small amount of food, for example a salad, served with the main course of a meal)

examples.en: Your dinner comes with a choice of two sides.

senses.definition: one of the two halves of an animal that has been killed for meat
a television channel

examples.en: What's on the other side?

senses.definition: to support and agree with somebody

examples.en: I'm definitely on your side in this.
Whose side are you on anyway?

senses.definition: the boyfriend or girlfriend of somebody who is already married or in a steady sexual relationship with somebody else

examples.en: Is he your bit on the side?

idioms.word: come down on one side of the fence or the other

senses.definition: to choose between two possible choices

idioms.word: err on the side of something

senses.definition: to show too much of a good quality in order to avoid showing too little

examples.en: I thought it was better to err on the side of caution (= to be too careful rather than take a risk).

senses.definition: moving to the left and then to the right and then back again

examples.en: He shook his head slowly from side to side.
The ship rolled from side to side.
The cat sat with its tail twitching from side to side.

idioms.word: from/on the wrong side of the tracks

senses.definition: from or living in a poor area or part of town

idioms.word: get on the right/wrong side of somebody

senses.definition: to make somebody pleased with you/annoyed with you

idioms.word: get out of bed on the wrong side

variants.text: (North American English get up on the wrong side of the bed)
variants.html: (North American English get up on the wrong side of the bed)

senses.definition: to be in a bad mood for the whole day for no particular reason

idioms.word: the grass is (always) greener on the other side (of the fence)

senses.definition: said about people who never seem happy with what they have and always think they could be happier in a different place or situation
to have something as an advantage that will make it more likely that you will achieve something

examples.en: She may not win this year, but she does have youth on her side.

idioms.word: know which side your bread is buttered

senses.definition: to know where you can get an advantage for yourself

idioms.word: laugh on the other side of your face

senses.definition: to be forced to change from feeling pleased or satisfied to feeling disappointed or annoyed

examples.en: He’ll be laughing on the other side of his face when he reads my letter.

senses.definition: to fail to give your friends, family, etc. the help and support they expect, or to behave in a way that makes them disappointed

examples.en: You can always rely on Maggie—she’d never let the side down.
I felt I was letting the side down by not going to the wedding.

senses.definition: to be cheerful or positive about a bad situation, for example by thinking only of the advantages and not the disadvantages

examples.en: Look on the bright side. You managed to do more than I did.

senses.definition: to stay with somebody, especially in order to take care of them

idioms.word: on/from all sides | on/from every side

senses.definition: in or from all directions; everywhere

examples.en: We realized we were surrounded on all sides.
Disaster threatens on every side.
She was bombarded with questions from all sides.

idioms.word: on the big, small, high, etc. side

senses.definition: slightly too big, small, high, etc.

examples.en: These shoes are a little on the tight side.
Don’t you think you’re a bit on the short side to play basketball?

senses.definition: used to introduce the good points about somebody/something, especially after the bad points have been mentioned

examples.en: On the credit side, she’s always willing to work very late.

senses.definition: on the woman’s side of the family
out of your way

examples.en: I left my bags on one side.

senses.definition: to be dealt with later

examples.en: I put his complaint to one side until I had more time.
Leaving that to one side for a moment, are there any other questions?

idioms.word: on the right/wrong side of 40, 50, etc.

senses.definition: younger or older than 40, 50, etc. years of age
being especially careful; taking no risks

examples.en: I took some extra cash just to be on the safe side.

senses.definition: in addition to your main job

examples.en: a mechanic who buys and sells cars on the side

senses.definition: secretly or illegally

examples.en: He's married but he has a girlfriend on the side.

senses.definition: served at the same time as the main part of the meal, but on a separate plate

idioms.word: on the wrong side of the law

senses.definition: in trouble with the police

idioms.word: the other side of the coin

senses.definition: the aspect of a situation that is the opposite of or contrasts with the one you have been talking about
with the top part turned to the top; in the correct, normal position

examples.en: I dropped my toast, but luckily it fell right side up.

senses.definition: close together and facing in the same direction

examples.en: There were two children ahead, walking side by side.
The two sat side by side on the bench.

senses.definition: together, without any difficulties

examples.en: We have been using both systems, side by side, for two years.
The two communities exist happily side by side.

variants.text: (North American English also side of the aisle)
variants.html: (North American English also side of the aisle)

senses.definition: used to refer to either of two opposite opinions on an issue

examples.en: The two countries are often on opposite sides of the fence when it comes to climate change.
There are arguments on both sides of the aisle.

senses.definition: to laugh a lot at somebody/something
to express support for somebody in an argument

examples.en: She didn't think it was wise to take sides in their argument.

senses.definition: to speak to somebody in private, especially in order to warn or tell them about something
before a particular time, event, age, etc.

examples.en: They aren't likely to arrive this side of midnight.

senses.definition: a person or thing that repeatedly annoys somebody or stops them from doing something
used to say that somebody can wait for something to happen or can wait before doing something

idioms.word: two sides of the same coin

senses.definition: used to talk about two ways of looking at the same situation
to take and then let out a long deep breath that can be heard, to show that you are disappointed, sad, tired, etc.

examples.en: He sighed deeply at the thought.
She sighed with relief that it was all over.

senses.definition: to say something with a sigh

examples.en: ‘Oh well, better luck next time,’ she sighed.

senses.definition: to make a long sound like a sigh

examples.en: the sighing of the wind through the trees
branches sighing in the wind

senses.definition: an act or the sound of sighing

examples.en: to give/heave/let out a sigh
a deep sigh
‘I'll wait,’ he said with a sigh.
We all breathed a sigh of relief when it was over.

senses.definition: the ability to see

examples.en: to lose your sight (= to become blind)
She has very good sight.
The disease has affected her sight.
He has very little sight in his right eye.
It's important that you have regular sight tests.

senses.definition: the act of seeing somebody/something

examples.en: She kept sight of him in her mirror.
She caught sight of a car in the distance.
After ten days at sea, we had our first sight of land.
The mere sight of him makes me want to scream.
The sight of him hobbling off so early in the match depressed everyone.
He laughed quietly to himself at the sight.
I have been known to faint at the sight of blood.
The soldiers were given orders to shoot on sight (= as soon as they saw somebody).

senses.definition: the area or distance within which somebody can see or something can be seen

examples.en: There was no one in sight.
They stole everything in sight.
The end is in sight (= will happen soon).
The goats ate everything in sight.
At last we came in sight of a few houses.
A bicycle came into sight on the main road.
They marched on and by the following afternoon the enemy was within sight.
He sprinted ahead as they came within sight of the finishing line.
Leave any valuables in your car out of sight.
Keep out of sight (= stay where you cannot be seen).
She never lets her daughter out of her sight (= always keeps her where she can see her).
Get out of my sight! (= Go away!)
The boat disappeared from sight.
The house was hidden from sight behind some trees.
He won't let the children leave his sight.
Her father was nowhere in sight.
The cricket ground was situated within sight of both village pubs.
They waited until the enemy was in plain sight.
He strode by, in full sight of the guards.
He didn't shoot until he had a clear sight of the goal.

senses.definition: a thing that you see or can see

examples.en: Roadside stalls are a common sight in the city.
It's a spectacular sight as the flamingos lift into the air.
The museum attempts to recreate the sights and sounds of wartime Britain.
He was a sorry sight, soaked to the skin and shivering.
The bird is now a rare sight in this country.
He became a familiar sight on the streets of Oxford.
The gardens were a beautiful sight to behold in the twilight.

senses.definition: the interesting places, especially in a town or city, that are often visited by tourists

examples.en: We're going to Paris for the weekend to see the sights.
The next day I did the sights of the city.
It's best if you can get someone local to show you the sights.

senses.definition: a person or thing that looks silly, untidy, unpleasant, etc.

examples.en: She looks a sight in that hat!

senses.definition: a device that you look through to aim a gun, etc. or to look at something through a telescope, etc.

examples.en: He had the deer in his sights now.
to align the sights on the target
Even as a young actress, she always had Hollywood firmly in her sights (= as her final goal).

senses.definition: when you first begin to consider something

examples.en: At first sight, it may look like a generous offer, but always read the small print.

senses.definition: when you see somebody/something for the first time

examples.en: It was love at first sight (= we fell in love the first time we saw each other).
We fell in love with the house at first sight.
He looked at first sight like a tourist.

idioms.word: hate, be sick of, etc. the sight of somebody/something

senses.definition: to hate, etc. somebody/something very much

examples.en: I can't stand the sight of him!
We've shared an office for too long and we're sick of the sight of each other.

senses.definition: to appear, especially when moving gradually closer from a long way off

examples.en: A ship hove into sight.
Like a galleon in full sail, Cara hove into view.

idioms.word: in the sight of somebody/in somebody’s sight

senses.definition: in somebody’s opinion

examples.en: We are all equal in the sight of God.

senses.definition: to recognize somebody without knowing them well
to become no longer able to see somebody/something

examples.en: They finally lost sight of land.

senses.definition: to stop considering something; to forget something

examples.en: We must not lose sight of our original aim.

senses.definition: not pleasant to look at

examples.en: You should have seen him in his swimming trunks—not a pretty sight!

idioms.word: nowhere to be found/seen | nowhere in sight

senses.definition: impossible for anyone to find or see

examples.en: I wanted to talk to him but he was nowhere to be found.
The children were nowhere to be seen.
A peace settlement is nowhere in sight (= is not likely in the near future).

idioms.word: out of sight, out of mind

senses.definition: used to say somebody will quickly be forgotten when they are no longer with you
to expect more/less from a situation

examples.en: If they can’t afford such a big house, they’ll just have to lower their sights a little.
After failing to get into university, he lowered his sights and got a job in a shop.

idioms.word: set your sights on something/on doing something

senses.definition: to decide that you want something and to try very hard to get it

examples.en: She's set her sights on getting into Harvard.
I had set my sights on a career in journalism.
He says he wants to win the trophy, but I think he's setting his sights too high.
She has her sights set on becoming a writer.

idioms.word: a (damn, etc.) sight better, etc. | a (damn, etc.) sight too good, etc.

senses.definition: very much better; much too good, etc.

examples.en: She's done a darn sight better than I have.
It's worth a damn sight more than I thought.

senses.definition: a person or thing that you are pleased to see; something that is very pleasant to look at
if you buy something sight unseen, you do not have an opportunity to see it before you buy it

examples.en: I bought it, sight unseen.

senses.definition: to suddenly see something, especially something you have been looking for

examples.en: After twelve days at sea, they sighted land.

senses.definition: an event, an action, a fact, etc. that shows that something exists, is happening or may happen in the future

examples.en: Looking back, I should have seen the signs.
a clear/visible sign
an encouraging sign
a positive sign
The fact that he didn't say ‘no’ immediately is a good sign.
If I had noticed the warning signs, none of this would have happened.
Early signs point to business improving.
This move will be seen as a sign of weakness.
Bankers say they can definitely detect signs of a recovery.
Headaches may be a sign of stress.
There is no sign of John anywhere.
Soldiers swarmed the city looking for any sign of her.
There was no sign of life in the house (= there seemed to be nobody there).
Her work is showing some signs of improvement.
I hope this incident isn't a sign of things to come.
Get this test if you have signs and symptoms of diabetes.
He is reading the signs all wrong.
Call the police at the first sign of trouble.
The gloomy weather shows no sign of improving.
There is little sign of this happening in the immediate future.
If an interview is too easy, it's a sure sign that you haven't got the job.
There were no outward signs that anything was wrong.

senses.definition: a piece of paper, wood or metal that has writing or a picture on it that gives you information, instructions, a warning, etc.

examples.en: to put up/post a sign
to carry/hold a sign
a street/stop sign
a shop/pub sign
a traffic sign
The sign read ‘No Fishing’.
The sign on the wall said ‘Now wash your hands’.
There was a 'Closed' sign in the window.
Follow the signs for the city centre.

senses.definition: a movement or sound that you make to tell somebody something

examples.en: He gave a thumbs-up sign (= to show approval/agreement).
She was waiting for some kind of sign from him.
At a sign from her, the band would start to play.
He gave a slight bow as a sign of respect.
She shook her head in a desperate sign to tell the child to remain silent.

examples.cf: sign for somebody to do something
examples.en: She nodded as a sign for us to sit down.
Three blasts on the whistle was the sign for visitors to leave.
to make the sign of the cross (= an act of moving one hand in the shape of a cross, done by Christians to show respect for God or by a priest to bless somebody/something)

senses.definition: a mark used to represent something, especially in mathematics

examples.en: a plus/minus sign (= +/−)
a dollar/pound sign (= $/£)
the sign for ‘square root’

senses.definition: a star sign (= one of the twelve signs of the zodiac)

examples.en: What sign are you?

senses.definition: something that you feel shows what things are like now, especially how bad they are

examples.en: The increasing number of people owning guns is an alarming sign of the times.

senses.definition: to write your name on a document, letter, etc. to show that you have written it, that you agree with what it says, or that it is real

examples.en: Sign here, please.
to sign an agreement/a deal/a contract
to sign a document/statement/declaration/form
to sign a petition/a bill/ an order
to sign a cheque
Sign your name here, please.
You haven't signed the letter.
The treaty was signed on 24 March.
The player was signing autographs for a group of fans.
I'm going to his office now to sign the papers.
The bill was signed into law by the president yesterday.
He signed himself ‘Jimmy’.

senses.definition: to arrange for somebody, for example a sports player or musician, to sign a contract agreeing to work for your company; to sign a contract agreeing to work for a company

examples.en: United have just signed a new goalie.
to sign a player
He signed for United yesterday.
The band signed with Virgin Records.
She was the first musician signed to the new record label.

senses.definition: to make a request or tell somebody to do something by using a sign, especially a hand movement

examples.en: The hotel manager signed to the porter to pick up my case.

examples.cf: sign for somebody to do something
examples.en: The police officer signed for us to stop.
The police officer signed that we were to stop.
He signed his troops to move out.

senses.definition: to use sign language to communicate with somebody

examples.en: She learnt to sign to help her deaf child.
An increasing number of plays are now being signed.

idioms.word: signed and sealed | signed, sealed and delivered

senses.definition: definite, because all the legal documents have been signed
to sign a document to show that you have agreed to buy something or do something

examples.en: Just sign on the dotted line and the car is yours.

senses.definition: to make a promise never to drink alcohol
a movement or sound that you make to give somebody information, instructions, a warning, etc.

examples.en: a danger/warning/distress signal
At an agreed signal they left the room.
She made an impatient signal to him, but he ignored her.
He thought he had heard the referee's signal to proceed.

examples.cf: signal for somebody to do something
examples.en: The siren was a signal for everyone to leave the building.
We spotted the scout's signal that four enemy soldiers were coming towards us.
Wait for the signal from the leader of your group.
When I give the signal, run!
All I get is a busy signal when I dial his number (= his phone is being used).
hand signals (= movements that cyclists make with their hands to tell other people that they are going to stop, turn, etc.)

senses.definition: a piece of equipment that uses different coloured lights to tell drivers to go slower, stop, etc., used especially on railways and roads

examples.en: The traffic signals were on red.
a stop signal
Delays are occurring as a result of signal failure on the northbound line.

senses.definition: a series of electrical waves that carry sounds, pictures or messages, for example to a radio, television or mobile phone

examples.en: radio signals
TV signals
a digital signal
a high-frequency signal
a radar signal
to emit a signal
to detect/pick up signals
I couldn't get a signal on my phone.
The signal is received by three different antennas at slightly different times.
The satellite is used for transmitting signals around the world.
The signal from the transmitter seems to have been boosted.

senses.definition: an event, an action, a fact, etc. that shows that something exists or is likely to happen

examples.en: The rise in inflation is a clear signal that the government's policies are not working.
The court has given a strong signal that it disagrees with the government's position.
Chest pains can be a warning signal of heart problems.
Reducing prison sentences would send the wrong signals to criminals.

senses.definition: to make a movement or sound to give somebody a message, an order, etc.

examples.en: Don't fire until I signal.
She signalled to the man, who immediately came over to her.
A woman was leaning out a top-floor window, signaling for help.
He signalled to the waiter for the bill.

examples.cf: signal to/for somebody to do something
examples.en: He signalled to us to join him.
The patrolman signalled for her to stop.
She signalled him to follow.
The referee signalled a foul.
She signalled (that) it was time to leave.
You must signal which way you are going to turn.

senses.definition: to show that your vehicle is going to change direction, by using lights or your arm

examples.en: Did you signal before you turned right?
to signal left/right
I signalled that I was going to turn left.

senses.definition: to be a sign that something exists or is likely to happen

examples.en: This announcement signalled a clear change of policy.
The scandal surely signals the end of his political career.
These events appeared to signal the end of an era.
These changes clearly signal the end of the welfare state as we know it.
A fall in demand does not necessarily signal the death of the industry.

senses.definition: to do something to make your feelings or opinions known

examples.en: He signalled his discontent by refusing to vote.
She has signalled (that) she is willing to stand as a candidate.

senses.definition: important, clear and definite

examples.en: a signal honour
a signal failure of leadership

senses.definition: your name as you usually write it, for example at the end of a letter

examples.en: Someone had forged her signature on the cheque.
They collected 10 000 signatures for their petition.
He was attacked for having put his signature to the deal.
Can you witness my signature on my will, please?

senses.definition: the act of signing something

examples.en: Two copies of the contract will be sent to you for signature.

senses.definition: a particular quality that makes something different from other similar things and makes it easy to recognize

examples.en: Bright colours are his signature.
The signature flavours of Thai cookery are coriander and lime.
Each song bears the signature of its performer.

senses.definition: the importance of something, especially when this has an effect on what happens in the future

examples.en: a decision of major political significance
The new drug has great significance for the treatment of the disease.
They discussed the statistical significance of the results.
We should be fully aware of the significance of television in shaping our ideas.

senses.definition: the meaning of something

examples.en: She couldn't grasp the full significance of what he had said.
Do these symbols have any particular significance?

senses.definition: large or important enough to have an effect or to be noticed

examples.en: There are no significant differences between the two groups of students.
Your work has shown a significant improvement.
a significant increase/decrease/reduction/loss
a significant amount/number/part/portion
significant change/progress
The results of the experiment are not statistically significant.
These views are held by a significant proportion of the population.
The 1992 reform made very significant contributions to the development of many rural areas.
The drug has had no significant effect on stopping the spread of the disease.
Asthma has a significant impact on the life and well-being of children affected by this disease.
The offender was assessed as posing a significant risk to others.
It is significant that girls generally do better in examinations than boys.

senses.definition: having a particular meaning

examples.en: The fact that her remarks were leaked to the media in advance is highly significant.
It is significant that he changed his will only days before his death.
This year's event is particularly significant as it takes place on the centenary of his birth.
rituals which are deeply significant to Christians
November 16th will always be an especially significant day for us, thanks to the birth of our second grandchild.

senses.definition: having a special or secret meaning that is not understood by everyone

examples.en: a significant look/smile

senses.definition: in a way that is large or important enough to have an effect on something or to be noticed

examples.en: significantly higher/lower/larger/smaller
The two sets of figures are not significantly different.
to differ/vary/change significantly
significantly greater/better
significantly more/less/fewer
Profits have increased significantly over the past few years.
The high school dropout rate has significantly decreased since then.
The risks can be significantly reduced by paying close attention to diet and lifestyle.
Your decision will significantly affect your future.
These services will significantly improve the quality of life for older people in the area.
Einstein contributed significantly to the early development of quantum mechanics.
Food prices are significantly lower in the US.

senses.definition: in a way that has a particular meaning

examples.en: Significantly, he did not deny that there might be an election.
Perhaps significantly, many of their illegal activities were not considered as crime.

senses.definition: in a way that has a special or secret meaning

examples.en: She paused significantly before she answered.

senses.definition: a complete lack of noise or sound

examples.en: Their footsteps echoed in the silence.
A scream broke the silence of the night.
I need absolute silence when I'm working.

senses.definition: a situation when nobody is speaking

examples.en: an embarrassed/awkward/uncomfortable silence
a moment’s stunned silence
I got used to his long silences.
They finished their meal in total silence.
She lapsed into silence again.
There was a deafening silence (= one that is very noticeable).
a two-minute silence in honour of those who had died
Her accusations reduced him to silence.
He’s not one to suffer in silence! (= to suffer without telling somebody)
There was a moment of uncomfortable silence.
They observed a two-minute silence in memory of the children.

senses.definition: a situation in which somebody refuses to talk about something or to answer questions

examples.en: She broke her public silence in a TV interview.
The company's silence on the subject has been taken as an admission of guilt.
the right to silence (= the legal right not to say anything when you are arrested)
There is a conspiracy of silence about what is happening (= everyone has agreed not to discuss it).

senses.definition: a situation in which people do not communicate with each other by letter or phone

examples.en: The phone call came after months of silence.

senses.definition: a situation when people do not say anything, but feel embarrassed or uncomfortable
an occasion when nobody speaks, although people are aware that there are feelings or thoughts to express

examples.en: There was a pregnant pause before she replied.

senses.definition: it is often best not to say anything
to make somebody/something stop speaking or making a noise

examples.en: She silenced him with a glare.
Our bombs silenced the enemy's guns (= they destroyed them).
Her scream was abruptly silenced.

senses.definition: to make somebody stop expressing opinions that are opposed to yours

examples.en: All protest had been silenced.
Her recent achievements have silenced her critics.

senses.definition: used to tell people to be quiet

examples.en: Silence in court!

senses.definition: where there is little or no sound; making little or no sound

examples.en: At last the traffic fell silent.
The streets were silent and deserted.

senses.definition: not speaking

examples.en: to remain/stay/keep silent
As the curtain rose, the audience fell silent.
He gave me the silent treatment (= did not speak to me because he was angry).
Half the room went silent and turned to see what was happening.
They huddled together in silent groups.
The mayor was silent for a moment.

senses.definition: not expressed with words or sound

examples.en: a silent prayer/protest
They nodded in silent agreement.

senses.definition: written but not pronounced

examples.en: The ‘b’ in ‘lamb’ is silent.

senses.definition: with pictures but no sound

examples.en: a silent film/movie
stars of the silent screen

senses.definition: not talking very much

examples.en: He's the strong silent type.

senses.definition: not giving information about something; refusing to speak about something

examples.en: The report is strangely silent on this issue.
the right to remain silent (= the legal right not to say anything when you are arrested)

senses.definition: fine soft thread produced by silkworms

examples.en: The caterpillar spins the silk around its entire body.

senses.definition: a type of fine smooth cloth made from silk thread; a piece of this cloth

examples.en: a silk dress/blouse/scarf/tie/sari
silk stockings
made of pure silk

fine silks produced in Italy

senses.definition: thread made of silk used for sewing
clothes made of silk, especially the coloured shirts worn by people riding horses in a race (= jockeys)

examples.en: ladies in silks and satins

senses.definition: a type of lawyer who represents the government (= a King’s Counsel / Queen’s Counsel)

examples.en: to take silk (= to become this type of lawyer)

idioms.word: (you can't) make a silk purse out of a sow’s ear

senses.definition: (you won't) succeed in making something good out of material that does not seem very good at all
showing a lack of thought, understanding, or judgement

examples.en: a silly idea/question/name
That was a silly thing to do!
It sounds silly, I know, but think about it.
Her work is full of silly mistakes.
‘I can walk home.’ ‘Don't be silly—it's much too far!’
The answers they give are plain silly.
You silly boy!

examples.cf: it is silly to do something
examples.en: It would have been silly to pretend that I wasn't upset.

examples.cf: it is silly of somebody to do something
examples.en: It would be silly of me to say no.
How silly of me to expect them to help!

senses.definition: stupid or embarrassing, especially in a way that is more typical of a child than an adult

examples.en: a silly sense of humour
a silly game
He would never dance in case he looked silly.
I feel silly in these clothes.
She had a silly grin on her face.

senses.definition: not practical or serious

examples.en: We had to wear these silly little hats.

idioms.word: bored stiff/silly | bored to death/tears | bored out of your mind

senses.definition: extremely bored

examples.en: I remember being bored stiff during my entire time at school.
She enjoys it. Everyone else is bored silly.
