She was alone all day and bored to death.

idioms.word: drink, laugh, shout, etc. yourself silly

senses.definition: to drink, laugh, shout, etc. so much that you cannot behave in a sensible way
to not be honest with somebody, especially in order to gain an advantage over them

examples.en: Don't play silly games with me; I know you did it.

senses.definition: to behave in a stupid and annoying way

examples.en: Stop playing silly buggers and give me a hand with this!

variants.html: (British English also silly billy)

senses.definition: often used when speaking to children to say that they are not behaving in a sensible way

examples.en: No, silly, those aren't your shoes!

senses.definition: a chemical element. Silver is a shiny, grey-white precious metal used for making coins, jewellery, beautiful objects, etc.

examples.en: a silver ring/chain
made of solid silver
a silver mine

senses.definition: a shiny grey-white colour

examples.en: There was a streak of silver in her hair.
the shimmering silver of the moon

senses.definition: dishes, beautiful objects, etc. that are made of silver

examples.en: Thieves stole £5 000 worth of silver.
They've had to sell the family silver to pay the bills.

senses.definition: coins that are made of silver or a metal that looks like silver

examples.en: I need £2 in silver for the parking meter.

variants.html: (also silver medal [countable])

senses.definition: a medal that is given to the person or the team that wins the second prize in a race or competition

examples.en: She won silver in last year's championships.
The team won two silvers and a bronze.

idioms.word: born with a silver spoon in your mouth

senses.definition: having rich parents
to give somebody money so that they will do you a favour, especially tell your fortune

idioms.word: every cloud has a silver lining

senses.definition: every sad or difficult situation has a positive side
if you are given something on a silver platter, you do not have to do much to get it

examples.en: These rich kids expect to have it all handed to them on a silver platter.

senses.definition: shiny grey-white in colour

examples.en: a silver car
silver hair

senses.definition: to cover the surface of something with a thin layer of silver or something that looks like silver
to make something become bright like silver

examples.en: Moonlight was silvering the countryside.

senses.definition: like somebody/something but not exactly the same

examples.en: We have very similar interests.
The experiment was repeated, with similar results.
I came across a similar situation last year.
The brothers look very similar.
The three portraits are remarkably similar.
My teaching style is similar to that of most other teachers.
The case is strikingly similar to another case from the 1990s.
The two houses are similar in size.
All the narratives follow a similar pattern.
The disease attacks the immune system in a similar way to AIDS.
She easily won today, and hopes to carry on in a similar vein tomorrow.
Stir the paint with a piece of wood or something similar.

senses.definition: the state of being similar to somebody/something but not exactly the same

examples.en: The report highlights the similarity between the two groups.
She bears a striking similarity to her mother.
There is some similarity in the way they sing.
In this work we can observe the stylistic similarity with Beethoven.
The results also showed the similarity of the two groups.
They are both doctors but that is where the similarity ends.

senses.definition: a feature that things or people have that makes them like each other

examples.en: a study of the similarities and differences between the two countries

The karate bout has many similarities to a boxing match.

senses.definition: in almost the same way

examples.en: It is a little cheaper than other similarly sized cars.
He has a similarly impressive record in the sport.
Husband and wife were similarly successful in their chosen careers.
The different groups of women in the study responded similarly.
All sections of society were similarly affected by the war.
Phosphorus behaves similarly to nitrogen.

senses.definition: used to say that two facts, actions, statements, etc. are like each other

examples.en: The United States won most of the track and field events. Similarly, in swimming, the top three places went to Americans.

senses.definition: not complicated; easy to understand or do

examples.en: a simple solution/explanation/question/task/example
You will soon see that what once seemed impossible is now simple for you.
This machine is very simple to use.

examples.cf: something is simple for somebody to do
examples.en: The game is supposed to be simple for anyone to play.

examples.cf: it is simple to do something
examples.en: It's too simple to blame the lack of manufacturing jobs on the last government.
Give the necessary information but keep it simple.

examples.cf: it is simple for somebody to do something
examples.en: It would be much simpler for me to go there myself and sort things out.
We lost because we played badly. It's as simple as that.
If you enjoy your workout, you'll want to do it. It's that simple.
It all sounds simple enough.
Let me make it simple —this is going to take years to do.
These are bad guys, plain and simple.
The answer is really quite simple.
There must be a simpler way of doing this.
In simple terms, the more saturated fat something contains, the less healthy it is.
a relatively simple process

senses.definition: basic or plain without anything extra or unnecessary

examples.en: simple but elegant clothes
We had a simple meal of soup and bread.
The accommodation is simple but spacious.
The simple things in life are often the best.
He was pleased to live the simple life and enjoy nature around him.
simple pleasures, like reading and walking
The engine design is elegantly simple.
contemporary furniture that is simple in design

senses.definition: used before a noun to emphasize that it is exactly that and nothing else

examples.en: We cannot ignore the simple fact that the country cannot sustain the current level of economic growth.
The simple truth is that we just can't afford it.
It's a simple matter of giving them enough to eat.
It was a matter of simple survival.
It's nothing to worry about—just a simple headache.
I had to do it for the simple reason that (= because) I couldn't trust anyone else.
A simple majority is all that is required.
The simple act of eating raises your metabolism.

senses.definition: consisting of only a few parts; not complicated in structure

examples.en: simple forms of life, for example amoebas
a simple machine
a simple sentence (= one with only one verb)
a simple model of a business market

senses.definition: ordinary; not special

examples.en: I'm a simple country girl.
The poem describes simple young soldiers in the Civil War.

senses.definition: slow to learn; having a learning disability
used to describe the present or past tense of a verb that is formed without using an auxiliary verb, as in She loves him (= the simple present tense) or He arrived late (= the simple past tense)
used after the noun that it refers to in order to emphasize that there is nothing but the thing you have just mentioned involved in something

examples.en: It's laziness, pure and simple.
The man wants revenge, pure and simple.

senses.definition: used to emphasize how easy or basic something is

examples.en: To order, simply click here.
This is not to suggest we simply ignore the problem.
She says that the company was simply trying to protect its business.
Simply add hot water and stir.
The runway is simply a strip of grass.
Fame is often simply a matter of being in the right place at the right time.
You can enjoy all the water sports, or simply lie on the beach.
We are simply saying research is good.
Most internet users simply want information.

senses.definition: in a way that is easy to understand

examples.en: The book explains grammar simply and clearly.
Anyway, to put it simply, we still owe them £2 000.
Simply put, electronic music is anything made using technology.
Put simply, cells contain an inbuilt mechanism which determines their lifespan.

senses.definition: in a way that is natural and plain

examples.en: The rooms are simply furnished.

senses.definition: used to emphasize a statement

examples.en: You simply must see the play.
You simply have to come with us.

The view is simply wonderful!

I haven't seen her for simply ages.

examples.en: I don't want to be rude, it's simply that we have to be careful who we give this information to.

senses.definition: to be made to look like something else

examples.en: a gas heater that simulates a coal fire

senses.definition: to pretend that you have a particular feeling

examples.en: I tried to simulate surprise at the news.

examples.en: a computer simulation of how the planet functions

senses.definition: the act of pretending that something is real when it is not

examples.en: the simulation of concern

senses.definition: at the same time as something else

senses.definition: an offence against God or against a religious or moral law

senses.definition: the act of breaking a religious or moral law

examples.en: a life of sin

senses.definition: an action that people think is very bad

examples.en: It's a sin to waste taxpayers' money like that.

senses.definition: used to say that something that somebody does is like a punishment

senses.definition: to hide the real situation or facts when these are not good or pleasant

senses.definition: to live together and have a sexual relationship without being married
used to emphasize that somebody is very unhappy or ugly
to break a religious or moral law

examples.en: Forgive me, Lord, for I have sinned.

senses.definition: sine
Social Insurance number (= a number that the Canadian government uses to identify you, and that you use when you fill out official forms, apply for a job, etc.)

I haven't eaten since breakfast.

senses.definition: from an event in the past until a later past event, or until now

It's twenty years since I've seen her.

senses.definition: because; as

senses.definition: from a time in the past until a later past time, or until now

idioms.word: sing from the same hymn/song sheet

examples.en: She's always singing his praises.

senses.definition: an act of singing

examples.en: Let's have a sing.

senses.definition: a person who sings, or whose job is singing, especially in public

examples.en: She's a wonderful singer.

the band's lead singer
a singer in a German rock band

senses.definition: the activity of making musical sounds with your voice

the singing of hymns/songs/carols
choral singing

a singing teacher

senses.definition: only one

examples.en: He sent her a single red rose.

a single honours degree (= for which you study only one subject)

a single sheet (= large enough for a single bed)

senses.definition: not married or having a romantic relationship with somebody

senses.definition: a single ticket, etc. can be used for travelling to a place but not back again

variants.html: (also old-fashioned (in) Indian file)

examples.en: How much is a single to York?

senses.definition: people who are not married and do not have a romantic relationship with somebody else

senses.definition: a piece of recorded music, usually popular music, that consists of one song; a CD that a single is recorded on

a game when only one player plays against one other; a series of two or more of these games

examples.en: the women’s singles champion
the first round of the men’s singles

a hit that only allows the player to run to first base
to go down below the surface or towards the bottom of a liquid or soft substance

examples.en: The ship sank to the bottom of the sea.

We're sinking!

The little boat sank beneath the waves.

senses.definition: to damage a boat or ship so that it goes below the surface of the sea, etc.

examples.en: The battleship was sunk by a torpedo.

senses.definition: to move slowly downwards

examples.en: The sun was sinking in the west.

senses.definition: to decrease in amount, volume, strength, etc.

examples.en: The pound has sunk to its lowest recorded level against the dollar.

senses.definition: to become quieter

examples.en: Her voice sank to a whisper.

senses.definition: to make a deep hole in the ground

examples.en: to sink a well/shaft/mine

senses.definition: to place something in the ground by digging

examples.en: to sink a post into the ground

senses.definition: to prevent somebody or somebody’s plans from succeeding

senses.definition: to drink something quickly, especially a large amount of alcohol

examples.en: They sank three pints each in 10 minutes.

senses.definition: to be in a state of unhappiness or deep thought

senses.definition: an unpleasant feeling that you get when you realize that something bad has happened or is going to happen

examples.en: I had a horrible sinking feeling when I saw the ambulance outside the house.

senses.definition: to be in a situation where you will either succeed by your own efforts or fail completely

idioms.word: sink so low | sink to something

a very large number of things, probably more than is necessary

senses.definition: located in a poor area where social conditions are bad

senses.definition: used to emphasize that something is true

examples.en: That's a fine car you have. Yes sir!

senses.definition: to be in a good situation, especially when others are not

It began broadcasting in 1989 but combined with another company the following year and changed its name to BSkyB (British Sky Broadcasting). It later became Sky UK. It uses the name Sky in several digital television channels, which can only be seen by people who pay a fee each month. Most of the channels broadcast one particular type of programme and have names like Sky Sports, Sky Movies or Sky Arts. Sky also provides internet and mobile phone services.

idioms.word: be able to do something in your sleep

senses.definition: to be able to do something very easily because you have done it many times before

examples.en: I haven’t done many portraits, but I could paint landscapes in my sleep.

senses.definition: if part of your body goes to sleep, you lose the sense of feeling in it, usually because it has been in the same position for too long

examples.en: My foot’s gone to sleep.

idioms.word: not get/have a wink of sleep | not sleep a wink

senses.definition: to not be able to sleep

examples.en: I didn't get a wink of sleep last night.
I hardly slept a wink.

idioms.word: not lose sleep/lose no sleep over something

senses.definition: to not worry much about something

examples.en: It's not worth losing sleep over.
Don't lose sleep over it—we'll sort everything out in the morning.

senses.definition: to make somebody unconscious before an operation by using drugs (called an anaesthetic)
to kill a sick or injured animal by giving it drugs so that it dies without pain. People say ‘put to sleep’ to avoid saying ‘kill’.

examples.en: We had to have our dog put to sleep.

senses.definition: a thin flat piece of bread, meat, cheese, etc. that has been cut off a larger piece; a piece of cake that has been cut from a larger cake

examples.en: Cut the meat into thin slices.
a slice of bread/pie
a slice of toast/pizza
Another slice of cake, anyone?

senses.definition: a part or share of something

examples.en: Our firm is well placed to grab a large slice of the market.
The rent for my room was a large slice out of my budget.
With this win, they can claim a slice of history.
Every organization in the land has tried to claim a slice of the cash from the National Lottery.

senses.definition: a kitchen utensil (= tool) that you use to lift and serve pieces of food

examples.en: a cake slice

senses.definition: a shot that makes the ball go to one side rather than straight ahead, while turning round and round
a share or role in an interesting or exciting activity, especially one that makes money

examples.en: Foreign firms will all want a slice of the action if the new airport goes ahead.

senses.definition: a film, play or book that gives a very realistic view of ordinary life

examples.en: This drama provides a slice of life in 1950s Connecticut.

variants.text: (British English also a slice/share of the cake)
variants.html: (British English also a slice/share of the cake)

senses.definition: a share of the available money or benefits that you believe you have a right to

examples.en: The company is demanding a larger slice of the corporate pie.

senses.definition: to cut something into slices

examples.en: to slice (up) onions
Slice the cucumber thinly.
Add a few very thinly sliced red onions.
a sliced loaf
sliced bread
Trim the leeks and finely slice them.
Add 6 hot dogs sliced into pieces.

senses.definition: to cut something easily with or as if with a sharp knife

examples.en: He accidentally sliced through his finger.
A piece of glass sliced into his shoulder.
Her speech sliced through all the confusion surrounding the situation.
He sliced the fruit open.

senses.definition: to hit a ball so that it turns round and round and does not move in the expected direction

examples.en: He managed to slice a shot over the net.

senses.definition: to hit the ball so that it flies away in a curve to the right (if you are right-handed) or left (if you are left-handed), when you do not mean to
to reduce something by a large amount

examples.en: The new tax has sliced annual bonuses by 30 percent.

senses.definition: however you choose to look at a situation
to divide information into small parts in order to study it more closely or to see it in different ways

examples.en: The software lets you slice and dice the data and display it in different formats.
Once you enter the budget, you can slice and dice it in the same way as sales information.

senses.definition: to move easily over a smooth or wet surface; to make something move in this way

examples.en: As I turned left on a bend, my car started to slide.
We slid down the grassy slope.
A plane slid off the runway in Denver on Sunday.
The drawers slide in and out easily.
She slid her hand along the rail.
You can slide the front seats forward if necessary.
The automatic doors slid open.
Quietly, she slid the drawer shut.

senses.definition: to move quickly and quietly, for example in order not to be noticed; to make something move in this way

examples.en: He slid into bed.
She slid out while no one was looking.
The man slid the money quickly into his pocket.
He slid a shy look at Claire.

senses.definition: to become gradually lower or of less value

examples.en: Shares slid to a 10-year low.

senses.definition: to move gradually into a worse situation

examples.en: The industry has slid into decline.
They were sliding towards bankruptcy.
He got depressed and began to let things slide (= failed to give things the attention they needed).
The Hong Kong economy was sliding into recession.
The economy is sliding rapidly downhill.

senses.definition: one page of an electronic presentation, that may contain text and images, that is usually viewed on a computer screen or projected onto a larger screen

examples.en: Here's a slide showing target markets.
I'm still working on the slides for my presentation.
Limit the amount of text on each slide.
The numbers mentioned in the slide are based on theoretical scenarios.
a slide presentation

senses.definition: a long, smooth movement on ice or a smooth surface

examples.en: Her car went into a slide.
a front wheel slide

senses.definition: a change to a lower or worse condition

examples.en: a downward slide in the price of oil
the team’s slide down the table
talks to prevent a slide into civil war
The economy is on the slide (= getting worse).
a stock market slide

senses.definition: a structure with a steep slope that children use for sliding down

examples.en: to go down the slide

senses.definition: a sudden fall of a large amount of rock or earth down a hill

examples.en: I was afraid of starting a slide of loose stones.

senses.definition: a small piece of film held in a frame that can be shown on a screen when you shine a light through it

examples.en: a talk with colour slides

senses.definition: a small piece of glass that something is placed on so that it can be looked at under a microscope
a part of a musical instrument or other device that slides backwards and forwards
a small attractive piece of metal or plastic used by women for holding their hair in place
very small in degree

examples.en: a slight increase/change/difference
a slight variation/improvement/advantage
It won't make the slightest bit of difference
There's been a slight delay, but we'll be landing in just a few minutes.
Mexican producers may gain a slight edge in competitiveness.
A slight smile appeared on her lips.
I woke up with a slight headache.
The damage was slight.
She takes offence at the slightest thing (= is very easily offended).
There was not the slightest hint of trouble.
He is, without the slightest doubt, the greatest living novelist.
He never had the slightest intention of agreeing to it.
The picture was at a slight angle.
A slight breeze was blowing.

senses.definition: small and thin in size

examples.en: a slight woman
He was of slight build.
She was smaller and slighter than I had imagined.

senses.definition: not deserving serious attention

examples.en: This is a very slight novel.

senses.definition: not at all

examples.en: He didn't seem to mind in the slightest.
I’m not in the slightest bit interested.

senses.definition: an act or a remark that criticizes something or offends somebody

examples.en: Nick took her comment as a slight on his abilities as a manager.

senses.definition: to treat somebody rudely or without respect

examples.en: She felt slighted because she hadn't been invited.

senses.definition: a little

examples.en: a slightly different version
slightly higher/lower/larger/smaller
She earns slightly less than $100  000 a year.
She smiled slightly, as if she were hiding something.
slightly better/older
We took a slightly more direct route.
There is a slightly increased risk of chest infection after the procedure.
I knew her slightly.
‘Are you worried?’ ‘Only slightly.’

senses.definition: a slightly built person is small and thin
to slide a short distance by accident so that you fall or nearly fall

examples.en: She slipped and landed flat on her back.
As I ran up the stairs, my foot slipped and I fell.
She got on her feet and ran towards the door, slipping and sliding.
He slipped on a bar of soap in the shower room.
She slipped over on the ice and broke her leg.

senses.definition: to slide out of position or out of your hand

examples.en: My hand slipped as I was slicing the bread and I cut myself.
His hat had slipped over one eye.
The fish slipped out of my hand.
The child slipped from his grasp and ran off.
She was careful not to let her control slip.

senses.definition: to go somewhere quickly and quietly, especially without being noticed

examples.en: She slipped out of the house before the others were awake.
I slipped away before the end of the performance.
The ship slipped into the harbour at night.
A guard was posted at the door, in case anyone tried to slip in.
She knew that time was slipping away.

senses.definition: to put something somewhere quickly, quietly or secretly

examples.en: Anna slipped her hand into his.
He slipped the letter back into its envelope.
He beat three defenders before slipping the ball past the goalkeeper.
She slipped her head around the door.
I managed to slip a few jokes into my speech.
I managed to slip in a few jokes.
I slipped the ring onto my finger.
They'd slipped some money to the guards.
They'd slipped the guards some money.

senses.definition: to fall to a lower level; to become worse

examples.en: Standards have slipped in the last few years.
His popularity has slipped recently.
The director never lets the tension slip.
That's three times she's beaten me—I must be slipping!
A defeat would see them slip down the rankings.
At that time the Conservatives were slipping in the polls.
Pre-tax profits slipped from $3.9 million to $3.7 million,.

senses.definition: to pass into a particular state or situation, especially a difficult or unpleasant one

examples.en: He began to slip into debt.
The patient had slipped into a coma.
We seem to have slipped behind schedule.

senses.definition: to put clothes on or to take them off quickly and easily

examples.en: to slip into/out of a dress
to slip your shoes on/off
He slipped a coat over his sweatshirt.

senses.definition: to get free; to make something/somebody/yourself free from something

examples.en: The ship had slipped its moorings in the night.
The dog slipped its collar.
The animal had slipped free and escaped.

senses.definition: to give somebody information that is supposed to be secret

examples.en: I happened to let it slip that he had given me £1 000 for the car.
She tried not to let slip what she knew.

senses.definition: to miss or fail to use an opportunity

examples.en: Don't let the chance to work abroad slip through your fingers.

senses.definition: (to become) out of control

examples.en: She said nothing in case her temper slipped out of gear.

senses.definition: to be easy to say or pronounce

examples.en: It's not a name that exactly trips off the tongue, is it?

senses.definition: if something slips your mind, you forget it or forget to do it

examples.en: I’m sorry I didn’t tell you. It completely slipped my mind.

senses.definition: to be easy to say or pronounce

examples.en: It's not a name that exactly slips off the tongue, is it?

senses.definition: to trick somebody

variants.html: (also fall/slip through the cracks)

senses.definition: when somebody/something slips through the net, an organization or a system fails to find them and deal with them

examples.en: We tried to contact all former students, but one or two slipped through the net.

senses.definition: a small mistake, usually made by being careless or not paying attention

examples.en: He recited the whole poem without making a single slip.
There were a few slips in the translation.

senses.definition: a small piece of paper, especially one for writing on or with something printed on it

examples.en: I wrote it down on a slip of paper.
a betting slip

senses.definition: an act of slipping

examples.en: One slip and you could fall to your death.

senses.definition: a piece of underwear like a thin dress or skirt, worn under a dress
a player who stands behind and to one side of the batter and tries to catch the ball; the position on the field where this player stands

examples.en: fielding in the slips

senses.definition: to get away from somebody who is following or running after you

examples.en: I managed to give him the slip by hiding behind a wall.

idioms.word: a slip of a boy, girl, etc.

senses.definition: a small or thin, usually young, person

examples.en: I was only a slip of a thing at the time.

senses.definition: a small mistake in something that you write or say

examples.en: Did I call you Richard? Sorry, Robert, just a slip of the tongue.
I didn't mean to say that—it was just a slip of the tongue.

idioms.word: there’s many a slip ’twixt cup and lip

senses.definition: nothing is completely certain until it really happens because things can easily go wrong

variants.html: (also informal tag line)

senses.definition: a word or phrase that is easy to remember, used for example by a political party or in advertising to attract people’s attention or to suggest an idea quickly

examples.en: an advertising slogan
a campaign slogan
The crowd began chanting anti-government slogans.

senses.definition: a surface or piece of land that slopes (= is higher at one end than the other)

examples.en: The town is built on a slope.
Down the slope and beyond the road lay the Pacific Ocean.
He made his way up the slope from the station to the bus stop.
a grassy slope

senses.definition: an area of land that is part of a mountain or hill

examples.en: the eastern slopes of the Andes
ski slopes
We camped on an open mountain slope.
He spends all winter on the slopes (= skiing).
There were more skiers further up the slope.
There was now molten lava several hundred metres down the slope.

senses.definition: the amount by which something slopes

examples.en: a steep slope
a gentle slope
a slope of 45 degrees
Because of the slope of the roof, the snow cannot accumulate.
the angle of slope

senses.definition: a course of action that is difficult to stop once it has begun, and can lead to serious problems or disaster

examples.en: She realized he was on the slippery slope towards a life of crime.

senses.definition: to be at an angle so that it is higher at one end than the other

examples.en: a sloping roof
sloping shoulders
The bedroom floors all sloped.
The garden slopes away towards the river.
The path sloped gently down.
It is a lake with steeply sloping sides.

senses.definition: to be at an angle rather than going straight up or straight across

examples.en: It was a very old house with sloping walls.
His handwriting slopes backwards.

senses.definition: a long, narrow opening, into which you put or fit something

examples.en: to put some coins in the slot

senses.definition: a position, a time or an opportunity for somebody/something, for example in a list, a programme of events or a series of broadcasts

examples.en: He has a regular slot on the late-night programme.
Their album has occupied the Number One slot for the past six weeks.
the airport’s take-off and landing slots

senses.definition: to put something into a space that is available or designed for it; to fit into such a space

examples.en: The bed comes in sections that can be quickly slotted together.
The dishwasher slots neatly between the cupboards.
These tubes slot together like this.

senses.definition: if something complicated or difficult to understand slots or falls into place, it becomes organized or clear in your mind

examples.en: Then I found his diary and it all began to slot into place.

senses.definition: not moving, acting or done quickly; taking a long time; not fast

examples.en: a slow pace/speed
Average earnings are rising at their slowest rate for 20 years.
a slow driver
Progress was slower than expected.
The country is experiencing slow but steady economic growth.
Collecting data is a painfully slow process.
Oh you're so slow; come on, hurry up!
a slow, lingering death
The slow movement opens with a cello solo.
For the third game in a row City made a slow start.
She gave a slow smile.

senses.definition: not going or allowing you to go at a fast speed

examples.en: I missed the fast train and had to get the slow one (= the one that stops at all the stations).

senses.definition: hesitating to do something or not doing something immediately

examples.en: She wasn't slow to realize what was going on.
The world's governments have been slow to respond to global environmental challenges.
Some insurance companies are particularly slow in processing claims.
His poetry was slow in achieving recognition.
The company has been too slow in upgrading its computer systems.
They were very slow paying me.

senses.definition: not quick to learn; finding things hard to understand

examples.en: He's the slowest in the class.

senses.definition: not very busy; containing little action

examples.en: Sales are slow (= not many goods are being sold).
There are slow passages in which little happens, but they help to build up the suspense.

senses.definition: showing a time earlier than the correct time

examples.en: My watch is five minutes slow (= it shows 1.45 when it is 1.50).

senses.definition: slow film is not very sensitive to light
to be quick/slow to understand something

examples.en: Is he always this slow on the uptake?

senses.definition: to slowly get angry
fast/slow in reacting to a situation

examples.en: If you’re quick off the mark in answering these questions, you could win a prize.
The government was slow off the mark in responding to the crisis.

senses.definition: to go or to make something/somebody go at a slower speed or be less active

examples.en: Economic growth has slowed a little.
The bus slowed to a halt.
He has been slowed by a knee injury.
The car slowed down as it approached the junction.
indications that the US economy is slowing down
You must slow down (= work less hard) or you'll make yourself ill.
The game slowed up a little in the second half.
Economic data for last month shows steps taken by the government are slowing growth.
We hope to slow the spread of the disease.
The ice on the roads was slowing us down.
He accused the government of intentionally slowing down the process.
Sending this file over the network to the printer may slow up the whole network.

senses.definition: at a slow speed

examples.en: Could you go a little slower?
slow-drying paint
slow-moving traffic
Drive slow!

senses.definition: to show less enthusiasm for achieving something

examples.en: The government is going slow on tax reforms.

senses.definition: at a slow speed; not quickly

examples.en: to move/walk/turn slowly
Please could you speak more slowly?
The boat chugged slowly along.
Don't rush into a decision. Take it slowly.
‘I don't really know,’ Anna said slowly.
Slowly things began to improve.
The film starts slowly, introducing each of the characters and establishing their relationships.
He found that life moved slowly in the countryside.

senses.definition: making slow but definite progress

examples.en: We'll get there slowly but surely.

senses.definition: not large in size, number, degree, amount, etc.

examples.en: a small town/village/community
A much smaller number of students passed than I had expected.
a small amount/percentage/sample
a small group/minority
Because of the small size of the sample, findings cannot be generalized.
They're having a relatively small wedding.
That dress is too small for you.
The cheeses are produced locally and only on a small scale.
a small part/piece/portion
a small area/country/island
a small house/room/car
small animals
a small man
The world seems so small now.
With just under 600 residents, it was small for a city.
‘I don't agree,’ he said in a small (= quiet) voice.

senses.definition: used to describe one size in a range of sizes of clothes, food, products used in the house, etc.

examples.en: The T-shirts come in small, medium and large.
This is too big—have you got a small one?

senses.definition: not as big as something else of the same kind

examples.en: the small intestine

senses.definition: young

examples.en: They have three small children.
We travelled around a lot when I was small.
As a small boy he had spent most of his time with his grandparents.

senses.definition: slight; not important

examples.en: I made only a few small changes to the report.
She noticed several small errors in his work.
Everything had been planned down to the smallest detail.
It was no small achievement getting her to agree to the deal.
Don’t worry. It’s only a small problem.
Can I ask you a small favour?

senses.definition: not doing business on a very large scale

examples.en: small companies/firms
The government is planning to give more help to small businesses.
a small farmer
small investors
Employers, large and small, face massive fines.

senses.definition: not written or printed as capitals

examples.en: Should I write ‘god’ with a small ‘g’ or a capital?
She's a socialist with a small ‘s’ (= she has socialist ideas but is not a member of a socialist party).

senses.definition: little; not much

examples.en: The government has small cause for optimism.
They have small hope of succeeding.

senses.definition: to be happy that a situation that is bad is not as bad as it could have been

examples.en: Well, at least you weren't hurt. I suppose we should be grateful for small mercies.

idioms.word: a big fish (in a small pond)

senses.definition: an important person (in a small community)
used to tell somebody not to worry about small details or things that are not important
of all sizes or types

examples.en: all creatures great and small

senses.definition: on a large/small scale

examples.en: The new delivery service has taken off in a big way.
Many people are investing in a small way in the stock market.
He then started spending money in a big way.

senses.definition: used to express your surprise when you meet somebody you know in an unexpected place, or when you are talking to somebody and find out that you both know the same person
to look or feel stupid, weak, ashamed, etc.

examples.en: There’s no need to make me look small in front of all these people.
I felt really small when I realized how much time he’d spent on it.

senses.definition: it is not surprising

examples.en: It is little wonder (that) she was so upset.
No wonder you're tired—you've been walking for hours.
No wonder you're still single—you never go out!

variants.text: (also especially Scottish English the wee small hours, especially North American English the wee hours)
variants.html: (also especially Scottish English the wee small hours, especially North American English the wee hours)

senses.definition: the period of time very early in the morning, soon after midnight

examples.en: We worked well into the small hours.
The fighting began in the early hours of Saturday morning.
The party continued well into the early hours.

senses.definition: it is not surprising

examples.en: It is small wonder (that) she was so upset.
No wonder you're tired—you've been walking for hours.

senses.definition: the voice of God or your conscience, that tells you to do what is morally right
into small pieces

examples.en: Chop the cabbage up small.

senses.definition: in a small size

examples.en: You can fit it all in if you write very small.

senses.definition: the lower part of the back where it curves in

examples.en: He felt a sharp pain in the small of his back.

senses.definition: small items of clothing, especially underwear
looking clean and neat; well dressed in fashionable and/or formal clothes

examples.en: I have to be smart for work.
You look very smart in that suit.
She was incredibly smart in navy blue silk.

senses.definition: clean, neat and looking new and attractive

examples.en: a smart suit
They were wearing their smartest clothes.

senses.definition: intelligent

examples.en: He is obviously a smart guy.
Why do smart people do such stupid things?
She's smarter than her brother.
That was a smart career move.
OK, I admit it was not the smartest thing I ever did (= it was a stupid thing to do)
He is too ambitious, too smart for his own good.

examples.cf: it is smart to do something
examples.en: It's always smart to have a Plan B.

senses.definition: controlled by a computer, so that it appears to act in an intelligent way

examples.en: smart bombs
This smart washing machine will dispense an optimal amount of water for the load.

senses.definition: connected with fashionable, rich people

examples.en: smart restaurants
She mixes with the smart set (= fashionable, rich people).

senses.definition: quick and usually done with force

examples.en: He was struck with a smart crack on the head.
We set off at a smart pace.

senses.definition: to feel a sharp pain in a part of your body

examples.en: His eyes were smarting from the smoke.

I rubbed my smarting eyes.

senses.definition: to feel upset about a criticism, failure, etc.

examples.en: They are still smarting from the 4–0 defeat last week.
He is still smarting over his humiliation in the election.

senses.definition: a mobile phone that also has some of the functions of a computer, for example the facility to use apps and the internet

examples.en: You can use your smartphone to access the internet.
The smartphone supports Wi-Fi networking.

senses.definition: to break something, or to be broken, violently and noisily into many pieces

examples.en: Several windows had been smashed.
He smashed the radio to pieces.
The glass bowl smashed into a thousand pieces.

senses.definition: to move with a lot of force against something solid; to make something do this

examples.en: the sound of waves smashing against the rocks
The car smashed into a tree.
Mark smashed his fist down on the desk.

senses.definition: to hit something very hard and break it, in order to get through it

examples.en: They had to smash holes in the ice.
The elephant smashed its way through the trees.
We had to smash the door open.
They had smashed through a glass door to get in.

senses.definition: to hit something/somebody very hard

examples.en: He smashed the ball into the goal.

senses.definition: to break a record by a large amount

examples.en: She has smashed the world record.

senses.definition: to destroy, defeat or put an end to something/somebody

examples.en: Police say they have smashed a major drugs ring.

senses.definition: to crash a vehicle

examples.en: He’s smashed (up) his new car.

senses.definition: to hit a high ball downwards and very hard over the net
to do something very well or be very successful

examples.en: After all that training, I’m sure he’ll smash it in the competition tonight.

senses.definition: an act of breaking something noisily into pieces; the sound this makes

examples.en: The cup hit the floor with a smash.
He heard the smash of breaking glass.

senses.definition: an accident in which a vehicle hits another vehicle

examples.en: a car smash

senses.definition: a way of hitting the ball downwards and very hard

examples.en: He can hit a powerful overhead smash.
He misses a smash to hand Thiem a 5–0 lead.

senses.definition: a song, film or play that is very popular

examples.en: her latest chart smash

senses.definition: to have a particular smell

examples.en: The room smelt damp.
Dinner smells good.
‘You smell nice,’ Aidan said with a smile.
a bunch of sweet-smelling flowers

When he did come home, he smelled of alcohol.

The crisp air smells like clean hay.

senses.definition: to notice or recognize a particular smell

examples.en: I was watching television when I smelled smoke.

The dog had smelt a rabbit.
I could smell alcohol on his breath.
Snow fell so that you could almost smell the cold.
Can you smell something burning?
As she came downstairs, she smelled bacon cooking.
I could smell that something was burning.

senses.definition: to be able to notice and recognize smells

examples.en: I can't smell because I've got a bad cold.
I can't smell anything because I've got a bad cold.

senses.definition: to put your nose near something and breathe in so that you can discover or identify its smell

examples.en: Smell this and tell me what you think it is.

senses.definition: to have an unpleasant smell

examples.en: The drains smell.
Does my breath smell?
He hadn't washed for days and was beginning to smell.
After a few days, the meat began to smell.
It smells in here.
It smells awful in here.

senses.definition: to feel that something exists or is going to happen

examples.en: He smelt danger.
I can smell trouble.

idioms.word: come up/out of something smelling of roses

senses.definition: to still have a good reputation, even though you have been involved in something that might have given people a bad opinion of you

examples.en: Nobody ever knew the details and he came out of the deal smelling of roses.

idioms.word: a rose by any other name would smell as sweet

senses.definition: what is important is what people or things are, not what they are called
to suspect that something is wrong about a situation

idioms.word: wake up and smell the coffee

senses.definition: used to tell somebody to become aware of what is really happening in a situation, especially when this is something unpleasant
the quality of something that people and animals sense through their noses

examples.en: a sweet/pleasant smell
a foul/pungent/musty smell
the air fresheners that we use to cover up unpleasant smells
a faint/strong smell of garlic
an acrid smell of smoke
There was a smell of burning in the air.
I love the smell of freshly baked bread.
The air is heavy with the smell of rain and moist vegetation.
The smells from the kitchen filled the room.

senses.definition: an unpleasant smell

examples.en: What's that smell?
Yuk! What a smell!
See if you can get rid of the smell.

senses.definition: the ability to sense things with the nose

examples.en: Dogs have a very good sense of smell.
Taste and smell are closely connected.

senses.definition: the act of smelling something

examples.en: He took one smell of the liquid and his eyes began to water.

senses.definition: the pleasant feeling of being successful
to make a smile appear on your face

examples.en: to smile slightly/broadly
to smile sweetly/warmly/brightly

to solve an issue/a crisis
You can't solve anything by just running away.
I hope that he can find a good way to solve these problems.

senses.definition: to find the correct answer or explanation for something

examples.en: to solve an equation/a puzzle
to solve a crime/mystery
to solve a riddle/conundrum
The police have appealed for help in solving the case.

senses.definition: a person who is not known or mentioned by name

examples.en: Somebody should have told me.

senses.definition: an important person

examples.en: She thinks she's really somebody in that car.

variants.text: (also North American English, informal someway, someways)
variants.html: (also North American English, informal someway, someways)

senses.definition: in a way that is not known or certain

examples.en: We must stop him from seeing her somehow.
Somehow or other I must get a new job.

senses.definition: for a reason that you do not know or understand

examples.en: Somehow, I don't feel I can trust him.

senses.definition: a person who is not known or mentioned by name

examples.en: There's someone at the door.
Someone's left their bag behind.
It's time for someone new (= a new person) to take over.
It couldn't have been me—it must have been someone else (= a different person).
Should we call a doctor or someone?

senses.definition: an important person

examples.en: He was a small-time lawyer keen to be someone.

senses.definition: a thing that is not known or mentioned by name

examples.en: We stopped for something to eat.
Give me something to do.
There's something wrong with the TV.
There's something about this place that frightens me.
Don't just stand there. Do something!
His name is Alan something (= I don't know his other name).
She's a professor of something or other (= I'm not sure what) at Leeds.
He's something in (= has a job connected with) television.

senses.definition: a thing that is thought to be important or worth taking notice of

examples.en: There's something in (= some truth or some fact or opinion worth considering in) what he says.
It's quite something (= a thing that you should feel happy about) to have a job at all these days.
‘We should finish by tomorrow.’ ‘That's something (= a good thing), anyway.’

senses.definition: used to show that a description or an amount, etc. is not exact

examples.en: She called at something after ten o'clock.
a new comedy aimed at thirty-somethings (= people between thirty and forty years old)

The programme's something to do with (= in some way about) the environment.

senses.definition: to be successful in life
a different thing; another thing

examples.en: He said something else that I thought was interesting.

senses.definition: a person, a thing or an event that is much better than others of a similar type

examples.en: I've seen some fine players, but she's something else.

senses.definition: used with an adjective to emphasize a statement

examples.en: She was swearing something terrible.

senses.definition: at a time that you do not know exactly or has not yet been decided

examples.en: I saw him sometime last summer.
We must get together sometime.

senses.definition: used to refer to what somebody used to be

examples.en: Thomas Atkins, sometime vicar of this parish

senses.definition: used to refer to what somebody does occasionally

examples.en: a sometime contributor to this magazine

senses.definition: occasionally rather than all of the time

examples.en: Sometimes I go by car.

senses.definition: to some degree

examples.en: somewhat different/similar

The situation has changed somewhat since we last met.

variants.html: (North American English also someplace)

senses.definition: in, at or to a place that you do not know or do not mention by name

examples.en: I read somewhere that she refuses to do interviews.

senses.definition: to make progress in what you are doing
approximately the number or amount mentioned

examples.en: It cost somewhere around two thousand dollars.

variants.html: (North American English also someplace)

senses.definition: a place that you do not know or do not mention by name

examples.en: We need to find somewhere to live.
I know somewhere we can go.

senses.definition: a person’s male child

examples.en: their four-year-old son
my teenage/eldest son
her young/baby son

the birth/death of a son

senses.definition: a friendly form of address that is used by an older man to a young man or boy

examples.en: Well, son, how can I help you?

senses.definition: a man who belongs to a particular place or country, etc.

examples.en: one of France’s most famous sons
a native son of Philadelphia

senses.definition: used by a priest to address a boy or man
Jesus Christ as the second member of the Trinity

examples.en: the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit

senses.definition: a performer, politician, sports player, etc., who is popular where they were born
(in the US) a candidate for president who is supported by his or her own state in the first part of a campaign
from one generation of a family to the next
used to say that a son’s character or behaviour is similar to that of his father
a person who leaves home and wastes their money and time on a life of pleasure, but who later is sorry about this and returns home
a short piece of music with words that you sing

examples.en: a love/pop/rock song

the theme song to the hit TV show
a hit/popular/traditional song
to write/record/perform/play a song
to listen to/hear a song

the best song on the album
songs about love
a song of praise/love
a collection of songs by various artists

senses.definition: songs in general; music for singing

examples.en: The story is told through song and dance.

I hate it when characters break into song (= start to sing) for no apparent reason.

senses.definition: the musical sounds that birds make

examples.en: the song of the blackbird

senses.definition: very cheaply; at a low price

examples.en: She bought the painting for a song.

senses.definition: working or performing well

examples.en: The whole team was on song.

idioms.word: sing from the same hymn/song sheet

senses.definition: to show that you are in agreement with each other by saying the same things in public
if you make a song and dance about something, you complain or talk about it too much when this is not necessary

examples.en: She gives generously to charity without making a song and dance about it.

senses.definition: a long explanation about something, or excuse for something
in a short time from now; a short time after something else has happened

examples.en: She sold the house soon after her husband died.
Soon afterwards, he joined a youth theatre group.
I'd love to meet up again sometime soon.
I soon realized the mistake.

We’ll be home soon./We’ll soon be home.

senses.definition: early; quickly

examples.en: How soon can you get here?

Please send it as soon as possible.

senses.definition: used in negative sentences and questions to refer to the near future

examples.en: Will she be back anytime soon?

examples.en: I'd just as soon stay at home as go out tonight.

idioms.word: I, etc. would sooner do something (than something else)

senses.definition: to prefer to do something (than do something else)

examples.en: She'd sooner share a house with other students than live at home with her parents.

senses.definition: a bad situation will pass or be forgotten most quickly if nothing more is said about it
used to say that something was, or will be, done immediately
used to say that something happens immediately after something else

examples.en: No sooner had she said it than she burst into tears.

senses.definition: very soon; as soon as possible

examples.en: ‘When shall I tell him?’ ‘The sooner the better.’

senses.definition: at some time in the future, even if you are not sure exactly when

examples.en: Sooner or later you will have to make a decision.

senses.definition: after a short time rather than after a long time

examples.en: We urged them to sort out the problem sooner rather than later.

senses.definition: clever and complicated in the way that it works or is presented

senses.definition: having a lot of experience of the world and knowing about fashion, culture and other things that people think are socially important

senses.definition: able to understand difficult or complicated ideas

examples.en: a sophisticated audience

senses.definition: feeling sad and ashamed about something that has been done

examples.en: We're very sorry about the damage to your car.

If you say you're sorry we'll forgive you.

senses.definition: to be sad or feel sympathy for somebody

examples.en: I'm sorry, I don't agree.

senses.definition: used for introducing bad news

examples.en: I'm sorry to have to tell you you've failed.

senses.definition: used for saying that something is disappointing

senses.definition: used when you are apologizing for something

examples.en: Sorry? Could you repeat the question?

senses.definition: used for correcting yourself when you have said something wrong

senses.definition: a particular type of person

senses.definition: the process of putting data in a particular order

senses.definition: to express feelings or opinions of a particular kind

senses.definition: good and accurate, but not excellent

examples.en: a sound piece of writing

chicken/vegetable/tomato soup
a soup spoon/bowl/plate
a tin/packet of soup

canned/packaged soups

senses.definition: in trouble
