senses.definition: an area or a place that is empty

examples.en: an empty space
a large/small/narrow/wide space
a space two metres by three metres
He reversed out of the parking space.
We were crowded together in a confined space.
They cram hundreds of animals into a tiny space.
Put it in the space between the table and the wall.
I'll clear a space for your books.
The sculpture occupies a space in the centre of the campus.

senses.definition: an amount of an area or of a place that is empty or that is available for use

examples.en: We have 50  000 square metres of floor space.
Different brands compete for shelf space.
Houses were built close together with almost no empty space between them.
We must make good use of the available space.
That desk takes up too much space.
Traffic tends to expand to fill the space available.
There is very little storage space in the department.
Arrive early because space is limited.
This creates space for a bigger table.
Can we make space for one more person?
disk/memory space (= on a computer or device)

senses.definition: a place, especially a room or a building, that can be used for a particular purpose

examples.en: The venue is a great space for music.
various gallery and exhibition spaces
to rent/lease (a) space
He was sharing office space with a lawyer.
The business began to occupy more space.

senses.definition: the quality of being large and empty, allowing you to move freely

examples.en: The room has been furnished and decorated to give a feeling of space.
We're enjoying the space here after living in a small flat.

senses.definition: a large area of land that has no buildings on it

examples.en: the wide open spaces of the Canadian prairies
protection for our parks and other green spaces
It's a city with fine buildings and plenty of open space.
Green space is important in the urban environment.

senses.definition: a period of time

examples.en: Leave a space of two weeks between appointments.
Forty-four people died in the space of five days.
They had achieved a lot in a short space of time.

senses.definition: the part of a line, page or document that is empty

examples.en: Don't waste space by leaving a wide margin.
There was not enough space to print all the letters we received.
Leave a space after the comma.

senses.definition: the freedom and the time to think or do what you want to

examples.en: She was upset and needed space.
You have to give teenagers plenty of space.

senses.definition: the whole area in which all things exist and move

examples.en: It is quite possible that space and time are finite.
the fabric of space and time

senses.definition: an area of business in which a person or an organization operates

examples.en: His investments have focused on the healthcare space.
Right now, the team is primarily at work on products within the mobile space.

idioms.word: be in a good, bad, dark, etc. place

variants.text: (also less frequent be in a good, bad, dark, etc. space)
variants.html: (also less frequent be in a good, bad, dark, etc. space)

senses.definition: to be feeling happy, sad, worried, etc. about something; to be in a good, bad, unhappy, etc. state

examples.en: I'm happy now. I'm in a good place.
Me and Ed are in a good space right now.
The economy is in a better place than it was a year ago.
He was in a bad place, mentally and emotionally.
She was in a dark place after her mother's death.

senses.definition: to look straight in front of you without looking at a particular thing, usually because you are thinking about something

examples.en: He sat staring into space, like a man in a trance.
She sat there motionless, staring into space.

senses.definition: a person who is not useful or good at anything

examples.en: You are a pathetic waste of space!

senses.definition: used in orders, to tell somebody to wait for more news about something to be announced

examples.en: I can't tell you any more right now, but watch this space.

senses.definition: to arrange things so that they have regular spaces between them

examples.en: evenly spaced plants
a row of closely spaced dots
Space the posts about a metre apart.

senses.definition: advertising material sent by email to people who have not asked for it; advertising material on the internet that is not wanted

examples.en: to send/block spam
I get thousands of spam emails each month.
Tougher laws and improved spam filters can help cut down on spam reaching your inbox.
The guidelines warn against posting spam.

senses.definition: cooked meat that has been cut up in very small pieces that are pressed together in a container, usually sold in cans and served cold in slices
to send the same message to large numbers of internet users who have not requested the information

examples.en: Some companies will keep spamming you until you change your email address.
Some idiot has been spamming my blog with comments.

senses.definition: to last all through a period of time or to cover the whole of it

examples.en: His acting career spanned 55 years.
Family photos spanning five generations were stolen.

senses.definition: to include a large area or a lot of things

examples.en: The operation, which spanned nine countries, resulted in 200 arrests.
His experience spanned not merely politics, but also business and journalism.

senses.definition: to stretch right across something, from one side to the other

examples.en: a series of bridges spanning the river
The roof was spanned by curved ribs of steel.

senses.definition: the length of time that something lasts or is able to continue

examples.en: I worked with him over a span of six years.
The project must be completed within a specific time span.
a study of the entire span of Arab history

senses.definition: a range or variety of something

examples.en: Managers have a wide span of control.
These forests cover a broad span of latitudes.

senses.definition: the part of a bridge or an arch between one support and another

examples.en: The bridge crosses the river in a single span.

senses.definition: the measurement of something from one side to the other

examples.en: The kite has a span of 1.5 metres.

variants.html: (also spic and span)

senses.definition: neat and clean

examples.en: Their house is always spick and span.

senses.definition: available to do what you want with rather than work

examples.en: He's studying music in his spare time.
I haven't had a spare moment this morning.

senses.definition: that is not being used or is not needed at the present time

examples.en: We've got a spare bedroom, if you'd like to stay.
I'm afraid I haven't got any spare cash.
Are there any tickets going spare (= are there any available, not being used by somebody else)?

senses.definition: kept in case you need to replace the one you usually use; extra

examples.en: a spare key/tyre
Take some spare clothes in case you get wet.

senses.definition: thin, and usually quite tall
to become very angry or upset

examples.en: Your mum would go spare if she knew!
I’ll go spare if I don’t get out of the house soon!

senses.definition: to make something such as time or money available to somebody or for something, especially when it requires an effort for you to do this

examples.en: I'd love to have a break, but I can't spare the time just now.
Could you spare one of your staff to help us out?
We can only spare one room for you.
You should spare a thought for (= think about) the person who cleans up after you.
He was late, but he spared a glance for the pretty girl at the desk.
Surely you can spare me a few minutes?

senses.definition: to save somebody/yourself from having to go through an unpleasant experience

examples.en: He wanted to spare his mother any anxiety.
Please spare me (= do not tell me) the gruesome details.
You could have spared yourself an unnecessary trip by phoning in advance.
She was spared from the ordeal of appearing in court.

senses.definition: to allow somebody/something to escape harm, damage or death, especially when others do not escape it

examples.en: They killed the men but spared the children.
She begged them to spare her life.
During the bombing only one house was spared (= was not hit by a bomb).
The storm largely spared Houston and surrounding districts.
The children were spared from the virus.
Hong Kong was spared a direct hit, but the storm still brought heavy rains and powerful winds.

senses.definition: to do everything possible to achieve something or to do something well without trying to limit the time or money involved

examples.en: He spared no effort to make her happy again.
No expense was spared in furnishing the new office.

senses.definition: to work as hard as possible
to save somebody from an embarrassing situation

examples.en: A last minute goal spared their blushes.

senses.definition: to be careful not to do or say anything that might upset somebody

examples.en: I kept off the subject of divorce so as to spare her feelings.

senses.definition: if you have time, money, etc. to spare, you have more than you need

examples.en: I've got absolutely no money to spare this month.
We arrived at the airport with five minutes to spare.

senses.definition: an extra thing that you keep in case you need to replace the one you usually use (used especially about a tyre of a car)

examples.en: to get the spare out of the boot/trunk
I've lost my key and I haven't got a spare.

senses.definition: spare parts (= new parts that you buy to replace old or broken parts of a car, machine, etc.)

examples.en: It can be difficult to get spares for some older makes of car.

senses.definition: to cause something to start or develop, especially suddenly

examples.en: The proposal would spark a storm of protest around the country.
Winds brought down power lines, sparking a fire.
The organizers are hoping to spark some interest in young people.
The riots were sparked off by the arrest of a local leader.

senses.definition: to produce small flashes of fire or electricity

examples.en: a sparking, crackling fire
The game suddenly sparked to life.

senses.definition: a very small burning piece of material that is produced by something that is burning or by hitting two hard substances together

examples.en: A shower of sparks flew up the chimney.
A spark from the machinery had set fire to some material.

senses.definition: a small flash of light produced by an electric current

examples.en: sparks from a faulty light switch
A spark ignites the fuel in a car engine.

senses.definition: a small amount of a particular quality or feeling

examples.en: a spark of hope
The woman’s eyes still had a spark of life in them.

senses.definition: a special quality of energy, intelligence or enthusiasm that makes somebody very clever, funny, etc.

examples.en: As a writer he seemed to lack creative spark.
She was a real star. She had a certain spark—that something extra.

senses.definition: an action or event that causes something important to develop, especially trouble or violence

examples.en: These were the sparks of revolution.

senses.definition: feelings of anger or excitement between people

examples.en: Sparks flew at the meeting (= there was a lot of argument).
She was suddenly aware of the romantic spark between them.

senses.definition: a lively and intelligent person, especially somebody young

examples.en: Some bright spark (= stupid person) left the tap running all night.

senses.definition: to talk to somebody about something; to have a conversation with somebody

examples.en: The President refused to speak to reporters.
We never spoke about her illness.
The confidential setting allowed us to speak freely about our concerns.
I've spoken to the manager about it.
Can I speak with you for a minute?
‘Do you know him?’ ‘Not to speak to.’ (= I recognize him but do not really know him)
‘Can I speak to Susan?’ ‘Speaking.’ (= at the beginning of a phone conversation)
I saw her in the street but we didn't speak.

senses.definition: to use your voice to say something

examples.en: The illness left him unable to speak.
Please speak more slowly.
Without speaking, she stood up and went out.
He speaks with a Scottish accent.
She speaks in a husky voice.
She has a beautiful speaking voice.

senses.definition: to be able to use a particular language

examples.en: to speak several languages
to speak a little Urdu
Do you speak English?

senses.definition: to use a particular language to express yourself

examples.en: What language is it they're speaking?
Would you prefer it if we spoke in German?
What language are they speaking in?

senses.definition: speaking the language mentioned

examples.en: French-speaking Canada
non-English-speaking students

senses.definition: to mention or describe something/somebody

examples.en: She still speaks about him with great affection.
He was speaking publicly for the first time about the incident.
Witnesses spoke of a great ball of flame.
Her students speak very highly of her (= they say very good things about her).
Speaking of travelling, (= referring back to a subject just mentioned) are you going anywhere exciting this year?
The brochure speaks of beautiful secluded grounds.

senses.definition: to make a speech to an audience

examples.en: Hundreds of people came to hear her speak.
I hate speaking in public.
He was invited to speak at a conference.
to speak on the radio
Professor Todd spoke to the group about her research.
She spoke in favour of the new tax.
He has a number of speaking engagements this week.

senses.definition: to say or state something

examples.en: She was clearly speaking the truth.
He spoke the final words of the play.
They had the courage to speak the truth.

senses.definition: what a person actually does means more than what they say they will do

idioms.word: be on speaking terms (with somebody) | be speaking (to somebody)

senses.definition: to be willing to be polite or friendly towards somebody, especially after an argument

examples.en: She's not been on speaking terms with her uncle for years.
Are they speaking to each other again yet?

senses.definition: it is not necessary to give any further explanation about something because the information that is available already proves that it is true

idioms.word: generally, broadly, roughly, relatively, etc. speaking

senses.definition: used to show that what you are saying is true in a general, etc. way

examples.en: Generally speaking, the more you pay, the more you get.
There are, broadly speaking, two ways of doing this.
Personally speaking, I've always preferred Italian food.

senses.definition: if you think about it in a particular way; true in some but not all ways

examples.en: All these points of view are related, in a manner of speaking.

senses.definition: such a small amount that it is not worth mentioning

examples.en: They've got no friends to speak of.
She's saved a little money but nothing to speak of.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you are expressing something in an unusual or humorous way

examples.en: They were all very similar. All cut from the same cloth, so to speak.

senses.definition: to be so easy to see and understand that you do not need to say anything else about it/them

examples.en: Her success speaks for itself.
Recent events speak for themselves.

senses.definition: to express what you think or want yourself, rather than somebody else doing it for you

examples.en: I'm quite capable of speaking for myself, thank you!

senses.definition: used to tell somebody that a general statement they have just made is not true of you

examples.en: ‘We didn't play very well.’ ‘Speak for yourself!’ (= I think that I played well.)

senses.definition: to say or think bad things about somebody

examples.en: Don't speak ill of the dead.

senses.definition: used to say that you are the type of person mentioned and are expressing your opinion from that point of view

examples.en: Speaking as a parent, I'm very concerned about standards in education.

senses.definition: to say exactly what you think, in a very direct way

examples.en: She’s never hesitated about speaking her mind.
Everyone should have the right to speak their mind.

senses.definition: people say speak/talk of the devil when somebody they have been talking about appears unexpectedly

examples.en: Well, speak of the devil—here's Alice now!

senses.definition: to say something when you should not, for example because it is not the right time or you are not the right person to say it
to say something that you should not because it is the wrong situation or because it offends somebody
to be able to communicate easily with another person because you share similar opinions and experience
to tell you a lot about something/somebody, without the need for words

examples.en: His achievement speaks volumes for his determination.
What you wear speaks volumes about you.

senses.definition: to say good or bad things about somebody

examples.en: She never speaks ill of anyone.

senses.definition: if you are using words or rules in their exact or correct sense

examples.en: Strictly speaking, the book is not a novel, but a short story.
Using the word in that context is not, strictly speaking, correct.

senses.definition: the language used by a particular group of people, especially when it is difficult for other people to understand or they find it annoying

examples.en: Visitors to websites don't want to read marketing-speak.
His email was a nonsensical paragraph of management-speak.
Unlike his colleagues, he avoids White House speak.
The ‘finished goods inventory’—that’s Wall Street speak for unsold goods.

senses.definition: a person who gives a talk or makes a speech

examples.en: He was a guest speaker at the conference.
a keynote speaker at the Republican convention
She was a brilliant public speaker.
The Society has an interesting talk by a visiting speaker every month.
Previous speakers include two former US Secretaries of State.
He was much in demand as a visiting speaker.
The conference featured a number of distinguished speakers from the world of business and industry.
She is a frequent speaker on human and civil rights.

senses.definition: a person who speaks a particular language

examples.en: English speakers
Spanish/Arabic/Chinese speakers
a fluent speaker of German

senses.definition: a person who is or was speaking

examples.en: I looked around to see who the speaker was.
A speaker conveys information through tone and body language.
Communication is an active process that involves both the speaker and the listener.

senses.definition: the part of a radio, computer or piece of musical equipment that the sound comes out of

examples.en: The car had a powerful sound system with four speakers.

senses.definition: the title of the person whose job is to control the discussions in a parliament

examples.en: the Speaker of the House of Commons/Representatives

senses.definition: not ordinary or usual; different from what is normal

examples.en: The school will only allow this in special circumstances.
An application has been filed for special leave to appeal in the High Court.
Some of the officials have special privileges.
There is something special about this place.
This type of wood needs special treatment.

senses.definition: more important than others; deserving or getting more attention than usual

examples.en: What are your special interests?
Our special guest on next week’s show will be…
a special occasion
a special 20th anniversary edition of the movie
It's a film that holds a special place in my heart.
What makes him special as a director is his obvious intelligence.
She makes me feel special.
She's a very special friend.
Don't lose it—it's special.

senses.definition: organized or intended for a particular purpose

examples.en: British special forces were employed on stealth operations.
a special event/report/team
There are almost no special features on this DVD.
These teachers need special training.
Dr Pearce is the special adviser on environmental issues.
a United Nations special envoy
The merger was approved at a special meeting of shareholders.

senses.definition: used by or intended for one particular person or group of people

examples.en: She has a special way of smiling.
He enlivens his lectures with his own special brand of humour.
He sent a special message to the men.

senses.definition: better or more than usual

examples.en: As an only child she got special attention.
Special thanks are due to the many volunteers who helped organize fundraising events.
People who grow things have a special relationship with the land.
Please take special care of it.
Police advised residents to take special precautions because of the increase in burglaries.

senses.definition: something that is not usually available but is provided for a particular purpose or on one occasion

examples.en: an election-night special on television
The menu changes regularly and there are daily specials to choose from.

senses.definition: a price for a particular product in a shop or restaurant that is lower than usual

examples.en: There's a special on coffee this week.

senses.definition: on sale at a lower price for a short period of time

examples.en: The chocolates were on special at my local store.
You can often find them on special.

senses.definition: a person who is an expert in a particular area of work or study

examples.en: a specialist in Japanese history
a communications/public relations/management specialist
This is the view of virtually all independent specialists on the region.

senses.definition: a doctor who has specialized in a particular area of medicine

examples.en: You need to see a specialist.
a cancer/fertility specialist
an eye/ear, nose, and throat specialist
I trained as a psychiatric specialist at the hospital.

senses.definition: having or involving expert knowledge of a particular area of work, study or medicine

examples.en: specialist knowledge/training/skills
The patient should be transferred to a specialist unit.
We don't need any specialist equipment.
a specialist registrar/nurse/doctor
You need some specialist advice.
Her specialist subject is Italian Renaissance painting.

variants.html: (British English also specialise)

senses.definition: to become an expert in a particular area of work, study or business; to spend more time on one area of work, etc. than on others

examples.en: Many students prefer not to specialize too soon.
He specialized in criminal law.
The shop specializes in hand-made chocolates.

variants.html: (British English also specialised)

senses.definition: designed or developed for a particular purpose or area of knowledge

examples.en: specialized equipment
a job calling for highly specialized skills
Our industry is quite specialized.

senses.definition: a group into which animals, plants, etc. that are able to have sex with each other and produce healthy young are divided, smaller than a genus and identified by a Latin name

examples.en: a conservation area for endangered species
plant/animal/bird/fish species
a native species of fish
two closely related species
Nearly 850 species of birds have been identified within the country's borders.
a rare species of beetle
There are many species of dog(s).
The effect of climate change on species richness was evaluated.

senses.definition: connected with one particular thing only

examples.en: specific needs/requirements
patients who suffer from a specific type of cancer
The money was collected for a specific purpose.
specific problems/issues
a specific location/task/case
children with specific learning difficulties (= in one area only)

senses.definition: detailed and exact

examples.en: specific information/details/examples/questions
‘I'd like your help tomorrow.’ ‘Can you be more specific (= tell me exactly what you want)?’
The regulations make specific reference to the transmission of personal data over a network.
I gave you specific instructions.
He was not specific about his plans.

senses.definition: existing only in one place or limited to one thing

examples.en: a belief that is specific to this part of Africa
These heart issues are specific to women.
These values are culturally specific, not naturally given.

senses.definition: connected with or intended for one particular thing only

examples.en: liquid vitamins specifically designed for children
the development of new treatments that specifically target cancer cells
The service has been designed specifically for use by children.
a magazine aimed specifically at working women
a specifically Christian approach to morality
The book focused specifically on Tom's boyhood.

senses.definition: in a detailed and exact way

examples.en: She had specifically asked him to keep her updated on the investigation.
The agreement specifically mentions the lifting of sanctions.
I specifically told you not to go near the water!
The author specifically addresses seven important issues.

senses.definition: used when you want to add more detailed and exact information

examples.en: The newspaper, or more specifically, the editor, was taken to court for publishing the photographs.

senses.definition: a detailed description of how something is, or should be, designed or made

examples.en: the technical specifications of the new model (= of car)
The house has been built exactly to our specifications.
The office was furnished to a high specification.

senses.definition: to state something, especially by giving an exact measurement, time, exact instructions, etc.

examples.en: Remember to specify your size when ordering clothes.
Forms must be returned by the specified date.
The contract clearly specifies who can operate the machinery.
The regulations specify that calculators may not be used in the examination.

senses.definition: a small amount of something that shows what the rest of it is like

examples.en: Astronauts have brought back specimens of rock from the moon.
Can you give me a specimen of your handwriting?

senses.definition: a single example of something, especially an animal or a plant

examples.en: The aquarium has some interesting specimens of unusual tropical fish.
Redwood trees can live for a long time; one specimen is 4 000 years old.
They were fine specimens of British youth!

senses.definition: a small quantity of blood, urine, etc. that is taken from somebody and tested by a doctor

examples.en: to provide/take a specimen

senses.definition: two lenses in a frame that rests on the nose and ears. People wear spectacles in order to be able to see better or to protect their eyes from bright light.

examples.en: a pair of spectacles
a spectacle case (= to put your spectacles in)

senses.definition: a performance or an event that is very impressive and exciting to look at

examples.en: The carnival parade was a magnificent spectacle.

senses.definition: a sight or view that is very impressive to look at

examples.en: The sunset was a stunning spectacle.
The wide plain, with thousands of wildebeest on the move, was an awesome spectacle.

senses.definition: an unusual or surprising sight or situation that attracts a lot of attention

examples.en: I remember the sad spectacle of her standing in her wedding dress, covered in mud.
the sad spectacle of him struggling to keep up with the younger players

senses.definition: to draw attention to yourself by behaving or dressing in a silly way in public
very impressive

examples.en: The coastal road has spectacular scenery.
Messi scored a spectacular goal.
It was a spectacular achievement on their part.
a spectacular display of fireworks
The special effects were quite spectacular.

senses.definition: an impressive show or performance

examples.en: a Christmas TV spectacular

senses.definition: a person who is watching an event, especially a sports event

examples.en: The new football stadium will hold 75 000 spectators.
Thousands of spectators lined the route of the royal procession.

senses.definition: a band of coloured lights in order of their wavelengths, as seen in a rainbow and into which light may be separated

examples.en: A spectrum is formed by a ray of light passing through a prism.
Red and violet are at opposite ends of the spectrum.

senses.definition: a range of sound waves or several other types of wave

examples.en: the electromagnetic/radio/sound spectrum

senses.definition: a complete or wide range of related qualities, ideas, etc.

examples.en: a broad spectrum of interests
We shall hear views from across the political spectrum.

senses.definition: having an autism spectrum disorder

examples.en: The chance of having a second autistic child is much higher for parents with one child on the spectrum.

senses.definition: to form an opinion about something without knowing all the details or facts

examples.en: We all speculated about the reasons for her resignation.
They were all speculating as to the identity of the stranger.
It is useless to speculate why he did it.
We can speculate that the stone circles were used in some sort of pagan ceremony.

senses.definition: to buy goods, property, shares, etc., hoping to make a profit when you sell them, but with the risk of losing money

examples.en: He likes to speculate on the stock market.

senses.definition: the act of forming opinions about what has happened or what might happen without knowing all the facts

examples.en: His private life is the subject of much speculation.
There was widespread speculation that she was going to resign.
Today's announcement ends months of speculation about the company's future.
The president’s absence led to speculation over his health.
She dismissed the newspaper reports as pure speculation.
Our speculations proved right.

senses.definition: the activity of buying and selling goods or shares in a company in the hope of making a profit, but with the risk of losing money

examples.en: speculation in oil
speculation against the euro
speculation on the stock market

senses.definition: a formal talk that a person gives to an audience

examples.en: Several people made speeches at the wedding.
She gave a rousing speech to the crowd.
to deliver a speech on human rights
He inspired everyone with a moving speech about tolerance and respect.
In his acceptance speech, the actor thanked his family.

senses.definition: the language used when speaking; the fact of speaking rather than writing

examples.en: This expression is used mainly in speech, not in writing.
a defence of free speech (= the right to say openly what you think)
speech sounds

senses.definition: the ability to speak

examples.en: I seemed to have lost the power of speech.
a speech impediment
The child was referred to a speech therapist.

senses.definition: the way in which a particular person speaks

examples.en: Her speech was slurred—she was clearly drunk.
Clear speech with crisp consonant sounds is very important.

senses.definition: a group of lines that an actor speaks in a play in the theatre

examples.en: She has the longest speech in the play.

senses.definition: the rate at which somebody/something moves or travels

examples.en: at high/low/full/top speed
The five-door version has a maximum speed of 130 mph.
a fast/slow speed
London traffic moves at an average speed of 11 mph.
travelling at the speed of light/sound
a speed of 50 mph/80 kph
The missile reaches speeds of 5  800 kilometres per hour.
The train began to pick up speed (= go faster).
at breakneck speed (= fast in a way that is dangerous)
an attempt to break the land speed record
It is best not to spray when wind speeds are greater than 5 miles per hour.
The car was gathering speed.
He reduced speed and turned sharp left.
There are speed restrictions on this road.
Increasing your walking speed will help to exercise your heart.

senses.definition: the rate at which something happens or is done

examples.en: the processing speed of the computer
This course is designed so that students can progress at their own speed.
We aim to increase the speed of delivery (= how quickly goods are sent).
broadband that runs at speeds in excess of 40 megabits per second

senses.definition: the quality of being quick or rapid

examples.en: The Kenyan runner put on a sudden burst of speed over the last 50 metres.
She was overtaken by the speed of events (= things happened more quickly than she expected).
A car flashed past them at speed (= fast).
If a footballer lacks speed, he has no chance at the top level.
The accident was due to excessive speed.
Speed is his greatest asset as a tennis player.

senses.definition: a measurement of how sensitive film for cameras, etc. is to light
the time taken by a camera shutter to open and close
a gear on a bicycle, in a car, etc.

examples.en: a four-speed gearbox
a ten-speed mountain bike

senses.definition: an illegal amphetamine drug that is taken to give feelings of excitement and energy
with as much speed or energy as possible

examples.en: We as a company are moving full speed ahead.

senses.definition: you will finish doing something sooner if you do not try to do it too quickly because you will make fewer mistakes
a sudden increase in your speed or rate of progress; the ability to suddenly increase your speed

examples.en: He put on an impressive turn of speed in the last lap.
The kangaroo has a fast turn of speed.
For a small car it has a good turn of speed.

senses.definition: not able to move, for example because you are frightened or surprised

idioms.word: have a soft spot for somebody/something

variants.html: (also Indian English have a soft corner for somebody/something)

senses.definition: to like somebody/something

senses.definition: if something hits the spot it does exactly what it should do

senses.definition: to be very much better than somebody/something

idioms.word: a leopard cannot change its spots

senses.definition: people cannot change their character, especially if they have a bad character

examples.en: You didn’t really expect her to be on time, did you? A leopard can’t change its spots.

senses.definition: immediately

examples.en: He answered the question on the spot.

senses.definition: at the actual place where something is happening

examples.en: An ambulance was on the spot within minutes.

variants.html: (North American English also in place)

senses.definition: to make somebody feel uncomfortable or embarrassed by asking them a difficult question

senses.definition: to give your opponent or the other team an advantage

senses.definition: to be covered with small round marks of something

senses.definition: connected with a system of buying and selling things where goods are delivered and paid for immediately after sale

senses.definition: the area of light that is made by a spotlight

senses.definition: to give special attention to a problem, situation, etc. so that people notice it

senses.definition: a husband or wife

senses.definition: to cover a large area

senses.definition: to tell people about something

senses.definition: to make something happen

examples.en: The dollar staged a recovery earlier today.
After five years in retirement, he staged a comeback to international tennis.

senses.definition: on, of or for stairs

examples.en: the stair carpet
The carpet was held in place by brass stair rods.

senses.definition: a set of steps built between two floors inside a building

examples.en: We had to carry the piano up three flights of stairs.
He climbed the stairs to his bedroom.
The children ran up the stairs.
He remembered passing her on the stairs.
at the bottom/top of the stairs

senses.definition: one of the steps in a set of stairs

examples.en: How many stairs are there up to the second floor?

senses.definition: a set of stairs inside a building including the banisters (= posts and bars that are fixed at the side)

examples.en: The house had a panelled hall and a fine oak stair.

senses.definition: in the part of a house where the servants lived in the past
money that somebody invests in a company

examples.en: a 20 per cent stake in the business
a controlling/majority/minority stake

senses.definition: a part or share in a business, plan, etc. that will bring you money or other benefits if it succeeds

examples.en: She has a personal stake in the success of the play.
Many young people no longer feel they have a stake in society.
He has a personal stake in the outcome of the war.

senses.definition: something that you risk losing, especially money, when you try to predict the result of a race, game, etc., or when you are involved in an activity that can succeed or fail

examples.en: How much was the stake (= how much did you bet)?
They were playing cards for high stakes (= a lot of money).
With only two points separating the top five players, the stakes are high as they enter the final round.

senses.definition: a wooden or metal post that is pointed at one end and pushed into the ground in order to support something, mark a particular place, etc.

examples.en: Tall plants can be secured by tying them to stakes.

senses.definition: a wooden post that somebody could be tied to in former times before being burnt to death (= killed by fire) as a punishment

examples.en: Joan of Arc was burnt at the stake.

senses.definition: the money that is paid to the winners in horse racing
used in the names of some horse races
that can be won or lost, depending on the success of a particular action

examples.en: We cannot afford to take risks when people's lives are at stake.
The prize at stake is a place in the final.

idioms.word: go to the stake over/for something

senses.definition: to be prepared to do anything in order to defend your opinions or beliefs

examples.en: He would have gone to the stake for his belief in his daughter’s innocence.

senses.definition: used to say how much of a particular quality a person has, as if they were in a competition in which some people are more successful than others

examples.en: John doesn't do too well in the personality stakes.
She was determined to win in the fashion stakes.

variants.html: (British English up sticks)

senses.definition: to suddenly move from your house and go to live somewhere else

examples.en: He pulled up stakes and went back to France.

senses.definition: to risk money or something important on the result of something

examples.en: He staked £25 on the favourite (= for example, in horse racing).
She staked her political career on tax reform, and lost.
That's him over there—I'd stake my life on it (= I am completely confident).

senses.definition: to support something with a stake

examples.en: to stake newly planted trees
The young trees should be staked after planting.

senses.definition: to say or show publicly that you think something should be yours

examples.en: Adams staked his claim for a place in the Olympic team with his easy win yesterday.

senses.definition: a table or small shop with an open front that people sell things from, especially at a market

examples.en: He works on a market stall in the Square.
They have a fish stall on the market.
Drinks were being sold from makeshift stalls at the side of the road.

senses.definition: a section inside a farm building that is large enough for one animal to be kept in

examples.en: We had to muck out stalls and groom the horses.

senses.definition: a small area in a room, surrounded by glass, walls, etc., that contains a shower or toilet

examples.en: a bathroom stall

senses.definition: the seats that are nearest to the stage in a theatre

examples.en: the front row of the stalls

senses.definition: the seats at the front of a church where the choir (= singers) and priests sit
a situation in which a vehicle’s engine suddenly stops because it is not getting enough power
a situation in which an aircraft loses speed and goes steeply downwards

examples.en: The plane went into a stall.

senses.definition: to stop suddenly because of a lack of power or speed; to make a vehicle or an engine do this

examples.en: The car stalled and refused to start again.
I kept stalling.
I stalled the car three times during my driving test.

senses.definition: to try to avoid doing something or answering a question so that you have more time

examples.en: They are still stalling on the deal.
‘What do you mean?’ she asked, stalling for time.
The opposition party was angered by the Prime Minister’s stalling tactics.
He asked them all kinds of pointless questions, stalling for time.

senses.definition: to make somebody wait so that you have more time to do something

examples.en: See if you can stall her while I finish searching her office.

senses.definition: to stop something from happening until a later date; to stop making progress

examples.en: There have been several attempts to revive the stalled peace plan.
Discussions have once again stalled.

variants.html: (also formal postage stamp)

senses.definition: a small piece of paper with a design on it that you buy and stick on an envelope or a package before you post it

examples.en: a 67p stamp
Could I have three first-class stamps, please?
He has been collecting stamps since he was eight.
a stamp album
The Post Office has issued a commemorative stamp to mark the event.

senses.definition: a tool for printing the date or a design or mark onto a surface

examples.en: a date stamp

senses.definition: a design or words made by stamping something onto a surface

examples.en: The passports, with the visa stamps, were waiting at the embassy.
The project has the government's stamp of approval.

senses.definition: a small piece of paper with a design on it, stuck on a document to show that a particular amount of money has been paid

examples.en: a TV licence stamp

senses.definition: the mark or sign of a particular quality or person

examples.en: All his work bears the stamp of authority.

senses.definition: a kind or class, especially of people

examples.en: men of a different stamp

senses.definition: an act or sound of stamping the foot

examples.en: The stamp of hoofs alerted Isabel.

senses.definition: to put your foot down heavily and noisily on the ground

examples.en: I tried stamping my feet to keep warm.
Sam stamped his foot in anger.
He stamped the snow off his boots.
The audience were stamping and cheering.
She stamped her foot impatiently.

senses.definition: to walk with loud heavy steps

examples.en: She turned and stamped out of the room.
The children came stamping down the stairs.

senses.definition: to print letters, words, a design, etc. onto something using a special tool

examples.en: The box was stamped with the maker's name.
Wait here to have your passport stamped.
I'll stamp the company name on your cheque.
The maker's name was stamped in gold on the box.

senses.definition: to make a feeling show clearly on somebody’s face, in their actions, etc.

examples.en: Their faces were stamped with hostility.

examples.cf: stamp B over, across, etc. A
examples.en: The crime had revenge stamped all over it.
Terror was stamped across her face.

senses.definition: to show that somebody has a particular quality

examples.en: Her success has stamped her as one of the country's top riders.

senses.definition: to stick a stamp on a letter or package
to cut and shape an object from a piece of metal or plastic using a special machine or tool

examples.en: The hinges are stamped out of sheets of metal.

senses.definition: the opinions that somebody has about something and expresses publicly

examples.en: What is the newspaper's stance on the war?
He is known for his anti-abortion stance.
Judges are increasingly taking a tougher stance on rape.

senses.definition: the way in which somebody stands, especially when playing a sport

examples.en: Widen your stance (= move your feet wider apart) for greater stability when hitting the ball.

senses.definition: to be on your feet; to be in a vertical position

examples.en: She was too weak to stand.
a bird standing on one leg
Don't just stand there—do something!
I was standing only a few feet away.
We all stood around in the corridor waiting.
to stand on your head/hands (= to be upside down, balancing on your head/hands)
Stand still while I take your photo.
We stood talking for a few minutes.
People stood waiting for a bus in the rain.
After the earthquake, only a few houses were left standing.

senses.definition: to get up onto your feet from another position

examples.en: Everyone stood when the president came in.
We stood up in order to get a better view.
I tried to stand up and found myself in agony.

senses.definition: to put something/somebody in a vertical position somewhere

examples.en: Stand the ladder up against the wall.
I stood the little girl on a chair so that she could see.

senses.definition: used especially in negative sentences and questions to emphasize that you do not like somebody/something

examples.en: I can't stand his brother.
I can't stand the sight of blood.
I can't stand it when you do that.
She couldn't stand being kept waiting.
She couldn't stand to be kept waiting.
I can't stand people interrupting all the time.
How do you stand him being here all the time?

senses.definition: used especially with can/could or will to say that somebody/something can survive something or can tolerate something without being hurt or damaged

examples.en: His heart won't stand the strain much longer.
Modern plastics can stand very high and very low temperatures.
It can stand being dropped from a great height without breaking.
Can you stand me touching your hand or is it too sore?
I can't stand to see him suffer any more.

senses.definition: to be in a particular place

examples.en: The castle stands on the site of an ancient battlefield.
An old oak tree once stood here.
Books stood in piles in the corner.

senses.definition: to be in a particular condition or situation

examples.en: The house stood empty for a long time.
'You're wrong about the date—it was 2008.’ ‘I stand corrected (= accept that I was wrong).'
You stand accused of a terrible crime.
You never know where you stand with her—one minute she's friendly, the next she'll hardly speak to you.
As things stand, there is little chance of a quick settlement of the dispute.

variants.html: (North American English usually run)

senses.definition: to be a candidate in an election

examples.en: He stood for election in Colchester.
He stood for parliament (= tried to get elected as an MP).
She stood unsuccessfully as a candidate in the local elections.
Her friends persuaded her to stand.

senses.definition: to be a particular height

examples.en: The tower stands 30 metres high.

senses.definition: to be at a particular level, amount, height, etc.

examples.en: Interest rates stand at 3 per cent.
The world record then stood at 6.59 metres.

senses.definition: to be in a particular place, especially while waiting to go somewhere

examples.en: The train standing at platform 3 is for London, Victoria.

senses.definition: to remain still, without moving or being moved

examples.en: Mix the batter and let it stand for twenty minutes.
standing pools of rainwater

senses.definition: if an offer, a decision, etc. made earlier stands, it is still available or relevant or still exists

examples.en: My offer still stands.
The world record stood for 20 years.

senses.definition: to be in a situation where you are likely to do something

examples.en: You stand to make a lot from this deal.
Who stands to benefit the most?
to stand to gain/lose something

senses.definition: to have a particular attitude or opinion about something or towards somebody

examples.en: Where do you stand on private education?

senses.definition: to buy a drink or meal for somebody

examples.en: He stood drinks all round.
She was kind enough to stand us a meal.

senses.definition: an attitude towards something or an opinion that you make clear to people

examples.en: He has avoided taking a firm stand.
The judge takes a tough stand on corruption.
I admire their principled stand against the war.

senses.definition: a strong effort to defend yourself or your opinion about something

examples.en: They are willing to take a stand and defend what they believe in.
We must make a stand against job losses.
the rebels’ desperate last stand

senses.definition: a table or structure that goods are sold from, especially in the street or at a market

examples.en: a lemonade/hot dog/newspaper stand
She sells fruit from a roadside stand.
The magazine sold out as soon as it hit the stands (= went on sale).

senses.definition: a table or a vertical structure where things are displayed or advertised, for example at an exhibition

examples.en: a display/an exhibition stand
Oxford University Press’s stand at the book fair

senses.definition: a piece of equipment or furniture that you use for holding a particular type of thing

examples.en: a bicycle/microphone/cake stand

senses.definition: a large sloping structure at a stadium with rows where people sit or stand to watch the game

examples.en: We had seats in the east stand.

variants.text: (British English also witness box, North American English also witness stand)
variants.html: (British English also witness box, North American English also witness stand)

senses.definition: the place in court where people stand to give evidence

examples.en: He took the stand as the first witness.

senses.definition: the period of time in which two people who are batting (= hitting the ball) play together and score points

examples.en: Clinch and Harris shared an opening stand of 69.

senses.definition: a place where taxis, buses, etc. park while they are waiting for passengers
a group of plants or trees of one kind

examples.en: a stand of pines

senses.definition: a piece of land that you can buy and use for building a house, etc. on

examples.en: A developer bought the land and divided it into stands.

senses.definition: a level of quality, especially one that people think is acceptable

examples.en: There has been a fall in living standards.
safety/quality standards
Who sets the standard for water quality?
A number of Britain's beaches fail to meet European standards on cleanliness.
to improve/raise standards
He failed to reach the minimum standard and did not qualify.
We aim to maintain high standards of customer care.
The standard of this year's applications is very low.
The quality of the image was below the standard I had hoped for.
The work was done to a professional standard.
Her work is not up to standard (= of a good enough standard).

senses.definition: a level of quality that is normal or acceptable for a particular person or in a particular situation

examples.en: You'd better lower your standards if you want to find somewhere cheap to live.
It was a simple meal by Eddie's standards.
The equipment is slow and heavy by modern standards.
His latest film is well below his usual standards.

senses.definition: a level of behaviour that somebody considers to be morally acceptable

examples.en: a man of high moral standards
Some people have no standards.
The government must uphold basic standards of decency.
My grandparents are always complaining about falling standards.
the advertising standards watchdog

senses.definition: a unit of measurement that is officially used; an official rule used when producing something

examples.en: a reduction in the weight standard of silver coins
industry standards

senses.definition: a flag that is used during official ceremonies, especially one connected with a particular military group

examples.en: the royal standard

senses.definition: a song that has been recorded by many different singers
average or normal rather than having special or unusual features

examples.en: the standard rate of tax (= paid by everyone)
It is standard practice to search visitors as they enter the building.
DNA was extracted by a standard procedure.
Touch screens are now a standard feature on most devices.
A standard letter was sent to all candidates.
The format of the show is fairly standard.
Front airbags come as standard on all models.

senses.definition: following a particular standard set, for example, by an industry

examples.en: standard sizes of clothes
Washing machines have standard measurements to fit under kitchen units.
The stations were built to a simple, almost standard design.
Our charges are standard throughout the country.

senses.definition: read by most people who are studying a particular subject

examples.en: the author of the standard textbook on the topic

senses.definition: believed to be correct and used by most people

examples.en: Standard English

senses.definition: done from a position in which you are standing rather than sitting or running

examples.en: a standing jump/start
The speaker got a standing ovation (= people stood up to clap after the speech).

senses.definition: existing or arranged permanently, not formed or made for a particular situation

examples.en: a standing army
a standing charge (= an amount of money that you pay regularly in order to use a service, such as gas or water)
a standing committee
It’s a standing joke (= something that a group of people regularly laugh at).
We have a standing invitation to visit them anytime.

senses.dis_g: (used about beginning a project or task)
senses.definition: from an initial position in which none of the necessary elements are in place

examples.en: The space project went from a standing start to the moon in ten years.

senses.definition: the position or reputation of somebody/something within a group of people or in an organization

examples.en: the high/low standing of politicians with the public

senses.definition: the period of time that something has existed

examples.en: a friendship of many years’ standing
Their relationship is of many years' standing.

senses.definition: a list of people, teams, etc. showing their positions in a sports competition

examples.en: He remains at the top of the championship standings.

senses.definition: a large ball of burning gas in space that we see as a point of light in the sky at night

examples.en: There was a big moon and hundreds of stars were shining overhead.
Sirius is the brightest star in the sky.
We camped out under the stars.

senses.definition: an object, a decoration, a mark, etc., usually with five or six points, whose shape represents a star

examples.en: a horse with a white star on its forehead
a sheriff’s star
I've put a star by the names of the girls in the class.
Liz deserves a gold star for all her hard work.
a four-star general

senses.definition: a mark that represents a star and tells you how good something is, especially a hotel or restaurant

examples.en: three-/four-/five-star hotels
What star rating does this restaurant have?

senses.definition: a famous and excellent singer, performer, sports player, etc.

examples.en: pop/rock/Hollywood/TV stars
a football/tennis/sports star
She acts well but she hasn't got star quality.
Get used to her face as she is a rising star.
She's a former child star.
He's so good—I'm sure he'll be a big star.
The best models receive star treatment.

senses.definition: a person who has the main part, or one of the main parts, in a film, play, etc.

examples.en: The star of the show was a young Italian singer.
The show has plenty of guest stars appearing each week.
She was the star of many popular television series.

senses.definition: a person or thing that is the best of a group

examples.en: a star student
Paula is the star of the class.
He was the star performer at the championships.
The star prize is a weekend for two in Paris.
The monkey was the star attraction (= the best or most popular act) at the show.
Through high school he was a track star.

senses.definition: used to show that you feel very grateful for something that somebody has done or that you think they are wonderful

examples.en: Thanks! You're a star!

senses.definition: a description of what somebody thinks is going to happen to somebody in the future, based on the position of the stars and planets when they were born

examples.en: Do you read your stars in the paper?

senses.definition: to try to be successful at something that is difficult
to see flashes of light in front of your eyes, usually because you have been hit on the head
if somebody has stars in their eyes, they have dreams of becoming famous, especially as an actor, singer, etc.
to feel very grateful and lucky about something

examples.en: Just thank your lucky stars you weren’t in the house at the time.

senses.definition: to have one of the main parts in a film, play, etc.

examples.en: He starred in that movie about the crazy professor.
She starred opposite Cary Grant in ‘Bringing up Baby’.
No one has yet been chosen for the starring role (= the main part).

senses.definition: if a film, play, etc. stars somebody, that person has one of the main parts

examples.en: a movie starring Jennifer Lawrence and Chris Pratt

senses.definition: to put a symbol with a shape like a star (= an asterisk) next to a word, etc. in order to make people notice it

examples.en: Treat all the sections that have been starred as priority.

senses.definition: to look at somebody/something for a long time

examples.en: I screamed and everyone stared.
I stared blankly at the paper in front of me.
They stared up at the hole in the ceiling.
He sat staring into space (= looking at nothing).
I was staring into her beautiful blue eyes.
She looked at them with dark staring eyes.

idioms.word: be staring somebody in the face

senses.definition: used to describe something that you have failed to see, even though it was obvious and should have been easy to see

examples.en: The answer was staring us in the face but we never saw it until it was too late.

senses.definition: to be certain to happen

examples.en: Defeat was staring them in the face.

idioms.word: be staring something in the face

senses.definition: to be unable to avoid something

examples.en: They were staring defeat in the face.

senses.definition: an act of looking at somebody/something for a long time, especially in a way that is unfriendly or that shows surprise

examples.en: She gave him a blank stare.
He fixed the interviewer with a penetrating stare.

senses.definition: unpleasant; real, and impossible to avoid

examples.en: The author paints a stark picture of life in a prison camp.
The government faced a stark choice between civil war and martial law.
The remains of the building stand as a stark reminder of the fire.
He now faces the stark reality of life in prison.
The stark truth is that there is not enough money left.
The stark fact is that even with more time, we still couldn’t raise enough money.

senses.definition: very different from something in a way that is easy to see

examples.en: stark differences
Social divisions in the city are stark.
The good weather was in stark contrast to the storms of previous weeks.

senses.definition: looking severe and without any colour or decoration

examples.en: I think white would be too stark for the bedroom.
The hills stood stark against the winter sky.

senses.definition: complete and total

examples.en: The children watched in stark terror.

senses.definition: wearing no clothes
completely crazy
to begin doing or using something

examples.en: I start work at nine.
He's just started a new job.
The kids start school next week.
I only started (= began to read) this book yesterday.
We need to start (= begin using) a new jar of coffee.
It's a long story. Where shall I start?
Can you start (= a new job) on Monday?
It started to rain.
I was starting to feel tired.
Mistakes were starting to creep in.
She started laughing.
Suddenly things started happening.
It's time you started on your homework.
Let's start by reviewing what we did last week.
If you want to find out more, this website is a good place to start.

senses.definition: to begin happening; to make something begin happening

examples.en: Work is due to start this weekend.
What time does the show start?
Have you any idea where the rumour started?
Who started the fire?
I'm ready to start the process of writing.
Do you start the day with a good breakfast?
You're always trying to start an argument.
The news started me thinking.

senses.definition: when you start a machine or a vehicle or it starts, it begins to operate

examples.en: Start the engines!
He started the recording.
I can't get the car started.
The car won't start.

senses.definition: to begin to exist; to make something begin to exist

examples.en: The company started in 1894 in Pennsylvania.
There are a lot of small businesses starting up in that area.
She started a business while she was still at school.
I decided to start a fashion blog.
They want to start a family (= to have children).
He decided to start up his own film festival.

senses.definition: to begin from a particular place, amount or situation; to begin in a particular way

examples.en: The trail starts just outside the town.
Hotel prices start at €80 for a double room.
A sentence always starts with a capital letter.
The evening started badly when the speaker failed to turn up.
The best professional musicians start young.

senses.definition: to begin, or to begin something such as a career, in a particular way that changed later

examples.en: She started as a secretary but ended up running the department.
It started as a hobby and grew from there.
The company started out with 30 employees.
I started off as a dishwasher making 25 cents an hour.
He started life as a teacher before turning to journalism.
She started her career working for the BBC.

senses.definition: to begin a journey; to leave

examples.en: What time are we starting tomorrow?

senses.definition: to begin to move in a particular direction

examples.en: I started after her (= began to follow her) to tell her the news.
He started for the door, but I blocked his way.

senses.definition: to move suddenly and quickly because you are surprised or afraid

examples.en: The sudden noise made her start.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody not to complain or be critical

examples.en: Don't start! I told you I'd be late.
Don't you start! It's hard enough managing the kids, without you complaining too.

senses.definition: to make something start happening; to make sure that something continues to happen

idioms.word: get/start off on the right/wrong foot (with somebody)

senses.definition: to start a relationship well/badly

examples.en: I seem to have got off on the wrong foot with the new boss.

senses.definition: to begin doing something

examples.en: It's nearly ten o'clock. Let's get started.
It's already late, so I think we should get started.

idioms.word: start/get off on the right/wrong foot (with somebody)

senses.definition: to start a relationship well/badly

examples.en: I seem to have started off on the wrong foot with the new boss.

senses.definition: to cause trouble
used when you are giving the first and most important reason for something

examples.en: To start with, it’s much too expensive…

senses.definition: at the beginning

examples.en: The club had only six members to start with.
I'll have melon to start with.
She wasn't keen on the idea to start with.

idioms.word: you, he, she, etc. started it

senses.definition: used to blame somebody for beginning a fight or an argument

examples.en: ‘Stop fighting, you two!’ ‘He started it!’

senses.definition: the point at which something begins

examples.en: If we don't hurry, we'll miss the start.
They haven't won since the start of the season.
Things didn't look too hopeful at the start of the year.
We've had problems right from the start.
We've had problems from the very start.
The trip was a disaster from start to finish.
a perfect start to the day
After a slow start to his career, things improved.
The campaign is off to a promising start.
a shaky/rocky start
This could be the start of something big.

senses.definition: the act or process of beginning something

examples.en: We need to get an early start in the morning.
I'll paint the ceiling if you make a start on the walls.
She's moving abroad to make a fresh start (= to begin a new life).
I think it's time we made a start.
It's not much, but it's a start (= something useful has been done, although there is a lot more still to do).

senses.definition: the opportunity that you are given to begin something in a successful way

examples.en: Many critics got their start writing for this magazine.
Moving to a different school gave Sally a fresh start.
They worked hard to give their children a good start in life.
The job gave him his start in journalism.

senses.definition: the place where a race begins

examples.en: The runners lined up at the start.
The runners walked up to the start line.

senses.definition: an amount of time or distance that somebody has as an advantage over other people at the beginning of a race

examples.en: I gave the younger children a start.
She went into the second round with a five-minute start on the rest of the cyclists.

senses.definition: an occasion when somebody/something competes in a race or competition, or when somebody is a member of a team that starts a game

examples.en: She has been beaten only once in six starts.
He has scored three goals in his last three starts.

senses.definition: an act of moving your body quickly and suddenly because you are surprised, afraid, etc.

examples.en: You gave me quite a start!
She woke from the dream with a start.

idioms.word: by/in fits and starts | in stops and starts

senses.definition: frequently starting and stopping again; not continuously

examples.en: Because of other commitments I can only write my book in fits and starts.

senses.definition: used to emphasize the first of a list of reasons, opinions, etc.

examples.en: I'm not working there—for a start, it's too far to travel.

senses.dis_g: (used about beginning a project or task)
senses.definition: from an initial position in which none of the necessary elements are in place

examples.en: The space project went from a standing start to the moon in ten years.

idioms.word: get off to a flying start | get off to a flyer

senses.definition: to make a very good start; to begin something well

examples.en: She’s got off to a flying start in her new career.

senses.definition: Strategic Arms Reduction Talks
to suffer or die because you do not have enough food to eat; to make somebody suffer or die in this way

examples.en: The animals were left to starve to death.
pictures of starving children
The new job doesn't pay as much but we won't starve!
She's starving herself to try to lose weight.
Many of the prisoners looked half starved.

senses.definition: not having something that you need

examples.en: supply-starved rebels

variants.text: (also be starved especially in North American English)
variants.html: (also be starved especially in North American English)

senses.definition: to feel very hungry

examples.en: When's the food coming? I'm starving!

senses.definition: a country considered as an organized political community controlled by one government

examples.en: the Baltic States
European Union member states

senses.definition: the level of importance that is given to something

examples.en: Stay clear of the centre of town at this time of the evening.

senses.definition: to continue doing something until it has finished or been completed, even though it is difficult

science, technology, engineering and mathematics (used to refer to these subjects as a group in the context of education and jobs)
