examples.en: cultural/gender/racial stereotypes
He doesn't conform to the usual stereotype of the businessman with a dark suit and briefcase.

senses.definition: to form a fixed idea about a person or thing which may not really be true

examples.en: Children from certain backgrounds tend to be stereotyped by their teachers.
Why are professors stereotyped as absent-minded?

senses.definition: to fix something to something else, usually with a sticky substance; to become fixed to something in this way

examples.en: He stuck a stamp on the envelope.
We used glue to stick the broken pieces together.
I stuck the photos into an album.
Her wet clothes were sticking to her body.
The glue's useless—the pieces just won't stick.

senses.definition: to become fixed in one position and impossible to move

examples.en: This drawer keeps sticking.
The key has stuck in the lock.

senses.definition: to push something, usually a sharp object, into something; to be pushed into something

examples.en: The nurse stuck the needle into my arm.
Don't stick your fingers through the bars of the cage.
I found a nail sticking in the tyre.

senses.definition: to put something in a place, especially quickly or carelessly

examples.en: Stick your bags down there.
He stuck his hands in his pockets and strolled off.
Can you stick this on the noticeboard?
Peter stuck his head around the door and said, ‘Coffee, anyone?’
He stuck the note through her letter box.
Stick 'em up! (= Put your hands above your head—I have a gun!)

senses.definition: used to say in a rude and angry way that you are not interested in what somebody has, offers, does, etc.

examples.en: I got sick of my boss's moaning and told him he could stick the job.

senses.definition: to accept a difficult or unpleasant situation or person

examples.en: I don't know how you stick that job.
They’re always arguing—I can’t stick it any longer.
The problem is, my mother can't stick my boyfriend.
John can't stick living with his parents.

senses.definition: to become accepted

examples.en: The police couldn't make the charges stick (= show them to be true).
His friends called him Bart and the name has stuck (= has become the name that everyone calls him).

senses.definition: to say that you will not take any more cards
people remember and believe the bad things they hear about other people, even if they are later shown to be false
to kick somebody very hard, especially when they are on the ground
to attack somebody by criticizing them when they are in a difficult situation

examples.en: I wonder if the press will put the boot in?

idioms.word: put/stick the knife in | put/stick the knife into somebody

senses.definition: to behave towards somebody in an unfriendly way and try to harm them
to give your opinion, advice, etc. without being asked and when it is probably not wanted

examples.en: I was getting along very nicely until Patrick stuck his oar in.

idioms.word: put/stick two fingers up at somebody

senses.definition: to form the shape of a V with the two fingers nearest your thumb and raise your hand in the air with the back part of it facing somebody, done to be rude to them or to show them that you are angry

examples.en: She enjoys sticking two fingers up to convention.

idioms.word: stand/stick out like a sore thumb

senses.definition: to be very easy to notice in an unpleasant way

examples.en: The blue building stood out like a sore thumb among the whitewashed villas.
If you wear a suit to the party, you’ll stand out like a sore thumb.

senses.definition: to be very obvious or easy to notice

examples.en: It stood out a mile that she was lying.

senses.definition: to kick somebody very hard, especially when they are on the ground
to attack somebody by criticizing them when they are in a difficult situation

examples.en: I wonder if the press will stick the boot in?

senses.definition: to be remembered for a long time

examples.en: One of his paintings in particular sticks in my mind.

senses.definition: to be difficult or impossible to say

examples.en: She wanted to say how sorry she was but the words seemed to stick in her throat.

senses.definition: to be difficult or impossible to accept; to make you angry
to do or say something when there is a risk that you may be wrong

examples.en: I’ll stick my neck out and say that Bill is definitely the best candidate for the job.

senses.definition: to try to become involved in something that should not involve you

examples.en: He's always sticking his nose into other people's business.

idioms.word: stick/stand out like a sore thumb

senses.definition: to be very easy to notice in an unpleasant way

examples.en: The blue building stuck out like a sore thumb among the whitewashed villas.
If you wear a suit to the party, you'll stick out like a sore thumb.

senses.definition: to be very obvious or easy to notice

examples.en: It stuck out a mile that she was lying.

senses.definition: to refuse to change your mind about something even when other people are trying to persuade you that you are wrong

idioms.word: tell somebody where to put/stick something | tell somebody what they can do with something

senses.definition: to make it clear to somebody that you are angry and are rejecting what they are offering you
a thin piece of wood that has fallen or been broken from a tree

examples.en: We collected dry sticks to start a fire.
He said he was beaten with a stick.
The boys were throwing sticks and stones at the dog.
Her arms and legs were like sticks (= very thin).

variants.text: (also walking stick British and North American English)
variants.html: (also walking stick British and North American English)

senses.definition: a stick that you carry and use as a support when you are walking

examples.en: He walks with a stick these days, but he still gets about.
The old lady leant on her stick as she talked.

senses.definition: a long, thin object that is used in some sports to hit or control the ball

examples.en: a hockey stick

senses.definition: a long, thin piece of something

examples.en: The man had sticks of dynamite strapped to his chest.
a stick of gum
carrot/cinnamon/celery sticks
a stick of butter
The savoury dips were served with sticks of carrot and celery.

senses.definition: a thin piece of wood or plastic that you use for a particular purpose

examples.en: pieces of pineapple on sticks
The men were carrying spades and measuring sticks.
I used a selfie stick to take the picture.

senses.definition: a quantity of a substance, such as solid glue (= a sticky substance), that is sold in a small container with round ends and straight sides, and can be pushed further out of the container as it is used
a stick with a handle in a plane that is used to control direction or height
a handle used to change the gears of a vehicle
a baton, used by the person who conducts an orchestra
criticism or severe words

examples.en: The referee got a lot of stick from the home fans.

senses.definition: country areas, a long way from cities

examples.en: We live out in the sticks.

senses.definition: a person

examples.en: He's not such a bad old stick.

senses.definition: to be in a difficult situation when any action you take will have bad results
the use or threat of force or power

examples.en: The authorities used quiet persuasion instead of the big stick.

senses.definition: if you use the carrot and stick approach, you persuade somebody to try harder by offering them a reward if they do, or a punishment if they do not

examples.en: The emphasis is on the carrot of incentive rather than the stick of taxes.

idioms.word: get the short end of the stick

variants.html: (British English draw the short straw)

senses.definition: to be the person in a group who is chosen or forced to perform an unpleasant duty or task

idioms.word: get (hold of) the wrong end of the stick

senses.definition: to understand something in the wrong way

idioms.word: a rod/stick to beat somebody with

senses.definition: a fact, an argument, etc. that is used in order to blame or punish somebody

variants.html: (North American English pull up stakes)

senses.definition: to suddenly move from your house and go to live somewhere else

examples.en: He upped sticks and went back to France.

senses.definition: made of or covered in a substance that sticks to things that touch it

examples.en: sticky fingers covered in jam
There's a dish of mango with sweet sticky rice.
Stir in the milk to make a soft but not sticky dough.
Her arms were covered in a sticky substance that could only be blood.

senses.definition: with glue (= a sticky substance) on one side so that you can stick it to a surface

examples.en: sticky tape

senses.definition: hot and slightly wet

examples.en: a sticky, humid afternoon
The air was hot and sticky.

senses.definition: feeling hot and uncomfortable

examples.en: She felt hot and sticky after six hours on the bus.

senses.definition: difficult or unpleasant

examples.en: I always seem to get into sticky situations on holiday.
Their relationship is going through a sticky patch and they’ve decided to have counselling.

senses.definition: so interesting and well organized that the people who visit it stay there for a long time
something unpleasant that happens to somebody, for example punishment or a violent death, usually because of their own actions

examples.en: He'll come to a sticky end one of these days if he carries on like that.

senses.definition: to be likely to steal something
a difficult situation
a small piece of sticky paper that you use for writing a note on, and that can be easily removed

examples.en: Never write your password on a sticky note!

senses.definition: difficult to bend or move

examples.en: a sheet of stiff black cardboard
Scrub away any residue with a stiff brush.
The windows were stiff and she couldn't get them open.

senses.definition: when a person or a part of their body is stiff, their muscles hurt when they move them

examples.en: I'm really stiff after that bike ride yesterday.
I've got a stiff neck.

senses.definition: thick; difficult to stir (= move around with a spoon)

examples.en: Whisk the egg whites until stiff.

senses.definition: more difficult or severe than usual

examples.en: It was a stiff climb to the top of the hill.
The company faces stiff competition from its rivals.
The new proposals have met with stiff opposition.
She offered stiff resistance to a thief attempting to snatch her bag.
Firms face stiff penalties for breaking the rules.
a stiff breeze/wind (= one that blows strongly)

senses.definition: not friendly or relaxed

examples.en: The speech he made to welcome them was stiff and formal.

senses.definition: costing a lot or too much

examples.en: There's a stiff $30 entrance fee to the exhibition.

senses.definition: strong; containing a lot of alcohol

examples.en: a stiff whisky
‘What you need is a stiff drink,’ he told her.

senses.definition: to keep calm and hide your feelings when you are in pain or in a difficult situation

examples.en: He was taught to keep a stiff upper lip and never to cry in public.
Their reaction contrasts sharply with the stiff upper lip of the English.

senses.definition: very much; to an extreme degree

examples.en: be bored/scared/worried stiff

senses.definition: very cold and hard because the water has become ice

examples.en: The clothes on the washing line were frozen stiff.
I came home from the game frozen stiff (= very cold).

senses.definition: the body of a dead person
to cheat somebody or not pay them what you owe them, especially by not leaving any money as a tip

examples.en: These people are taxed on the tips they make. When you stiff ’em, you cost them money.

senses.definition: continuing until a particular point in time and not finishing

examples.en: I am very happy that you all are still alive and well.
Tickets are still available for the 8 o'clock performance.
He's still very young and has a lot to learn.
She still has a chance to win the title.
If you still need help next week, contact me.
I wrote to them last month and I'm still waiting for a reply.
There's still time to change your mind.

senses.definition: despite what has just been said

examples.en: Although he promised faithfully to come, I still didn't think he would.
We searched everywhere but we still couldn't find it.
The weather was cold and wet. Still, we had a great time.
I know it's not rational, but I still feel terribly guilty.
He was wounded but he was still able to paint.

senses.definition: used for making a comparison stronger

examples.en: The next day was warmer still.
If you can manage to get two tickets that's better still.

senses.definition: even more

examples.en: There was still more bad news to come.

idioms.word: it's still early days | it's early days (yet)

senses.definition: used to say that it is too soon to be sure how a situation will develop

examples.en: It's still early days. We don't know if the play will be a success.

senses.definition: and certainly not

examples.en: No explanation was offered, still less an apology.
He’s too shy to ask a stranger the time, much less speak to a room full of people.

senses.definition: not moving; calm and quiet

examples.en: A fallen tree floated in the still water.
Keep still while I brush your hair.
The kids found it hard to stay still.
Can't you sit still?
We stayed in a village where time has stood still (= life has not changed for many years).

senses.definition: a still photograph or image does not move, in contrast to a moving image from a film or video

examples.en: At this time cinema began to influence both still photography and painting.

senses.definition: with no wind

examples.en: a still summer’s day
the still night air

senses.definition: not containing bubbles of gas; not fizzy

examples.en: still mineral water

senses.definition: the voice of God or your conscience, that tells you to do what is morally right
a person who seems to be quiet or shy may surprise you by knowing a lot or having deep feelings
a photograph of a scene from a film or video

examples.en: a publicity still from his new movie
The police studied the stills from the security video.

senses.definition: a piece of equipment that is used for making strong alcoholic drinks

examples.en: a whisky still

senses.definition: the time during the night when it is quiet and calm
to become calm and quiet; to make something calm and quiet

examples.en: The wind stilled.
She spoke quietly to still the frightened child.
to still somebody’s doubts/fears
His words stilled my fears.

senses.definition: to make something develop or become more active; to encourage something

examples.en: The exhibition has stimulated interest in her work.
The article can be used to stimulate discussion among students.
a government package designed to stimulate economic growth

senses.definition: to make somebody interested and excited about something

examples.en: Parents should give children books that stimulate them.
Both men and women are stimulated by erotic photos (= sexually).
The conference stimulated him to study the subject in more depth.

senses.definition: to make a part of the body function

examples.en: The women were given fertility drugs to stimulate the ovaries.

senses.definition: something that helps somebody/something to develop better or more quickly

examples.en: Books provide children with ideas and a stimulus for play.
The new tax laws should act as a stimulus to exports.
This development also acted as a stimulus for Britain to modernize her air force.

senses.definition: something that produces a reaction in a human, an animal or a plant

examples.en: sensory/verbal/visual stimuli
The animals were conditioned to respond to auditory stimuli (= sounds).

senses.definition: to move a liquid or substance around, using a spoon or something similar, in order to mix it completely

examples.en: She stirred her tea.
Stir the paint before you use it.
The vegetables are stirred into the rice while it is hot.
Stir in the milk until the sauce thickens.

senses.definition: to move, or to make something move, slightly

examples.en: She heard the baby stir in the next room.
A slight breeze was stirring the branches.
A noise stirred me from sleep.

senses.definition: to move, or to make somebody move, in order to do something

examples.en: You haven't stirred from that chair all evening!
Come on, stir yourself. You're late!
Their complaints have finally stirred him into action.

senses.definition: to make somebody excited or make them feel something strongly

examples.en: It's a book that really stirs the imagination.
She was stirred by his sad story.
The preachers were stirred to new zeal.

senses.definition: to begin to be felt

examples.en: A feeling of guilt began to stir in her.
New optimism was stirring throughout the country.

senses.definition: to try to cause trouble

examples.en: You're just stirring it!

senses.definition: to make somebody excited

examples.en: The atmosphere in a theatre never failed to stir her blood.

senses.definition: to begin to move; to hurry
excitement, anger or shock that is felt by a number of people

examples.en: Her resignation caused quite a stir.
The discovery caused something of a stir among physicists.
There was quite a stir about the book.

senses.definition: the action of stirring something

examples.en: Could you give the rice a stir?

senses.definition: a supply of goods that is available for sale in a shop

examples.en: We have a fast turnover of stock.
That particular model is not currently in stock.
I'm afraid we're temporarily out of stock.
We don't carry a large stock of pine furniture.
It is important to carry out regular stock checks.

senses.definition: a supply of something that is available for use

examples.en: Food stocks are running low.
declining fish stocks in the oceans
a country’s housing stock (= all the houses available for living in)
She's built up a good stock of teaching materials over the years.

senses.definition: the value of the shares in a company that have been sold

examples.en: The company's stock hit an all-time high of $94.66.

senses.definition: a share that somebody has bought in a company or business

examples.en: stock prices
to buy/sell/trade stocks
to invest in stocks and shares
to invest in stocks and bonds

senses.definition: money that is lent to a government at a fixed rate of interest; an official document that gives details of this

examples.en: government stock

senses.definition: farm animals, such as cows and sheep, that are kept for their meat, wool, etc.

examples.en: breeding stock

senses.cf: of farming, noble, French, etc. stock
senses.definition: having the type of family or ancestors mentioned
a liquid made by cooking bones, meat, etc. in water, used for making soups and sauces

examples.en: vegetable stock

senses.definition: a wooden structure with holes for the feet, used in the past to lock criminals in as a form of punishment, especially in a public place
the degree to which somebody is respected or liked by other people

examples.en: Their stock is high/low.

senses.definition: the part of a gun that you hold against your shoulder when firing it
a garden plant with brightly coloured flowers with a sweet smell
a theatre company that does several different plays in a season; a repertory company
including everything

examples.en: He sold the business lock, stock and barrel.

senses.definition: in the process of being made, built or prepared

examples.en: Our new model is already on the stocks and will be available in the spring.

senses.definition: to have a particular amount of belief in something

examples.en: She no longer puts much stock in their claims.

senses.definition: to stop and think carefully about the way in which a particular situation is developing in order to decide what to do next

examples.en: It was time to stand back and take stock of his career.

senses.definition: to keep a supply of a particular type of goods to sell

examples.en: Do you stock green tea?

gift shops stocked with cheap souvenirs

senses.definition: to fill something with food, books, etc.

examples.en: The pond was well stocked with fish.
a well-stocked library

senses.definition: a stock excuse, answer, etc. is one that is often used because it is easy and convenient, but that is not very original

examples.en: ‘No comment,’ was the actor's stock response.
Her stock excuse was: ‘I’m washing my hair tonight’.

senses.definition: usually available for sale in a shop

examples.en: stock sizes

senses.definition: the organ inside the body where food goes when you eat it

examples.en: stomach pains/cramps
an upset stomach
a stomach upset
It's not a good idea to drink (= alcohol) on an empty stomach (= without having eaten anything).
You shouldn't exercise on a full stomach.

senses.definition: the front part of the body below the chest

examples.en: The attacker kicked him in the stomach.
Lie on your stomach with your arms by your side.
They crawled along the ground on their stomachs.
exercises to strengthen the stomach muscles

idioms.word: somebody’s eyes are bigger than their stomach

senses.definition: used to say that somebody has been greedy by taking more food than they can eat
to have a nervous feeling in your stomach before doing something

examples.en: I had butterflies in my stomach as I went to get my exam results.

senses.definition: to not want to eat something

examples.en: She had no stomach for the leftover stew.

senses.definition: to not have the desire or courage to do something

examples.en: They had no stomach for a fight.

senses.definition: to be able to see or do unpleasant things without feeling sick or upset

examples.en: You need a strong stomach to go on the giant roller coaster.

senses.definition: the bottom of the stomach where people say they feel strong feelings, especially fear

examples.en: He had a sudden sinking feeling in the pit of his stomach.
I felt a sickening feeling in the pit of my stomach when I saw the ambulance.

senses.definition: to remove the contents of somebody’s stomach using a pump, because they have swallowed something harmful

examples.en: He had his stomach pumped after taking an overdose.

senses.definition: feeling very angry or worried

examples.en: Nora turned sick to her stomach on hearing this news.
It makes me sick to my stomach to hear such stupid attitudes.

senses.definition: feeling that you want to vomit
to make you feel upset, sick or full of horror

examples.en: Pictures of the burnt corpses turned my stomach.
The smell of the dead dog turned his stomach.

senses.definition: to approve of something and be able to enjoy it; to enjoy being with a person

examples.en: I can't stomach violent films.
I find him very hard to stomach.

senses.definition: to be able to eat something without feeling sick

examples.en: She couldn't stomach any breakfast.

senses.definition: a hard solid mineral substance that is found in the ground, often used for building

examples.en: Most of the houses are built of stone.
stone walls
a stone floor/bridge/carving/pillar/slab
a brick and stone building
a flight of stone steps
a huge block of stone

senses.definition: a small piece of rock of any shape

examples.en: a pile of stones
Some children were throwing stones into the lake.

senses.definition: a piece of stone shaped for a particular purpose

examples.en: These words are carved on the stone beside his grave.

senses.definition: a rare valuable stone, such as a diamond, that is used in jewellery

examples.en: She had the stone set in a ring.

variants.html: (North American English usually pit)

senses.definition: a hard shell containing the nut or seed in the middle of some types of fruit

examples.en: cherry/peach stones

senses.definition: a small piece of hard material that can form in the bladder or kidney and cause pain

examples.en: kidney stones

senses.definition: (in the UK) a unit for measuring weight, equal to 6.35 kilograms or 14 pounds

examples.en: He weighs over 15 stone.
She's trying to lose a stone.

senses.definition: unable to be changed

examples.en: People should remember that our proposals aren't set in stone.
These rules are not set in stone.

senses.definition: to be a person who does not show other people sympathy

idioms.word: kill two birds with one stone

senses.definition: to achieve two things at the same time with one action
to try every possible course of action in order to find or achieve something

idioms.word: like getting blood out of/from a stone

senses.definition: almost impossible to obtain

examples.en: Getting an apology from him was like getting blood from a stone.

idioms.word: people (who live) in glass houses shouldn’t throw stones

senses.definition: you should not criticize other people, because they will easily find ways of criticizing you

idioms.word: a rolling stone gathers no moss

senses.definition: a person who moves from place to place, job to job, etc. does not have a lot of money, possessions or friends but is free from responsibilities
a very short distance away

examples.en: We live just a stone's throw from here.
The hotel is within a stone's throw of the beach.

senses.definition: to throw stones at somebody/something

examples.en: Shops were looted and vehicles stoned.
to be stoned to death (= as a punishment)

variants.text: (also pit North American English, British English)
variants.html: (also pit North American English, British English)

senses.definition: to remove the stone from the inside of a fruit

examples.en: stoned black olives

senses.definition: used to express surprise, shock, anger, etc.
to no longer move; to make somebody/something no longer move

examples.en: The car stopped at the traffic lights.
Ann stopped in front of the house.
This train doesn’t stop at Oxford.
He was stopped by the police for speeding.
She stopped the car opposite the school.

senses.definition: to no longer continue to do something; to make somebody/something no longer do something

examples.en: Can't you just stop?
That phone never stops ringing!
Don't you ever stop talking?
Please stop crying and tell me what's wrong.
She criticizes everyone and the trouble is, she doesn't know when to stop.
Stop me (= make me stop talking) if I'm boring you.
Stop it! You're hurting me.
Mike immediately stopped what he was doing.

senses.definition: to end or finish; to make something end or finish

examples.en: When is this fighting going to stop?
The bus service stops at midnight.
Has it stopped raining yet?
Doctors couldn't stop the bleeding.
The referee was forced to stop the game because of heavy snow.
She called on both sides to stop the violence.

senses.definition: to prevent somebody from doing something; to prevent something from happening

examples.en: I want to go and you can't stop me.
efforts to stop the spread of the disease
There's no stopping us now (= nothing can prevent us from achieving what we want to achieve).
You can't stop people (from) saying what they think.
They tried to stop me from leaving.
There's nothing to stop you from accepting the offer.

senses.definition: to end an activity for a short time in order to do something

examples.en: I'm hungry. Let's stop for lunch.
We stopped for the night in Port Augusta.
We stopped to admire the scenery.
People just don't stop to think about the consequences.

senses.definition: to no longer be working or functioning; to make something be no longer working or functioning

examples.en: Why has the engine stopped?
What time is it? My watch has stopped.
I felt as if my heart had stopped.
Can you stop the printer once it’s started?

senses.definition: to stay somewhere for a short time, especially at somebody’s house

examples.en: I'm not stopping. I just came to give you this message.
Can you stop for tea?

senses.definition: to prevent money from being paid

examples.en: to stop a cheque (= tell the bank not to pay it)
Employees of the failed company will have their wages stopped from tomorrow.
Dad threatened to stop £1 a week from our pocket money if we didn't clean our rooms.

senses.definition: to block, fill or close a hole, an opening, etc.

examples.en: Stop up the other end of the tube, will you?
I stopped my ears but still heard her cry out.

senses.definition: to be willing to do anything to get what you want, even if it is dishonest or wrong

examples.en: She’ll stop at nothing to make money.

senses.definition: to stop measuring time in a game or an activity that has a time limit

idioms.word: stop/halt somebody in their tracks | stop/halt/freeze in your tracks

senses.definition: to suddenly make somebody stop by frightening or surprising them; to suddenly stop because something has frightened or surprised you

examples.en: The question stopped Alice in her tracks.
Suddenly he stopped dead in his tracks: what was he doing?
The disease was stopped in its tracks by immunization programmes.

senses.definition: to suddenly stop, or make somebody suddenly stop, doing something

examples.en: He stopped short when he heard his name.
‘I’m pregnant,’ she said. That stopped him short.

idioms.word: stop short of something/of doing something

senses.definition: to be unwilling to do something because it may involve a risk, but to nearly do it

examples.en: She stopped short of calling the president a liar.
The protest stopped short of a violent confrontation.

senses.definition: a place where a bus or train stops regularly for passengers to get on or off

examples.en: I get off at the next stop.
Is this your stop?
Winchester will be the next station stop.
Where's the nearest subway stop?

senses.definition: an act of stopping or stopping something; the state of being stopped

examples.en: The trip included an overnight stop in Brussels.
We made several stops along the way.
She brought the car to a stop.
Work has temporarily come to a stop while the funding is reviewed.
It is time to put a stop to the violence.
They campaigned to put up a stop sign at the busy intersection outside the school.

variants.text: (also more frequent full stop, full point)
variants.html: (also more frequent full stop, full point)

senses.definition: the mark ( . ) used at the end of a sentence and in some abbreviations, for example e.g.
a row of pipes on an organ that produce the different sounds
a handle on an organ that the player pushes in or pulls out to control the sound produced by the pipes
a speech sound made by stopping the flow of air coming out of the mouth and then suddenly releasing it, for example /p/, /k/, /t/
to stop completely

examples.en: The car began to shudder and eventually came to a full stop in front of the church.

idioms.word: in stops and starts | by/in fits and starts

senses.definition: frequently starting and stopping again; not continuously

examples.en: Babies do not grow at a steady rate but in stops and starts.

senses.definition: to make the greatest effort possible to achieve something
the process of keeping something in a particular place until it is needed; the space where things can be kept

examples.en: tables that fold flat for storage
There's a lot of storage space in the loft.
food storage facilities
We need more storage now.

senses.definition: the process of keeping information, etc. on a computer; the way it is kept

examples.en: the storage and retrieval of information
data storage

senses.definition: the process of paying to keep furniture, etc. in a special building until you want it

examples.en: When we moved we had to put our furniture in storage for a while.

senses.definition: a large shop that sells many different types of goods

examples.en: It's available at London's three biggest stores.

senses.definition: a shop, large or small

examples.en: I'm going to the store.
His father opened a small grocery store.
