Stress is often a factor in the development of long-term sickness.
Few of us can understand the stresses of a job where an everyday mistake can cost lives.

senses.definition: physical pressure put on something that can damage it or make it lose its shape

examples.en: When you have an injury you start putting stress on other parts of your body.
Little is known about the effects of water stress on plants.
The building was condemned because of the damage caused by excessive heat stress.
Different organisms react differently to environmental stress (= damage to the environment caused by human activity or natural events).
a stress fracture of the foot (= one caused by such pressure)

senses.definition: an extra force used when pronouncing a particular word or syllable

examples.en: We worked on pronunciation, stress and intonation.
There's a stress on the second syllable.
In ‘strategic’ the stress falls on the second syllable

senses.definition: special importance given to something

examples.en: She lays great stress on punctuality.
I think the company places too much stress on cost and not enough on quality.

senses.definition: extra force used when making a particular sound in music
illness caused by difficult physical conditions
to give extra force to a word or syllable when saying it

examples.en: You stress the first syllable in ‘happiness’.
They might (and I stress the word 'might') do the right thing the next time.

senses.definition: to emphasize a fact, an idea, etc.

examples.en: He stressed the importance of a good education.
She stressed the need for cooperation with the authorities.
She is at pains to stress the cultural differences between the two countries.
I must stress that everything I've told you is strictly confidential.
I can't stress enough that security is of the highest importance.
‘There is,’ Johnson stressed, ‘no real alternative.’
It must be stressed that this disease is very rare.
I cannot stress too much how important this is.

senses.definition: to become or make somebody become too anxious or tired to be able to relax

examples.en: I just need to get some sleep and stop stressing.
I try not to stress out when things go wrong.
Driving in cities really stresses me (out).

senses.definition: to make something longer, wider or looser, for example by pulling it; to become longer, etc. in this way

examples.en: Is there any way of stretching shoes?
Stop stretching your sleeves like that!
This sweater has stretched.

senses.definition: to become bigger or longer when you pull it and return to its original shape when you stop

examples.en: The jeans stretch to provide a perfect fit.

senses.definition: to pull something so that it is smooth and tight

examples.en: Stretch the fabric tightly over the frame.
Striped awnings had been stretched across the courtyard.
Make sure that the rope is stretched tight.

senses.definition: to put your arms or legs out straight and contract your muscles

examples.en: He stretched and yawned lazily.
Andrea turned out the light and stretched full-length on the bed.
The exercises are designed to stretch and tone your leg muscles.
It was impossible to bend or stretch my legs.

senses.definition: to put out an arm or a leg in order to reach something

examples.en: She stretched across the table for the butter.
She stretched up to reach the top shelf.
I stretched out a hand and picked up the book.

senses.definition: to spread over an area of land

examples.en: Fields and hills stretched out as far as we could see.
The traffic jam seemed to stretch for miles.
A line of cars stretched into the distance.
The flat landscape stretched to the horizon.
Beyond the mountains stretches a vast desert.

senses.definition: to continue over a period of time

examples.en: The town's history stretches back to before 1500.
to stretch back years/decades/generations/centuries
The training stretches over a period of 16 months.
Endless summer days stretched out before us.
The talks look set to stretch into a second week.
The future stretched out endlessly in front of me.

senses.definition: to be enough to buy or pay for something

examples.en: I need a new car, but my savings won't stretch to it.
There are lots of things I’d like to buy, but our budget just won’t stretch that far.

senses.definition: to make use of a lot of your money, supplies, time, etc.

examples.en: The pandemic has stretched healthcare resources to the limit.
We can't take on any more work—we're fully stretched as it is.
The budget is already stretched to breaking point.

senses.definition: to increase your lead over somebody in a game or competition

examples.en: A minute later, Kelly stretched their lead to eight points.

senses.definition: to make use of all somebody’s skill, intelligence, etc.

examples.en: I need a job that will stretch me.
She was never really stretched at school.
The book really stretches your imagination.

senses.definition: to use something in a way that would not normally be considered fair, acceptable, etc.

examples.en: He admitted that he had maybe stretched the truth a little (= not been completely honest).
The play's plot stretches credulity to the limit.

senses.definition: to change the rules to suit a particular person or situation

examples.en: Couldn't they just bend the rules and let us in without a ticket?

senses.definition: to go for a short walk after sitting for some time

examples.en: It was good to get out of the car and stretch our legs.

senses.definition: to allow or do something that is not usually acceptable, especially because of a particular situation

examples.en: I was hoping they would stretch a point and let me stay on for a while.

senses.definition: an area of land or water, especially a long one

examples.en: a particularly dangerous stretch of road
There are tailbacks along a 10-mile stretch of the motorway.
an unspoilt stretch of coastline
You rarely see boats on this stretch of the river.

senses.definition: a continuous period of time

examples.en: They worked in four-hour stretches.
She used to read for hours at a stretch (= without stopping).

senses.definition: a period of time that somebody spends in prison

examples.en: He did a ten-year stretch for fraud.

senses.definition: an act of stretching out your arms or legs or your body and pulling the muscles tight; the state of being stretched

examples.en: We got out of the car and had a good stretch.
Only do these more difficult stretches when you are warmed up.
Stay in this position and feel the stretch in your legs.

senses.definition: the ability to be made longer or wider without breaking or tearing

examples.en: You need a material with plenty of stretch in it.
stretch jeans

senses.definition: a straight part at the end of a racing track

examples.en: the finishing stretch
The campaign has entered its final stretch.

senses.definition: using as much energy as possible, or the greatest possible amount of supplies

examples.en: Fire crews have been operating at full stretch.

idioms.word: not by any stretch of the imagination | by no stretch of the imagination

senses.definition: used to say strongly that something is not true, even if you try to imagine or believe it

examples.en: She could not, by any stretch of the imagination, be called beautiful.
By no stretch of the imagination could the trip be described as relaxing.

senses.definition: that must be obeyed exactly

examples.en: strict rules/regulations
There are strict guidelines on how the work is to be carried out.
The head teacher imposed very strict discipline.
She's on a very strict diet.
He told me in the strictest confidence (= on the understanding that I would tell nobody else).
He expected strict adherence to his rules.

senses.definition: demanding that rules, especially rules about behaviour, should be obeyed

examples.en: a strict teacher/parent/disciplinarian
I had a very strict upbringing.
She's very strict about things like homework.
They were always very strict with their children.

senses.definition: obeying the rules of a particular religion, belief, etc. exactly

examples.en: a strict follower of the faith
a strict vegan

senses.definition: very exact and clearly defined

examples.en: It wasn’t illegal in the strict sense (of the word).
They insisted on their strict legal rights.

senses.definition: with a lot of control and rules that must be obeyed

examples.en: She was brought up very strictly.
The industry is strictly regulated.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that something happens or must happen in all circumstances

examples.en: Smoking is strictly forbidden.
My letter is, of course, strictly private and confidential.

senses.definition: in all details; exactly

examples.en: This is not strictly true.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that something only applies to one particular person, thing or situation

examples.en: We'll look at the problem from a strictly legal point of view.
I know we're friends, but this is strictly business.
Their relationship is strictly platonic.

senses.definition: if you are using words or rules in their exact or correct sense

examples.en: Strictly speaking, the book is not a novel, but a short story.
Using the word in that context is not, strictly speaking, correct.

senses.definition: to hit somebody/something hard or with force

examples.en: The ship struck a rock.
The child ran into the road and was struck by a car.
The tree was struck by lightning.
Warplanes struck several targets in the city.
He fell, striking his head on the edge of the table.
He was struck in the head by a bullet.
The stone struck her on the forehead.
The oar struck against something hard.

senses.definition: to hit somebody/something with your hand or a weapon

examples.en: She struck him in the face.
He struck the table with his fist.
Who struck the first blow (= started the fight)?
Did she ever strike you?
He struck her two blows on the leg.

senses.definition: to hit or kick a ball, etc.

examples.en: He walked up to the penalty spot and struck the ball firmly into the back of the net.

senses.definition: to attack somebody/something, especially suddenly

examples.en: The lion crouched ready to strike.
Police fear that the killer may strike again.
The guerrillas struck with deadly force.

senses.definition: to happen suddenly and have a harmful or damaging effect on somebody/something

examples.en: Two days later tragedy struck.
Disaster struck again when their best player was injured.
The area was struck by an outbreak of cholera.

senses.definition: to come into somebody’s mind suddenly

examples.en: An awful thought has just struck me.
I was struck by her resemblance to my aunt.
One thing that really struck me was how calm he appeared.

examples.cf: it strikes somebody how, what, etc…
examples.en: It suddenly struck me how we could improve the situation.

senses.definition: to give somebody a particular impression

examples.en: Another part of his comment struck me.
His reaction struck me as odd.
She strikes me as a very efficient person.
How does the idea strike you?
It strikes me that nobody is really in favour of the changes.

senses.definition: to refuse to work because of an argument over pay or conditions

examples.en: Over 100 000 civil servants are set to strike on Tuesday.
Drivers are threatening to strike over pay.
The union has voted to strike for a pay increase of 6%.
Striking workers picketed the factory.

senses.definition: to fall on a surface

examples.en: The windows sparkled as the sun struck the glass.

senses.definition: to put somebody suddenly into a particular state

examples.en: to be struck dumb/deaf/blind

senses.definition: to rub something such as a match against a surface so that it produces a flame; to produce a flame when rubbed against a rough surface

examples.en: to strike a match on a wall
The sword struck sparks off the stone floor.
The matches were damp and he couldn't make them strike.

senses.definition: to show the time by making a ringing noise, etc.

examples.en: Did you hear the clock strike?
Four o’clock had just struck.
The clock has just struck three.

senses.definition: to produce a musical note, sound, etc. by pressing a key or hitting something

examples.en: She struck a chord on the piano and the children began to sing.

senses.definition: to discover gold, oil, etc. by digging or drilling

examples.en: They had struck oil!

senses.definition: to go somewhere with great energy or purpose

examples.en: We left the road and struck off across the fields.
He struck out (= started swimming) towards the shore.
The German army struck deep into northern France.

senses.definition: to be impressed or interested by somebody/something; to like somebody/something very much

examples.en: I was struck by her youth and enthusiasm.
We're not very struck on that new restaurant.

senses.definition: to argue in an aggressive way and force somebody to agree on the best possible price or arrangement
if a remark, etc. hits/strikes home, it has a strong effect on somebody, in a way that makes them realize what the true facts of a situation are

examples.en: Her face went pale as his words hit home.

senses.definition: to suddenly be in a successful situation, especially one that makes you rich

examples.en: The band really hit pay dirt with their last album.

senses.definition: to do, say or write something that is suitable/not suitable for a particular occasion

examples.en: It is a bizarre tale and the author hits just the right note of horror and disbelief.
Unfortunately, the president struck the wrong note in his speech, ignoring the public mood.

senses.definition: to hit the wooden frame of the goal in the game of football (soccer), instead of scoring a goal

examples.en: She hit the woodwork twice before scoring.

idioms.word: lightning never strikes (in the same place) twice

senses.definition: an unusual or unpleasant event is not likely to happen in the same place or to the same people twice
to express feelings or opinions of a particular kind

examples.en: She sounded a note of warning in her speech.
The touch of cynicism struck a slightly sour note.

idioms.word: strike a balance (between A and B)

senses.definition: to manage to find a way of being fair to two things that are opposed to each other; to find an acceptable position that is between two things

examples.en: We need to strike a balance between these conflicting interests.

senses.definition: to make an agreement with somebody in which both sides have an advantage

examples.en: Perhaps we could strike a bargain.
The United States has struck a historic deal with India.

senses.definition: to do something in support of/against a belief, principle, etc.

examples.en: He felt that they had struck a blow for democracy.

senses.definition: to say or do something that makes people feel sympathy or enthusiasm

examples.en: The speaker had obviously struck a chord with his audience.

idioms.word: strike fear, etc. into somebody/sb’s heart

senses.definition: to make somebody be afraid, etc.

examples.en: The sound of gunfire struck fear into the hearts of the villagers.

senses.definition: to find or do something that brings you a lot of success or money

examples.en: He has struck gold with his latest novel.

senses.definition: if a remark, etc. strikes/hits home, it has a strong effect on somebody, in a way that makes them realize what the true facts of a situation are

examples.en: His face went pale as her words struck home.

senses.definition: to get a lot of money, especially suddenly or unexpectedly
to have good luck

examples.en: We certainly struck it lucky with the weather.

senses.definition: to have a strong effect

examples.en: His work strikes a nerve with people who are attracted to nostalgia.
It seems I struck a nerve with my last post about cell phones.
Nissan may well strike a popular nerve here.

senses.definition: to suddenly be in a successful situation, especially one that makes you rich

examples.en: The band really struck pay dirt with their last album.

senses.definition: to hold your body in a particular way to create a particular impression

examples.en: to strike a dramatic pose
He strikes an attitude of bravery and lonely defiance.

senses.definition: to do, say or write something that is suitable/not suitable for a particular occasion

examples.en: It is a bizarre tale and the author strikes just the right note of horror and disbelief.

idioms.word: strike while the iron is hot

senses.definition: to make use of an opportunity immediately
near enough to be reached or attacked easily; near enough to reach or attack something easily

examples.en: The beach is within striking distance.
The cat was now within striking distance of the duck.

senses.definition: a period of time when an organized group of employees of a company stops working because of an argument over pay or conditions

examples.en: the miners'/firefighters'/teachers' strike
a strike by teachers
a one-day strike
an unofficial strike
Union leaders called a strike.
Air traffic controllers are threatening to go on strike.
Half the workforce are now (out) on strike.
to come out on strike
The train drivers have voted to take strike action.
The student union has called for a rent strike (= a refusal to pay rent as a protest).

senses.definition: a military attack, especially by aircraft dropping bombs

examples.en: They decided to launch a pre-emptive strike.
Diplomatic efforts have averted a military strike against the country.
The President ordered missile strikes against them in retaliation for the earlier bombing.

senses.definition: an act of hitting or kicking something/somebody

examples.en: His spectacular strike in the second half made the score 2–0.

senses.definition: an unsuccessful attempt to hit the ball
a situation in tenpin bowling when a player knocks down all the pins with the first ball
a sudden discovery of something valuable, especially oil
a bad thing or action that damages somebody/something’s reputation

examples.en: The amount of fuel that this car uses is a big strike against it.

idioms.word: three strikes and you’re out | the three strikes rule

senses.definition: used to describe a law that says that people who commit three crimes will go straight to prison
interesting and unusual enough to attract attention

examples.en: a striking feature
She bears a striking resemblance to her older sister.
In striking contrast to their brothers, the girls were both intelligent and charming.
The similarities between the two cases are striking.

senses.definition: very attractive, often in an unusual way

examples.en: striking good looks
She was undoubtedly a very striking young woman.
That hat looks very striking.

senses.definition: long, thin material used for tying things together, made of several threads that have been twisted together; a piece of string used to fasten or pull something or keep something in place

examples.en: a piece/length/ball of string
He wrapped the package in brown paper and tied it with string.
The key is hanging on a string by the door.

senses.definition: a set or series of things that are joined together, for example on a string

examples.en: a string of pearls
The molecules join together to form long strings.

senses.definition: a series of things or people that come closely one after another

examples.en: The band had a string of hits in the nineties.
He owns a string of racing stables.

senses.definition: a series of characters (= letters, numbers, etc.)

examples.en: to key in/enter a search string

senses.definition: a tightly stretched piece of wire, nylon, or catgut on a musical instrument, that produces a musical note when the instrument is played

examples.en: Play it on the G string.

senses.definition: the group of musical instruments in an orchestra that have strings, for example violins; the people who play them

examples.en: The opening theme is taken up by the strings.

senses.definition: any of the tightly stretched pieces of nylon or natural gut in a racket, used for hitting balls in tennis and some other sports
special conditions or limits

examples.en: Major loans like these always come with strings.
It's a business proposition, pure and simple. No strings attached.

senses.definition: (too much under) the influence and control of somebody

examples.en: The British prime minister is too apt to cling to Washington's apron strings.

idioms.word: have another string/more strings to your bow

senses.definition: to have more than one skill or plan that you can use if you need to

examples.en: The exhibition shows that he has other strings to his artistic bow.

idioms.word: how long is a piece of string?

senses.definition: used to say that there is no definite answer to a question

examples.en: ‘How long will it take?’ ‘How long's a piece of string?’

variants.html: (North American English also pull wires)

senses.definition: to use your influence in order to get an advantage for somebody
to control events or the actions of other people
to hang or tie something in place, especially as decoration

examples.en: We strung paper lanterns up in the trees.

examples.cf: string A on, along, in, etc. B
examples.en: Flags were strung out along the route.
The route was strung with flags.

senses.definition: to put a series of small objects on string, etc.; to join things together with string, etc.

examples.en: She had strung the shells on a silver chain.
carbon atoms strung together to form giant molecules

senses.definition: to put a string or strings on a racket or musical instrument
consisting of musical instruments that have strings; connected with these musical instruments

examples.en: a string quartet
a string player

senses.definition: made of string or something like string

examples.en: a string bag/vest

senses.definition: a long narrow piece of paper, metal, cloth, etc.

examples.en: a strip of material
Cut the meat into strips.

senses.definition: a long narrow area of land, sea, etc.

examples.en: the Gaza Strip
a tiny strip of garden
The islands are separated by a narrow strip of water.

variants.html: (North American English uniform)

senses.definition: the uniform that is worn by the members of a sports team when they are playing

examples.en: Juventus in their famous black and white strip
the team’s away strip (= that they use when playing games away from home)

senses.definition: an act of taking your clothes off, especially in a sexually exciting way and in front of an audience

examples.en: to do a strip
a strip show

senses.definition: a street that has many shops, stores, restaurants, etc. along it

examples.en: Sunset Strip

senses.definition: a series of drawings inside boxes that tell a story and are often published in newspapers

idioms.word: tear somebody off a strip | tear a strip off somebody

senses.definition: to speak angrily to somebody who has done something wrong
to take off all or most of your clothes or another person’s clothes

examples.en: I stripped and washed myself all over.
They ordered us to strip and lie down on the grass.
She stripped down to her underwear.
We stripped off and ran down to the water.
She stripped off her clothes and got into bed.
He stood there stripped to the waist (= he had no clothes on the upper part of his body).
He was stripped naked and left in a cell.

senses.definition: to take off your clothes as a form of entertainment; to perform a striptease
to remove a layer from something, especially so that it is completely exposed

examples.en: Strip off all the existing paint.
After the guests had gone, I stripped all the beds (= removed all the sheets in order to wash them).
Deer had stripped all the bark off the tree.
Deer had stripped the tree of its bark.

senses.definition: to remove all the things from a place and leave it empty

examples.en: We had to strip out all the old wiring and start again.
First, you need to strip away all the old plaster.
The movie aims to strip away the lies surrounding Kennedy's life.
Thieves had stripped the house bare.

senses.definition: to separate a machine, etc. into parts so that they can be cleaned or repaired

examples.en: He strips and cleans his rifle every morning.
They taught us how to strip down a car engine and put it back together again.

senses.definition: to take away property or honours from somebody, as a punishment

examples.en: He was disgraced and stripped of his title.
The president had been completely stripped of power.

senses.definition: to try very hard to achieve something

examples.en: We encourage all members to strive for the highest standards.
They were always striving towards perfection.
striving against corruption
Newspaper editors all strive to be first with a story.
She strove to find a solution that was acceptable to all.

senses.definition: an act of hitting a ball, for example with a bat or racket

examples.en: What a beautiful stroke!
He won by two strokes (= in golf, by taking two fewer strokes than his opponent).
He played some powerful backhand strokes throughout the game.

senses.definition: a single movement of the arm when hitting somebody/something

examples.en: His punishment was six strokes of the cane.

senses.definition: a single successful action or event

examples.en: Your idea was a stroke of genius.
It was a stroke of luck that I found you here.
It was a bold stroke to reveal the identity of the murderer on the first page.
She never does a stroke (of work) (= never does any work).
I had a sudden stroke of inspiration.

senses.definition: a sudden serious illness when a blood vessel (= tube) in the brain bursts (= breaks open) or is blocked, which can cause death or the loss of the ability to move or to speak clearly

examples.en: to have/suffer a stroke
The stroke left him partly paralysed.
Smoking increases the risk of stroke.

senses.definition: any of a series of repeated movements in swimming or rowing

examples.en: She took a few more strokes to reach the bank.
He swam with long powerful strokes.

senses.definition: a style of swimming

examples.en: Butterfly is the only stroke I can't do.

senses.definition: the person who sets the speed at which everyone in a boat rows
an act of moving your hand gently over a surface, usually several times

examples.en: He gave the cat a stroke.

senses.definition: a mark made by moving a pen, brush, etc. once across a surface

examples.en: to paint with fine brush strokes
At the stroke of a pen (= by signing something) they removed thousands of people from the welfare system.

senses.definition: each of the sounds made by a clock or bell giving the hours

examples.en: At the first stroke it will be 9 o'clock exactly.
on the stroke of three (= at 3 o’clock exactly)

idioms.word: at a (single) stroke | at one stroke

senses.definition: with a single immediate action

examples.en: They threatened to cancel the whole project at a stroke.
They lost half their fortune at a stroke.

senses.definition: to make somebody make a mistake or hesitate in what they are doing

examples.en: My speech was going well until I was put off my stroke by an interruption.

senses.definition: to move your hand gently and slowly over an animal’s fur or hair

examples.en: He's a beautiful dog. Can I stroke him?
She stroked the cat absently.

senses.definition: to move your hand gently over a surface, somebody’s hair, etc.

examples.en: He stroked her hair affectionately.
He stroked his beard thoughtfully.
He stroked back his hair.

senses.definition: to move something somewhere with a gentle movement

examples.en: She stroked away his tears.
He stroked the ball between the posts.

senses.definition: to be very nice to somebody, especially to get them to do what you want
having a lot of physical power so that you can lift heavy weights, do hard physical work, etc.

examples.en: He's strong enough to lift a car!
strong muscles
She wasn't a strong swimmer (= she could not swim well).

senses.definition: having great power

examples.en: Stay indoors in the middle of the day, when the sun is strongest.
a strong wind
a strong magnet/current

senses.definition: having a powerful effect on the body or mind

examples.en: a strong drug
His imagery made a strong impression on the critics.

senses.definition: having a lot of power or influence

examples.en: a strong leader
What the country needs right now is a strong government.

senses.definition: people who are rich or powerful
difficult to attack or criticize

examples.en: There is strong evidence of a link between exercise and a healthy heart.
You have a strong case for getting your job back.

senses.definition: very powerful and difficult for people to fight against or defeat

examples.en: a strong team
The proposal aroused strong opposition.
The temptation to tell her everything was very strong.
He exerts an extremely strong influence on his classmates.

senses.dis_g: (of an opinion, a belief, or a feeling)
senses.definition: very powerful

examples.en: strong support for the government
People have strong feelings about this issue.

senses.definition: holding an opinion or a belief very seriously

examples.en: a strong supporter of the government
a strong opponent
She has long been one of the strongest advocates of sanctions.

senses.definition: easy to see, hear, feel or smell; very great or intense

examples.en: a strong smell
a strong feeling of nausea
a strong voice (= loud)
strong colours
a face with strong features (= large and easy to notice)
She spoke with a strong Australian accent.
He was under strong pressure to resign.

senses.definition: having a lot of taste

examples.en: strong cheese
You'll need to use plenty of strong French mustard.

senses.definition: containing a lot of a substance

examples.en: strong black coffee

senses.definition: not easily broken or damaged; made well

examples.en: The box looks strong enough.

senses.definition: not easily upset or frightened; not easily influenced by other people

examples.en: You need strong nerves to ride a bike in London.
Every child needs to develop a strong sense of identity.
It's difficult, I know. But be strong!
a strong personality
She’s had a strong will since she was a baby.
We must stand strong in the face of adversity.

senses.definition: likely to succeed or happen

examples.en: a strong candidate for the job
You're in a strong position to negotiate a deal.
There's a strong possibility that we'll lose the game.

senses.definition: having existed for a long time and functioning well; difficult to destroy

examples.en: a strong marriage
The college has strong links with local industry.
I know that their relationship is growing stronger every day.

senses.definition: having a value that is high or increasing

examples.en: strong share prices
The country is currently experiencing particularly strong economic growth.
The euro is getting stronger against the dollar.
This news helped keep the dollar relatively strong today.

senses.definition: in a safe financial position

examples.en: Their catering business remained strong despite the recession.

senses.definition: good at something; done well

examples.en: The play has a very strong cast.
The actors give extremely strong performances.
Mathematics was never my strong point (= I was never very good at it).

senses.definition: great in number

examples.en: There was a strong police presence at the demonstration.
Sales were surprisingly strong in the second half of the year.

senses.definition: used after numbers to show the size of a group

examples.en: a 5 000-strong crowd
The crowd was 5 000 strong.

senses.definition: not easily affected by disease; healthy

examples.en: These vitamins are meant to keep you healthy and strong.

senses.definition: having a lot of force, often causing offence to people

examples.en: The movie has been criticized for strong language (= swearing).

senses.definition: forming the past tense and past participle by changing a vowel, not by adding a regular ending, for example sing, sang, sung
used to describe the way some words are pronounced when they have stress. For example, the strong form of and is /ænd/.
used to say that you think what somebody has said is unfair or too critical
something that gives somebody an advantage over other people in a particular situation
to be good at something

examples.en: I'm not very strong on dates (= I can't remember the dates of important events).

senses.definition: to have a lot of something

examples.en: The report was strong on criticism, but short on practical suggestions.

senses.definition: to be a subject that somebody knows a lot about

examples.en: I'm afraid geography is not my strong suit.

senses.definition: to make your feelings clear in an aggressive way, especially your sexual feelings towards somebody
to continue to be healthy, active or successful

examples.en: My grandmother is 90 and still going strong.
The business is still going strong.

senses.definition: to be able to see or do unpleasant things without feeling sick or upset

examples.en: You need a strong stomach to go on the giant roller coaster.

senses.definition: in a way that shows definite and serious opinions or beliefs

examples.en: a strongly worded protest
He was strongly opposed to the idea.
This is an issue I feel strongly about.
This decision was strongly criticized by both sides.
Nearly all of them strongly agree that education is the key to success.
I strongly disagree with this statement.
We believe strongly in the importance of taking personal responsibility for our own actions.
We strongly urge the British government to take the necessary action.
I strongly suspect that this whole story is fictional.
The company says it strongly believes in the importance of organic agriculture.

senses.definition: to a great degree or extent

examples.en: Health spending is strongly linked to the country's wealth.
These conclusions are strongly supported by a recent study.
Interest is already very high and advance booking is strongly recommended.
She was strongly influenced by his views.
The evidence strongly suggests that he did not commit the crime.

senses.definition: in a way that is easy to notice

examples.en: The room smelt strongly of polish.
These works are strongly reminiscent of earlier paintings.

senses.definition: with a lot of power or force

examples.en: a light shining strongly
He finished strongly in a time of 38 minutes, 44 seconds.
The market rebounded strongly in the second half of the year.

senses.definition: in a way that means something cannot be easily broken or damaged

examples.en: a strongly built boat

senses.definition: connected with the way in which something is built or organized

examples.en: Storms have caused structural damage to hundreds of homes.
structural changes in society
a structural survey (= an examination of a building to check for any damage to the walls, roof, etc.)
There is an urgent need to address structural racism within the organization.

senses.definition: the way in which the parts of something are connected together, arranged or organized; a particular arrangement of parts

examples.en: the structure of the building
changes in the economic structure of society
Bees have a complex social structure.
the grammatical structures of a language
the structure of proteins/DNA

senses.definition: a thing that is made of several parts, especially a building

examples.en: a stone/brick/wooden structure
She used sand and rocks to build elaborate structures on the beach.

senses.definition: the state of being well organized or planned with all the parts linked together; a careful plan

examples.en: Your essay needs (a) structure.

senses.definition: to arrange or organize something into a system or pattern

examples.en: How well does the teacher structure the lessons?
Make use of the toys in structured group activities.
The exhibition is structured around the themes of work and leisure.

senses.definition: to try very hard to do something when it is difficult or when there are a lot of problems

examples.en: life as a struggling artist (= one who is very poor)
Shona struggled for breath.
a country struggling for independence
The firm is struggling to cope with the demand for its products.
Local workers were still struggling to find employment.
Most social enterprises struggle to survive.
We're already struggling to keep up with demand.
They struggled just to pay their bills.
She struggled for 10 years to achieve success as an actress.
I was unemployed and struggling financially.
The housing market continues to struggle.

senses.definition: to move somewhere or do something with difficulty

examples.en: I struggled up the hill with the heavy bags.
Paul struggled out of his wheelchair.
She had to struggle into the tight dress.

senses.definition: to fight against somebody/something in order to prevent a bad situation or result

examples.en: Chloe continued to struggle, but her eyes began to close.
He struggled against cancer for two years.
We should all struggle against injustice.
I have been struggling with injury for a couple of years.
I am struggling with the same issues that other people are.
Lisa struggled with her conscience before talking to the police.

senses.definition: to fight somebody or try to get away from them

examples.en: I struggled and screamed for help.
James was hit in the mouth as he struggled with the raiders.
How did she manage to struggle free?

senses.definition: to compete or argue with somebody/something, especially in order to get something

examples.en: rival leaders struggling for power
countries struggling with each other for economic and military advantage

senses.definition: a hard fight in which people try to obtain or achieve something, especially something that somebody else does not want them to have

examples.en: Marx wrote about the class struggle.
She played a very important role during the freedom struggle.
a struggle for independence
Three teams are locked in a struggle for this year's title.
They took up the struggle against racism.
her struggle with cancer
He is engaged in a bitter struggle with his rival to get control of the company.
an ongoing power struggle between president and prime minister
the struggle between good and evil
She will not give up her children without a struggle.

senses.definition: a physical fight between two people or groups of people, especially when one of them is trying to escape, or to get something from the other

examples.en: There were no signs of a struggle at the murder scene.
After a short struggle, I managed to get the knife away from him.
He was involved in a struggle with the police.
The group supported the armed struggle against the dictator.

senses.definition: something that is difficult for you to do or achieve

examples.en: It was a real struggle to be ready on time.
They face an uphill struggle to get to the finals of the competition.

senses.definition: a person who is studying at a university or college

examples.en: a college/university student
a graduate student
a medical/law student
international students (= who come to study from other countries)
She's a student at Oxford.
He's a third-year student at the College of Art.
a student loan (= money lent to students to pay for their studies)
He is here on a student visa.
a plan to reduce student debt
student fees (= to pay for the cost of teaching)
a student nurse/teacher
a dramatic increase in student numbers
I did some acting in my student days.

senses.definition: a person who is studying at a school, especially a secondary school

examples.en: a 15-year-old high school student
a teacher who engages her students

senses.definition: a person who is very interested in a particular subject

examples.en: a keen student of human nature
He was a deeply observant man, a close student of the natural world.

senses.definition: a room where radio or television programmes are recorded and broadcast from, or where music is recorded

examples.en: a television/recording studio
a studio audience (= one in a studio, that can be seen or heard as a programme is broadcast)
She has released eight studio albums.

senses.definition: a place where films are made or produced

examples.en: The tour guide is showing a group of tourists around a movie studio.
a film studio

senses.definition: a company that makes films

examples.en: She works for a major Hollywood studio.
a film/movie studio
a studio executive

senses.definition: a room where an artist works

examples.en: I wanted to turn the room into an artist's studio.
a sculptor’s studio
He was hoping to convert the cellar into a photographic studio.

senses.definition: a place where dancing is taught or where dancers practise

examples.en: a dance studio

variants.html: (British English also studio flat)

senses.definition: a small flat with one main room for living and sleeping in and usually a kitchen and bathroom
the activity of learning or gaining knowledge, either from books or by examining things in the world

examples.en: a room set aside for private study
academic/literary/scientific study
It is important to develop good study skills.
Physiology is the study of how living things work.

senses.definition: a particular person’s learning activities, for example at a college or university

examples.en: to continue your studies
Many undertake further studies after college.

senses.definition: used in the names of some academic subjects

examples.en: business/media/American studies

senses.definition: a piece of research that examines a subject or question in detail

examples.en: to conduct/undertake a study
Research studies carried out in Italy confirmed the theory.
He has recently done a study on the effects of traffic and aircraft noise.
a detailed study of how animals adapt to their environment
scientific studies of fishing grounds and methods of fishing
This study shows/finds/suggests that…
the purpose/aim of a study
the results/findings of a study
the methods used in the present study
in previous/earlier studies
According to a recent study published in the Journal of Sleep Research…

senses.definition: an academic book or article on a particular topic

examples.en: a study of Jane Austen's novels
Shakespeare is the subject of a new study by Anthony Bryan.

senses.definition: the act of considering or examining something in detail

examples.en: These proposals deserve careful study.
the biochemical process under study

senses.definition: a room, especially in somebody’s home, used for reading and writing

examples.en: She crossed the hallway and opened the door to her private study.

senses.definition: a drawing or painting of something, especially one done for practice or before doing a larger picture

examples.en: a study of Chartres Cathedral
a nude study

senses.definition: the act of showing or describing somebody/something in literature or another art form, especially a character or an aspect of behaviour

examples.en: The novel is a character study of a city and its people.

senses.definition: a piece of music designed to give a player practice in technical skills
a perfect example of something

examples.en: His face was a study in concentration.

senses.definition: thinking deeply so that you do not notice what is happening around you
to spend time learning about a subject by reading, going to college, etc.

examples.en: He sat up very late that night, studying.
How long have you been studying English?
Don't disturb Jane, she's studying for her exams.
My brother studied photography at the Royal College of Art.
She studied at New College, Oxford.
a composer who studied music under Nadia Boulanger (= was taught music by Nadia Boulanger)
He studied under Wagner in Vienna.
Nina is studying to be an architect.
He is studying to teach children with special needs.

senses.definition: to watch or to look at somebody/something carefully in order to find out something

examples.en: Scientists are studying photographs of the planet for signs of life.
He studied her face thoughtfully.
Fran was studying the menu.
She picked up the letter and studied it carefully.

senses.definition: to examine something carefully in order to understand it

examples.en: We will study the report carefully before making a decision.
The group will study how the region coped with the loss of thousands of jobs.
They are studying what happens to people who unexpectedly win a lot of money.

senses.definition: used to refer to a substance, material, group of objects, etc. when you do not know the name, when the name is not important or when it is obvious what you are talking about

examples.en: What's all that sticky stuff on the carpet?
The chairs were covered in some sort of plastic stuff.
This hot sauce is good stuff.
I don't know how you can eat that stuff!
They sell stationery and stuff (like that).
Where's all my stuff (= my possessions)?
Could you move all that stuff off the table?
I want to buy some expensive tech stuff.

senses.definition: used to refer in a general way to things that people do, say, think, etc.

examples.en: Peter's article had lots of interesting stuff in it.
There's still a lot of cool stuff happening in Manchester.
I've got loads of stuff to do today.
I like reading and stuff.
The band did some great stuff on their first album.
This is all good stuff. Well done!
I don't believe in all that stuff about ghosts.
What's all this ‘Mrs Smith’ stuff? Call me Anna.
He's done so much stuff and been so many interesting places.
I've read a whole bunch of stuff by different people over the past few days.

senses.definition: the most important feature of something; something that something else is based on or is made from

examples.en: The trip was magical; the stuff of which dreams are made.
Parades and marches were the very stuff of politics in the region.
Connor's story is the stuff of legend.
the stuff of dreams/nightmares
Let’s see what stuff you’re made of (= what sort of person you are).

senses.definition: to have a stronger character and to be more determined in dealing with problems than other people

examples.en: Many would have given up, but Tim was made of sterner stuff.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody not to worry about small details or things that are not important
to do what you are good at or what you have been trained to do

examples.en: Some members of the team are just not doing their stuff (= doing as well as they should).
The medicine has clearly done its stuff.

variants.html: (North American English kid stuff)

senses.definition: something that is so easy to do or understand that it is thought to be not very serious or only suitable for children

examples.en: That was kids' stuff compared with what lies ahead.
The movie is pure kids' stuff from beginning to end.

senses.definition: to know a lot about a particular subject or job
to not care at all about something
to proudly show your ability, especially at dancing or performing

examples.en: strutting your stuff to the latest chart hits

senses.definition: used to say that something is stupid or not true
to fill a space or container tightly with something

examples.en: She had 500 envelopes to stuff with leaflets.

examples.cf: stuff B in, into, under A
examples.en: She had 500 leaflets to stuff into envelopes.
The fridge is stuffed to bursting.
All the drawers were stuffed full of letters and papers.

senses.definition: to push something quickly and carelessly into a small space

examples.en: She stuffed the money under a cushion.
His hands were stuffed in his pockets.
Robyn quickly stuffed clothes into an overnight bag.
The police found the money that she'd stuffed down her dress.

senses.definition: to fill a vegetable, chicken, etc. with another type of food

examples.en: Are you going to stuff the turkey?
stuffed peppers

senses.definition: to eat a lot of food or too much food; to give somebody a lot or too much to eat

examples.en: He sat at the table stuffing himself.
Don't stuff the kids with chocolate before their dinner.
We stuffed our faces at the party.

senses.definition: to fill the dead body of an animal with material and preserve it, so that it keeps its original shape and appearance

examples.en: They had had their pet dog stuffed.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody in a rude and angry way to go away, or that you do not want something

examples.en: If they don’t offer you more money, tell them to get stuffed.

senses.definition: used to show that you have changed your mind about something or do not care about something

examples.en: I didn't want a part in the play, then I thought—stuff it—why not?
Stuff it. At my age it doesn’t matter.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody in a rude and angry way that you do not want something

examples.en: I told them they could stuff their job.

senses.definition: a problem or temporary failure when you are on the way to achieving something

examples.en: There were good reasons for the team's first-round stumble against Los Angeles.

senses.definition: an act of falling or almost falling, especially because you hit your foot against something

examples.en: After a slight stumble backwards, he regained his balance.

senses.definition: a mistake that causes you to stop when you are reading, speaking or playing music

examples.en: verbal stumbles

senses.definition: to hit your foot against something while you are walking or running and almost fall

examples.en: The child stumbled and fell.
I stumbled over a rock.

senses.definition: to walk or move in an unsteady way

examples.en: Max stumbled out of bed sleepily.
We were stumbling around in the dark looking for a candle.

senses.definition: to make a mistake or mistakes and stop while you are speaking, reading to somebody or playing music

examples.en: In her nervousness she stumbled over her words.
I stumbled through the piano piece with difficulty.

senses.definition: to make a person or an animal unconscious for a short time, especially by hitting them on the head

examples.en: The fall stunned me for a moment.
The animals are stunned before slaughter.

senses.definition: to surprise or shock somebody so much that they cannot think clearly or speak

examples.en: Her words stunned me—I had no idea she felt that way.
The guests were stunned into silence.
The company stunned investors with its third profits warning in five months.

senses.definition: to impress somebody very much

examples.en: They were stunned by the view from the summit.

senses.definition: extremely attractive or impressive

examples.en: You look absolutely stunning!
a stunning view of the lake
His performance was simply stunning.

senses.definition: that surprises or shocks you very much

examples.en: He suffered a stunning defeat in the election.

senses.definition: showing a lack of thought or good judgement

examples.en: a stupid mistake/question/idea
It was a pretty stupid thing to do.
You've been warned, so don't do anything stupid.
I was stupid enough to believe him.
It was stupid of you to get involved.
That was just plain stupid!
We made some incredibly stupid business mistakes.

senses.definition: not clever or intelligent; slow to learn or understand

examples.en: He'll manage—he isn't stupid.
Forgetting my notes made me look stupid.
She always makes me feel really stupid.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you are annoyed with somebody/something

examples.en: I can't get the stupid thing open!
Get your stupid feet off the chair!

senses.definition: an offensive word for somebody who you think is not being very intelligent

examples.en: Yes, stupid, it's you I'm talking to!

senses.definition: the particular way in which something is done

examples.en: a wide range of musical styles
They want a wide range of learning resources to suit different learning styles.
a management style
a style of management
furniture to suit your style of living
His aggressive style of play sometimes gets him in trouble.
I really enjoy playing this style of music.
I like your style (= I like the way you do things).
Caution was not her style (= not the way she usually behaved).
I'm surprised he rides a motorbike—I'd have thought big cars were more his style (= what suited him).

senses.definition: a particular design of something, especially clothes

examples.en: We stock a wide variety of styles and sizes.
Have you thought about having your hair in a shorter style?
a style that was popular in the 1950s

senses.definition: the quality of being fashionable in the clothes that you wear

examples.en: style-conscious teenagers
Some people have no sense of style.
Short skirts are back in style (= fashionable).
They still refer to her as a style guru and a trend-setter.

senses.definition: the quality of being attractive and made or done to a high standard

examples.en: The hotel has been redecorated but it's lost a lot of its style.
This movie is all surface style and no substance.
She does everything with style and grace.

senses.definition: the features of a book, painting, building, etc. that make it typical of a particular author, artist, historical period, etc.

examples.en: a style of architecture
a fine example of Gothic style
The film has a unique visual style.
He developed a distinctive style of painting.
a parody written in the style of Molière
The palace was rebuilt in the same style.

senses.definition: the correct use of language

examples.en: It's not considered good style to start a sentence with ‘but’.
Please follow house style (= the rules of spelling, etc. used by a particular publishing company).

senses.definition: having the type of style mentioned

examples.en: Italian-style gardens
a buffet-style breakfast

senses.definition: the long, thin part of a flower that carries the stigma
to stop somebody from behaving in the way they want to

examples.en: She didn’t want me to go with her to the party in case I cramped her style.

senses.definition: in an impressive way

examples.en: She always celebrates her birthday in style.
He won the championship in great style.

senses.definition: to design, make or shape something in a particular way

examples.en: an elegantly styled jacket
He'd had his hair styled at an expensive salon.

senses.definition: to give somebody/something/yourself a particular name or title

examples.en: He styled himself Major Carter.
The company was originally styled ‘Imperial Designs’.

senses.definition: a thing or person that is being discussed, described or dealt with

examples.en: Walker's work has been the subject of much debate.
a subject of discussion/conversation
Nelson Mandela is the subject of a new biography.
The incident is currently the subject of a police investigation.
books on many different subjects
I have nothing more to say on the subject.
a magazine article on the subject of space travel
How did we get onto the subject of marriage?
I wish you'd change the subject (= talk about something else).
We seem to have got off the subject we're meant to be discussing.
a subject for debate/discussion
The university runs a wide range of research programmes in different subject areas.

senses.definition: an area of knowledge studied in a school, college, etc.

examples.en: Biology is my favourite subject.
Which subjects are you studying?
The college offers a wide range of subjects.

senses.definition: a person or thing that is the main feature of a picture or photograph, or that a work of art is based on

examples.en: Focus the camera on the subject.
Classical landscapes were a popular subject with many 18th century painters.

senses.definition: a person or thing being used to study something, especially in an experiment

examples.en: We need male subjects between the ages of 18 and 25 for the experiment.

senses.definition: a noun, noun phrase or pronoun representing the person or thing that performs the action of the verb (I in I sat down.), about which something is stated (the house in the house is very old) or, in a passive sentence, that is affected by the action of the verb (the tree in the tree was blown down in the storm)
a person who belongs to a particular country, especially one with a king or queen

examples.en: a British subject
The prince had to tax his subjects heavily to raise money for the war.

senses.definition: likely to be affected by something, especially something bad

examples.en: At this stage these are proposals and are still subject to change.
The rent is subject to review every five years.
Flights are subject to delay because of the fog.

senses.definition: depending on something in order to be completed or agreed

examples.en: The article is ready to publish, subject to your approval.
The offer is subject to certain conditions.
We are now in the process of agreeing a sale, subject to contract.
All the holidays on offer are subject to availability.

senses.definition: under the authority of something/somebody

examples.en: As a diplomat, he is not subject to local laws.
All nuclear installations are subject to international safeguards.
Everyone was entirely subject to the whim of the Sultan.

senses.definition: controlled by the government of another country

examples.en: subject peoples

senses.definition: to bring a country or group of people under your control, especially by using force

examples.en: The Roman Empire subjected most of Europe to its rule.

senses.definition: the act of accepting that somebody has defeated you and that you must obey them

examples.en: a gesture of submission
to beat/force/starve somebody into submission
His response was one of resistance, not submission.

senses.definition: the act of giving a document, proposal, etc. to somebody in authority so that they can study or consider it; the document, etc. that you give

examples.en: When is the final date for the submission of proposals?
They prepared a report for submission to the council.
The deadline is 1 October and late submissions will not be marked.
Many diploma courses require the submission of a project.

senses.definition: a statement that is made to a judge in court

examples.en: All parties will have the opportunity to make submissions relating to this case.
The judge upheld the defendant's submission and quashed his conviction.

senses.definition: to give a document, proposal, etc. to somebody in authority so that they can study or consider it

examples.en: to submit an application/a claim/a proposal
Completed projects must be submitted by 10 March.
She submitted her report to the committee.
Articles should be submitted electronically as email attachments.

senses.definition: to accept the authority, control or greater strength of somebody/something; to agree to something because of this

examples.en: She refused to submit to threats.
He submitted himself to a search by the guards.

senses.definition: to say or suggest something

examples.en: Counsel for the defence submitted that the evidence was inadmissible.

senses.definition: a person who pays money, usually once a year, to receive regular copies of a magazine or newspaper or have access to it online

examples.en: subscribers to ‘New Scientist’
Subscribers to the magazine can take advantage of this special offer.

senses.definition: a person who pays to receive a service

examples.en: subscribers to cable television

senses.definition: a person who gives money regularly to help the work of an organization such as a charity

examples.en: subscribers to Oxfam

senses.definition: an amount of money that you pay regularly to receive a service, be a member of a club, support a charity or receive regular copies of a newspaper or magazine; the act of paying this money

examples.en: an annual subscription
a subscription to Netflix
a monthly subscription to Oxfam
to take out a subscription to ‘Newsweek’
to cancel/renew a subscription
Copies are available by subscription.
Subscriptions are due annually by the end of January.

senses.definition: the act of people paying money for something to be done

examples.en: A statue in his memory was erected by public subscription.

senses.definition: happening or coming after something else

examples.en: subsequent generations
Subsequent events confirmed our doubts.
Developments on this issue will be dealt with in a subsequent report.

senses.definition: afterwards; later; after something else has happened

examples.en: The original interview notes were subsequently lost.
Subsequently, new guidelines were issued to all employees.
He subsequently became chairman of the party.

senses.definition: money that is paid by a government or an organization to reduce the costs of services or of producing goods so that their prices can be kept low

examples.en: agricultural subsidies
to reduce the level of subsidy

senses.definition: a type of solid, liquid or gas that has particular qualities

examples.en: a sticky substance
a chemical/radioactive/hazardous substance
Some frogs produce toxic substances in their skin.

senses.definition: a drug, especially an illegal one

examples.en: illegal/controlled substances
He was disqualified from competing after testing positive to a banned substance.
Adolescent substance use remains high in the United States.

senses.definition: the quality of being based on facts or the truth

examples.en: The commission's report gives substance to these allegations.
There is some substance in what he says.
It was malicious gossip, completely without substance.

senses.definition: the most important or main part of something

examples.en: Love and guilt form the substance of his new book.
The real substance of the report was in the third part.
I agreed with what she said in substance, though not with every detail.
There seems to be no difference in substance between the two procedures.

senses.definition: importance

examples.en: matters of substance
Nothing of any substance was achieved in the meeting.

senses.definition: a rich and powerful man or woman
large in amount, value or importance

examples.en: substantial sums of money
a substantial change
Substantial numbers of people support the reforms.
He ate a substantial breakfast.
There are substantial differences between the two groups.
Their share of the software market is substantial.
We were able to see a substantial improvement.

senses.definition: large and solid; strongly built

examples.en: a substantial house
a street of substantial Victorian villas

senses.definition: very much; a lot

examples.en: The costs have increased substantially.
The plane was substantially damaged in the crash.
The company’s profits have been substantially lower this year.

senses.definition: mainly; in most details, even if not completely

examples.en: What she says is substantially true.

senses.definition: a person or thing that you use or have instead of the one you normally use or have

examples.en: a meat substitute
a substitute family
Paul's father only saw him as a substitute for his dead brother.
The course teaches you the theory but there's no substitute for practical experience.
The local bus service was a poor substitute for their car.

senses.definition: a player who replaces another player in a sports game

examples.en: He was brought on as (a) substitute after half-time.

senses.definition: to take the place of somebody/something else; to use somebody/something instead of somebody/something else

examples.en: Nothing can substitute for the advice your doctor is able to give you.
Can you find someone to substitute for you at the meeting?
Margarine can be substituted for butter in this recipe.
Butter can be substituted with margarine in this recipe.
Kane was substituted in the second half after a knee injury (= somebody else played instead of Kane in the second half).

senses.definition: an act of using one person or thing in the place of another

examples.en: Two substitutions were made during the game.
the substitution of low-fat spreads for butter
the substitution of butter with low-fat spreads

senses.definition: not very obvious or easy to notice

examples.en: subtle colours/flavours/smells, etc.
There are subtle differences between the two versions.
The fragrance is a subtle blend of jasmine and sandalwood.
She's been dropping subtle hints about what she'd like as a present.

senses.definition: behaving or organized in a clever way, and using indirect methods, in order to achieve something

examples.en: I decided to try a more subtle approach.
a subtle plan
a subtle use of lighting in the play

senses.definition: good at noticing and understanding things

examples.en: The job required a subtle mind.

variants.text: (also North American English, informal the burbs)
variants.html: (also North American English, informal the burbs)

senses.definition: an area where people live that is outside the centre of a city

examples.en: a suburb of London
a London suburb
They live in the suburbs.

senses.definition: in or connected with a suburb

examples.en: suburban areas
a suburban street
life in suburban London

senses.definition: boring and ordinary

examples.en: a suburban lifestyle

senses.definition: to achieve something that you have been trying to do or get; to have the result or effect that was intended

examples.en: Our plan succeeded.
Whether we succeed or fail depends on ingenuity and luck.
He succeeded in getting a place at art school.
I tried to discuss it with her but only succeeded in making her angry (= I failed and did the opposite of what I intended).

senses.definition: to be successful in your job, earning money, power, respect, etc.

examples.en: You will have to work hard if you are to succeed.
She doesn't have the ruthlessness required to succeed in business.
He had hoped to succeed as a violinist.

senses.definition: to come next after somebody/something and take their/its place or position

examples.en: Who succeeded Kennedy as President?
Their early success was succeeded by a period of miserable failure.
Strands of DNA are reproduced through succeeding generations.

senses.definition: to gain the right to a title, property, etc. when somebody dies

examples.en: She succeeded to the throne (= became queen) in 1558.
He had no right to succeed to the tenancy when his father died.

senses.definition: when you are successful in one area of your life, it often leads to success in other areas
the fact that you have achieved something that you want and have been trying to do or get

senses.definition: the fact of becoming rich or famous or of getting a high social position

senses.definition: a person or thing that has achieved a good result and been successful

senses.definition: when you are successful in one area of your life, it often leads to success in other areas

senses.definition: a very great success

senses.definition: the pleasant feeling of being successful

senses.definition: in a way that achieves your aims or what was intended

senses.definition: the regular pattern of one thing following another thing

senses.definition: of the type already mentioned

senses.definition: of a kind that; like

senses.definition: used to say that there is not much of something or that it is of poor quality

senses.definition: used to say that something is very bad

idioms.word: teach your grandmother to suck eggs

senses.definition: to tell or show somebody how to do something that they can already do well, and probably better than you can

senses.definition: to be very impatient with people that you think are stupid

senses.definition: enough for a particular purpose; as much as you need

variants.html: (North American English also grocery store)
