This information was kindly supplied by the manufacturer.
Please supply your email address.
He was charged with intent to supply (= planning to sell) class A drugs.

senses.definition: to help or encourage somebody/something by saying or showing that you agree with them/it

examples.en: to support an idea/a view
The party fully supports new welfare reform bill.
Efforts to reduce waste are strongly supported by environmental groups.
The majority of ordinary citizens did not support the war.
If you raise it at the meeting, I'll support you.
The government supported the unions in their demand for a minimum wage.

senses.definition: to give or be ready to give help to somebody if they need it

examples.en: an organization that supports people with AIDS
She supported her husband through many difficult times.
The company will support customers in Europe (= solve their problems with a product).

senses.definition: to like a particular sports team, watch their games, etc.

examples.en: Which team do you support?
Who do you support?

senses.definition: to help or encourage something to be successful by giving it money

examples.en: The project was supported by grants from various charities.
A number of famous actors actively supported the campaign.
Several major companies are supporting the project.

senses.definition: to provide everything necessary, especially money, so that somebody/something can live or exist

examples.en: He struggles to support his family.
She supported herself through college by working as a waitress in a local bar.
He turned to crime to support his drug habit.
The atmosphere of Mars could not support life.

senses.definition: to help to show that something is true

examples.en: Current data support this hypothesis.
There is no evidence to support his claims.
The witness's story was not supported by the evidence.
He said the figures were questionable and not well supported.

senses.definition: to hold somebody/something in position; to prevent somebody/something from falling

examples.en: a platform supported by concrete pillars
Support the baby's head when you hold it.
She walked carefully down the stairs, supported by her grandson.

senses.definition: to perform in a pop or rock concert before the main performer

examples.en: They were supported by a local Liverpool band.

senses.definition: to allow a particular program, language or device to be used with it

examples.en: This digital audio player supports multiple formats.

senses.definition: approval that you give to somebody/something because you want them to be successful

examples.en: There is strong public support for the policy.
There is a continued lack of support for the war.
His ideas are gaining popular support (= the support of many people).
to provide/offer support
I intend to lend my full support to the campaign.
to win/gain somebody's support
Can I rely on your support (= will you vote for me) in the election?
The policy has broad support from industry.
Only a few people spoke in support of the proposal.
organizations that provide advice and support to small businesses

senses.definition: money or goods that you give to somebody/something in order to help them

examples.en: They received no financial support from the government.
She has no visible means of support (= no work, income etc.).

senses.definition: sympathy and help that you give to somebody who is in a difficult or unhappy situation

examples.en: Her family and friends have given her lots of support.
Thank you for all your messages of support at this difficult time.
He turned to his closest friends for support.
support staff/services
a support network/system

senses.definition: evidence that helps to show that something is true or correct

examples.en: This suggestion lacks convincing experimental support.
The statistics offer further support for our theory.
There is little evidence in support of this hypothesis.

senses.definition: a thing that holds something and prevents it from falling

examples.en: The supports under the bridge were starting to bend.
When my father died, Jim was a real support.

senses.definition: the act of holding something in position or preventing it from falling

examples.en: She held on to his arm for support.
After the operation he couldn't walk without support.
A firmer mattress gives your back an improved level of support.

senses.definition: something you wear to hold an injured or weak part of your body in position

examples.en: a knee/back support

senses.definition: a band or singer who performs in a pop or rock concert before the main performer

examples.en: The support (act) has yet to be confirmed.

senses.definition: technical help that a company gives to customers using their computers or other products

examples.en: There is a lack of decent home user support.

senses.definition: a person who supports a political party, an idea, etc.

examples.en: a strong/loyal/staunch/ardent supporter
Labour supporters
The magazine is free to members and supporters.
About a hundred of his supporters rallied to demand justice.

senses.definition: a person who supports a particular sports team

examples.en: I'm an Arsenal supporter.

senses.definition: encouraging somebody or giving them help or sympathy

examples.en: a supportive family
She was very supportive during my father's illness.
a mutually supportive relationship
He was strongly supportive of my career.

senses.definition: to think or believe that something is true or possible (based on the knowledge that you have)

examples.en: Getting a visa isn't as simple as you might suppose.
Prices will go up, I suppose.
I don't suppose for a minute that he'll agree (= I'm sure that he won't).
It's reasonable to suppose that he left the note after he tried to call her.
Why do you suppose he resigned?
I suppose all the tickets have been sold now, have they?
There is no reason to suppose she's lying.
I suppose you think it's funny, do you (= showing anger)?
She had supposed him (to be) very rich.
I had supposed him a younger man.

senses.definition: used to make a statement, request or suggestion less direct or less strong

examples.en: I could take you in the car, I suppose (= but I don't really want to).
‘Can I borrow the car?’ ‘I suppose so (= Yes, but I'm not happy about it).’
What I’m saying, I suppose, is that she’s not really suitable for the job.
I don’t suppose (that) I could have a look at your newspaper, could I?
Suppose we take a later train?

senses.definition: to pretend that something is true; to imagine what would happen if something were true

examples.en: Suppose flights are fully booked on that day—which other day could we go?
Let us suppose, for example, that you are married with two children.
Let's suppose for a moment that these four points are correct.
The theory supposes the existence of life on other planets.
Suppose him (to be) dead—what then?

senses.definition: to be expected or required to do/be something according to a rule, a custom, an arrangement, etc.

examples.en: What am I supposed to do?
You're supposed to buy a ticket, but not many people do.
I thought we were supposed to be paid today.
The engine doesn't sound like it's supposed to.
You were supposed to be here an hour ago!
Oops—that wasn't supposed to happen.
How was I supposed to know you were waiting for me?
‘Yes and no.’ ‘What is that supposed to mean?’ (= showing that you are annoyed)

senses.definition: to be generally believed or expected to be/do something

examples.en: I haven't seen it myself, but it's supposed to be a great movie.
This combination of qualities is generally supposed to be extremely rare.
She's supposed to have had hundreds of lovers.

idioms.word: not be supposed to do something

senses.definition: to not be allowed to do something

examples.en: You're not supposed to walk on the grass.

senses.definition: according to what is generally thought or believed but not known for certain

examples.en: The novel is supposedly based on a true story.
a poem supposedly written by Shakespeare
Police have found the supposedly stolen car.

senses.definition: to put an end, often by force, to a group or an activity that is believed to threaten authority

examples.en: The rebellion was brutally suppressed.

senses.definition: to prevent something from being published or made known

examples.en: The police were accused of suppressing vital evidence.
This information had been deliberately suppressed.

senses.definition: to prevent yourself from having or expressing a feeling or an emotion

examples.en: to suppress a smile
She was unable to suppress her anger.
He had suppressed the painful memories of his childhood.
He could hardly suppress his surprise.
Her face was charged with barely suppressed anger.
She was unable to suppress a giggle.
The disloyal thought was instantly suppressed.
He couldn't suppress the excitement in his voice.

senses.definition: to prevent something from growing, developing or continuing

examples.en: drugs that suppress the appetite

senses.definition: highest in rank or position

examples.en: the Supreme Commander of the armed forces
the supreme champion
It is an event in which she reigns supreme.

senses.definition: very great or the greatest in degree

examples.en: to make the supreme sacrifice (= die for what you believe in)
a supreme effort
She smiled with supreme confidence.

senses.definition: confident that you know something or that you are right

examples.en: ‘Is that John over there?’ ‘I'm not sure.’
You don't sound very sure.
I'm pretty sure (that) he'll agree.
Are you sure you don't mind?
I’m sure he’s still alive.
I hope you are sure of your facts.
Are you sure about that?
Ask me if you're not sure how to do it.
I'm not sure whether I should tell you this.
not exactly/entirely/absolutely/really sure
I still wasn't even sure who I was talking to.
I like this bit, but I'm not so sure about that one.

senses.definition: certain that you will receive something or that something will happen

examples.en: You're always sure of a warm welcome there.
We could not be sure of financial support.
England must win this game to be sure of qualifying for the World Cup.

senses.definition: certain to do something or to happen

examples.en: The exhibition is sure to be popular.
It's sure to rain.
You’re sure to get lost if you don’t keep to the path.
She's sure to be picked for the team.

senses.definition: that can be trusted or relied on

examples.en: It's a sure sign of economic recovery.
There's only one sure way to do it.
He is a sure bet for the presidential nomination (= certain to succeed).
I told my friends that our winning was a sure thing.

senses.definition: steady and confident

examples.en: We admired her sure touch at the keyboard.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody to do something

examples.en: Be sure to give your family my regards.
Be sure to check out our website.

senses.definition: without doubt

examples.en: No one knows for sure what happened.
I think he'll be back on Monday, but I can't say for sure.
One thing is for sure—it's not going to be easy.
‘Will you be there?’ ‘For sure.’

senses.definition: something that is likely to happen, to succeed or to be suitable

examples.en: He's a good bet to earn a spot on the US team.
Clothes are a safe bet as a present for a teenager.
The movie looks like a sure bet for Best Film.

senses.definition: to do something in order to be certain that something else happens

examples.en: Make sure (that) no one finds out about this.
They scored another goal and made sure of victory.
Our staff will do their best to make sure you enjoy your visit.
To make doubly sure they would not be disturbed she turned the key in the lock.

senses.definition: to check that something is true or has been done

examples.en: She looked around to make sure that she was alone.
I think the door's locked, but I'll just go and make sure.

senses.definition: very confident

examples.en: She seems very sure of herself.

senses.definition: used to say ‘yes’ to a suggestion or request

examples.en: ‘Are you coming?’ ‘Sure thing.’

senses.definition: used to admit that something is true

examples.en: He is intelligent, to be sure, but he's also very lazy.

senses.definition: used to say ‘yes’ to somebody

examples.en: ‘Will you get me my coat?’ ‘Sure, where is it?’
Did it hurt? Sure it hurt.
Sure, no problem.

senses.definition: used to emphasize something that you are saying

examples.en: Boy, it sure is hot.
‘Amazing view’. ‘Sure is.’
I sure hope you are right about that.
That song sure as hell sounds familiar.
He sure looked unhappy.
Working in technology sure beats flipping burgers.
I sure do agree with that.

senses.definition: used to reply to somebody who has just thanked you for something

examples.en: ‘Thanks for the ride.’ ‘Sure—anytime.’

senses.definition: used to say that something is definitely true
used to say that something happened as expected

examples.en: I said he'd forget, and sure enough he did.
‘Stop,’ she said, ‘I can hear something.’ Sure enough, in the distance we could hear the sound of a car approaching.

senses.definition: used to show that you are almost certain of what you are saying and want other people to agree with you

examples.en: Surely we should do something about it?
It's surely only a matter of time before he is found, isn't it?
Surely by now, things could be organized better?
Oil prices will surely have some impact on trade.

senses.definition: used with a negative to show that something surprises you and you do not want to believe it

examples.en: Surely you don't think I was responsible for this?
‘They're getting married.’ ‘Surely not!’
They won't go, surely?

senses.definition: without doubt; certainly

examples.en: He knew that if help did not arrive soon they would surely die.

senses.definition: used to say ‘yes’ to somebody or to agree to something
making slow but definite progress

examples.en: We'll get there slowly but surely.

senses.definition: the outside or top layer of something

examples.en: We need a flat, smooth surface to play the game on.
an uneven road surface
a broad leaf with a large surface area
Surface water (= rainwater that has collected on the surface of a road) made driving conditions hazardous.
Teeth have a hard surface layer called enamel.

senses.definition: the top layer of an area of water or land

examples.en: the earth's surface
These plants float on the surface of the water.
We could see fish swimming just below the surface.
Alligators lurk beneath the surface of the swamp.
The earth’s surface temperature is rising.

senses.definition: the flat upper part of a piece of furniture, that is used for working on

examples.en: She's cleaned all the kitchen surfaces.
You'll need a large smooth surface for rolling out the pastry.

senses.definition: the outer appearance of a person, thing or situation; the qualities that you see or notice, that are not hidden

examples.en: Rage bubbled just below the surface of his mind.
She gives the impression of being rather conventional, but under the surface she is wildly eccentric.

senses.definition: when not thought about deeply or carefully and completely; when not looked at carefully

examples.en: It seems like a good idea on the surface but there are sure to be problems.
On the surface, he appeared unchanged.
On the surface his words were funny, but I detected a lot of anger behind them.

senses.definition: to deal with, understand, or find out about only a small part of a subject or problem

examples.en: We left feeling that we had just scratched the surface of this fascinating country.
The investigation barely scratched the surface of the city's drug problem.

senses.definition: to come up to the surface of water

examples.en: The ducks dived and surfaced again several metres away.

senses.definition: to suddenly appear or become obvious after having been hidden for a while

examples.en: Doubts began to surface.
She surfaced again years later in London.
No further information has surfaced yet.

senses.definition: to wake up or get up after being asleep

examples.en: He finally surfaced around noon.

senses.definition: to put a surface on a road, path, etc.
a sudden increase of a strong feeling

examples.en: She felt a sudden surge of anger.
a surge of excitement

senses.definition: a sudden increase in the amount or number of something

examples.en: a surge in consumer spending
We are having trouble keeping up with the recent surge in demand.
A last-minute surge in ticket sales saved the show from closure.
After an initial surge of interest, there has been little call for our services.

senses.definition: a sudden, strong movement forward or upwards

examples.en: a tidal surge
A surge of people poured through the gates.
Police struggled to control the sudden surge forward by the demonstrators.

senses.definition: a sudden increase in the flow of electrical power through a system

examples.en: An electrical surge damaged the computer's disk drive.
The National Grid was hit by a huge power surge.

senses.definition: to move quickly and with force in a particular direction

examples.en: The gates opened and the crowd surged forward.
Flood waters surged into their homes.
He surged past the other runners on the last lap.

senses.definition: to fill somebody with a strong feeling

examples.en: Relief surged through her.

senses.definition: to suddenly increase in value

examples.en: Share prices surged.

senses.definition: to increase suddenly
a doctor who is trained to perform surgery (= medical operations that involve cutting open a person’s body)

examples.en: a brain/heart surgeon
Surgeons performed two operations on him yesterday.

senses.definition: medical treatment of injuries or diseases that involves cutting open a person’s body and often removing or replacing some parts; the branch of medicine connected with this treatment

examples.en: major/minor surgery
to undergo heart/knee/shoulder surgery
He will require surgery on his left knee.
The doctor had to perform emergency surgery to the patient's head.
She's a specialist in reconstructive and cosmetic surgery.
The president is to undergo minor surgery to remove a small growth from his hand.

variants.html: (North American English office)

senses.definition: a place where a doctor, dentist or vet sees patients

examples.en: a doctor’s/dentist’s/vet's surgery

senses.definition: the time during which a doctor, dentist or vet is available to see patients

examples.en: morning/afternoon/evening surgery
surgery hours
Is there a surgery this evening?
He holds surgery from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m.

senses.definition: a time when people can meet their Member of Parliament to ask questions and get help

examples.en: a constituency surgery

senses.definition: used in or connected with surgery

examples.en: surgical procedures
a surgical ward (= for patients having operations)

senses.dis_g: (especially of a military attack from the air)
senses.definition: very accurate

examples.en: They launched surgical strikes against enemy targets.
surgical bombing
The quarterback found the wide receiver with a pass of almost surgical precision.

senses.definition: an amount that is extra or more than you need

examples.en: food surpluses
Wheat was in surplus that year.

senses.definition: the amount by which the amount of money received is greater than the amount of money spent

examples.en: a surplus of £400 million
The balance of payments was in surplus last year (= the value of exports was greater than the value of imports).

senses.definition: more than is needed or used

examples.en: surplus cash
Surplus grain is being sold for export.
This diet guarantees to help you shed surplus fat.
These items are surplus to requirements (= not needed).

senses.definition: an event, a piece of news, etc. that is unexpected or that happens suddenly

examples.en: What a nice surprise!
I have a surprise for you!
a surprise attack
There are few surprises in this year's budget.
It comes as no surprise to learn that they broke their promises.
Her letter came as a complete surprise.
‘The appointment came as a pleasant surprise to me,’ she says.
The announcements came as something of a surprise to them.
There are lots of surprises in store for visitors to the gallery.
He was there on a surprise visit to the troops.
Life’s full of surprises.
She likes springing surprises on people.
Visitors to the gallery are in for a few surprises.

senses.definition: a feeling caused by something happening suddenly or unexpectedly

examples.en: a look of surprise
She looked up in surprise.
He gasped with surprise at her strength.
They couldn't conceal their surprise at seeing us together.
I got a surprise when I saw the bill.
To everyone's surprise, the plan succeeded.
Much to my surprise, I passed.
Imagine our surprise when he walked into the room!
When we went inside we got a nasty surprise.
The decision has been greeted with surprise.
They expressed surprise at the outcome.

senses.definition: the use of methods that cause feelings of surprise

examples.en: A successful campaign should have an element of surprise.

senses.definition: used to show that something is not a surprise to you, as you could easily have predicted that it would happen or be true

examples.en: One of the candidates was the manager's niece, and surprise, surprise, she got the job.
Bob turned up half an hour late, surprise surprise.

senses.definition: used when giving somebody a surprise

examples.en: Surprise, surprise! Look who's here!

senses.definition: to happen unexpectedly so that somebody is slightly shocked; to surprise somebody

examples.en: His frankness took her by surprise.
The storm took us completely by surprise.

senses.definition: to attack or capture somebody/something unexpectedly or without warning

examples.en: The police took the burglars by surprise.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel surprised

examples.en: It wouldn't surprise me if they got married soon.
It's always surprised me how popular he is.
It surprises me that you've never sung professionally.
It will surprise no one to hear that the aubergine is my favourite vegetable.

examples.cf: it surprises somebody to do something
examples.en: Would it surprise you to know that I'm thinking of leaving?

senses.definition: to attack, discover, etc., somebody suddenly and unexpectedly

examples.en: The army attacked at night to surprise the rebels.
We arrived home early and surprised a burglar trying to break in.

senses.definition: feeling or showing surprise

examples.en: a surprised look
She looked surprised when I told her.
I was surprised at how quickly she agreed.
I'm surprised at you, behaving like that in front of the kids.

examples.cf: surprised to see, hear, learn, discover, find
examples.en: They were surprised to find that he'd already left.
You shouldn’t be surprised (that) he didn’t come.
Don't be surprised if I pretend not to recognize you.
‘Will she cancel the party?’ ‘I wouldn't be surprised.’
You’d be surprised how many people voted for him.
He was pleasantly surprised to discover that he was no longer afraid.
to be a little/a bit/quite surprised
She seemed somewhat surprised at his reaction.

senses.definition: causing surprise

examples.en: It’s not surprising (that) they lost.
The frequency of such bad weather is hardly surprising given how far north we are.
A surprising number of people came.
We had a surprising amount in common.
It's surprising what people will do for money.
It’s surprising how many people applied for the job.

senses.definition: to admit that you have been defeated and want to stop fighting; to allow yourself to be caught, taken prisoner, etc.

examples.en: The rebel soldiers were forced to surrender.
He surrendered voluntarily to his enemies.
The hijackers eventually surrendered themselves to the police.

senses.definition: to give up something/somebody when you are forced to

examples.en: He agreed to surrender all claims to the property.
They surrendered their guns to the police.
The defendant was released to await trial but had to surrender her passport.
The dictator surrendered power to Parliament.

senses.definition: an act of admitting that you have been defeated and want to stop fighting

examples.en: They demanded (an) unconditional surrender.
He raised his hands in surrender.

senses.definition: the fact of allowing yourself to be controlled by something

examples.en: They accused the government of a surrender to business interests.

senses.definition: an act of giving something to somebody else even though you do not want to, especially after a battle, etc.

examples.en: They insisted on the immediate surrender of all weapons.

senses.definition: to be all around something/somebody

examples.en: Tall trees surround the lake.
the membranes surrounding the brain
The garden is surrounded by a wall.
As a child I was surrounded by love and kindness.
I loved being surrounded by enthusiastic young people.
The lake is surrounded with trees.

senses.definition: to move into position all around somebody/something, especially so as to prevent them from escaping; to move somebody/something into position in this way

examples.en: Police surrounded the building.
They've surrounded the building with police.

senses.definition: to be closely connected with something/somebody

examples.en: publicity surrounding the divorce
the controversy/circumstances surrounding his death
The report explores the issues surrounding the case.

senses.definition: to choose to have particular people or things near you all the time

examples.en: I like to surround myself with beautiful things.

senses.definition: a border or an area around the edge of something, especially one that is decorated

examples.en: a fireplace with a tiled surround

senses.definition: that is near or around something

examples.en: Oxford and the surrounding area
From the top of the hill you can see all the surrounding countryside.
the immediately surrounding area
The college tries to respond to the needs of the surrounding community.

senses.definition: the act of carefully watching a person suspected of a crime or a place where a crime may be committed

examples.en: The police are keeping the suspects under constant surveillance.
surveillance cameras/equipment

senses.definition: an investigation of the opinions, behaviour, etc. of a particular group of people, which is usually done by asking them questions

examples.en: A recent survey showed 75 per cent of those questioned were in favour of the plan.
The survey revealed/found that…
to conduct/carry out/do/complete a survey
According to the survey, many young adults have experimented with drugs of some kind.
Another national survey conducted last year found the same result.
Roughly half of survey respondents express strong interest in additional education.
The results of the survey come as no surprise to us.

senses.definition: the act of examining and recording the measurements, features, etc. of an area of land in order to make a map or plan of it

examples.en: an aerial survey (= made by taking photographs from a plane, drone, etc.)
A geological survey revealed the presence of oil beneath the ground.

senses.definition: an examination of the condition of a house, etc., usually done for somebody who is thinking of buying it

examples.en: a detailed structural survey

senses.definition: a general study, view or description of something

examples.en: a comprehensive survey of modern music
a historical survey of children's clothing

senses.definition: to look carefully at the whole of something, especially in order to get a general impression of it

examples.en: The next morning we surveyed the damage caused by the fire.
He surveyed himself in the mirror before going out.
She opened her eyes and surveyed her surroundings.

senses.definition: to study and give a general description of something

examples.en: This chapter briefly surveys the current state of European politics.

senses.definition: to investigate the opinions or behaviour of a group of people by asking them a series of questions

examples.en: We surveyed 500 smokers and found that over three quarters would like to give up.
87% of the 1 000 companies surveyed employ part-time staff.
The aim of the project is to survey public attitudes to disability.
62 percent of those surveyed disapprove of the president's handling of the problem.

senses.definition: to measure and record the features of an area of land, for example in order to make a map or in preparation for building
to examine a building to make sure it is in good condition

examples.en: Have the house surveyed before you decide whether to buy it.

senses.definition: the state of continuing to live or exist, often despite difficulty or danger

examples.en: the struggle/battle/fight for survival
His only chance of survival was a heart transplant.
Exporting is necessary for our economic survival.
Continued trade in these products is a threat to the survival of the species.

senses.definition: something that has continued to exist from an earlier time

examples.en: The ceremony is a survival from pre-Christian times.

senses.definition: the principle that only the people or things that are best adapted to their environment will continue to exist
a popular British television series about nature. Each programme described the life of a particular wild animal. It was broadcast from the 1960s until the 1990s.
to continue to live or exist

examples.en: She was the last surviving member of the family.
Of the six people injured in the crash, only two survived.
Many of these teachers are struggling to survive financially.
He must betray his friend in order to survive.
The children had to survive by begging and stealing.
‘How are you these days?’ ‘Oh, surviving.’
Don't worry, it's only a scratch—you'll survive.
Some strange customs have survived from earlier times.
I can't survive on £40 a week (= it is not enough for my basic needs).
They spent two months in the jungle, surviving on small animals and fruit.
He survived as party leader until his second election defeat.

senses.definition: to continue to live or exist despite a dangerous event or time

examples.en: Her 5-year-old son miraculously survived the crash.
He only survived the attack because he was wearing body armour.
Many birds didn't survive the severe winter.
The company managed to survive the crisis.
Few buildings survived the war intact.

senses.definition: to live or exist longer than somebody/something

examples.en: She survived her husband by ten years.
He is survived by his wife and two sons (= he has just died but they are still alive).

senses.definition: a person who continues to live, especially despite being nearly killed or experiencing great danger or difficulty

examples.en: the sole/only survivor of the massacre
The plane crashed in an area of dense jungle. There were no survivors.
There are only a few survivors from the original team (= members who remain in it while others have been replaced).
She'll cope. She's one of life's great survivors (= somebody who deals very well with difficult situations).
A movie has been made about the last remaining survivor of the tribe.

senses.definition: to have an idea that something is probably true or likely to happen, especially something bad, but without having definite proof

examples.en: As I had suspected all along, he was not a real policeman.
If you suspect a gas leak, do not strike a match or even turn on an electric light.
Suspecting nothing, he walked right into the trap.
I didn’t want the neighbours suspecting anything.
I began to suspect (that) they were trying to get rid of me.
I strongly suspect (that) this whole story is fictional.
She had no reason to suspect (that) Sylvia had not been telling the truth.
I suspect (that) she might be lying.
It was suspected that the drugs had been brought into the country by boat.
She suspected him to be an impostor.

senses.definition: to have an idea that somebody is guilty of something, without having definite proof

examples.en: He resigned after being suspected of theft.
He is not suspected of any involvement in the recent attacks.
He was wrongly suspected of the crime.
They arrested four men suspected of links to an extremist group.
I suspected her of damaging the equipment.
The drug is suspected of causing over 200 deaths.
Whom do the police suspect?

senses.definition: to feel that something is not completely right, legal or honest, without having any proof; to not trust something

examples.en: I suspected her motives in offering to help.
He dealt through a broker whose honesty he had no reason to suspect.

senses.definition: a person who is suspected of a crime or of having done something wrong

examples.en: a murder suspect
He is the prime suspect in the case.
Five suspects have been detained for questioning.
Do you have a list of likely suspects?

senses.definition: the people you would usually expect to do something or be included in something

examples.en: She thanked all the usual suspects in her acceptance speech: her family, the director, the cast and the crew.

senses.definition: that may be false and that cannot be relied on

examples.en: Some of the evidence they produced was highly suspect.
The theory is rendered suspect by its reliance on now discredited sources.

senses.definition: that you suspect to be dangerous or illegal

examples.en: a suspect package (= one that may contain drugs, a bomb, etc.)
a controlled explosion of a suspect device (= a bomb)

senses.definition: to hang something from something else

examples.en: A lamp was suspended from the ceiling.
Her body was found suspended by a rope.

examples.cf: be suspended by/on something from something
examples.en: A boat was suspended on wires from the rafters.

senses.definition: to officially stop something for a time; to prevent something from being active, used, etc. for a time

examples.en: Production has been suspended while safety checks are carried out.
The constitution was suspended as the fighting grew worse.
In the theatre we willingly suspend disbelief (= temporarily believe that the characters, etc. are real).

senses.definition: to officially delay something; to arrange for something to happen later than planned

examples.en: The introduction of the new system has been suspended until next year.
to suspend judgement (= delay forming or expressing an opinion)

senses.definition: to officially prevent somebody from doing their job, going to school, etc. for a time, as a punishment or while a complaint against them is investigated

examples.en: The police officer was suspended while the complaint was investigated.
She was suspended from school for a week.

senses.definition: to float in liquid or air without moving

examples.en: Small droplets are held suspended in the atmosphere.

senses.definition: the act of officially removing somebody from their job, school, team, etc. for a period of time, usually as a punishment

examples.en: suspension from school
The two players are appealing against their suspensions.

senses.definition: the act of delaying something for a period of time, until a decision has been taken

examples.en: These events have led to the suspension of talks.
Many movies require the viewer to engage in a willing suspension of disbelief.

senses.definition: the system of springs, etc. by which a vehicle is supported on its wheels and that makes it more comfortable to ride in when the road surface is not even

examples.en: the front/rear suspension
The new model is fitted with computer-controlled suspension.

senses.definition: a liquid with very small pieces of solid matter floating in it; the state of such a liquid

examples.en: The suspension was passed through a filter to separate out the solid particles.
The material carried in suspension by the tide is deposited on the shore.

senses.definition: a feeling that somebody has done something wrong, illegal or dishonest, even though you have no proof

examples.en: They drove away slowly to avoid arousing suspicion.
He was arrested on suspicion of murder.
I have a sneaking suspicion that she's not telling the truth.
My suspicions were confirmed when police raided the property.
She was reluctant to voice her suspicions.
His resignation seemed only to fuel suspicions.
It’s time to confront him with our suspicions.

senses.definition: a feeling or belief that something is true, even though you have no proof

examples.en: I have a horrible suspicion that we've come to the wrong station.

senses.definition: the feeling that you cannot trust somebody/something

examples.en: Their offer was greeted with some suspicion.
Water from shallow wells should be regarded with suspicion, as it may be contaminated.

senses.definition: a small amount of something

examples.en: His mouth quivered in the suspicion of a smile.
Wasn’t there even a suspicion of truth in what he said?

senses.definition: too good, honest, etc. to have done something wrong, illegal or dishonest

examples.en: Nobody who was near the scene of the crime is above suspicion.
They thought the head teacher was beyond suspicion.

senses.definition: if the finger of blame/suspicion points or is pointed at somebody, they are suspected of having committed a crime, being responsible for something, etc.

examples.en: The inquiry pointed the finger of blame at the driver of the crashed coach.
The finger of suspicion was pointed at the chicken served for lunch.

senses.definition: suspected of doing something wrong, illegal or dishonest

examples.en: The whole family is currently under suspicion of her murder.
A number of doctors came under suspicion of unethical behaviour.
He fell under suspicion of tax evasion.

senses.definition: feeling that somebody has done something wrong, illegal or dishonest, without having any proof

examples.en: They became suspicious of his behaviour and contacted the police.
a suspicious look
You have a very suspicious mind (= you always think that people are behaving in an illegal or dishonest way).

senses.definition: making you feel that something is wrong, illegal or dishonest

examples.en: Didn't you notice anything suspicious in his behaviour?
She died in suspicious circumstances.
Police are not treating the fire as suspicious.
It might look suspicious if we arrived together.
It was all very suspicious.

senses.definition: not willing or able to trust somebody/something

examples.en: I was suspicious of his motives.
Many were suspicious of reform.

senses.definition: to provide enough of what somebody/something needs in order to live or exist

examples.en: Which planets can sustain life?
I only had a little chocolate to sustain me on my walk.
The love and support of his family sustained him during his time in prison.
When she lost her job they could no longer sustain their expensive lifestyle.
The soil was so badly eroded it could no longer sustain crop production.

senses.definition: to make something continue for some time without becoming less

examples.en: She managed to sustain everyone's interest until the end of her speech.
Kangaroos can sustain high speeds over long distances.
the sustaining pedal of a piano (= that allows a note to continue sounding for a long time)
This relationship would be very difficult to sustain.

senses.definition: to experience something bad

examples.en: to sustain damage/an injury/a defeat
The company sustained losses of millions of dollars.

senses.definition: to provide evidence to support an opinion, a theory, etc.

examples.en: The evidence is not detailed enough to sustain his argument.

senses.definition: to support a weight without breaking or falling

examples.en: The ice will not sustain your weight.

senses.definition: to decide that a claim, etc. is true or legally valid

examples.en: The court sustained his claim that the contract was illegal.
Objection sustained! (= said by a judge when a lawyer makes an objection in court)

senses.definition: involving the use of natural products and energy in a way that does not harm the environment

examples.en: sustainable forest management
an environmentally sustainable society
This type of farming is simply not sustainable any more.

senses.definition: that can continue or be continued for a long time

examples.en: sustainable economic growth
Unfortunately, this level of output is not sustainable.

senses.definition: to make food, drink, etc. go down your throat into your stomach

examples.en: Always chew food well before swallowing it.
I had a sore throat and it hurt to swallow.
The pills should be swallowed whole.

senses.definition: to move the muscles of your throat as if you were swallowing something, especially because you are nervous

examples.en: She swallowed hard and told him the bad news.

senses.definition: to take somebody/something in or completely cover them/it so that they/it cannot be seen or exist separately any longer

examples.en: I watched her walk down the road until she was swallowed by the darkness.
Large areas of countryside have been swallowed up by towns.

senses.definition: to use up something completely, especially an amount of money

examples.en: Most of my salary gets swallowed (up) by the rent and bills.

senses.definition: to accept that something is true; to believe something

examples.en: I found her excuse very hard to swallow.
He told her a pack of lies, but she swallowed it whole.

senses.definition: to hide your feelings

examples.en: to swallow your doubts
You're going to have to swallow your pride and ask for your job back.

senses.definition: to accept offensive remarks, criticisms, etc. without complaining or protesting

examples.en: I was surprised that he just sat there and swallowed all their remarks.

senses.definition: a fact or an event that is unpleasant and difficult to accept

examples.en: The election defeat was a bitter pill for the party to swallow.

idioms.word: like the cat that got/ate/swallowed the canary

variants.text: (British English like a cat that’s got the cream)
variants.html: (British English like a cat that’s got the cream)

senses.definition: very pleased with yourself

examples.en: She looked like the cat that’s swallowed the canary. She was almost purring with pleasure.

senses.definition: a small bird, with long pointed wings and a tail with two points, that migrates (= moves from one part of the world to another according to the season)
an act of swallowing; an amount of food or drink that is swallowed at one time

examples.en: She took a swallow of coffee.

idioms.word: one swallow doesn’t make a summer

senses.definition: you must not take too seriously a small sign that something is happening or will happen in the future, because the situation could change
to use rude or offensive language, usually because you are angry

examples.en: She fell over and swore loudly.
I don't like to hear children swearing.
He heard her swear under her breath.
She was shouting, swearing, and acting in an aggressive manner towards the staff
Why did you let him swear at you like that?

senses.definition: to make a serious promise to do something

examples.en: He swore revenge on the man who had killed his father.
I solemnly swear (that) it will never happen again.
I swear (that) I’ll never leave you.
He swore solemnly that he would never hit her again.
She made him swear not to tell anyone.
He left, swearing never to return.

senses.definition: to promise that you are telling the truth

examples.en: She swore (that) she’d never seen him before.
I could have sworn (= I am sure) I heard the phone ring.
I swear to God I had nothing to do with it.

senses.definition: to make a public or official promise, especially in court

examples.en: Witnesses were required to swear on the Bible.
Are you willing to stand up in court and swear that you don't recognize him?
Remember, you have sworn to tell the truth.
Barons had to swear an oath of allegiance to the king.
I swear by Almighty God to tell the truth.
They refused to swear allegiance to the new ruler.

senses.definition: to make somebody promise not to tell something to anyone

examples.en: Everyone was sworn to secrecy about what had happened.

senses.definition: to say that something is definitely true

examples.en: He swore blind that he’d already paid back the money he owed me.
He swore blind that you knew all about it.

senses.definition: to often use very rude or offensive language
a piece of clothing for the upper part of the body, made of wool or cotton, with long sleeves

examples.en: She wore jeans and a sweater.
He was wearing a cashmere sweater over his shirt.
She has knitted me beautiful sweaters and socks.
a grey merino wool turtleneck sweater

senses.definition: to clean a room, surface, etc. using a broom (= a type of brush on a long handle)

examples.en: to sweep the floor
Chimneys should be swept regularly.
I don't have to sweep and mop every day.
Don't just stand around—grab a broom and sweep up.
The showroom had been emptied and swept clean.

senses.definition: to remove something from a surface using a brush, your hand, etc.

examples.en: She swept the crumbs into the wastebasket.
He swept the leaves up into a pile.
She swept the clothes onto the floor and invited him to sit down.

senses.definition: to move or push somebody/something suddenly and with a lot of force

examples.en: The little boat was swept out to sea.
Their tent was swept away in the storm.
She let herself be swept along by the crowd.

senses.definition: to move suddenly and/or with force over an area or in a particular direction

examples.en: Rain swept in through the broken windows.
A fire swept through the store on Tuesday night.
Strong winds regularly sweep the islands.

senses.definition: to move quickly and/or smoothly, especially in a way that impresses or is intended to impress other people

examples.en: Without another word she swept out of the room.
Two police motorcycles swept through the village.
A pair of golden eagles swept across the sky.
She swept past the photographers without a glance.
He swept into the lead with an almost perfect performance.

senses.definition: to move something, especially your hand or arm, quickly and smoothly in a particular direction

examples.en: He rushed to greet her, sweeping his arms wide.

senses.definition: to suddenly affect somebody strongly

examples.en: A wave of tiredness swept over her.
Memories came sweeping back.

senses.definition: to spread quickly

examples.en: Rumours of his resignation swept through the company.
the latest craze sweeping the nation

senses.definition: to move over an area, especially in order to look for something

examples.en: His eyes swept around the room.
The car headlights swept across the front of the building.
Searchlights swept the sky.
She swept the crowd with her binoculars.

senses.definition: to move, or move something, over a surface, touching it lightly

examples.en: Her dress swept the ground as she walked.

senses.definition: to brush, comb, etc. your hair in a particular direction

examples.en: Her hair was swept back from her face.

senses.definition: to form a long, smooth curve

examples.en: The hotel gardens sweep down to the beach.

senses.definition: to win all the games in a series of games against another team or all the parts of a contest

examples.en: The Blue Jays have a chance to sweep the series.
New Jersey swept Detroit last season.

senses.definition: to win all the prizes, etc. in a competition
to make somebody fall suddenly and deeply in love with you

examples.en: She’s waiting for some hero to come and sweep her off her feet.

senses.definition: to win an election by a large number of votes; to make somebody win an election with a large number of votes
to win a contest easily

examples.en: Macron swept to victory in 2017.

variants.text: (North American English also sweep something under the rug)
variants.html: (North American English also sweep something under the rug)

senses.definition: to try to stop people from finding out about something wrong, illegal, embarrassing, etc. that has happened or that you have done

examples.en: An earlier report, implicating the government, had been conveniently swept under the carpet.

senses.definition: an act of cleaning a room, surface, etc. using a broom

examples.en: Give the room a good sweep.

senses.definition: a smooth curving movement

examples.en: He indicated the door with a sweep of his arm.

senses.definition: a long, often curved, piece of road, river, coast, etc.

examples.en: the broad sweep of white cliffs around the bay

senses.definition: the range of an idea, a piece of writing, etc. that considers many different things

examples.en: Her book covers the long sweep of the country's history.
the broad cultural sweep of Flaubert's novel

senses.definition: a movement over an area, for example in order to search for something or attack something

examples.en: The rescue helicopter made another sweep over the bay.

senses.definition: a person whose job is to clean the inside of chimneys

variants.html: (North American English also sweeps)

senses.definition: a sweepstake (= a type of betting in which the winner gets all the money bet by everyone else)
a series of games that a team wins against another team; the fact of winning all the parts of a contest

examples.en: a World Series sweep

senses.definition: a time when television companies examine their programmes to find out which ones are the most popular, especially in order to calculate advertising rates

examples.en: the May ratings sweeps

senses.definition: to remove all the people or things from an organization that are thought to be unnecessary or need changing

examples.en: The new manager made a clean sweep of the department.

senses.definition: to win all the prizes or parts of a game or competition; to win an election completely

examples.en: China made a clean sweep of the medals in the gymnastics events.
The opinion poll suggests a clean sweep for the Democrats.

senses.definition: containing, or tasting as if it contains, a lot of sugar

examples.en: a cup of hot sweet tea
sweet food
I had a craving for something sweet.
roast duck with a sweet and sour sauce
sweet sherry
This wine is too sweet for me.
I found the dessert a bit sweet for my taste.

senses.definition: having a pleasant smell

examples.en: a sweet-smelling rose
The air was sweet with incense.

senses.definition: having a pleasant sound

examples.en: a sweet voice

senses.definition: pleasant and not containing any harmful substances

examples.en: the sweet air of a mountain village

senses.definition: making you feel happy and/or satisfied

examples.en: Goodnight. Sweet dreams.
I can't tell you how sweet this victory is.
He played a sweet shot onto the final green (= in golf).
an act of sweet revenge

senses.definition: attractive

examples.en: His sister's a sweet young thing.
You look sweet in this photograph.
We stayed in a sweet little hotel on the seafront.

senses.definition: having or showing a kind character

examples.en: She gave him her sweetest smile.
He's one of the sweetest people I know.

examples.cf: it is sweet of somebody to do something
examples.en: It was sweet of them to offer to help.
He’s not what you’d call sweet-tempered!

senses.definition: used to show that you approve of something

examples.en: Free tickets? Sweet!

senses.definition: to like somebody very much in a romantic way
to like food that contains a lot of sugar
used to say how pleasant your home is (especially when you really mean that it is not pleasant at all)
how and when you want to, even though this might annoy other people

examples.en: He always does the work, but in his own sweet time.
She just ignores all the criticism and continues in her own sweet way.

senses.definition: to say or do pleasant things in order to keep somebody in a good mood so that they will agree to do something for you

examples.en: You’d better keep her sweet if you want her to lend you the money.

idioms.word: a rose by any other name would smell as sweet

senses.definition: what is important is what people or things are, not what they are called
everything is all right
pleasant but not lasting a long time

examples.en: We haven't much time so I'll keep it short and sweet.

senses.definition: nothing at all. People say ‘sweet FA’ to avoid saying ‘fuck all’.
romantic words

examples.en: to whisper sweet nothings in somebody’s ear

senses.definition: the pleasant feeling of being successful
a small piece of sweet food, usually made with sugar and/or chocolate and eaten between meals

examples.en: a packet of sweets
a sweet shop

senses.definition: a sweet dish eaten at the end of a meal

examples.en: I haven't made a sweet today.
Would you like some more sweet?

senses.definition: a way of addressing somebody that you like or love

examples.en: Don't you worry, my sweet.

senses.definition: to move through water by moving your arms and legs, without touching the bottom

examples.en: I can't swim.
The boys swam across the lake.
We swam out (= away from land) to the yacht.
They spent the day swimming and sunbathing.
I've only just learned to swim.
I have always found it easy to swim underwater.
They are too far out to swim to shore.
Can you swim backstroke yet?
How long will it take her to swim the Channel?

senses.definition: to spend time swimming for pleasure

examples.en: I go swimming twice a week.
We always went swimming together in our indoor pool.

senses.definition: to move through or across water

examples.en: Sharks must swim or die.
A shoal of fish swam past.
Ducks were swimming around on the river.
A beaver swam vigorously upstream.

senses.definition: to be covered with a lot of liquid

examples.en: The main course was swimming in oil.
Her eyes were swimming with tears.

senses.definition: to seem to be moving around, especially when you are ill or drunk

examples.en: The pages swam before her eyes.

senses.definition: to feel confused and/or as if everything is turning round and round

examples.en: His head swam and he swayed dizzily.

senses.definition: to be in a situation where you will either succeed by your own efforts or fail completely

examples.en: The new students were just left to sink or swim.
In a situation like this, you either sink or swim.

senses.definition: a period of time during which you swim

examples.en: Let's go for a swim.
How about a quick swim before breakfast?
She got up early and went for a swim.
a sponsored swim

senses.definition: (in compounds) related to or used for swimming

examples.en: a swim meet (= a swimming competition between teams)
swim trunks

senses.definition: involved in things that are happening in society or in a particular situation

examples.en: Since leaving the company, he’s no longer in the swim of things.

senses.definition: the sport or activity of swimming

examples.en: Swimming is a good form of exercise.

senses.definition: to move backwards or forwards or from side to side while hanging from a fixed point; to make something do this

examples.en: His arms swung as he walked.
As he pushed her, she swung higher and higher (= while sitting on a swing).
A set of keys swung from her belt.
He sat on the stool, swinging his legs.

senses.definition: to move from one place to another by holding something that is fixed and pulling yourself along, up, etc.

examples.en: The gunshot sent monkeys swinging away through the trees.
He swung himself out of the car.

senses.definition: to move or make something move with a wide curved movement

examples.en: A line of cars swung out of the palace gates.
He swung his legs over the side of the bed.
The door swung open.
She let the door swing shut behind her.
She swung the door open.

senses.definition: to change or make somebody/something change from one opinion, mood, etc. to another

examples.en: The state has swung from Republican to Democrat.
His emotions swung between fear and curiosity.
The game could swing either way (= either side could win it).
I managed to swing them round to my point of view.

senses.definition: to turn or change direction suddenly; to make something do this

examples.en: She swung back to face him.
The bus swung sharply to the left.
He swung the camera around to face the opposite direction.

senses.definition: to try to hit somebody/something

examples.en: She swung at me with the iron bar.
He swung another punch in my direction.

senses.definition: to succeed in getting or achieving something, sometimes in a slightly dishonest way

examples.en: We're trying to swing it so that we can travel on the same flight.
Is there any chance of you swinging us a couple of tickets?

senses.definition: to have a strong rhythm
if a party, etc. is swinging, there are a lot of people there having a good time

idioms.word: no room to swing a cat

senses.definition: when somebody says there’s no room to swing a cat, they mean that a room is very small and that there is not enough space

variants.html: (also tip the balance/scales)

senses.definition: to affect the result of something in one way rather than another

examples.en: In an interview, smart presentation can swing the balance in your favour.
New evidence swung the balance against the prosecution.

senses.definition: to be bisexual (= sexually attracted to both men and women)
to really try to achieve something great, even when it is not reasonable to expect to be so successful

examples.en: entrepreneurs who think big and swing for the fences
Investors need to manage risk and not swing for the fences.

senses.definition: to start doing something quickly and with a lot of energy

examples.en: The ambulance crew swung into action to resuscitate the patient.
The rescue operation swung into action immediately.
The emergency services swung into action as soon as the disaster was reported.

senses.definition: to pretend to be ill when in fact you are not, especially to avoid work

examples.en: I don't think there's anything wrong with her—she's just swinging the lead.

senses.definition: a swinging movement or rhythm

examples.en: He took a wild swing at the ball.
the swing of her hips

senses.definition: a change from one opinion or situation to another; the amount by which something changes

examples.en: Voting showed a 10 per cent swing to Labour.
There are indications of a swing towards nuclear power.

senses.definition: a seat for swinging on, hung from above on ropes or chains

examples.en: The kids were playing on the swings.
Her dad pushed her on the swing.

senses.definition: the swinging movement you make with your arms and body when you hit the ball in the game of golf

examples.en: I need to work on my swing.

senses.definition: a type of jazz with a smooth rhythm, played especially by big dance bands in the 1930s
a quick journey, especially one made by a politician, in which somebody visits several different places in a short time

examples.en: a three-day campaign swing through California

senses.definition: to get used to an activity or a situation and become fully involved in it

examples.en: I’ve only been here a week so I haven’t got into the swing of things yet.

senses.definition: to be lively and fun

examples.en: She made the whole party go with a swing.

senses.definition: to have a strong rhythm
having reached a very lively level

examples.en: When we arrived the party was already in full swing.

senses.definition: used to say that there are advantages and disadvantages whatever decision you make

examples.en: If you earn more, you pay more in tax, so it's all swings and roundabouts.
What you gain on the swings you may lose on the roundabouts.

senses.definition: to change or make something change from one thing to another

examples.en: We're in the process of switching over to a new system of invoicing.
The company is offering good deals to customers who switch over from a competitor.
He switched over from acting to journalism.
If you'd like to pay monthly rather than annually, it's easy to switch over.
I found a better phone plan so I asked if I could switch.
Press these two keys to switch between documents on screen.
The meeting has been switched to next week.
It takes a few days to switch your account over from another bank.

examples.cf: switch something (over) from something to something
examples.en: He switched his allegiance from the British to the French.
I decided to switch my focus from swimming to cycling.
Your broadband will be switched over in less than a week.
He switched sides halfway through the debate.

senses.definition: to exchange one thing for another

examples.en: The dates of the last two exams have been switched.
I see you've switched the furniture around (= changed its position).
Do you think she'll notice if I switch my glass with hers?
We asked them if they would switch places with us.

senses.definition: to do somebody else’s job for a short time or work during different hours so that they can do your job or work during your usual hours

examples.en: I can't work next weekend—will you switch with me?
Have you been able to switch your shift with anyone?
Can we switch our shifts around?

senses.definition: a small device that you press or move up and down in order to turn a light or piece of electrical equipment on and off

examples.en: a light switch
an on–off switch
He flipped a switch and the lights came on.
to flick/press a switch
to throw a switch (= to move a large switch)
A young team can't just flip a switch and have the experience needed to win.
That was in the days before electricity was available at the flick of a switch (= by simply pressing a switch).

senses.definition: a change from one thing to another, especially when this is sudden and complete

examples.en: a policy switch
a switch of priorities
She made the switch from full-time to part-time work when her first child was born.

senses.definition: the points on a railway line
a thin stick that bends easily

variants.text: (also asleep on the job, asleep at the wheel (both British and North American English))
variants.html: (also asleep on the job, asleep at the wheel (both British and North American English))

senses.definition: not paying enough attention to what you need to do

examples.en: Someone must have been asleep at the switch to alow this to happen.
They were asleep on the job as the financial crisis deepened.
Let's hope the regulators are not asleep at the wheel.

senses.definition: a weapon with a long metal blade (= sharp cutting part) and a handle

examples.en: to draw/sheathe a sword (= to take it out of/put it into its cover)

senses.definition: to be something that has both advantages and disadvantages

examples.en: Fame is a double-edged sword.

senses.definition: to fight or argue with somebody

idioms.word: the pen is mightier than the sword

senses.definition: people who write books, poems, etc. have a greater effect on history and human affairs than soldiers and wars
to kill somebody with a sword

examples.en: All the men were put to the sword.

senses.definition: a bad or unpleasant thing that might happen to you at any time and that makes you feel worried or frightened
to stop fighting and return to peaceful activities
a person, an object, an event, etc. that represents a more general quality or situation

examples.en: The vase is decorated with religious symbols.
The new school stands as a symbol of hope for a better future.
Mandela became a symbol of the anti-apartheid struggle.

senses.definition: a sign, number, letter, etc. that has a fixed meaning, especially in science, mathematics and music

examples.en: the mathematical symbol for infinity
Hotels that display this symbol offer activities for children.

senses.definition: containing symbols, or being used as a symbol

examples.en: He shook his fist in a symbolic gesture of defiance.
The ceremony has a deep symbolic meaning.
The new regulations are largely symbolic (= they will not have any real effect).
The dove is symbolic of peace.

senses.definition: kind to somebody who is hurt or sad; showing that you understand and care about their problems

examples.en: a sympathetic listener
a sympathetic response
She was very sympathetic when I was sick.
I did not feel at all sympathetic towards Kate.
I'm here if you need a sympathetic ear (= somebody to talk to about your problems).

senses.definition: showing that you approve of somebody/something or that you share their views and are willing to support them

examples.en: He was speaking to a highly sympathetic audience.
to be sympathetic to the party’s aims
Russian newspapers are largely sympathetic to the president.

senses.definition: easy to like

examples.en: a sympathetic character in a novel
I don't find her a very sympathetic person.
The character's faults actually make him more sympathetic.

senses.definition: the feeling of being sorry for somebody; showing that you understand and care about somebody’s problems

examples.en: to express/feel sympathy for somebody
I have no sympathy for Jan—it's all her own fault.
I wish he'd show me a little more sympathy.
Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to the victims of the war.
Shops were closed out of sympathy for the victims.
May we offer our deepest sympathies on the death of your wife.
I would like to extend our sincere sympathies to his family at this sad time.

senses.definition: the act of showing support for or approval of an idea, a cause, an organization, etc.

examples.en: The seamen went on strike in sympathy with (= to show their support for) the dockers.
Her sympathies lie with the anti-abortion lobby.

senses.definition: friendship and understanding between people who have similar opinions or interests

examples.en: There was no personal sympathy between them.
He has a total lack of sympathy for young people.

senses.definition: happening because something else has happened

examples.en: Share prices slipped in sympathy with the German market.

senses.definition: not agreeing with or not wanting to support somebody/something
a change in your body or mind that shows that you are not healthy

examples.en: Symptoms include a headache and sore throat.
If symptoms persist, consult your doctor.
to experience symptoms of anxiety and depression
to show/develop symptoms of illness
to relieve/alleviate symptoms

senses.definition: a sign that something exists, especially something bad

examples.en: The rise in inflation was just one symptom of the poor state of the economy.
Their relationship was obviously failing, but they just ignored the symptoms.

senses.definition: a set of physical conditions that show you have a particular disease or medical problem

examples.en: PMS or premenstrual syndrome
This syndrome is associated with frequent coughing.
This syndrome mostly affects women in their forties.

senses.definition: a set of opinions or a way of behaving that is typical of a particular type of person, attitude or social problem

examples.en: With teenagers, be prepared for the ‘Me, me, me!’ syndrome (= they think of themselves first).
This phenomenon has become known as the ‘Californian syndrome’.

senses.definition: the act of combining separate ideas, beliefs, styles, etc.; a mixture or combination of ideas, beliefs, styles, etc.

examples.en: the synthesis of art with everyday life
a synthesis of traditional and modern values

senses.definition: the natural chemical production of a substance in animals and plants

examples.en: protein synthesis
the synthesis of nucleic acids

senses.definition: the artificial production of a substance that is present naturally in animals and plants

examples.en: the synthesis of penicillin

senses.definition: the production of sounds, music or speech by electronic means
an organized set of ideas or theories or a particular way of doing something

examples.en: reform of the country's education system
the criminal justice system
the healthcare system
the legal/financial/political system
Systems are in place for dealing with complaints.
a system of government

senses.definition: a group of things, pieces of equipment, etc. that are connected or work together

examples.en: They installed a security system but it failed.
How does the system work?

senses.definition: a set of computer equipment and programs that are used together

examples.en: to develop a new computer system
We're designing a voice-recognition system.
computerized information systems

senses.definition: a human or an animal body, or a part of it, when it is being thought of as the organs and processes that make it function

examples.en: Wait until the drugs have passed through your system.
the male reproductive system
Returning to work after a long break can be a terrible shock to the system (= a big change that is difficult to deal with).

senses.definition: the rules or people that control a country or an organization, especially when they seem to be unfair because you cannot change them

examples.en: You can't beat the system (= you must accept it).
You have to learn how to work the system if you want to succeed.
young people rebelling against the system

senses.definition: used to say that everything is working well or that everything is ready for something to happen or be successful

examples.en: The firm struggled to generate much business at the start, but now it's all systems go.
Last weekend's heavy snowfall means it's all systems go for the ski season.

idioms.word: get something out of your system

senses.definition: to do something so that you no longer feel a very strong emotion or have a strong desire

examples.en: I was very angry with him, but now I feel I've got it out of my system.

senses.definition: done according to a system or plan, in a complete, efficient or determined way

examples.en: a systematic approach to solving the problem
a systematic attempt to destroy the organization
The prisoner was subjected to systematic torture.
the systematic analysis of the risks involved
